description: The Art exhibit is a forested east facing crag on the south side of Debecks hill, just behind the sky ridge development. The cliff gets filtered morning sun and stays cool all day on hot summer days. The cliff is vertical to gently overhanging and is mostly smooth granite with sharp positive edges. Routes are roughly 18-20m tall. A single 60m rope will work for all routes. With any new wall, there will always be a bit of exfoliation and wearing a helmet is always recommended! Casey and I developed only a small portion of the entire cliff band. There is still a significant amount of rock left, undeveloped. An additional 20-30 routes could easily be added if other developers decide to add some lines.
getting_there: Park at the North end of Tantalus drive. Approx 10-15mins uphill. Hike up through the looking glass trail until a T intersection. Go right up Plural of Nemesis until another T intersection. Go left and over a little wooden bridge. You will see the cliff on the right side of the trail just about the bridge. Follow the light climbers trail along the base of the cliff until you reach the Art Exhibit. The red x on the map is the location of the crag.

routes.description: Once again a slightly tricky start eases off to more positive hold up the face. Good movement on thin crimps takes you to the anchors.
routes.location: Bolts

routes.description: The rightmost route climbs an aesthetic right facing corner crack. No offwidth skills required due to many positive face edges.
routes.location: Gear to 5"

routes.description: Climb up the face past two bolts then through a cruxy overlap. Trend left past sharp edges and rest before the pumpy overhanging corner.
routes.location: First route on the left end of face.

routes.description: Very tricky climbing off the deck. Simmers down midway and ends with awesome moves on a left leaning corner.
routes.location: Bolts
Bolts

routes.description: Technical face climbing off the ground to a midway rest. Then a tricky to onsight crux and a sting in the tail finish.
routes.location: Bolted

routes.description: Fun face moves lead to a wide crack corner. Stem past the crack to a large chock stone. Pull left onto the face past several bolts. The crux comes at the very end as the wall steepens and the holds change from jugs to powerful sidepulls.
routes.location: 6 bolts and a #4 and .2

description: Debeck's Hill is a  sport climbing crag sitting conveniently a 15-20 min walk up a a forest service road in Alice Lake Park. While a couple of routes had been done in the late 1990's, it was cleaned and further developed in 2019 with additional development ongoing. There are currently about 20 climbs with more in work. There is a first tier of climbs about 20m tall and a second tier of slightly longer climbs which can be accessed by climbing the lower climbs or using a fixed line up a mossy ramp. The lower tier is in the trees and stays mostly shaded but the upper tier gets morning and midday sun. The crag sits directly next to the trail / road giving it a chill cragging vibe. The climbing is much more fun and interesting than it first appears with many great routes.I have only climbed some of the climbs on the first tier but there is also a second tier with a few routes and more in development. All the climbs seemed to have fixed anchors / chains and some had biners set up for easy cleaning. Feel free to add more routes to MP as you climb them!As of July 2023, crag is a bit mossy in spots (adds to the less than inspiring appearance), but most of the climbs are sufficiently cleaned to climb. Could use some additional scrubbing though!News article about crag:  seatoskyclimbing.ca/latest-… link to topo on "Sea to Sky Climbing":  static1.squarespace.com/sta…
getting_there: Park in the southern most lot at Alice Lake Provincial park. Walk south to the turn around loop and at the end of the pavement turn right onto a dirt road blocked by a yellow gate (sign for Debeck's hill). Keep right at the first junction and walk 15-20 minutes uphill. The crag will be on your left directly off the side of the dirt road.(Walking another 15 minutes up the road gets you to the top of Debeck's hill and a great lunch spot with a view!)

routes.description: Fun climbing with committing moves to the first bolt, stick clip recommended if you're not solid at the grade.
routes.location: Second route from the left.

routes.description: Steep, fun layback flake with some fun jams, stems, and maybe even chimneying thrown in. Really fun! Could likely be climbed on gear.First ascensionist rated 5.10d / 5.11a. I would say 10d if you jam, 11a if you layback the entire thing.
routes.location: Large, left facing layback flake / crack just left of ramp feature.

routes.description: Fun but pumpy climbing leads through a steep and blank looking wall with just enough holds (first crux) to a good rest below the roof. Work your way up into the short dihedral (second crux) above before climbing eases to the anchor.
routes.location: Look for a horizontal deep crack / seam with twin triangle roofs above it. Climb goes between triangle roofs. Right of two lines that are close together. Other line is Moss Ceiling (12b).

routes.description: Thoughtful climbing leads up through closely bolted low angle terrain
routes.location: The rightmost climb at the lower main wall

routes.description: Steep and stemmy start past the first couple bolts (crux) leads to easier climbing up a ramp to the right.
routes.location: Just right of Covid Crack, starts up a steep corner to a rightward leaning ramp

routes.description: Route leading to the burly roof just left of Deflowered.
routes.location: bolts

routes.description: Thoughtful and balancy climbing down low leads to steep but surprisingly juggy climbing up the blank looking wall up higher - a must do at the crag! Some may say this feel a bit soft for the grade.
routes.location: On the left side (uphill) of the crag. Starts in a small right facing corner.

routes.description: Fun climbing tackles a couple of bulges. Crux between bolts 3 and 4.
routes.location: The left most line on the lower main wall.

routes.description: A tricky start leads to interesting but insecure climbing along the leftward leaning arch. A final tough sequence (maybe crux?) at at the end of the arch guards the anchors above. Felt tough for the grade.
routes.location: The obvious leftward facing arch at the leftmost point the crag meets the road

description: Mycology Rock is a mostly overhanging cliff that faces west at the bottom of the Alice lake rd. It has one of the fastest and flattest approaches, a comparable walking distance from smoke bluffs parking to free and easy crag (approx 10 mins). The cliff has filtered sun and stays cool on hot days. There is also a year round creek nearby for water. A 60m rope will work for all routes. Most routes are mixed. Most routes have only seen 1 or 2 ascents and with any new wall there will always be some rock exfoliation, so wearing a helmet is always recommended.PDF topo link belowhttps://drive.google.com/file/d/1-A6Fp3dqAkOjO2fldePilMgjXClKtFhR/view?usp=drivesdk
getting_there: Park on the corner of Black Bear Rd and Alice Lake Rd. Hike south down the very popular wonderland trail back to Squamish (use trail forks if you dont know where the trail is). This patch of forest is exceptionally beautiful and the walk alone is worth it through those woods. When you hit a creek, stay on the main trail (southbound) until the trail crosses over the creek. Roughly 30 meters after the bridge, Follow the light climbers trail on the left, that leads past two boulders. You’ll see the looming cliff up and on your left. 10 mins of flat easy walking from car.

routes.description: Climb the main lower corner of Matsutake crack until you see a bolt out left. Cruxy moves to the main ledge. From here boulder your way up the overhanging wall on mostly good holds. Pumpy!
routes.location: It's the only route with fixed draws.

routes.description: Same start as matsutake. Half way up the steep dihedral, take the right crack and pull the lip to midway anchors.
First climb at the cliff as you come up the trail. Technical with lots of compression, bouldery climbing.
routes.location: First climb at the cliff when you come up the trail.

routes.description: Climbs up a technical and burly v groove feature to a rest and a powerful roof pull on mostly good holds. Some may want to place an optional .2 or .3 just before the rest on easy terrain. Top roping is not recommended on this route.
routes.location: 2 route on the right.

routes.description: The striking overhanging, corner crack. It's the most obvious route on the wall. Climb the steep corner crack and pull the roof. Follow the traversing crack to the anchors. This is not your typical smoke bluff 5.11 splitter.

Climbs the curved arete feature. Start by climbing a wide crack until you can climb right across a broken face to the main arete. Techy face moves up the arete past bolts leads to the steep crux finger crack.
routes.location: Second most right route on the wall.
routes.protection: Bolts, a single #2, and a blue or black totem

routes.description: A 2 bolt direct boulder problem start climbs powerful crimps into the arete of Mycotopia. Some may want to stick clip.
routes.location: 3rd most left route

routes.description: 2 pitches. First pitch is a short 5.8 broken crack that leads to the main climbing. The upper belay is a much better stance for the harder climbing.Climb up the wickedly steep dihedral with unique movement and a building crux just before the chains.
routes.location: First route on the left.

description: See sky pilot
getting_there: Follow sky pilot approach, traverse west on the stadium glacier towards co pilot

routes.type: Trad, Snow, Alpine, 3 pitches, Grade II
routes.description: More technical climbing than the standard routes on co pilot, solid rock and protection where the climbing is hard, plenty of moss and loose rock, a decent moderate Alpine climb that can Be done in a day from squamishPitch 1 50m 5.10b/c Start up the slab on the left of the major chimney/gash that splits the face, make challenging moves across the gash to establish below the crack. Pull the small roof to enter the slot, cruxy moves to establish above the small rood, continue up the obvious crack line to a big ledge below the second pitch. Wet early season from snow melt off the ledgePitch 2 30m 5.10aContinue up the corner with an intermittent crack to a crux pulling above the corner. Good rock. Continue up through a choice of cracks onto a ledge with loose rock. Pitch 3 20m low 5th Gain the short ridge on blocky terrain to gain the summitDescent: rap from bolted anchors down the NE route.
routes.location: From the stadium glacier (approach described in sky pilot page) traverse west to the north side of co pilot, locate the route on the right side of the major chimney splitting the face on the lookers left, the first pitch starts up a right arcing crack/slot that starts with a small roof pull.
routes.protection: Single rack .2-3 Knifeblades, small lost arrows and angles critical for belays. A few pins in the pitches added comfort to harder sections.

description: 10 mins approach.  Filtered sun pm.  Secluded.  Quick drying.  Good landings.
getting_there: From E end of Park Crescent follow trail into forest for about 10 minutes paralleling a golf course until trail crosses a boardwalk over a swampy area.  Stay left at junction.  Follow trail uphill winding across the slope.  The first boulder/small cliff will be on the right of the trail.

routes.description: Climb the weird lil ramp feature on the left edge of the slab.
routes.location: Left of The Fishure

routes.description: Climb the scooped fractured arete on the wall that is below the trail.
routes.location: below trail N of Barbless

routes.description: Sit down start.  Start seated on a convenient patio and layback the short crack to the top.
routes.location: Short slabby 2nd wall on right of the trail.

routes.description: Start on edges at two meters underneath the crack feature. Slap left to the slopey arête beside the crack, make a big reach right to the far arête and up
routes.location: This is the first problem encountered while walking down the trail.

routes.description: Technical.  Start crouching matched on the thin horizontal seam.  Smear up the short wall just right of the bridge railing.
routes.location: just b4 bridge

routes.description: This problem scales a short buttress right by the path. Start seated matched on edges and slap to better holds. Muscle onto the shelf.
routes.location: None

routes.description: Start seated and climb the short, diagonal flake crack up the left side of the wall.
routes.location: None

description: A tall, south/east facing crag with a variety of different styles - mostly old school.
getting_there: The first crag on the left as you approach

routes.description: Farthest left route on the wall. Climb up to a small roof and into an awkward corner. Finish at the shared anchor.
routes.location: Far left side of the wall, under a small roof.

routes.description: Start in the corner and go up to a roof. Work up through a slot to a layback.Can finish to the left on the shared anchor, or continue upwards to the tree.
routes.location: Left side of the main wall, starting in a wide corner.

routes.description: A very wild, varied journey on excellent rock. One of the best 5.7s in Squamish, not often you get to climb so many unique styles in a single route.Start on steep jugs, clipping a bolt and plugging extra gear if you wish. Next, move onto the low-angle face for a few delicate thin and balancy moves as you climb left through glacier polish into a friendly (but steep) layback flake. Layback or jam up the flake, then foot-traverse along the top of it left for 10 feet (unprotectable but easy, place a #2 or #3 Camalot at the top of the flake before the traverse) until you get to a beautiful hand-crack. Get to jamming, the crack goes from #3 to #1 Camalots if I remember correctly. At the giant perched boulder, traverse left underneath it, then walk up a bit to a steep, blocky chimney finish.**Be careful when lowering. This is a rope-stretcher even with a 70m, tie knots in your rope** Another option is to bring up your second and walk off together, potentially safer.
routes.location: Because of the nature of the flake it's almost invisible until you traverse up the trail far enough, then it will seem obvious. It takes the line to the left of the low-angle slab route directly up the face with a line of bolts.
routes.protection: Standard rack to #3. You can find a place for a #4. I'd take doubles from 0.4 to #2. There are also two bolts you can clip at the start. Bolted anchor at the top.

routes.fa: C. Austrom, 1978. FFA: B. Milward, J. Campbell, 1983
routes.description: Challenging route up a groove.Walk off the top towards the left.
routes.location: Left side of the wall, to the left of an open project with two bolts on it.

routes.description: Go up the obvious dirty crack, tending slightly left to the shared anchor.
routes.location: Crack on the far left side of the wall.

routes.description: Strenuous and bouldery climb up the centre of the wall.
routes.location: In the middle of the main wall, starting just to the right of the left facing corner.

routes.description: Shares a start with Garfield, but then step right onto the slab. Follow the slab up to a dirty crack.
routes.location: Shares start with Garfield, but then goes straight up the slab.

description: The small slab in the gravel lot alongside the highway.
getting_there: Park. Climb.

routes.description: Climb the arête on the left side of the slab.
routes.location: Left arête of the slab.

routes.description: Climb the obvious hand crack in the centre of the slab straight up.
routes.location: The one crack in the middle of the slab.

description: Small crag further up the road.
getting_there: Approx. 100m further up the dirt road from the mail wall.

routes.description: A thin heady battle up good stone.Video of yours truly doing what I do best, getting terrified like a little wimp and taking the whip ​Here​​​
routes.location: Same start as Rufus but head straight up through the roof and climb the seams on the face joining back into Rufus for the finish.

routes.fa: J. Campbell & B. Milward, 1983. FFA: D. Lane & P. Beckham, 1984
routes.description: Up the crack on the right buttress into the crazy roof. Continue through the roof and up onto the face above. Follow the crack to a bolted anchor.
routes.location: The obvious, epic crack going through the large roof on the right.

description: Newly developed shady west-facing crag with 8 routes (sport and gear) ranging from 5.8 to 5.10 with one 11+. The crag is pretty tall and steep, but the many features keep the grades down. The only downside is traffic noise - the crag is pretty close to the highway and you won't be able to hear your belayer once you're past halfway. You are very likely to have the crag to yourself here, which is surprising because there is basically no approach and the climbing is quite interesting.You can read the topo here:  quickdrawpublications.com/w…
getting_there: Park on the north section of Depot Road just east of the highway. Take the bike trail (Wonderland) north for 3 minutes, once you have trees on your left you will start to see the crag on your right.

routes.description: Quite a lot of climbing of different sorts on this engaging route. A bolt-protected bouldery start leads to a sporty section before reaching the main crack (bring some small wires or maybe a microcam to keep you safe before you reach it - I used a #3 and a #4 RP doubled up - you might be able to get a shallow finger-sized piece a little further left in a horizontal but it didn't look inspiring to me.) From there the crack slowly widens through interesting climbing from fingers to hands, to wide hands until you ultimately reach the 6" crack that takes you to the top. Lots of friendly wavy jugs and edges for the feet to augment the crack climbing. The climb was a little dusty/dirty when I got on it, maybe because there isn't a huge overlap between 5.8 climbers and climbers who own wide gear, but it's definitely clean enough to be very fun. The route reminded me a little of Garfield in spirit, in that it's much more adventurous climbing than you tend to get in Squamish at the grade. Not quite as classic though. There are apparently two variations where you break right at different points to avoid the wide crack, both go at 5.10 and I can't comment to their quality.
routes.location: The right-most crack line on the crag. The most diagnostic element is the vertical 6" flake that covers the last 4 meters of climbing. It is flanked by two sport routes on the right and one on the left, and has a single bolt you can reach from a dusty ledge.
routes.protection: Single rack from small wires to #4 Camalots + 1 #6. You can get away with no #4, but an extra #3 wouldn't hurt as it goes at wide hands for a good while. Bolted anchors with rap rings.

routes.description: Quite pleasant gear-protected jug-pulling to a big ledge, then steep finger-locks with decent feet for the second half. From the ground, the first half looks quite bold as the gear placements are not very easy to see, but it can be protected very safely - there are lots of opportunities for gear, just make sure you bring some slings too.From the ledge, traverse left to the finger crack (which looks like a hand-crack from the ground). The climbing here is much steeper than your average Smoke Bluffs 5.9, with locker fingers in a fine-grained crack that feels much more like climbing a basalt crack sometimes. 10 meters of fairly strenuous climbing for the grade gets you two a few body-weight jugs that aren't obvious until you pull on them. Don't get too comfortable though, as you have to pull one more honest move on fingers to get to the anchors. Fun!
routes.location: This is the middle gear line on the crag. It starts below two sawed-off stumps in the wall on a blocky layback, and climbs right through blocky features to the ledge, then left and up a vertical finger crack. To the left are two sport routes, and another unnamed 5.9 that opens up into a wide chimney.
routes.protection: Gear, recommend to bring doubles in the 0.3-0.75 range, even a third 0.4 if you've got one, and nuts. Bolted anchors with rap rings.

description: This area host 3 beautiful steep technical routes in the trees.
getting_there: From the Gondola walk down the sea to sky trail pass the Gondolarium.

routes.description: Vertical corner to dyke and a burly layback.
routes.location: The left most line, star with 2 bolts
routes.protection: 4 bolts, complete with double rack up to 1''

description: A slightly overhanging roadside crag just minutes from the top of the Sea to Sky Gondola. Also known as "The Klettergarden"  This crag is directly next to a main road/trail, so you will have a steady stream of hikers passing by underneath.
getting_there: From the top of the Sea to Sky Gondola, walk East past the playground and down the Sky Pilot Trail (Shannon Creek FSR). The crag will appear next to the road after about 2-3 minutes.

routes.description: The dramatic, steep, thin crack that splits the middle of the South Face. Crack tends diagonally up towards the right.
routes.location: The obvious crack that splits the middle of the South Face.

routes.description: The impressive corner in middle of the South Face
routes.location: Obvious corner in the middle of the South Face, to the right of the large roof.

routes.description: The impossibly thin crack/seam that starts under the large roof and ends at the upper right side. Waiting for a FFA?
routes.location: Underneath the large roof, on the right side.West Face

routes.description: Another thin crack that starts similar to Nancy, but then curves diagonally up and to the right.
routes.location: Starts to the left of the trees. Begins left of Nancy but then crosses over that route to the right.

routes.fa: Robin Barley, Nancy Henderson, Bernie Protsch 1987
routes.description: A thin crack that moves up and left where the two cracks cross in the middle of the face.
routes.location: Starts on the ledge to the left of the trees. Nancy starts on the right and moves up and left where the two cracks cross.

routes.fa: Colin Haley, Jeremy Frimer & Sarah Hart, 2013
routes.description: Straight hand crack on the left side of the face.
routes.location: Left side of the South Face, behind a tree.
routes.route_name: She's the Son of a Logger

routes.description: Small crack start with a tricky slab finish.
routes.location: Middle-right of the South Face, ending on the bulge

routes.description: Hand-offwidth crack on the left.
routes.location: Farthest left crack line on the South Face.

description: The Canola Crag is on the North side of Wrinkle Dome and features a variety of long, moderate routes in a quiet setting with great views.
getting_there: From the base of the Gondolarium, traverse left around Wrinkle Dome for approx. 5 minutes.

routes.description: Diagonal crack from different sizes. Can stay wet for a very long time after rain.
routes.location: SR to #4

description: This is the main South facing slab that is right next to the lift line. The wall receives direct sun for most of the day, and has several fun multi pitch routes on it. It features several cracks running all along the face, with the potential for more new routes to be established.The wall is about 150ft from the gondola cables, so you will have a steady stream of tourists staring at you as they float past. Look your best.
getting_there: From the top of the Sea to Sky Gondola, hike down either the Wrinkle Rock trail or Sparky's Spin trail for approx. 10-15 minutes. The crag will be on your right at the junction of the two trails.

routes.fa: P. Schlotfeldt, R. Barley, G. Woloski. P2: R. Barley, J. Komori, 2013
routes.description: P1: Start on a ledge and climb up to a roof, and onto the slab above.P2: Continue up and right along the cracks to a thin seam.
routes.location: Left side of the wall, starting on a ledge.

routes.description: P1, (10a). Start on a small slab with black streaks, continuing up to the cracks above. P2, (5.8). Short pitch connecting the next crack systemP3. (10c). Face climbing to the top.
routes.location: 20m left of CTC

routes.description: Start on a bulge to gain the flaring crack. Continue up to the arete and onto the face.
routes.location: About 30ft off the trail when you first encounter the base of the wall.

description: Pleasant crack and face climbing with a great view of Howe Sound. The wall gets full sun after 2pm, with the bottom staying shady. Fairly quick to dry.
getting_there: Above It All is just uphill from the Ffery’s Wheel and on the same level as the Isengard cliffs. 25 - 35min from the road. Park in the chain up area 900m South of Shannon Falls or in the pullout with the interpretive sign 2.7km North of Murrin. Starting from the yellow gate, follow the main road into the second hydro cut until 30m before a hydro tower. Take the first of two trails which start 5m apart and follow it steeply uphill. About 30m below the Ffery’s Wheel, take a right fork (flagging) and continue uphill and then back left to the base of the cliff. Watch It Burn starts on a belay platform below a detached boulder. Alternately, approach by cutting 150m left from the base of the Breakfast Wall at Isengard or up from the top of Gonzales Creek Wall.

routes.description: This excellent addition to this wall makes the steep approach well worth the trip. Climb both routes for a fantastic 7 pitches, while escaping the weekend crowds.Follow approach beta in for "Watch it Burn" from Squamish select guidebook, or Gonzalez Heights found here https://quickdrawpublications.com/free-topos/..  Route found at "Above it all" Directly right of Watch it Burn. Pitch 1 (5.9) Ramble up 20 m of fourth-class terrain, passing 1 bolt to gain a rightfacing corner with a wide crack. At its end, pull up and left to a bolt belay.  Pitch 2 (5.10b) Move the belay left to a bolted station around the corner.  Protect finger-crack moves off the belay with a small cam and then climb a long, fun crack system of varied sizes past a tree on the right. A great 35-m pitch! Pitch 3 (5.10a) Climb a short wide crack to join the fun, steep finish of Watch It Burn. Rappel either route with single 70m to descend. SR to 4" FA Marcus Wybrow, Andrew Moores, 2020.
routes.location: Trad, all anchors fixed. Protects well.

routes.description: The first route at Above It All follows finger and hand cracks to the top of the wall.P1. Start up the detached boulder, head left past a bolt, and make your way to a handcrack.(5.8, 1 bolt, 20m)P2. Climb cracks and flakes through the steep wall. Hidden jugs on both sides keep thegrade reasonable. (10c, 6 bolts, 25m)P3. Climb the sweet splitter through a cool undercling crux. Where it ends before a tree,step right and up to the anchor. (10c, 30m)P4. Follow the curving flake above and face climb past two bolts. Step right at the third togain a fun crack and follow it through the steepening wall to the top. (10a, 3 bolts, 35m)Rap the route with a single 70m
routes.location: Start on the belay platform below a detached boulder

description: Very nice secluded bouldering spot! Dense forest surrounds you and the rush of Golzales Creek provides nice ambiance.
getting_there: All the established boulders are located a bit South of Gonzales Creek in the forest. Specific steps shared by the boulders:Park at the Gonzales Creek pullout with the interesting Native American info signWalk back South along the highwayRight before (just North of) Gonzales Creek itself, start hiking up a scree ridge that slices randomly through the forestWhen you hit a small, undeveloped cliff, turn rightCross Gonzales Creek here. Looking downstream, you should see a vaguely developed-looking riverside boulder, which apparently has a V5 on it (The Water Throne).Fantastic Mr. Fox is uphill (further up the creek, see individual page) and the supposed "Tea Cosy" boulder is further into the forest.

routes.description: Start hugging the underside of the roof using:Left hand on incut 3 finger edge just under lipRight hand on incut 1 pad crimp under roofLeft heal on large sloper jug just over lipFrom there, make a hard move to a big undercling under the roof, then move left to a cool rail feature and top out onto slab above.
routes.location: Follow directions to cross Gonzales Creek. Then:Start hiking uphillAngle parallel to the creek again and continue hiking. Stay left of a large, semi-developed boulder.Hit a mossy slope, and scramble up the right side of it.Angle parallel to the creek again and you should start to see the sick roof of Fantastic Mr. Fox.
routes.protection: Low to the ground, good landing!

description: Hard Sport routes and one Trad route.   West facing, protected in the trees.    Quailty rock similar to Murin.
getting_there: Park at The Gonzalez Creek pullout on the right between Murin and The Chief.  Walk 1 minute down the highway and follow the faint orange flagging into the forest. At the Electrical tower in the clearing veer left and continue on small path.  Follow flagging and carins   Pass an undeveloped cliff on the right and continue up and slightly left.  Cliff will become obvious after about 6 minutes.    (about 20-30 minute hike, steep)

routes.description: No text - use the 'Improve This Page' link to add something useful!
routes.location: N/A

description: Steep, featured face and crack climbing. There are single pitch climbs on the left. And several four pitch routes climb the large slab on the right to the top of the wall.   The wall faces WSW and the bottom stays shady.
getting_there: Park in the Gonzales Creek pullout 2.8km North of Murrin on the E side of Hwy 99 (or at the chain up area 900m South of Shannon Falls on the W side). Leave the road at the yellow gate 900m South of Shannon Falls on the E side. Follow the main road into the second hydro cut. 30m before the hydro tower, just past a large stump, turn left into the forest. Follow a flagged trail to the crag. 7-10 minutes from the yellow gate.

routes.description: Fun, well protected climbing leads to the top of the wall and a great view of Howe Sound.P1. Start up jugs on the right side of the slender buttress. Stem, layback, and face climb past bolts and gear up the buttress to finish at an anchor on the left at a small ledge. Fun and technical climbing with multiple cruxes (.10c, 4 bolts, ~25m).P2. Follow the small buttress up cracks and face holds to a neat crux stemming or laybacking past two bolts. Can be easily linked with pitch 1 (.10b, 3 bolts, ~20m).P3. Climb a crack in the wall above the belay. Move right when possible, clip a bolt, and stem higher until it’s possible to make an engaging step right onto the main face. Cruxy slab moves past bolts (easily aided) lead to an anchor (.10c, 6 bolts, ~25m).P4. A tough move at the first bolt leads to easier slab climbing. At an overlap, step left past a bolt and continue to an anchor on a beautiful ledge (.10a, 6 bolts, ~30m).Rap the route with a single rope.
routes.location: Starts on the slender buttress just left of the railroad spike
routes.protection: SR from #0 Metolius to #1 BD, 2x #1 - #3 Metolius

routes.description: The extension to Go Directly to Jail. Pull the very cruxy roof left of the anchor, reach right, and power-teeter-layback up good holds on the arete.
routes.location: As for Go Directly to Jail, up the first shallow right facing corner right of the obvious undercling
routes.protection: 7 bolts, SR from #0 Metolius to #2 BD

routes.description: The testpiece of the crag. Work up into the obvious undercling and make a powerful move up and right to mini jugs. Continue up the easier crack system to below the widest part of the roof. Pull it and launch onto the pumpy face above. Small yet solid gear and excellent climbing. Just possible to lower with a 70m rope.
routes.location: Starts below the obvious undercling
routes.protection: 1 bolt, SR from #00 Metolius to #1 BD, 2-3x #0 - #3 Metolius, small nuts

routes.description: A difficult move past a bolt gains fun climbing up the shallow corner to a ledge. Climb a layback crack and the face above past bolts. Use the stump out right to mantel onto the sloping ledge to an anchor on the face.
routes.location: Up the first shallow right facing corner right of the obvious undercling
routes.protection: 5 bolts, SR from #0 Metolius to #2 BD

routes.description: P1. Follow Jenga for Dummies to the right facing corner. Hand traverse right along the rail, mantle below a bolt, and foot traverse to an anchor (10b, 2 bolts, ~20m). P2. Head up past two bolts to a roof crux (#0 Met). Above, move up on big holds, then left to layback steep and fun flakes to the anchor (10d, 2 bolts, ~20m). It’s possible to link these if you’re really stubborn.
routes.location: Starts at the bottom of the stairs, as per Jenga for Dummies
routes.protection: SR from #0 Metolius to #2 BD, 2x #2 - #3 Metolius

routes.description: Starts at the bottom of the stairs. Clip a bolt and follow cracks through a little roof into a right facing corner. Move up left on jammed blocks to a ledge (.10a to this anchor). A few balancy crux moves lead up the arete, then consistent and fun climbing up the crack through a couple more cruxes. Best climbed as one pitch.
routes.location: Starts at the bottom of the stairs directly below an obvious right facing corner
routes.protection: 3 bolts, SR from #0 Metolius to #3 BD, 2x #1 Metolius - #0.75 BD

routes.description: The original start to Candyland, it ends at the first pitch anchor. Gain the small right facing corner with a difficult start and follow it to a ledge. Continue up easy terrain, then right when possible past a bolt to finish at an anchor on the face.
routes.location: Starts up a shallow right facing corner in a small bay 5m left of the railroad spike
routes.protection: 1 bolt, SR from #0 Metolius to #2 BD, 2x #.75 - #1 BD

routes.description: A direct line up the buttress that will test your technical skill.  P1. Start just right of the bay below a bolt. Climb face holds and cracks to a ledge and a thin crux gaining the dyke above (.12c, 3 bolts, ~25m).  P2. Climb the layback flake to a technical crux when the corner closes. At the top of the flake, gain a ramp back left to an anchor that is shared with S&L (.11d, 7 bolts, ~25m).  P3. Climb the sustained, featured slab directly above. When a dyke finally provides some relief, follow it up and right to an anchor (.11c, 6 bolts, ~25m).  P4. Continue straight above to a flake and easier climbing. Finish straight up or to the right in the shallow dihedral with S&L (.11a, 4 bolts, ~20m).
routes.location: Start just to the right of the bay. The flake of pitch two is visible above.
routes.protection: SR #1 Metolius to #2 BD, offset nuts for P1 (optional #4 BD for P2)

routes.description: Climb past the first three bolts of You Sunk My Battleship. Once reaching the groove, step right onto a big hold and climb up and right through a bulge to a ledge (small cams). Continue rightwards to a bolt and then straight up to a small roof. Pull the roof, easier with trickery, past three bolts. Move back left on big holds to finish up the final layback crack of You Sunk My Battleship.
routes.location: Same as You Sunk My Battleship
routes.protection: 7 bolts, SR from #0 Metolius to #2 BD, 2x #1 Metolius

routes.fa: Carl Austrom, Robin Barley, 1981. Direct start: Chris Joseph, Steve Wickham, July 2003
routes.description: The original route here. Named for the weaving path the line takes up the wall, where if you step on a snake on pitch 3 you’ll end up right back on pitch 2. FA'd ground up, onsight, while scrubbing with a brush and drilling on lead. Recleaned July 2018.P1. Gain the corner from the right and exit left when possible. Gear belay near a stump up higher. The original start comes in on ledges from ~10m up the gully on the right (.9, ~20m).  P2. Climb the fun curving corner above, then traverse a thin slabby ramp left to a bolted belay (.9, 2 bolts, ~25m).  P3. Excellent climbing on dyke features right then up to a bolted belay on a ledge. Committing moves to get to the first bolt (.11a, 6 bolts, ~20m).  P4. Up dyke features on the right to gain easier ground and a ramp to the top (.10a, 1 bolt, ~20m).
routes.location: Start below the steep right facing corner 15 meters from the gully at the right end of the wall.

routes.fa: Joe Buszowski, Peder Ourom, Craig Thompson, 1982
routes.description: Start up the corner. Step left before the roof and continue up the shallow left facing corner to an anchor on the face. Cleaned and anchor added in 2018.
routes.location: Start up a handcrack in the left side of the large bay

routes.description: Difficult climbing past three bolts leads to an easier crack/groove. Follow it to a face crux at the second of two bolts. Jam a strange but solid #1 BD in the horizontal and head through a couple harder moves past a bolt to a small ledge. Fun climbing up and left (another #1 BD in a slot) into a layback finish up an easy crack.
routes.location: Starts at the top of the stairs past three bolts up a curving seam
routes.protection: 7 bolts, SR from #1 Metolius to #3 BD (optional #4 BD), 2x #1 BD for pockets

description: Isengard is home to a dozen steep gear climbs from 5.10 to 5.12  The crag is shady and stays cool even in mid-summer.  Some climbs seep and are slow to dry
getting_there: The approach is 20 minutes and steep.Park at the Gonzales Creek pullout on Highway 99 Northbound (if you're coming South from Squamish, you'll have to turn into the viewpoint after the chain-up area, then turn North onto the highway). The pullout is between Murrin and Shannon Falls and has a trash bin and interpretive sign.Walk about 50 paces North along the highway. Take a trail up the grass bank to a flagged tree, then follow the trail through two hydro slashes and into the forest. After walking under a big duck bill, turn right along the base of Gonzales Creek Wall (left goes to this wall), then go up into the forest.This takes you to the White Tower crag.The Precious is just left of the White Tower.For Bat Rat, Second Breakfast and Elevensies, continue left for a minute and go up a fixed handline.Cracks of doom are another 10 minutes.Flagging marks the trail the whole way.

routes.description: Double-cracks through a roof
routes.location: From White Tower wall, walk left for a few minutes. Take a fixed hand-line up a little gulley

routes.description: Climb steep double handcracks to a ledge, then enter the chimney and prepare to battle the Balrog.
routes.location: White Tower wall

routes.fa: Drew M, Danny G, Jon R
routes.description: Adventurous offwidth questing!Chain anchor
routes.location: This one's a long hike (40 minutes total) - from the White Tower Wall follow the trail left past Bat Rat and the Breakfast Wall. Go up the gully left of Breakfast Wall, following a rough flagged trail with fixed lines

routes.description: Diagonal crack with a burly finish
routes.location: the right of two diagonals on the Breakfast Wall

routes.description: Take an easy corner up to a ledge. (or, walk to the ledge).Then, climb the hand-and-fingercrack that crosses the blunt arete.Steep, burly jamming at its best
routes.location: White Tower Wall

routes.description: Nice thin hands
routes.location: About a minute left of White Tower wall

routes.description: Tricky, with a reachy gear placement. Medium offset nuts are the key.
routes.location: on the Breakfast WallThe left of two diagonal cracks

routes.description: Short and stout. The pro is bomber but hard to place. Pre-place a piece to bump it down a letterSet up a TR from the Balrog
routes.location: White Tower wall. Starts with a bolt then goes up a finger/handcrack on the left

routes.description: A short but quality layback.
routes.location: White Tower WallThe farthest-right route - scramble up to a ledge at the base of a right-facing corner, which is wide at the top

routes.description: Climb an easy layback to a sloping ledge (as per the Wizard) then crimp your way left into the seam.Face climb straight up to the top of this seam and use the Wizard's anchor out right.It's safe, but worth scoping the gear out on toprope.
routes.location: White Tower WallThis is the left of two seams that tackle the aesthetic steep face.

routes.description: The king line! Bouldery and sustained, with a little spice. A crash pad on the sloping ledge makes it safe. It's easy to set up a toprope from Shelob.
routes.location: White Tower WallThe right of the two thin cracks on the steep wall - this one pulls straight into a little corner at the top

description: A area that comprises some excellent boulders, but is low-density. It can take much more time and effort by Squamish standards to find boulders here.
getting_there: Best approached through the yellow gate on the northbound side of 99.

routes.description: Begin seated on the prow with a high right sidepull and low left hold. Make several pleasant, easier moves before reaching a poor undercling. Slap for the sloper shelf. Keep cool and make some balancey moves to top out at the apex of the boulder.
routes.location: N/A

description: A unique, standalone crag in the Garibaldi Highlands which features a handful of burly splitter cracks of very high quality on vertical to overhanging rock. Despite the short approach, the crag has an isolated atmosphere and is rarely crowded. It is shady and pleasant during the hot summer days. The rock at Highlander is more coarse-grained than in much of Squamish and there are still many loose crystals. A lot of work has gone into cleaning and equipping this crag, props to the developers. Expect solid grades and good gear.Topo and additional info can be found here:  quickdrawpublications.com/w…
getting_there: Park at the cul-de-sac at the end of Perth drive, but respect the residents of the neighbourhood and avoid the west side of the street. Take a faint trail from the north-east end of the parking area which quickly heads down-hill and across a stream. Up the other side and you're there, 2-minute approach.

routes.description: The right-most route at the crag is very short but packs a punch. Starts with an awkward move into a corner chimney feature. After that an unlikely and very balancey move to the left grants access to a tough finger crack finish.
routes.location: The corner system at the far right end of the crag.
routes.protection: SR to 1" with a single large piece (4-5"). Bolts and rings at the top.

routes.description: Left leaning fingers-to-hands crack to the left of the large corner of crossroads. Powerful bouldery start leads to sustained thin hands. Gets easier the higher you go. Good quality!
routes.location: Starts on the face to the left of the large left-facing corner of crossroads. This is not the left-leaning crack system that shares a start with crossroads, it starts independently.
routes.protection: Single rack from fingers to hands with an extra 1" piece should do it. Bolts with rings at the top

routes.description: Appealing finger crack which is much harder than it appears at first. A real exercise in body tension with several consecutive cruxes. The tips crack is tough, but the real challenge lies in tackling the shallow, flaring ringlocks above.
routes.location: left-most crackline on the face immediately to the left of "crossroads" dihedral.
routes.protection: SR from tips to thin hands. Bolts and rings at the top.

routes.fa: R Lange, J Lange, J Mcconnell
routes.description: Appealing left facing corner crack to hard crack moves on the face above. Traverse right onto the face when the corner peters out. A committing move  off slabby feet near the end will feel harder for shorter climbers. Although this is the easiest route at the crag, it's a bit of a rude warm-up.
routes.location: Starts with the very prominent left-facing corner which divides the crag into left and right sectors.
routes.protection: Single cams from 3" down to small fingers. A selection of small cams will help with tricky placements on the face.

routes.description: Start on Crossroads but quickly diverge left up the crumble layback crack. Plug gear and execute the sporty crux. Follow the enjoyable hand to butterfly splitter to top.
routes.location: Crack line between Arc Strike and Crossroads. Start as for Crossroads.

routes.fa: N. Elson,	K. Benevides,	J. Mcconnell
routes.description: Lots of good wide-hands jamming on this little route, definitely packs a punch. Starts in a left-facing corner that starts on blocks, then a wide section climbs into #3 Camalots to a roof. Traverse left to a strenuous stance, then move right into a final jam crack that looks easier than it is.
routes.location: Left side of the crag, the obvious LFC that climbs hands into a roof (that isn't Crossroads).
routes.protection: I'd suggest 2 #3 Camalots. Placed a #4 at the bottom and was glad to have it. Standard rack otherwise, but make sure to bring some slings to extend around the roof. Rap rings on hangers for an anchor.

routes.description: A cool route that begins on Mouth of Madness and links into Tres Amigos following a horizontal crack. Unique movement, good gear, clean falls!
routes.location: Begins on Mouth of Madness, follow the horizonal crack right.
routes.protection: singles from Blue Metolius to 0.75. Golden Nugget.

routes.description: The best route at the crag and sure to become a Squamish classic. This is the first major crack system you see when you approach the crag and it's even better than it looks from the bottom. Full-on straight off the ground with a technical, barn-door crux down low, powerful crux up high, and few chances to rest in-between.
routes.location: Hard to miss! Starts on the right end of the sharp "teeth" at the right end of the wall. Up the obvious crack system to a "choose-your-own-adventure" finish.
routes.protection: Singles from fingers to 3", with some extra padding in the #0.75 camalot range. Bolts and rings at the top

routes.description: Left-leaning finger and hand crack up the gently overhanging wall to the left of Mouth of Madness. Strong moves up the crack lead to a brutal boulder problem clearing a small alcove near the top. Finish on dirty, flaring fists.
routes.location: Starts on the stepped ledges immediately to the left of Mouth of Madness.
routes.protection: Protects more easily than it looks from the ground with cams from fingers to 3". Save a fist-sized piece for the top. Bolts and rings for the anchor.

routes.description: Some good climbing in this little pitch interrupted by a sandy, dusty, hard-to-protect/jam horizontal break in the middle. Starts on fierce fingerlocks on a slight overhang into easier jamming, then a crimp traverse right through a dirty horizontal fault. Eventually you can work your way to a strenuous no-hands rest before the final left-facing stem corner (good pro).
routes.location: Left-most route at the crag, starting up a slightly overhanging finger crack with a horizontal ledge for your right foot ~80cm off the deck.
routes.protection: Standard rack, doubles in finger sizes. Rap rings on hangers up top.

description: Only one boulder/DWS but it’s worth it. Top 100 and must do for the grade
getting_there: Park at 49.6060, -123.2161 on the west side of the freeway. It’s a gravel pullout on your right when going south towards Vancouver, after Britannia Beach up the hill.

routes.description: Mega classic! Start on the obvious hueco and do big moves on good holds until you reach the crux at the lip, do a classic granite mantle and then take the victory whip! At lower tides it’s best to find a big log and use it as a plank to reach the start. At higher tides it’s best to have a paddle board or the like. Better to go at medium to high tide to make it less spicy.
routes.location: From the pullout go down the trail until you reach the tracks. The go the opposite direction from the tunnel (do NOT go near the tunnel) until you can go down the rock towards the big UFO looking boulder.

description: The top far North part of the Malamute.
getting_there: Take the trail north from Starr Wall around the far north end of the Malamute and hang a left to a bright white wall.

routes.description: A nice friction face climb on the northernmost wall of upper Malamute.  A cruxy start off the ledge leads to easier climbing above.
routes.location: Hike around the north side of the Malamute to a small but secure ledge.  A belay bolt near the dike marks the start of Sparky and Pacing the Cage.  This dike is almost certainly the same giant intrusion that splits the face of the chief-- pretty cool.

routes.fa: Jeff Thomson, Gelnn Payan, Jack Fieldhouse 98
routes.description: More sustained than it's neighbor Pacing the Cage, Sparky shares the cruxy start of that route, then follows a left traverse across the slab.
routes.location: One of the northernmost routes on upper Malamute.  Start as for Pacing the Cage next to the dike.

description: A number of climbs off a wide treed ledge about halfway up the Malamute. The top 100 climb chasing rainbows following up a black dyke can be found at the southern end.
getting_there: Either approach from the north end of the Malamute or continue on the ridge trail past The Cage until you can walk down a a step grove towards the northern lower end of the Malamute. Take a sharp left and walk along a large treed ledge about halfway down south until you see pinky locks. Continue along to find Chasing Rainbows.

routes.description: Sweet technical face. A nice crux lower down leads to some easier climbing, followed by another technical crux getting to jugs which take you to the anchor. This pitch was rescrubbed early 2020 by Nicole Deuchar.
routes.location: 30 seconds right of Giv’er

routes.description: A novelty climb, Chasing Rainbows climbs a basalt dike that continues underneath Highway 99 to form the Black Dike all the way up the Chief!  After locating the dike, you will have to climb some granite to get there, placing gear along the way. Most of the dike is steep with big holds, with a techy move thrown in there. The angle lessens at the top, and protection opportunities decrease as well, a fall up here would be heinous, but unlikely. When you top out, look for anchors on a slab to the left.
routes.location: From HWY 99 footbridge, head North (Right) on several trails in the forest until you reach the slabs on top of the Malamute, you should see a pond near the logging business here. Drop down the slabs in a gully, and then head left around the base.  Keep an eye out for the dike, it starts on a steep hillside.
routes.protection: Single rack to #3 Camelot, make sure you have a .75 & .5 for the dike portion. Slings!

routes.description: Starting of flake boulder climb cracks to gain the nice right facing corner
routes.location: Just right of pinky locks

routes.description: Easy walking up dyke then some solid face climbing to the top of that wall. Pretty good. This pitch was given a rescrubbing early 2020 by Nicole Deuchar
routes.location: 15seconds right of pinky locks.

routes.description: thin seam lead to a pancake flake hard layback crimping with poor feet leads to a trick mantel the easy climbing to the chains.route video:
routes.location: small wire/offsets 1x .5 cam 3 bolts

routes.description: Route featuring some harder slab moves down low, leading to easier climbing through the overlaps, then rightward to the anchor. Not the best but worth doing if you're here for Blue Steel. Boulder is solid as fuck.
routes.location: Just right of Blue Steel.

routes.description: This obvious splitter crack is the 2nd route you'll encounter in the Chasing Rainbows area. It is straightforward jamming until it splits into two cracks and it becomes a jug haul. A little mossy. There isn't much reason to be down here unless you're climbing 10+, so I will throw in that you cannot get to the anchors of any other climbs from the top of this one.
routes.location: Left of Coronary Corner. First climb encountered in Chasing Rainbows area.
routes.protection: Gear to 2". Two-bolt anchor with chains.

routes.description: A long journey following a wide, leftward traversing dyke to a layback arete encounter at the end. I bolted this when I was working Emubigs to convince Nicole to come down and belay me a couple times. She did the FA and thought I could have added another bolt or two but the slight run outs are on easy ground. Belay just left of 1st tree at start, passing rope around the right side of this tree so climber can start on the right side. Since the FA someone dropped a tree from the ledge above which is now wedged between the wall and one of the trees but the route is still climbable.Video Here
routes.location: Just below and the the left of chasing rainbows.

routes.description: Short slab featuring some cool pockets and technical moves.
routes.location: First (or leftmost) route on the chasing rainbows ledge.

description: The area under Stooges Slab from the ground to midway ledge.
getting_there: Approach by rappel off the top of Stooges Slab to a makeshift bridge over a tidal pool.

routes.description: Some great, well protected face climbing along the dike. Prepare thy dancing shoes for battle.   P1: Start up the corner from the logs, then steer right along the infant dike. Belay at right most ring-bolt-thingy  5.10   P2: Move along the overlap/roof, following the bolts rightwards.  A tough sequence gets your feet above the overlap.  Make your way daintily across the dance floor to double bolts.  5.11   P3: Continue along the dike and make a long reach straight up to gain the flake.  A couple small pieces (red C3) help protect between the bolts.  "Walk" right to the slab and make your way to the top of the buttress.
routes.location: Starts on the log bridge at the base, climb up the corner then angle right along bolts, continue that theme to the top.
routes.protection: Bolts and a very light single rack (some finger and tight hand pieces)

routes.description: The crux is near the start of this great sinker finger crack. Starts with some thin moves up to an overhang. Pulling over this bulge to get into the finger crack was the most challenging part of the climb. Finishes with about 40 feet of fantastic splitter finger crack.
routes.location: Continues from the top of Old Style. Tops out near the base of Star Wall, finish to the top of the cliff on any of those routes (5.8-5.9)
routes.protection: Chain anchors, doubles in finger sized gear.

routes.description: yet another excellent route at the Malamute. It was graded 10d originally, feels more 10c to me.   Pitch 1) begin on Old Style, veer off on bolted dyke till you reach the ledge, crux between 1st and 2nd bolt and reaching crack, old bolts ( 3 ) and some gear,  not too dirty seldom climbed. ( original start was straight up from bog further right, never climbed)   Pitch 2) 4 star 10c  pitch, starts at far right end of ledge with a glue in U-bolt. traverse right, pass cedar, bolt, pull though roof on good holds, thin crack up to Midway ledge.   Pitch 3) move to your left and start up crack to small ledge, traverse on slanting crack right with several bolts ahead, traverse left till gaining thin seam ( crux), good finger crack above till at base of Stooges slab (10c) This is also described as a pitch of the "Grub St. Connection".   Pitch 4) Rosebud was the original finish and only route on this slab in 1978 with no bolts (bolts added later), it is the 3rd line from the left with Moe on the right. The chain anchor above is on this route. We did the Curly finish furthest left with 6 bolts.
routes.location: furthest right on the Grub Street wall.  Starts on the Old Style 5.9 ( where the tree bridge crosses the tide pool pond)  Rap stations all the way down the wall, starting on one of the Stooges anchors.  One can also approach the base from the south side trail ( start near 99 pedestrian bridge, make left where other trail goes up sandy hill.
routes.protection: standard rack to 2", mostly finger size. All bolted anchors

routes.description: The Grub Street area has many possible link ups and variations. What's commonly known as Grub Street is a short 11a tips crack from the Lower Ledge to the Midway Ledge, with different options above and below. The different combinations have different names in different guidebooks, but the common line for Grub Street is as follows.P1 - 10b - Start up the corner of Old Style but go out right along a dyke past bolts and eventually up to the Lower Ledge and an anchor. This is the first pitch of Aganol.P2 - 11a - Head up into the pod and then into a tips crack up to Midway Ledge.P3 - 10b - Follow the crack just right of the belay up past bolts on a slab to the base of the Stooges Slab. This pitch is called Sodbusters.P4 - 5.9 - Finish on one of the Stooges Slab routes.P3 Alt - 10c. Go left on Midway Ledge to climb the line at the far left of the wall at 10c, 50m. It's worth switching anchors or finishing the 11a pitch by moving to the far left anchor above Cider Crack. Climb past a few cracks up to and around the obvious overlaps, finishing with some bolted slab moves. This brings you to the top of the wall.
routes.location: Follow the trail to the Malamute (the one that heads around the left side) and it ends right atop the Stooge Wall.  Four single rope raps lead down to the belay platform above Old Style.  You need to trend climber's left on the third rap.
routes.protection: Standard rack but throw in some small micronuts or HB offsets for the seam.

routes.description: Great right hand facing corner crack. The description in the book says that it is easy than it looks... Felt pretty hard for 5.9. Delicate slab moves using laybacks and poor jams. Sustained climbing for the grade. (Links into Cider Crack 5.9 for the second pitch, or lower back down to do more climbs at the base of the Malamute)
routes.location: Rap into the South side of the Lower Malamute. This climb starts at a tidal pool with a metal platform bolted to the base of the cliff.
routes.protection: Chain anchors, standard rack, mostly thin hands and smaller.

routes.description: P1: Climb the crack to the right of the middle rap station on Midway Ledge, half way up continue trending right along the diagonal crack. If you transition left halfway up to the bolts you are climbing Sodbuster instead. P2: Climb the furthest right bolted line.
routes.location: Rapell down from the top of Stooges Slab to Midway Ledge or climb Old Style and Cider Crack (Grub Street Complex)

routes.description: From the middle midway ledge anchor go up the crack to the right to a good rest. Follow the right trending diagonal seam for a couple meters before cutting left towards a bolt and a technical crux. More face climbing through two more bolts gets you to the anchor.
routes.location: Just right of the middle anchor on midway ledge.
routes.protection: Standard rack. 3 bolts for the face climbing.

description: A crag of mostly sport polished slab routes with a few horizontal cracks.
getting_there: As for The Cage, and then traverse across the ledge below The Cage.

routes.description: Climb the polished slab past two horizontal cracks to the top. There are just enough dimples and edges to get you to the top. Optionally place gear in one or both of the horizontal cracks. Very thin climbing just after the cracks.
routes.location: Second line of bolts to the left of the Jacob's Other Ladder route on Jacob's Wall.
routes.protection: 5 bolts plus a cam or two for the two horizontal cracks.

routes.description: The namesake route for this wall- Jacob's Wall is a feisty little 5.8.  Jeff and Glenn did all the routes here and to the left at the Cage in 1998.  Make sure you figure out the crux start so as to not fall before reaching the little corner after a balancy few moves with scant protection.  I tried going straight up the slab at the start to reach good holds sooner, much harder, best to come in from the left and traverse right, not too high.
routes.location: You could hike in from the upper North corner of the Malamute, coming to the Cage area with 3 slab climbs, then 5 bolted routes on Jacob's Wall with this being next right. It happens to be directly above Quagmire crack, and that is how we found it.
routes.protection: there are 2 bolts mid way up the slab, follow a dyke up and right after the initial corner. A few cam placements and tree sling options.

routes.description: A 2 bolt variation on Jacob's Other Ladder that starts at the base of the large flake on the ground. Scramble up the flake, clip the bolt, make a few thin slab moves and get up onto the ledge where you walk left and continue up Jacob's Other Ladder. Looks like there used to be a bolted anchor at the ledge to top rope this and make it a ~10 meter climb, but one of the bolts is missing a hanger now.
routes.location: The bolted line right of Jacob's Other Ladder, starts at the base of the flake.

routes.fa: Jeff Thomson, Glenn Payan & Jack Fieldhouse, 1998
routes.description: A low wandery start leads to two horizontal cracks (will take small cams), and a crux near the top.
routes.location: 6 bolts and optional small cams

routes.description: A fun and well bolted friction slab that passes two horizontal cracks. This is a great area for practicing 5.10 slab climbing.
routes.location: Keep going right past Sparky and Pacing the Cage. This is the farthest climb on the right before the dike.
routes.protection: 7 bolts plus recommended small cam for horizontal.

routes.description: The leftmost line zig zags past the first three bolts and up and over the horizontal cracks to the top of the slab.
routes.location: Bolts, optional small cam

routes.description: Follow a thin dyke up a relatively easy slab to a crux up high.
routes.location: Bolts, optional small cam for the middle.

description: A tiny crag just below the Malamute's summit.
getting_there: Scramble down South from the main summit towards a big slab/ledge (top of Terraces Wall), then make a sharp right to the slab just below the summit.

routes.description: Climb the arete on the far right of Upper Jacob's Wall.
routes.location: Far right of side of Upper Jacob's Wall.
routes.route_name: I Love the Smell of Nuprin in the Mornin

routes.description: It is a short easy slabby route, not really worth it.
routes.location: It is the far left rampy bit just to the left of "Ya Gonna Do Something or Just Stand There and Bleed?"
routes.route_name: No Need But a Little Parsley

routes.description: Do a couple slab moves to follow a thin crack up to the anchors.
routes.location: Immediately right of "Ya Gonna Do Something or Just Stand There and Bleed?"
routes.route_name: With Friends Like That Who Needs Enemas

routes.description: A short but sweet slabby climb on the centre of Upper Jacob's Wall.
routes.location: Centre of Upper Jacob's Wall.
routes.route_name: Ya Gonna Do Something or Just Stand There and Bleed

description: Along the base of the Malamute are numerous closed climbs due to their proximity to the CN rail tracks. Any climb within 8 meters is closed and some start 2 meters from the tracks.* Only routes that are not specifically labelled as CLOSED and that can be approached from above are within limits for climbing.
getting_there: Do not take the trail north around to the base of the Malamute.

routes.fa: Gordie Small, Brian Norris 1970. FFA: Peter Croft, 1979
routes.description: This looked good, and a local said it was 12a, but could be A0 at the bolt and there were folks on all other stuff so I had to try it. The 11d rating was given by Peter Croft. I tried to free it and fell trying to reach the bolt. Fun and interesting climbing mostly in the 10a/b range.It is a shallow right facing corner. The route leaves the corner heading toward a bolt that is hard to reach. Good face holds after gaining the bolt and left to anchor.
routes.location: left of Crescent crack and right of Hand Jive.
routes.protection: standard rack to 2". there are some committing moves on small gear, have extra small cams. If you want to aid to the bolt you may want a yellow alien for the pocket before the 2nd bolt, it would also be the only hold to reach the bolt if freeing the move. I missed the first bolt. A good rap anchor up and left after leaving the corner and traversing left.

routes.fa: Tony Cousins  Jim Sinclair 1963 FFA: Eric Weinstien  J.Haeck  W.Hack 1975
routes.description: This is the left-facing corner to the right of "Clean Crack".
routes.location: Pro to 2".

routes.description: This is the obvious right-leaning, thin crack.  A beautiful climb.
routes.location: Small.

routes.fa: Tony Cousins, Jim Sinclair, Wade Chernekoff 1963  FFA Dave Nicol, Paul Piro 1976
routes.description: Fantastic arching crack that gets steeper and steeper.
routes.location: Right end of the lower malemute. Note-it is in the CN Rail right of way but not as close to the tracks as Hand Jive, Clean Crack etc.
routes.protection: Gear to 2", chains at the top

routes.fa: FA Robin Barley, Randy Atkinson (4pa), 1987. FFA Andrew Boyd, Vicky Sullivan, 1998.
routes.description: Damascus Steel is an outstanding but little known route located just below Paul's Crack on Starr Wall. The route can be accessed from below by climbing Berrycup or Crescent Crack but the 'legal' approach involves an easy rap in, which is good if you want to TR or pre-hang some draws.Begin from an anchor on a slab above Berrycup. Face climb easily and clip a couple bolts to where the wall steepens. Dance up tricky 5.11 to gain the left angling crack, which is well protected and succumbs to balancy laybacking. When the crack peters out, compose yourself and launch into an improbable looking hand traverse on decent edges, but almost nothing to speak of for feet. Crimp along clipping 3 bolts until you reach a dyke crack, and some respite. Finish up a beautiful short tips to fingers splitter which forms the left boundary of a humongous detached flake (it's not going anywhere). Savor the amazing position above Howe Sound and clip the chains.This pitch is absolutely classic and deserves a place on more people's ticklist, get on it!
routes.location: Climb Berrycup, but keep climbing past the first anchor OR rappel Paul's Crack on Starr Wall, and hike up and right into the forest until you find the edge of the cliff. Carefully walk down to the edge, and a hidden belay station with chains will appear. It's possible to set up a belay on trees to reach this anchor if needed.
routes.protection: A selection of gear from tips to tight hands (.2 to #1) some doubles from .4 to .75 are nice. Draws for the bolts (7).

routes.description: The crux is getting your way out of the restful alcove. I guess it's also a little cruxy traversing to the anchors; you want there to be a jug for that move, but...   Anyway. Amazing route. Definitely out of bounds, you're not allowed to climb it. It's as close to the tracks as Clean Crack and Caboose are.
routes.location: Just past Crescent Crack (climber's left), next to a sign that tells you you're not allowed to climb on it.
routes.protection: So, you'd think it would take a lot of hand-sized gear, right? That's what I thought. In reality, it takes as many Grey Camalots (.4, not #4) that you can throw at it. If I went back to it I'd take 4 greys, 2 purples, 2 greens and then some hand-sized stuff. Oh, and a #5. I placed a #5 in the alcove. You definitely don't need to, but I'd just bought it and wanted to place it. Definitely extend it if you do. Chains at the top.

routes.description: This left-facing corner is left of "Clean Crack".  Climb to a ledge with bolts.
routes.location: Pro to 2".

description: Bouldering on the malamute
getting_there: See routes.

routes.description: Easy boulder problem for people with longer reach. Features nice foot work once you are on.
routes.location: From the Stooges Slab or(Star Wall) (where you are not suppose to sleep) continue north-north east up the trail. You will see a wall, and the arret is on the right corner.
routes.protection: Crash pad or a spotter with long arms.

description: This small crag is on the far southern end of the Malamute. The routes start on a small ledge called "Meares island".
getting_there: Hike down past Stooges Slab to find a rap station on top of a smooth slab. Rappel down and be careful not to go to far and end up on the ground.

routes.fa: R. Ron, T. Gibson, P. Croft, T. Knight, 1980
routes.description: This classic deserves more traffic.  It's adventurous, unusual, and excellent.   P1 (5.8). The first pitch could probably be skipped (which you can do since you rap in), but it's necessary for the full experience.  The stump that in 1980 was probably quite solid, is now quite questionable.  Unfortunately, until it comes off completely, you pretty much have to use it to get started.  The rest of the climbing isn't hard, but it's dirty from lack of use and some of the blocks and flakes move.   P2 (5.11b) This spectacular pitch heads up the arch passing a number of overlaps.  To be sure you head right under the correct overlap, note the following: you'll get a very weird long skinny flexing flake for your hands and see a bolt on the face above the next overlap.  Clip the bolt, but don't pull up over the overlap, instead, head right and clip another bolt and you'll curve around to the belay.  We got confused and pulled up that overlap (aid) and suffered through dirt and scary loose flakes.  A first we thought going right at the bolts was another route, Underly Hanging Out, but that one is one overlap lower.   P3 (5.10a) From the belay pull up and left into the obvious cracks.  Getting over the lip is harder than it looks involving a tight hand jam, a fist jam and something akin to humping.  The guidebook describes a final sting in the tail, but it's very mild, especially if you have small cams (I used a blue alien, but there are other options).
routes.location: This is the southernmost climb on the Malamute.  It's considered to be the Lower Malamute, but it doesn't violate the rail right-of-way.   Hike south along the top of the Malamute and follow the trail down until there's an obvious anchor beyond which the cliff pretty much ends.  Rap from this anchor (50m) to a treed ledge called Meare's Island.  The best option is to bring two ropes and do a single rope rap, carrying your lead rope down with you.  This works well since you won't need to pull your rope and then haul the extra line back up the climb.  You could get by with a single rope, but since the anchors have no chains, you would have to leave 'biners on at least one of the stations on the way down (and recover them on the way back up).   At the bottom of the rap, look left and you'll see a chain hanging from a bolt.  Batman up the chain and start the first pitch from there.  Alternatively, you could stop at the anchor at the start of the second pitch and skip the first one.
routes.protection: Up to #3 camalot and down to some small alien-sized pieces.  Doubles in the finger sizes recommended.

routes.description: A good easier variation to Overly Hanging Out that veers right on the second pitch.P1: climb the awkward 5.8 corner.P2: at the jug rest after the initial layback, instead of heading slightly up to the bolt, make a traverse along the lower roof via thin underclings and decent but well spaced feet. Great thoughtful climbing. The book gives this 10c.P3: finish on the committing arete. This pitch has an oddly placed first bolt and makes for tricky route finding. Beta alert: clip the bolt and downclimb to make the traverse onto the arete. Felt about 5.9 to us, will feel much harder if following the first bolt.
routes.location: Very south end of the Malamute.
routes.protection: Doubles from 0.2 to #1 and singles of #2 and #3 will be more than enough.

description: The large face in the central part of the Malamute, many excellent crack climbs can be found here.
getting_there: The area can be accessed by either rappeling down The Clearing on the right side, or Quagmire Crack dividing the smooth wall on the left.

routes.description: This route climbs the wide hand crack in a flare that offers some good, blue-collar jamming and thrutching through the business. The climbing to (and from) that feature is dirty and lackluster, but the main feature is as good as it looks from the ground (or as bad as it looks if you hate cupped hands).    Clip a bolt from the ground, then move through a lower 5th staircase for 20 feet or so, plugging a piece every now and then. Extend the pieces.    The main feature itself took pretty much exclusively bomber #3 Camalots. I had two, and shuffled them up as I went. While it's surely a grunt, the nature of the flare is quite secure.   After my sport climbing partner topped out after grunting and french freeing through the flare, his eyes bugged out of his head when I told him it was graded 10a in the guidebook. It'd probably be 5.9+ in Indian Creek though.
routes.location: On the main headwall of the Lower Malamute, between the Clean Crack and Crescent Crack areas,  below the obvious epic 40m finger crack that splits the middle of the headwall (Quagmire). The main feature of Canadian Compromise can be seen by walking from the South. Start on a boulder below a bolt.
routes.protection: 1 quickdraw, single rack from .5 to #2 C4s, 2 #3s.    If you're climbing this to get to Quagmire Crack, sling the tree at the top and keep climbing through easy but dirty and overgrown (in Spring 2016) ground to a kind of shitty hangerless chain anchor next to the base of Quagmire. You may want an extra #1 and #2 C4 for this section, and some slings to extend them. From this anchor the route is over 30m, maybe longer than 35m so be careful if you intend to rap from this anchor.    If you're just climbing the feature, sling the tree when you top out of the crack - this will likely match the guidebook's measure of 20m.

routes.description: Unique 1980's Croft test piece. Originally freed in two pitches. Can be done in one pitch with clever use of two ropes. Classic 5.10d corner (good on it's own), to a wild finger traverse, to even wilder roof/mantle.
routes.location: The only legal way to approach this climb is by rapping in on Quagmire Crack.
routes.protection: Excellent protection, small nuts and finger size cams.

routes.fa: Dan Tate,Barry Hagen, 11/65 FFA : Peter Croft, Tami Knight, 1979
routes.description: This would be a classic if not so close to railroad, and if it were clean.  I think it may also be 10a, not too strenuous, just techy.  The right facing corner left of cedar trees dividing it from the more obvious crack of Hand Jive.Intimidating looking, but don't let the dirty start scare you off. The gear is tricky and a few technical moves make it exciting. It was damp and mossy, so avoid after a rain.
routes.location: 15 meters left of Hand Jive ( crack with the do not climb sign next to it) the Arete left of the corner has some bolts- Will Power. Pull up on Salal bushes to reach ledge with a bolt up left. We rapped back to the ground  at the tracks with a 70 m. rope.
routes.protection: standard rack to 2". I used a tiny nut and cam right after the belay bolt,.  There is a fixed pin near the rap anchor.  I keep seeing that a standard rack is .5 - #3 camalot, for me it is blue, green, yellow, red Alien the the .5 and up. and a set of nuts.

routes.fa: Robin Barley, Andreas Maurer, Kevin McLane, 1976, recleaned in 1998 by Andrew Boyd.
routes.description: This is a great finger crack and I am surprised to not already find it here. MP seems to not have caught on in Squamish, at least not the off the beaten path routes.It is listed as 10c in the books, seems lots harder then Bulletheads east or Peasants route, more like the last Liquid Gold pitch so maybe 10d.( was considered 10b in the 1970/80's) Maybe it is the approach. A good way to climb out would be on Jacobs other Ladder which is a 5.8 dyke traverse just above which is described as being bold, and it is.
routes.location: If you look at the Malamute photo on the header of this page taken from the log yard across the railway you will see an obvious white rock fall scar at the north end ( occurred in 1979) and the corner in the middle of this is Canadian Compromise and long splitter crack above is Quagmire. We rapped in with double ropes( at top of Besot and Flushed) and ended up at the very rusty bolts of Milkwood Forest. Rapped to base and fought our way up through moss past 2) 1/4" bolts and loose flake- not recommended.( original start of Porco on the first ascent.)The McLane book recommends the Smithereens approach, I noticed bolts over there without hangers.Rapping down Stone Cold would put you right above Quagmire if you wanted to rap. 2 rope rap.
routes.protection: It is 40- 45 Meter pitch so having many finger size is recommended. Double rack to 3", maybe 3 each in the 1/4"-  1/2" size or lots of nuts work too. Bolted belay on ledge at base and tree belay at top. There is a 2 bolt anchor about 10' north but I came up the OW finish which seems to make sense with a tree right there.I was not prepared for the OW, placed a #2 at start of it and layback up to top, could use a #4, but not really needed.I was informed by a local that the OW finish used to be full of vegetation and I guess that is why there is the bolted anchor off left at the top.

routes.description: A dirty line that if clean would be a nice alternative to Quagmire Crack. Pitch 1 10b "Smithereens"Look for a few bolts near the flake that arcs left. Climb until you reach a very bushy ledge and pull your way up the bushes to the belay.  Pitch 2 10dStep right around the corner and protect with small cams, the crack starts thin but gets wider until you must choose to go left or right. Stay left and climb the exposed line on your left, protect delicately with nuts and small cams, there is a piton a few meters before the anchor. You can rap with a single 70m
routes.location: Double rack with emphasis on small cams and nuts
routes.protection: Ten meters to the right of Quagmire Crack

description: Located between The Terraces and Stooges Slab.
getting_there: The main approach trail, as of 2019, brings you out close to the top of the Malamute. The Starr Wall is 100 meters or so south, or climbers' right, of where the trail comes out to the cliff.  Note, the slab with sport routes just to climbers right at this point is -not- Stooges slab.If it's your first visit, it's best to rappel, and scope out the trail down to the wall as you do so. To find the rappel, walk back into the woods a few meters, down a slab, a bit of trail, and then you'll see the top of High Mountain Woody's crack (bolts but no chains, to the side of the topout). To climber's left, you'll see bolts and chains, above Paul's crack. Use those.The trail down to the Starr Wall from the approach trail is heady and sandy at points, and may involve a fixed line. The book will tell you, in a highlighted section, to use it at all costs. You probably should, but only once you know where you're going.

routes.description: Start left of Paul's Crack, past 2 bolts, then go right across PC and continue towards High Mountain Woody passing another 3 bolts. Hard for the grade.
routes.location: Left of Paul's Crack.
