routes.description: This classic crack offers some excellent crack climbing with some of the most amazing views in Squamish. The 5.8/5.9 crux is right at the bottom, it's all smooth sailing from there.
routes.location: Hike to the top of the Malamute formation straight across the road from the Chief campground. Find a series of chains at the top of the cliff. Rappel (Double rope!) to a large ledge at the base of the climb. You can rap with a single rope but this requires stopping at the large tree to set up a second rappel (no slings or rap rings here anymore).

routes.description: The crux is leaving the ledge before getting to the first bolt.  There is good gear around the corner in a crack if you place it high. A bit scruffy but good. A wider crack appears on the left followed by a thinner horizontal crack and then there are some slab moves and a scramble to the anchor.
routes.location: Climb to View Ledge by Gonch Pull, Neighbourhood Bully, Stephanie's Tears or Sorry John! . The climb starts off the right hand side of the ledge along the arete.
routes.protection: Mixed. 3 bolts. Standard rack to 3.5" (you could get by with gear to just 2"). Chains on two bolts for the anchor.

routes.description: A thin, balancy slab climb ascends to View Ledge, between Stefanie's Tears and Slap and Tickle.
routes.location: Between Stefanie's Tears and Slap and Tickle.
routes.protection: 5 bolts plus a couple trad pieces for the start.

routes.description: This good route has a finger crack crux in the first ten feet and fun but easier climbing above.
routes.location: Just left of High Mountain Woody, but starting from a terrace fifty or sixty feet higher than the start of HMW.  The easier approach is probably to just rappel in since the trail takes you to the top and there is an easily accessible bolted (two bolts, no chains or rings but they aren't necessary).  Alternatively you could continue north along the top of the crag, drop down a level between "Smell of Nuprin" and "Remembrance Day", then walk south until a fixed hand line will take you down to the starting terrace.   Note that McLane's guidebook has a wee typo relevant to the second approach described above.  Remembrance Day is listed as route 385, but the line on the topo is labeled 365.  365 is correctly labelled elsewhere as a Lower Malamute route.
routes.protection: Finger sized nuts or cams for the start.  A small selection of larger nuts and hand sized cams for the rest.

routes.description: Want to climb Pauls crack, but you are sitting at the base of High Mountain Woody? Enter "Paul's Shwack".Start as for High Mountain Woody for 8 ft, then traverse left on somewhat tenuous slab into the gully. Follow up into the chimney. A #2 and #3 protect the chimney, a small cam could protect the traverse down low.
routes.location: The bushy chimney between Paul's crack and High Mountain Woody.

routes.description: Science Friction ascends the clean arete left of Stephanie's Tears p2 corner. Step left off of the View Ledge and climb the sustained face and arete to an anchor.
routes.location: The route starts from an anchor on the View Ledge.

routes.description: A great challenging 10b.  I tried to enter this in meters, but it kept turning 50 m to 50 ft.  I did the Gonch start which is about 40' below the Woody.Same as Stefanie's Tears start but goes left where ST goes right. Also 5.9. Makes it a 55m pitch.  The Woody start is good too, cuts right up thinner crack that a nut tool was needed for cleaning, might be 10a.  When you near the View Ledge you can get a cam in the top of the Gonch crack with a long sling, but don't climb to the ledge, head for the left arching thin crack.
routes.location: starts same as High Mtn. Woody, or better yet start with Gonch Pull to the right to make it even longer. Where that route ends on the ledge for the 2nd pitch start of Stefanie's Tears, or a little before the ledge go left on thin left trending crack. Before you run into High Mtn. Woody near the top go more right and up. Finish is thin and hard to protect.
routes.protection: plenty of cams for this long pitch, many small cams and offset brass nuts good for upper half.  Gonch pull takes medium to large nuts, so you can conserve cams for up higher.  The top out is a bit run-out after the tiny gear seam runs out.

routes.description: The crux comes after the third bolt at a relatively blank slab section. Good face climbing and a couple crack climbing moves here and there. A good mix of gear protected and bolt protected climbing. Really a nice route overall that doesn't seem to get a lot of traffic but is quite clean.
routes.location: Descend to the far climbers right side of Starr wall. To the right of a large cut off stump on the wall is a sharp flake. The route begins on this flake. Climb up it and then trend right following a line of bolts along the arete.
routes.protection: Mixed protection. 5 bolts. Standard rack to 2". The anchor is two Metolius Rap Hangers.

routes.description: Stefanie's Tears is a sweet little 2 pitch climb right of High Mountain Woody.  A small step up in difficulty and more sustained than that route, but well within the grasp of anyone leading HMW.   P1.  Scramble up past the tree stump into a left-angling finger crack.  When you reach the large undercling on the right, reach over and clip the second bolt on Neighbourhood Bully, then move right (tricky and fun) and finish up the arete.  Nice exposure and committing moves take you to a bolted belay on View Ledge. 5.9   P2.  Climb the obvious corner crack above.  There are certainly many ways to do this, but it is a fun layback.  5.8
routes.location: Stefanie's Tears climbs the rightmost crack on the Starr Wall. Descend to the left of HMW via your method of choice (go down to the second ledge and rap again off the slung tree), then scramble down another 20 feet to a finger crack above a flake and cedar stump. This is the start of Stefanie's Tears, Gonch Pull, and Neighbourhood Bully.
routes.protection: Gear to 1".  A double or two around .5 or .75 camalot is nice for the second pitch, but not needed.  Bolted anchors.

routes.fa: Glenn Payan, Jeff Thomson, John Thomson 1998
routes.description: This route climbs up to and across a flake to start (easy, no gear) until you reach a brief layback crack about 20 feet up. Climb this to some monster jugs, then turn the corner onto the face and clip a bolt. Pull an awkward move then continue up discontinuous cracks to a diagonal. Step left along this, then enjoy some slab action to the top out.   NOTE: This route, along with all routes at the Starr Wall, does not anchors that allow top-roping. Someone must second the route to clean the gear.
routes.location: On the Starr Wall's upper-left side, locate a set of rappel anchors

description: Three slab climbs on a small wall above Grub Street to the south of Starr Wall.
getting_there: Walk south and then around to the base of this small wall.

routes.description: Short slab climb with 1 or 2 5.9 moves on Stooge's Slab.
routes.location: 4 bolts

routes.description: Super fun and sustained 5.9 slab on Stooge's Slab.
routes.location: 5 bolts

routes.description: slab climb with good feet on Stooge's Slab.
routes.location: 4 bolts

description: A small wall with mostly sport routes on the top of the Malamute between Jacobs Wall and Starr Wall.
getting_there: Walk north from "Star Wall" along the Malamute Ridge until it is possible to head down to the ledges below.

routes.description: Hard slab for most of the way, high first bolt.
routes.location: Right most climb of the formation

routes.description: Up the slab
routes.location: Obvious steep slabs with 3 bolts

routes.description: A slab route on a nice face with few features.  It is the middle route on the face.  There is a decent belay ledge.  This is the middle route on the face.  Thin smearing, but reasonably bolted.
routes.location: If approaching the Malamute from the North (walking north to south) this slab is just past the high point and just below the rap in for Paul's Crack etc.

routes.description: Ultra thin vertical dyke tuff like line.https://youtu.be/1IaX7k5v9UU
routes.location: Rightmost line on Terraces wall, after going around the corner. Can be seen when standing on top of Starr Wall.

description: Steep cliff to lookers left of Photophobia Buttress and Dog Cliff. Quality, beautiful, harder cracks in a great setting.
getting_there: Follow trail to Top shelf for 5-10 min, cairn marks turn to right. Take trail for another 10 min to base.

routes.description: P1) 5.11a   Climb Pitch 1 of “Road to Amritsar”P2) 5.11a.  Follow the cracks up to a ledge. from here go up  and left past a couple bolts to some hollow flakes and cracks to anchor.P3) 5.12a   Follow cracks and flakes up and left to a Bouldery bolt protected crux, to a finger crack which leads to the anchor.P4) 5.11c   Climb the finger crack above to a chain anchor. Descent: RappelSR to 2”  Tripples: 0.2 - 0.4” cams
routes.location: All Anchors Bolted

routes.fa: FA : Harry Young, Colin Moorhead, Jason Green. June 2015.
routes.description: Steep, exposed, continuously good. Mostly finger to tight hands, with a short overhanging chimney crux !P1 11a: Steep corner dual cracks lead over a tricky bulge to a big ledge. 11aP2 11c: Beautiful corner. Money. Stem, layback, and grovel up an overhanging chimney crux. 11cP3 10d: Very fun glory hands lead up and traverse left, before entering somewhat-hollow sounding flakes. Type 1 fun.P4 11b: Very exposed and *stellar* thin hands, with a great crux! Topout on wide ledgeP5 9: Short fist jamming pitch to trees. Feels like a logical conclusionP6 11c: If you choose to do it, the true crux. Sweaty rock, ring locks, and odd movement.
routes.location: Obvious line in the corner up to the right at the base. Look for the bulge with dual cracks leading up.
routes.protection: Bolted anchors. triples of finger to hand size.

description: North northwest facing. The wall is comprised to stacked pillar features and has a sky cragging feel.
getting_there: Main Barbarian Wall approach. Left wall at the trails top. Roughly 20 minutes uphill with some static lines up steeper sections. Recommend to wear a helmet during upper portion of approach up steep gully.

routes.fa: Luc Kennedy May 28, 2023, support from Chris Phillips
routes.description: Goat Whisperer 5.12- 6 pitchesP1: 5.10 20mClimb the blocky feature on the left (don't go out right to the bolt). Step right to gain thin cracks at/above overlap. Continue to comfy belay ledge. Bolted Anchor.P2: “Fight of the Spidermen” 5.11+ 30m      Climb up through diagonal crack features (micro cams),  then left past 2 bolts. Follow crack to the top. Gear anchor at the angle change. Name comes from a hostile, defensive spider puffing up his chest and challenging Chris to a fight near the little tree.P3: 5.8 20m   Ramble up to the ledge, skip the rap station here and Climb the steep, crack to a bolted station below the arette. P4: "Consequential Ethics" 5.11 50m      Climb boldly up the arette on tricky small gear placements and 3 bolts. Make a few slab moves right past a bolt to finger cracks. Follow them up and meander left after the the last small overlap. Comfy bolted belay station at the top of the wall. Manage your rope drag with slings. P5: 5.8 20m     Climb the left leaning wide crack then traverse awkwardly left (Protect your follower) and step across a chimney to a comfy ledge and bolted station. Move the belay around the corner below the final head wall. Bolted AnchorP6 “Prance upon the Precipice” 5.12-  35m     This is what you came for! Climb the finger crack up the corner (Strenuous Gear Placements) and gain the arette before moving right to a small diehedral and the delightful headwall crack. Bolted Anchor.Recommended to Rappel the route from here with a FULL 70m ropeP7: 5.10 20mClimb up the cliff bands and ledges to a tree belay.  Rappel the route with a 70m rope.
routes.location: Be comfortable placing and climbing above small nuts and cams.GEAR:     SR 0.1 - 4, Doubles: 0.1, 0.75, Triples 0.2-0.5, Nuts, Small Nuts and/or RPs, 8 - 10 quickdraws, 6 - 8 alpine draws, double length sling.

description: Distinct black and gold streaked cliff above and west of Top Shelf. This cliff has several high quality lines and is well worth the hike.
getting_there: This cliff is an additional 10-15 minutes beyond top shelf, walking around either side of Top shelf will bring you past the next tier "The Upper Deck" and beyond to Black Streak Dome.

routes.description: This worthwhile corner features steep laybacking, stemming, and jamming. The distinct crux through the upper arch culminates in a pumpy hand crack finale.
routes.location: This is listed as open project #72 in the latest edition of Squamish Select. To the right of the Drang and to the left of The Sulker.
routes.protection: 3 bolts supplemented with a single set of cams to #3 BD.

description: Recently developed quartzite crag with mostly moderate sport routes. It dries quickly and gets a lot of sun. Helmets are advised as this area is still relatively new. Developers ask that you please don’t leave any garbage, no fires, and avoid going to top to set up top ropes - anchors are not set up for that. Destruction or torment to all living things are not necessary nor welcome.
getting_there: From 99, Turn onto Mamquam FSR east. Follow this for about two miles and turn left onto Powerhouse Springs FSR (unnamed on google maps, but there is a street sign). Less than one mile down the road you should come to a large boulder on the right. The crag is on your left and only a minute away. The trail will deposit you close to the right side of the crag.

routes.description: Weave around through challenging mild slab and committing mantels.
routes.location: Left of center, a few feet to the right of a short vertical crack.

routes.description: Fun technical climbing. Tricky right off the bat.
routes.location: Several feet left of the "Motivator" roof there is a small bulge over the diagonal crack. This route climbs up just left of that small bulge.

routes.description: Hardest at the bottom, mild crimps up above.
routes.location: Second bolted route from the end.

routes.description: Delicate moves up the ridge on the right side of the roof.
routes.location: Just right of the "Motivator" roof.

routes.description: Shared start with "Homeless". Continue straight up after the third bolt. The crux is high up on this technical climb, and she demands commitment.
routes.location: Several feet left of the "Motivator" roof.

routes.description: Use Laybacks on the crack to get to the first bolt. Deceptively tricky face climbing up the rest of the face.
routes.location: Towards the left of the wall, starts at a few feet of vertical crack leading up to the diagonal crack.

routes.description: The climb veers left at the roof to avoid it. Pull the corner and head up the bulging arete. Going around the arete will make this about a grade easier.
routes.location: Starts just under the left side of the "Motivator" roof.

routes.description: Shared start with "Dirtbaggers". Fork left after the third bolt and head up the nose-shaped feature.
routes.location: Several feet left of the "Motivator" roof.

routes.description: Fun route for kids -- short person beta is to heel hook a lip at the crux in the middle of the route.
routes.location: Around the corner all the way on the left.

routes.description: A steep start veers a bit left into slab and gets steeper again at the top. The slab is probably the hardest part.
routes.location: The right-most route on the wall. Just left of the mossy rock.

routes.description: You guessed it, the roof is the crux. Complete the route on easy but run out slab or veer left and merge into Hollow Flake.
routes.location: Right up the center of the roof.
routes.protection: bolts. You might set up a TR by climbing Hollow Flake first.

routes.description: Pull the lip to gain the face to an easy slightly runout finish.
routes.location: Just to the left of the diagonal crack. Alternate start just to the right of the crack.

routes.description: Starts near "Slab Your Face", but head left over the bulge to easy finish.
routes.location: A few feet right of the "Motivator" roof.

routes.description: Head up the low angle wall with tight bolting. Easy middle with a little more difficulty at beginning and end.
routes.location: third route left of the "Motivator" roof.

routes.description: Start out with tricky vertical face climbing to a crux move at the ledge up top.
routes.location: Just to the right of where there is a giant rock wedged into the diagonal crack.

routes.description: Difficult start on steeper and less featureful rock than most of the wall. Merge with "Mediocrity" about a third of the way up.
routes.location: This is an alternate start several feet to the left of "Masters of Mediocrity"

description: This is a new old crag.  One route was done in 1996 and then over the last year or two (2007 and 2008), Peter Winter cleaned it up and put in about 20 bolted routes.  The climbs are primarily 5.11 and 5.12, although there are two at 5.10b and one 5.9.   The wall is taller and steeper than many sport areas around squamish and has good, though-provoking climbing.  It faces east and has sun until about noon depending on the season.  The base can be buggy, bring bug juice.   Here's a link to a topo that also includes directions.   Peter Winter has requested that TRs be done from draws rather than through the chains; good advice in any area.
getting_there: While this crag is in the same vicinity as The Sanctuary, the approach is different.   Take the Mamquam Forest Service Road (the one you take for  The Apron parking lot), drive past Slhanay and stay left at the forks until you can park in a clearing just left of a gate (Epcor).   Walk along the trail at the end of the clearing, past concrete barriers, until you can head left onto the Farther Side mountain bike trail.  Follow the trail, staying left, until it has turned to head east and is fairly level.  In a few minutes the crag should then be just barely visible from the trail, and flagging tape helps locate the very rough trail to the base.  You'll probably bushwack the first time.  Total time from parking should be 10 to 15 minutes.

routes.description: Crux gaining the ledge at the anchor.
routes.location: Just left of Twick or tweet

routes.description: This is an extension above "3 or 4 times a Night". 3 bolts to lower-off.
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: This long route is adventurous, especially when wet, which is can be, even if most of the other routes are dry.
routes.location: Near the left side of the crag there is hump in the base trail, this route starts on the left slope of the hump.
routes.protection: approximately 10 bolts, there is a bit of a longer gap between bolts on an easier section, so not a good first sport lead...

routes.description: A long sport climb with multiple cruxes between rests.
routes.location: Starts between Kenny Vs Spenny and Snowglobe

routes.description: Easy climbing to a tricky crux on the arete. If you puss out left you lose a letter grade. High crux as well. High first bolt, but easy climbing.
routes.location: Get psyched for some severe crimping! Start at the bottom left toe of the South face of Acid rock. Crimp through Ice,.. chill as best you can at the slim ledge hold, then bust your best move on Psilocybin. Had enough? Not quite over,... finish on the thin crimpers on Slut for Punishment. A complete left to right rising finger screamer. Happy trails.

routes.description: This route is sustained with bouldery cruxes and a few good rests.Easy climbing leads to the first bolt at about 30 feet. There are two distinct points on the route at which you may choose to climb either left or right of the bolt line, with the different paths potentially suiting different strengths. There are two different sets of anchors at the top: one on the left, one on the right. The grade is the same regardless which anchors you clip. This route tends to seep after a rain, especially at the bulge below the fifth bolt.
routes.location: Right of the dyke route Burp the Worm

routes.description: Building pump up the potruding dyke. A final sting in the tail just below the anchor, which is above and RIGHT of the dyke.
routes.location: Obvious dyke right of the trailhead

routes.description: Fingery wall with a pumpy finish
routes.location: Behind the tree stump, left of Story of my life

routes.description: Moderate climbing to a good rest, crux pulling out of the rest
routes.location: start off the big ledge, belay can be on the ground

routes.description: Climbs the shallow corner to a break then up the short face above. Bouldery climbing with some decent rests.
routes.location: Leftmost route of the new 5.12a at the left side of the crag
routes.protection: Bolted. Well protected with top anchors with fixed carabiners

routes.description: The crux is around the 3rd bolt, just past the bulge.The rest of the climb is relatively moderate, but fun to climbThere is an alternative start on the left, but most boulder up on the right.
routes.location: 2nd of the 4 new 12a routes to the left of “Story of my life”
routes.protection: Well protected with top anchors with fixed carabiners

routes.description: Low crux, with some fingery climbing to finish. Multi-color bolts!
routes.location: Second route from the left end of the crag, just right of Codgery

routes.description: Pumpy route with good variety. Hard pulling up the open corner then some delicate face climbing and boulder finish
routes.location: Just right of the woodpecker stump. High first bolt above the big ledge. Behind you is a cut survey line in the forest

routes.description: Shares the start of Where are they now? Instead of traversing left on the ledge campus up right up the open book corner. Get some respite in the middle and then the crux up to the chains on the upper headwall.
routes.location: Left of Dividing Line.

routes.description: A great, sustained route with multiple cruxes and fun roof finish.  Definitely one of the best of its grade in the Squamish area.   Some powerful reaches early on take you to some delicate sequences below the roof.  The roof seems unlikely when you're under it, but clip the bolt and swing out, you'll figure it out.
routes.location: Roughly in the middle of the crag, where the base is nice and flat.  Look for the triangular roof above.  Check the topo too.

routes.description: Link up of Good Times into Snowglobe. Traverse up left after the sixth draw on Good Times, then finish through the dihedral and roof on Snowglobe.
routes.location: Same start as Good Times. Cut left after the sixth bolt.
routes.protection: Bolts with lower-offs at the anchor.

routes.description: Easy climbing up the corner, still a bit scruffy but not as dirty as it looks. Should clean up with a few ascents.  In a natural water runnel. Crux at the top. Make sure to stem!
routes.location: Up the dirty "looking" diagonal corner crack.

routes.description: Crux down low.
routes.location: Left side of crag, just right of a large dirty corner crack

routes.description: Steep climbing out a bulge to an endurance finish.
routes.location: Left side of the crag out the cave like feature

routes.description: Bullet proof rock (except for the start) Sustained. Harder than it's neighbour to the right.
routes.location: Starts up marginal rock through a sandy flake

routes.description: A good and varied climb that's harder than it looks.  It starts casually, toughens up to a bulge which is the first crux and then moves into a crux corner with strange, slick holds.  To finish, a few easy but intimidating layback moves take you to the anchor.
routes.location: See topo.
routes.protection: Bolted. Fixed biners and chains for anchors.

routes.description: Traverse right on fixed draws-techy!. Then straight up on steep jugs.
routes.location: Left side of crag with fixed draws

routes.description: Crux at the chains, awkward climbing. You can continue to the anchors of Vikings but would be a bit scruffy
routes.location: Furthest to the right around the corner. Start and belay off the ledge.

routes.description: Nasty boulder crux over the starting bulge. Techy face the rest of the way
routes.location: Right of the woodpecker stump. Starts off the big ledge.

routes.description: Face climb up to the horizontal break and then pump up the dihedral feature to small edges
routes.location: Between Ants go Marching and Quaker Oats

routes.description: Crux pulling out of the little corner feature, but don't blow it up high
routes.location: On the prow by itself, left of the trailhead.

routes.description: A very bouldery route that makes a good workout, especially on a TR set by climbing good times.
routes.location: Immediately right of Good Times.
routes.protection: Bolted, but clips awkward and disconcerting...  Bolted anchor under the roof.

routes.description: A great climb that is immediately left of Good Times. Sharp holds, reachy moves and balancy climbing defines the first section of this climb. Milk the no-hands rest about half way up and fire the powerful dihedral for a couple bolts. Move up through the reachy, but great holds for the final short headwall to the anchor.
routes.location: 9 draws + anchor

routes.description: This was the original route on the crag.  I'm surprised more weren't developed at the time.   Although it's close to Good Times, the climbing is completely different.  It's not pumpy at all, but is technically challenging, especially the one real crux.  Enjoyable.
routes.location: Right of Good Times and Serenity Now, left of the obvious dike.

routes.description: Boulder problem crux in the scoop like feature.
routes.location: Far left side of the crag, around the corner.

routes.description: Crux is above a small roof. Fun climb with great views from the top
routes.location: Is located between Ants go marching (10b) & 3 or 4 times a night (10a)

routes.description: Start just left of the corner crack route.
routes.location: Start up average rock, to typical granite higher up, sustained, no distinct crux.

routes.description: Boulder crux at the start. Pumpy finish, milk the no-hands
routes.location: Right side of headwall, up the crack start and belay off the ledge.

routes.description: Funky climbing to a classic Squamish granite crux up high.
routes.location: left side of crag, near the tall woodpecker stump.start up a usually wet blocky corner. traverse left and then straight up.

routes.description: Power endurance with a sting in the tail. Nice steep climbing. Bolts are a little more spaced than the average Fern route.  The top runout is easy.
routes.location: Far left end, climbs out of the steep part of the wall

routes.description: Crux up high. Be careful of the odd little rock breaking as it's a new route. Better than it looks.
routes.location: In the yellow wall.

description: Shady mostly north facing, some sun in the morning. Best when it's been dry for awhile and hot in Squamish.   It's a lot lower than Habrich and is a different approach.   It's a Secluded and the rock quality is fantastic.  Alpine cragging at it's finest.
getting_there: Take Mamquam FSR (the dirt road that goes past the Slahany). Follow Stawamus FSR for awhile. It's about 10Km from HWY 99. Park when the road gets too rock to drive (unless you have high clearance). The road was washed out, but has been repaired. The following parking location is very close to the trailhead (49.666343, -123.065648). Hike down to the river, usually marked. You'll know you have the right river crossing if you see a rope bridge. Follow trail steeply for 30-40 mins.

routes.description: Apex Predator takes a plumb line up the centre of the Fluffy Kitten Wall.The first 3 pitches take Route #2 from McLane’s Squamish Rockclimbs guidebook (2018) - ‘Unknown 5.9 A1’ and continues to the top of the wall directly above.7 pitches, bolted anchors set up for 60 metre rappels.Gear: Pack a big rack for long pitches. Some small gear, triples in 0.3 - #1 is nice to have, 2 x #2, 1 x #3.Pitch 1 - 5.6 - shared with Cat O’Nine Tails - an easy chimney groove feature leads to a new bolted anchor. 50mPitch 2 - 5.10a - climb up and right to find an easy ‘rock ladder’ in the middle groove system. At the top, keep right (anchor out left is for Cat O’Nine) and climb a left facing hand crack groove to a high anchor - 55mPitch 3 - 5.10c - The outstanding hand crack in a corner goes on forever. At the top, clip a bolt and slab climb right to bolted anchor - 55mPitch 4 - 5.11c - The crux pitch follows steep finger cracks above the belay, swich crack systems to the left half way up (watch for rope drag) and enter the sentry box - exiting out left to a nice belay ledge. Mega! - 55mPitch 5 - 5.10d - Layback, stem and smear up the slabby corner past 2 bolts. Exit out left to easy climbing past a piton to a bolted anchor - 25mPitch 6 - 5.11b - Climb the steep crack directly above which widens from fingers to hands. It’s possible to link pitches 5 & 6 for another rope stretcher - 25mPitch 7 - 5.10a -  A short pitch quickly turns into a vertical bushwhack to get to the top of the wall. If you do it, expect a bit of dirt - 15mDescription credit:  seatoskyclimbing.ca/latest-…
routes.location: Fluffy kitten wall.

routes.fa: Brian Pegg, Andy Durie, 1997. FFA: John Ford, Andy Durie, 1998
routes.description: I guess the approach scares people off of this excellent route.It does tend to be wet on the first approach bit and might seep on the first pitch.This is a great hot summer day adventure.Pitch 1) start up ledges to gain dihedral, great cracks and stem box. 5.9, 40-50mPitch 2) Move up and left from the anchor into a clean dihedral. Follow this up, trending right until on top of "Scratching Post Ledge", and at a bolted station. 5.9, 40m.Pitch 3) Move the anchor down and right around the corner and across 3rd class terrain to another bolted anchor. From this anchor, climb a long crack pitch up to two anchor stations (one was added while the other was covered in ice). 5.10b, 55mPitch 4) Continue up the crack before making a move left across the face to a flake/crack. A bolt protects where the flakes are weak, continue up the good crack reached on the left to bolted anchor. 5.9 35-40m.Pitch 5) Continue up the crack until you have to transition into face climbing past 2 bolts, getting to the 1st one was the crux for me, making the move at the 3rd bolt is the 10c A0 or 11a move, pretty short but committing feeling above big ledge( there are good holds above this), followed by more 5.9 crack to bolted anchor. 11a or 10cA0.Pitch 6) slight right traverse and stay left of bulge, then right around right facing dihedral to tree with slings at top.5.9, 20 or 30mhttp://squamishclimbing.com/squamish_climbing_bb/viewtopic.php?f=1&t=4601
routes.location: Finding the trail can be hard, we drove past it, if you drive under the power lines you have gone too far. You will be directly across the river from the wall and at the top of a particularly rough 4X4 hill, there is a cairn and the river near by, rope bridge on the left. 45min hike up steep hill, right turn at cliff base, a fixed rope leads up wet corner to base of big  left facing dihedral. All good bolted anchors, slings on tree at rim of wall.
routes.protection: Well protected route with long pitches of mostly crack. Double rack to 3", lots of nuts and extra in small cams. If everyone who climbs this brought up a 4 link 3/8" chain, quick link, wrench, all of the anchors could be upgraded. As of summer 2015, there is good cord/slings on hangers.We took a tag line and left it at the top of pitch 6, did a single rope rap from top back to that anchor and then did double rope raps back to ground. From the top of the 10b anchor we went to the top of the Scratching post. The crack below this eats ropes, we had to climb back up to clear it.

description: Quality granit, scenic view and amazing splitter with a short approach.Bravo to the route developer, if any of this pitches was in the bluff or on the chief, they would be Ultra classic !!
getting_there: Drive the Shannon FSR for 9.7km, you will see a 9km yellow sign. The parking is left of the yellow gate. Walk past the gate for 200m turn right on a faith trail just before going up hill again. Hike down 10 minutes, the cliffs is obvious on your right.  quickdrawpublications.com/w…

routes.description: Amazing splitter crack, hand, fingers..
routes.location: Double 2's, triple finger, you can place 2x 4's in pods

routes.description: P1 : Layback the nice crack to a tree, and more layback to a short wide section, more crack to the chain of natural perfection. (10c, 30m)P2: Up the crack, a small slab section to a corner join the chain. (10a, 25m)
routes.location: Double rack to 4's, 1x5 useful for the wide part

routes.description: P1 : Up the flairing crack passing a small buldge, a bit spooky. Small gear and nuts (10d,18m)P2 : Finger crack, get wider save some number 3's for the top (10d, 25m)P3 : Finger and small hand (10a, 20m)
routes.location: Double rack to 4's, you could use a 5 in on spot

routes.description: P1 : Long diagonal hands-to-fists crack (10b, 35m)P2 : Up the crack and travers left to the bolted face (10c, 30m)
routes.location: Double rack to 4

routes.fa: Angela Muellers, Harry Young, Gusta Van Zwieten
routes.description: This is a superb route that deserves more traffic. The off-putting name doesn't help.Pitch 1: interesting face climbing past two bolts to fun layback feature. 11-Pitch 2: crack that widens from hands to squeeze chimney. Varied wide technique required.10+Pitch 3: hand crack starting with a short shut seam with one bolt. Allegedly 8 but felt harder.
routes.location: Standard Squamish rack (doubles from Camalot #0.3 to #3, triples in #2) plus more big cams for pitch 2: double #4, at least one #5. A #6 isn't obligatory but would likely get used. Quickdraws for bolts on pitches 1 and 3.

description: Squamish cracks not steep enough for you? Not splitter enough? Take a trip to the Longhouse.   Lots of quality single pitch splitters in beautiful granite. A fair bit of wide stuff as well. Brings lots of cams, as the usual Squamish single/double rack will probably not be enough.   This area is quite shaded and much less busy than the usual Squamish crag, you might even have the place to yourself..
getting_there: Parking is along the road leading to the top of the gondola. 4WD high clearance required. Please don't try to hammer up the road in a 2WD as it will just make it harder for the rest of us to get up there after.    Head up the Mamquam FSR, turn right after the pump house then two more rights. Park on the side of the road just before KM marker 8. If you see the clearing on the right with steep switchbacks afterwards then you've gone too far.   An obvious trail leads directly into the forest. Follow flagging for 10-15 minutes until you reach the Stratosphere cliff.   Additional info can be found at squamishclimbingsource.com

routes.fa: FA Hazel Findlay, 2012; FA (The Garder) Josh Lavigne, 2014.
routes.description: Tucked away in the forest, Adder Crack is one of Squamish's best hard cracks with several sort-of variations:i) The Garder (12d): Climb the flakes to the right and traverse left to bypass the bottom crux of Adder. Not sure whether you'd protect the right with runners, or double ropes. Maybe someone can add some helpful information on this.  ii) Adder Crack (13b?), but climbing up the flakes, placing gear, and then down climbing and climbing the direct. I've heard that this is how the first ascent was done and how some folks have repeated it. Seems like you may want double ropes. Not sure!iii) Adder Crack (13b?), from the bottom. Though it'd be red-hot ground up, as a headpoint, this was much more reasonable than I anticipated and is what I would recommend. Protected well with a #3 RP placed high from the ground, a Blue Metolius, and a 0.2/0.3 offset cam.However you do it, just do it! This thing is so, so good.
routes.location: Right of PG Tips in the far right corridor of the Longhouse. Shares the anchor with PG tips.
routes.protection: There's a smattering of very small to #4 C4 available in terms of gear. I'd bring triples from 0.2 to 0.75 with singles to 4, plus some offset nuts and/or cams to sort out your own scene. Seriously, this thing is dope. Do it!

routes.description: Climb out of the alcove up a short overhanging finger crack to easier climbing above.
routes.location: single rack to 4"

routes.description: Jam the right leaning crack with a couple of offwidth moves until it thins out near the top. Quality!
routes.location: single rack to 1", doubles (or triples) to 4", single 5" should do

routes.description: Nice double cracks on either side of a mega flake Jump into the wide crack, or shift over to the corner.NOTE - The flake in the middle (which is multiple feet wide at the bottom) narrows as you go up. In Aug 2020 the last 3-4 feet of the flake had cracked and detached, leaving an enormous block ready to crush an unsuspecting climber/belayer. I trundled it along with any other loose blocks in the crack in the crack I could reach (Don't trust flakes in the back). With the top of the flake missing, the climb is now harder, and harder to protect, due to the tricky pod in the middle. A single bolt would solve this nicely.
routes.location: One of the earlier climbs that you pass walking in.
routes.protection: Single rack to #6. Two 6's would be handy if you want to place one near the beginning.

routes.description: A splitter hand and fist corner crack with a few face features, enabling the climber to perform stemming maneuvers while scaling.
routes.location: single rack to 5"

routes.description: Long right leaning offwidth.
routes.location: About 50yds right of Shapeshifter. Left of The Crosmonaut

routes.description: This line is characterized by the stunning second pitch dihedral which breaks out above the thick forest canopy providing stunning views clear from Garibaldi Park to Howe Sound.Pitch 1. 5.10b, 20m. starts up a grungy thin crack on slab to access the righthand of two left diagonalling  crack/corners, enjoyable steep handjamming to a traverse right to belay ledge at the base of the dihedral. This pitch is unfortunately slow to dry.Pitch 2 5.11d, 20m. The initial vertical corner provides an immediate crux lasting for several body lengths in spaced out tips to second knuckles layback. A brief respite in the middle leads excellent, technical 5.11- stemming up the micro nut corner.
routes.location: Same start and then immediately right of "Cedar Strips" which is listed in 4th edition Squamish Select Book.
routes.protection: Doubles of .1 - 2 BD, 1 x 3 BD. Small nuts or offsets with a few tiny.

routes.description: Climb the corner crack until its possible to pull out right onto the face and up the finger crack
routes.location: double rack to 3"

routes.description: A steep hand crack with a wide alcove in the middle that is awkward to navigate.
routes.location: On the far upper right side of the crag, starts beside a large detached block sitting at the base.

routes.fa: FA Hazel Findlay, 2012; FA (var) M. Leclerc, 2012.
routes.description: Right leaning wide crack
routes.location: Right of Shapeshifter

routes.description: A steep diagonal crack with a wide kink at the beginning and awesome tight hands up top.
routes.location: Doubles or triples, something wide for the beginning.

routes.description: This route climbs the awesome shallow corner to the right of the offwidth "Firewater". Hands to thin hands up the corner lead to two wider sections above (hard to see from below). Bring some wider cams for the top.
routes.location: double rack to 5", a 6" helps but isn't really required

routes.description: Tricky start leads to quality 5.8 jamming to the top of the cliff.
routes.location: This climb is on the far right side of 'Bannock Buttress'.

routes.description: Starting at the tall tree stump, climb the right traversing crack. Finish up the finger cracks.
routes.location: double rack to 4"

description: New sport crag in a beautiful forest setting just off Powerhouse Spring FSR. Developed by Tess and Jay Robinson in 2016/7. New / Helmet recommended. Please don't walk up to the top to set up TRs -- Loose debris at the top might be knocked onto unsuspecting climbers below. 60 meter rope should be good for everything.
getting_there: Turn down Powerhouse Spring FSR, off of Mamquam FSR. Head down hill and after road veers right you will see a wet land on your right side. Just past this you will see a large boulder 10m off road on your left, 0.6 km from Mamquam FSR. park here (this is the "classic rock" boulder field).   Head North through the boulders in the woods, trail meanders through the classic rock boulders. The last boulder will be on your right (classic slab) and trail will continue left, winding up hill. Once at top of the hill, the trail leads along side a very large boulder. Parkland will come into view through the trees. 10 min approach.

routes.description: Having a tall stature or huge reach is crucial for this route to go. Short people may need to dino/smear to the odd crimp. The face is pretty blank.
routes.location: bolts

routes.description: Difficult start leads to easier ground, making way up and over ramps
routes.location: bolts
routes.route_name: Best Things in Life are Tree, The

routes.description: Crux start in featured corner, making your way up broken juggy arete right to a giant ledge. A little vertigo inducing.
routes.location: Start off far left edge on top of a boulder

routes.description: Start left of crumbling stump on ledge, then head left of a bulge, and move onto the face. Fun route, takes some thought
routes.location: bolts

routes.description: Start in stepped rock leading to a crack. Crux is mid way, where crack widens. Fun but awkward route.
routes.location: bolts

routes.description: Start in lay back moves into slots, then make your way up the center of an open book feature. Trickier then it looks, great route. You can finish straight up or alternatively move into Pages Edge
routes.location: bolts. Shared last bolt and anchor with Pages Edge

routes.description: Clip first bolt then pull lip onto easier ground.
routes.location: Start far left on jugs off of the boulder

routes.description: Start right, then make your way towards the right arete, pull a fun bulge and hug the arete to the top. awesome climb!
routes.location: All the way on the right
routes.protection: bolts. Shared last bolt and anchor with "No Walk in the Park".

routes.description: Start right of crumbled tree stump, climb fun jugs, then venture off easy ramp onto slabbier face.
routes.location: bolts

routes.description: Start in corner, then head up to a large ledge, and then proceed with difficulty through corner of roof. Difficulty eases off to a slab/mantle finish
routes.location: bolts

routes.description: Start above a crumbly tree stump, climb through difficult/reachy start (crux), continue up easier ground towards next bulge futher up. Very enjoyable climbing,
routes.location: bolts. recommend stick clip as stump is not trust worthy and crux is down low.

routes.description: The start is the same for Walk in the Park, but head left at broken arch. Follow the arch onto the ledge where you will find the shared anchor for Piece of Cake. (This is a great way to set up TR for Piece of Cake or Whine and Cheese)
routes.location: bolts

routes.description: Start off boulder on jugs. Clip bolt and pull powerful 5.9 move onto easy terrain.
routes.location: bolts

routes.description: Start is the for same as Peaceful stroll. Clip 4th bolt of that route, then head right.
routes.location: bolts

routes.description: Start in the broken face and head up to the ledge. Go left around corner for a hidden jug and no feet after clipping second bolt(crux). (Not moving left will increase grade) Follow broken ramp traversing right for a finish above the blank face.
routes.location: bolts

routes.description: Fun climbing leads to the big roof, but you will have to work for it. You can lower down to set up TR from anchor of 'Piece of Cake" and "Slice of Cake Walk"
routes.location: Roof all the way on the left

description: Recently developed crag with mostly beginner or moderate sport routes. Helmets are advised as this area is still relatively new.    Many thanks to Tess Egan, Jason Robinson and Kye Egan-Robinson for developing this area. They built it out with families in mind and the bottom of has been well cleared. Please do not cut down any more trees. They provide excellent shade in the heat of summer. Avoid hiking around to the top of the crag to set up top-ropes since the easy routes on the far let provide safe, quick access to the top. Finally, we ask that guides not use this crag for large groups since it would make it impossible for anyone else to climb.
getting_there: From 99, Turn onto Mamquam FSR east. Follow this for about two miles and turn left onto Powerhouse Springs FSR (unnamed on google maps). Less than one mile down the road you should come to a large boulder on the right. Go another 50 meters and the white crag is on your left. About a minute later you will be picking out a route.

routes.description: A tricky start through small incuts leads to a juggy rail. After clipping the fifth bolt, head left and follow a ramp to the top. Fun!
routes.location: bolts

routes.description: Enjoyable climbing up the low-angle roof. Stay left of the small roof.
routes.location: Several feet right of the top rope section.

routes.description: Shared start with "Lost and Found". After a few feet up, head right, towards the gully and follow nice features to the top.
routes.location: A few feet right of the first bolted line.

routes.description: Light warmup and great access for setting up top ropes.
routes.location: First sport line on the left

routes.description: Low-angled and well-featured top rope right on the left end of the wall.
routes.location: Far left side of the wall.

routes.description: Shared start with "Enough!" Head up and slightly left onto the slab to read the top.
routes.location: Just right of the first bolted line. Small indent in the wall

routes.description: Head up the ramp and pull directly over the roof (crux). Skipping the roof by going right brings it down to 5.9.
routes.location: Start below the little roof and head over it.

routes.description: Crux is at second bolt. Sustained climbing.
routes.location: fifth bolted line from the right. Around where the ground begins to slightly tilt uphill towards the right.

routes.description: Shorter face climb. Crimpy crux in the middle.
routes.location: All the way on the right.

routes.description: Fun climbing with a crimpy crux below the third bolt. Jugs at the top!
routes.location: fourth from the right. Where it starts to get a little more overhanging down low.

routes.description: Really fun juggy climbing. A little tough at the start but a jug haul up top, with lots of great rests.
routes.location: third from the right.

routes.description: Pull a roof, leading to fun jugs and ending in slab.
routes.location: steeper section getting towards the right of the wall
routes.route_name: Shits and Giggles in the Lake

routes.description: Hard start followed by easy ledges. Clip the bolt above the pointy ledge and mantel over.
routes.location: A little bit right of the small roof.

routes.description: Bouldery crux in the middle after some easy climbing.
routes.location: Second from the right, starts off a tree root.

description: Amazing wall lookers right of the Fluffy Kitten Wall, beautiful granite and shady most of the day.
getting_there: Take the Mamquam FSR and turn right on the Stawamus Indian Arm FSR for a while, you will be passing 2 bridges. It's about 10km from HWY 99. Park on the left after a main rock slide.The following parking location is very close to the trailhead (49.666343, -123.065648), you will se the wall slightly behind you from the road (better to have a high clearance all wheel drive).Hike down to the river, usually marked. Cross the river via a rope bridge then follow a steep trail for 30-40 mins you will arrive at the Fluffy Kitten wall, keep going on your right for 20 minutes and you will be reaching the Stawamus Headwall.

routes.fa: Colin Moorhead, Jamie Selda, Nick McNutt, and Nick Bejcar. September 2021.
routes.description: Beautiful 15-pitch climb on a shady wall.If you like long moderate multipitch with a bit of approach this wall is for you. There are 2 pitches a bit scruffy but the rest is endless climbing and jamming to the top of a beautiful alpine area.Link to the description of the developers: The Goldilocks ZoneI will recommend walk back up to the second gully to join the Robin's connector or the Habrich saddle and go down the climber's trail to the gondola and have a fresh pinacolada!!Rapping the route is a really bad idea, lot's of loose stuff for the teams below and a place you could get your rope stuck, and don't leave anything in the alpine in such a pristine place.
routes.location: The base of the route is above the top of a prominent fallen tree, cairn at the base of slab and lots of vegetation.
routes.protection: Double set of cams from .3 – #3 + single #4 (I was happy to carry it, placed it 2 times, you could do without it), nuts and lots of alpine draws.

routes.description: VC Express was put up ground up in day with no bolts. The knowledge of the cliff gained from this FA allowed us to piece together the line that would later become Goldilocks Zone. With a dangerous crux followed by a long and involved traverse there is little to recommend this route. I will enter for the record and to offer future explorers some insight to what has been done on this portion of the wall.  The first 4 pitches are pretty much the same as GL Zone. Following the line of weakness lead us up to left side of the arching overhangs that cap the lower wall. The crux involved high quality but dangerous climbing (feel free to add a bolt here) up a shallow corner followed by a long, tedious traverse under the massive arch feature. From here we climbed essentially what would become the finish Goldilocks Zone.
routes.location: See Goldilocks Zone. Detailed approach and descent info can be found here.
routes.protection: Double set of cams, nuts, bolt kit.

description: Top Shelf is a relatively new crag in the Squamish area that is stacked with high quality crack lines. The rock is bomber, the routes are clean, and the lines are aesthetic. My hat goes off to the folks who developed this area, as I'm sure it was no easy task to get this wall to the beautiful condition that it's in. The wall faces northwest and gets shade for most of the day. The base of the wall is very well maintained with logs and flat belay areas. Nearly all of the routes can be climbed with a 60 m rope (always tie knots!), most anchors have fixed draws on them for lowering (don't remove them!), and most folks will want a double set of cams from fingers to wide hands and a #4. It would not be out of the question to bring triples up to a #1 camalot, as many of the routes are so splitter! The only thing lacking at this wall are moderates. Most of the climbs are 5.10 and up, and the grades felt a bit harder than similarly graded climbs in the area. The wall is steeper than it appears, so the climbs tend to be pretty pumpy.There are quite a few projects on the wall. Please respect those as the route developer has put a lot of hard work in to the line.Additional info can be found at  squamishclimbingsource.word…
getting_there: The closest parking pull out to the trailhead is about 1.7 miles (2.7 km) along the Mamquam Forest Service road. Before you get to the pullout, you'll pass a black and yellow "2 up" road sign on the right.  Directly across from the sign, on the left side of the road, is a small pullout.  Consider this "pullout 1"  A little futher, there is a large pullout on the left with a no camping sign, "pullout 2."  And little further is another pullout on the left, "pullout 3."  The trail, which starts on the right side of the road, is between pullout 3 and pullout 4 (pullout 4 is a little further along the road).  As of June 2019, the trail was marked with orange flagging tape.  Using Gaia, the waypoint at the trailhead was 49.70334, -123.11871.Follow the trail into the forest. The trail is pretty well worn and easy to follow, but steep.  After roughly 15 minutes, you'll come to a cairned junction.  To the right is the New Dehli and Lantern Wall.  Stay left for Top Shelf.  After another 15 minutes or so, you'll come to another junction.  This junction is about 100 feet away from the base of a dirty, mossy cliff.  Go right at this junction, and after a couple minutes you'll you arrive at the well worn base area.  Eye Catcher is the obvious left-facing dihedral just to the left of where the trail meets the cliff.A fixed rope left of Eye Catcher leads to the left side of the wall.  Looking at the photos in McLane and Boyd's 2018 guidebook, it would be easy to mistake the second trail junction as the split between the left and right side of the walls, but this is not the case.Using Gaia, the waypoint at the base of Eye Catcher was 49.70085, -123.11427.

routes.description: Easy 5.9/10a corner crack climbing 3/4 of the way up, pull above a small flake to a spicy slab finish. 2 bolts at the top in the slab section.
routes.location: The corner behind a large thick flake, and left of the thin face wall (cursed crack and cursing all the way)
routes.protection: Mixed - 2 bolts at the top in the slab section

routes.description: The extension to Miasmic. Put your granite corner skills to the test. Get on it before - or after - the sun does!Climb Miasmic to the anchor. Belay here, or even better keep climbing for the full 30m experience. Clip a bolt, then abandon the sweet comfort of the belay ledge entering straight into a puzzling and tenuous corner crux. Don't be lulled by the friendly handcrack above - it's not over. Finish under the roof
routes.location: Extension to Miasmic.Miasmic starts with a right-facing handcrack with a chocked flake, into a right-facing corner ramp.Baby Beluga is a right-facing corner capped with a prominent rectangular roof.

routes.description: A short handcrack at the start leads to a mantle and another, steeper handcrack(crux). After this the route continues up a low angle hand and fist crack until it thins down again just before the chains.
routes.location: 1m to the right of David Hasselhoffwidth. Left of Shock Collars for Christmas.
routes.protection: SR with extras in hand - fist sizes. The upper section will eat as many 3s and 4s as you want to bring.

routes.description: An overlooked but quite obvious natural line, likely remaining unclimbed due to its proximity to the seldom climbed neighboring routes and confusion over where these routes went. It was quite pleasing to nab such an easy FA on this well travelled crag.Face climb past two bolts to the obvious left leaning handcrack which is part of the route Intractable Lassitude. Follow the crack left around the arete where it forms a strenuous hand traverse with bad feet, the crack turns to a vertical hand/fist splitter at the top of this a juggy traverse leads back right to to the anchor of Intractable Lassitude.Another burly Top Shelf 5.11!
routes.location: Located just left of the very popular Eye Catcher. The route starts immediately off of the rope pull that separates to two sectors of Top Shelf. It joins Intractable Lassitude for a tiny bit before breaking left.
routes.protection: Two bolts to start and then double set of cams from .4 -3 BD.Bolts and hardware provided by the Sea to Sky bolt fund, please support the bolt fund : https://www.seatoskyclimbing.ca/donate

routes.fa: Drew Marshall, Dee Anna, Nicole Deuchar, Oct 2017
routes.description: This is a wild climb with solid but sometimes tricky gear.It might be worth rappelling in to scope the gear (and maybe some of the moves!)You can access the top anchors by hiking straight down from Kitten Fists.P1 (11b, 25m)Start as for Maker's Mark, up a fingercrack toward a chimney on the left side of a huge pillar.Use extendable draws generously as you traverse across the front of the pillar, then climb up its right side.Once atop the pillar, clip a bolt and techily traverse a dyke, into a flake system out right. Try not to pump out climbing steep flakes to the big ledge (bolt anchor).Rumour has it that Nicole Deuchar boldly flashed the FA of this pitch before some softy added the boltP2 (12b, 15m)Climb steep finger cracks to the roof, then pull the roof at a seam with an unlikely sequence. Steep fingers and hands to the top!Descent: 2 raps with a 70 or walk off
routes.location: At the Bottom Shelf wall.On the way to Top Shelf, just before the trail meets a 30m wall, take the left fork toward Pilot's Lounge instead of going right toward Top Shelf. Walk about 50m until you can see a nice left-facing corner capped with a roof (Maker's Mark)Alternatively, hike straight down from Kitten Fists to a big mossy ledge to find the top anchors
routes.protection: Double camalots 0.2 to 1, Singles 2 to 4, nuts and RPs, 70m rope preferred

routes.description: Make your way through some awkward moves to gain the thin crack.  Take time to protect the first 15 feet.  Good locks and sporty moves up the steeper-than-it-appears crack get you to a jug and then a bit of a wide section.  Continue up and left in a wide hands, left facing corner.
routes.location: Immediately left of "Cursing All The Way"
routes.protection: Heavy on fingers and stoppers.  Save a #2 or #3 for the top.  Fixed anchors.

routes.description: Appropriately named, you won't find many good holds on this climb.  Follow scoops and sloping ledges up the wall, ending at an arete.  Well bolted, but harder, and pumpier than it looks.
routes.location: 100 feet to the right of Eye Catcher.

routes.description: Offwidth left of Meltdow
routes.location: The obvious offwidth/chimney slot

routes.description: The thin diagonal extension to Baby Beluga. Climb it as a full 40m pitch for best results.Climb Baby Beluga making generous use of extendable draws. Skip the bolted anchor and instead pull left around the roof and prepare for battle. Here reach deep into your quiver of granite wizardry and sneak past a baffling crux before it notices you. Keep it together for the pumpy finish!Cool, dry conditions are essential.Lower with an 80 (mega toprope) or twice with a 60.
routes.location: extension to Baby Beluga
routes.protection: doubles micro to 1.5", nuts, RPs, many extendable draws

routes.description: A more direct and striking version of Jason Greens original Demon Sweat.Demon Days starts on Shock Collars For Christmas (all previous known ascents started on Meltdown). Moving past the anchor of SCFC adds an exciting balancing crux (11+) traverse with a precarious high rock over into the start undercling where the original DS comes in from Meltdown. Climb the bulk of the Demon Sweat line, passing the crux (12+/13-) which entails powerful straight on, pressure laybacking off decent inverted incuts.  Where DS continues following the diagonal left to an anchor DD pulls out into the straight up headwall crack. The straightforward looking fingers to hands size crack throws out a slightly horrendous off fingers crux (12-) right below the top that could tragically thwart the send. Quite an epic pitch!
routes.location: Roughly a double set ranging from tiny cams up to #1BD. Plenty of small to medium nuts, offsets seem to work well. Some triples but which sizes will vary for different people. My specific redpoint rack included 4 .75 size, a 000c3, one #4 camalot. I didn't clip the Shock Collars anchor or the single protection bolt which i believe was designed for protecting the traverse off the SC anchor. Skipping the bolts feels kind of bold and would be spooky on an onsight. If you think you are going up for a working session or to set up a top rope bringing some tiny wires is helpful for aiding through and/or working the crux. 80m rope is perfect for lowering and top roping, otherwise possible to lower twice with a 60m or 70m.You can decrease the physical difficulty of the crux by running it out or decrease the mental difficulty by fiddling in a blind RP.Anchor bolts and hardware provided by the Sea to Sky bolt fund, please support the bolt fund : https://www.seatoskyclimbing.ca/donate

routes.description: The left-angling crack extension to Meltdown or Shock Collars.The crux section is either protected blindly or run out, but has a nice clean fall line.Follow the diagonal crack to the end or fork up at a vertical crack near the top - I'm not sure if the 'direct' finish has been done but it looks nice2 lower-offs or maybe one with an 80m rope
routes.location: Camalots - doubles 0.2 to 3, nuts and RPs, optional third set of tips/fingers

routes.description: Layback flake to a technical bolted arete (crux) and some nice cracks. Very sequency
routes.location: 5 bolts, gear micro to hands. Optional 4 for the bottom

routes.description: Stem, jam, and layback your way up the beautiful open book with two small roofs.  Starts out thin and gradually widens to thin hands at the top.  Good one for the small handed folks.  Might feel harder if you've got big mitts.
routes.location: Where the approach trail meets the wall.  It should, dare I say, catch your eye...
routes.protection: Fingers to #1 camalot.  The bottom part takes stoppers very well.  Go heavy on the 0.5, 0.75, and #1 camalots.

routes.description: Yet another must do pitch at the Shelf.This route is an extension to Hand Slotter. Although it could be nicely broken into two pitches the best way is to do it is in one 40m pitch, an 80m rope is optimal as it allows you to lower to the ground and set up a sweet mega top rope for all the homies.Several cruxy sequences lead past the anchor of HS. Charge into the overhanging finger crack, battle crux. Try not to get triggered by the presence of bolts beside the crack, instead focus your attention on whether you can pull off the onsight of this burly beauty.
routes.location: Double set of cams to #1 BD, 1x  #2, #3 BD, wires. The extension requires a couple of pieces + 4 draws for the bolts.

routes.description: What a pitch!  Start by climbing a left leaning ramp with 4 bolts.  From the last bolt, head up the finger crack on the face.  A short section of finger locks get you to a powerful move getting in to the pod.  Rest up in the pod and do some thuggy moves to get up and out.  Finish on the easier left facing, low angle corner.  The name made sense to me, hopefully it does for you, too.
routes.location: About 200 ft. to the right of Eye Catcher
routes.protection: Doubles from fingers - #2 camalot should be fine.  I placed one #3 before the finger crack.  Stoppers.  A 60 m rope JUST gets you down.  Tie knots!!

routes.description: 5.10 climbing out of the alcove leads to steep jams and locks lead to a cruxy face climb section, continue up into the shallow chimney (there is some crumbly rock here, watch where you put your pro) and figure out the final pull to the chains. There are rests, but the wall is steep expect to fight the pump.
routes.location: On the left side of the cliff, starting out of a small alcove.
routes.protection: Single rack blue alien to #2, doubles from green alien to #0.75. Fixed biners on top.

routes.description: A corner makes its way to a small roof, and some techy moves up and around it to the top.
routes.location: Lower Top Shelf - Treasury of Cracks area.

routes.description: Short, but quality.  Climb the large flake feature, which starts as fingers and brings you to a no-hands rest.  Rest up and finish with thin hands.  Pumpy!
routes.location: the furthest left side of the wall
routes.protection: fingers at the bottom and 0.75-1 camalot at the top.  A #2 can be placed halfway, but there are other options.  Most will want at least two each 0.75-1.

routes.description: Extension to Ludovico TechniqueAfter Ludovico's anchor, two bolts lead through an overhang to a crack by the areteThe crack zags left across the face into a wild crux sequence. If you can stick this you're rewarded with a nice handcrack to the topLong and excellent70m rope to leave a toprope for the droogs
routes.location: Doubles micro to hands

routes.description: Route is split into parts with the first part climbing cracks for 10ft to a mossy ledge. From the ledge climb up and left on laybacks and under clings (protected by two bolts) until able to access the crack above. The crux is busting out left as the crack peters out halfway up the wall.
routes.location: On the far right side of the crag. Look for a small moss covered ledge with a short crack section below it.
routes.protection: Bolt anchors with chains at the top

routes.description: This climb is super bad! I mean that in the way that Michael Jackson was Bad. Essentially a harder, and better version of the nearby "Meltdown". The route follows a twin crack system, but the right "crack" is more of just a flare and only usable in a few spots. Make a hard move off the ground and get some good locks and thin, flaring hand jams to a tough move off of a pinch to gain a sloping ledge. Move left on jugs and get a good rest below the thin crack. Place some high pieces and punch it through 20 feet of technical and insecure climbing. Fancy footwork is key to success here as the locks are not that great. Figure out the sequence that works for you and hit the "thank god" hand jam! Some pumpy, 5.9 jamming gets you to the anchors.    This felt quite a bit harder to me than Sentry Box, but that's just, like, you know, my opinion.
routes.location: to the left of Eye Catcher, at the top of the fixed line.
routes.protection: The gear I used in order was:   gold BD nut  silver BD nut (big one)  0.5 camalot  #1 camalot  #1 camalot  red DMM offset nut  blue DMM offset nut  red BD nut  blue BD nut (big one)  yellow metolius  #2 camalot  0.75 camalot

routes.fa: Jon Rigg, Danny Guestrin, Drew Marshall, June 2017
routes.description: P1 (10a, 20m)Climb a finger crack and/or chimney on the left side of a pillar, to a bolted anchor on a spacious belay ledgeP2 (11c, 25m)Climb double cracks up the corner, and an airy layback out the roof. Save a .75 for the lip (chain anchor)Descent: 2 rappels with a 60m, or walk up and off.
routes.location: At the Bottom Shelf wall.On the way to Top Shelf, just before the trail meets a 30m wall, take the left fork toward Pilot's Lounge instead of going right toward Top Shelf. Walk about 50m until you can see an attractive corner capped with a roof.

routes.description: Thin and technical sums it up.  Use twin cracks and the occasional face hold to make your way up.  The cracks have decent locks, but are also a bit flaring.  I was able to get several "finger lock + flared hand jams" and the occasional layback.  Focus on your footwork as you can get good feet in the pods and flares.  The climb broke down to having three hard sections (each harder than the last), separated by good, active rests.  Once you hit the arete, there's still some pumpy finger locks that get you to the chains.
routes.location: Just left of "Cursed Crack"
routes.protection: Mostly thin up to a 0.5 camalot.  Stoppers.  You can place a #1, but it will get in the way of the only real hand jam!  Fixed anchors.

routes.description: A left leaning cracked ramp. Lots of hollow sounding rocks so take care placing gear.
routes.location: To the right of the waving looking face that has a bolted route on it and 10ft flake at the bottom of the climb.

routes.description: Follow wide cracks to the roof.  Surmounting the roof is strange, and while I didn't find it to be the crux, I certainly thought it was the "what the hell do I do here?" crux.  I found that chimneying with my left side in was the key to success.  Be smart about your gear at the lip of the roof or the rope will either get stuck on it or suck it deep in to the crack!  Gain the offset, big fingers crack - the feet are thin here, so just keep cranking.  The last few moves pinch down to tight fingers, but there's finally some better feet out left.
routes.location: 75 feet left of "Made From Fire"
routes.protection: Hands to #4 camalot for the bottom and 0.3-0.5 camalots for the upper crack.  Heavy on the 0.5 camalot size.  Stoppers.  2 fixed pieces on the upper crack as of July 2015.

routes.description: The hands and fingers splitter to the left of Meltdown with lots of interesting and sustained climbing. A testpiece at the grade and one of the best 12a cracks around.   Two distinct cruxes and an additional "mounting pump" (ie: clipping the chains) crux as well.
routes.location: Double rack #0.3-#2.

routes.description: Start up the corner and make some moves up and right into the double crack system, using either the fingers on the left or hands/fists on the right to the top.
routes.location: Lower Top Shelf - Treasury of Cracks area. Just left of a big gnarly-blocky roof.

routes.description: Thin and bouldery crack climbing on the gently overhanging face. Foot features galore. Short and punchy.
routes.location: cams, nutters

description: "Valleycliffe Heights" (VCH) is another addition of Sport climbing to the crumpit woods area, located 20 min up hill from Powerhouse springs FSR
getting_there: Turn down Powerhouse Spring FSR off of Mamquam fsr, head down hill , after road veers right you will see a wet land on your right side, just pass this you will see a large boulder 10m off road on your left, 0.6 km from Mamquam FSR. park here (this is the "classic rock" boulder field)HEad North through the boulders in the woods, trail meanders through the classic rock boulders last boulder will be on your right (classic slab) and trail will continue left , winding up hill once at top of hill the trail leads along side a very large boulder, . Parkland Crag will come into view through the trees 15 min , hike to right past Parkland continuing up hill, trail will continue around the bottom of small cliff that is wet or waterfall most of the yr, trail will take you to far left end of cliff, cliff conitnues right going around massive fir tree(please protect) to all centre right routes.

routes.description: This a link up starting on the first 3 bolts of the Old and the Ugly and finishing on the last two bolts of Middle Age Madness. Bypasses the cruxes on both routes to produce a super juggy and steep 5.11 with great flow. Provides an excellent warm up for the harder routes in the cave.
routes.location: Starts up chossy ledges just to the right of Middle Age Madness.
routes.protection: 5 bolts with fixed chain draws and lower offs makes cleaning a cinch. Resist the temptation to clip fourth bolt of MAM as it will result poor flow.

routes.description: head up to pull little roof search for holds...what was once thought to be a possible good warm up turned out to not be. on the bouldery side. suprisingly sustained.
routes.location: Turn down Powerhouse Spring FSR off of Mamquam fsr, head down hill , after road veers right you will see a wet land on your right side, just pass this you will see a large boulder 10m off road on your left, 0.6 km from Mamquam FSR. park here (this is the "classic rock" boulder field)HEad North through the boulders in the woods, trail meanders through the classic rock boulders  last boulder will be on your right (classic slab) and trail will continue left ,   winding up hill  once at top of hill the trail leads along side a very large boulder, . Parkland Crag will come into view through the trees 15 min , hike to right past Parkland continuing up hill, trail will continue around the bottom of small cliff that is wet or waterfall most of the yr, trail will take you to far left end of cliff, cliff conitnues right going around massive fir tree(please protect) to all centre right routes.

routes.description: Start on arette, crips, jugs, a sloper and vertical...everything you could ask for
routes.location: bolt

routes.description: Not the best warm up but it will have to do. easier if you move around
routes.location: Turn down Powerhouse Spring FSR off of Mamquam fsr, head down hill , after road veers right you will see a wet land on your right side, just pass this you will see a large boulder 10m off road on your left, 0.6 km from Mamquam FSR. park here (this is the "classic rock" boulder field)HEad North through the boulders in the woods, trail meanders through the classic rock boulders  last boulder will be on your right (classic slab) and trail will continue left ,   winding up hill  once at top of hill the trail leads along side a very large boulder, . Parkland Crag will come into view through the trees 15 min , hike to right past Parkland continuing up hill, trail will continue around the bottom of small cliff that is wet or waterfall most of the yr, trail will take you to far left end of cliff, cliff conitnues right going around massive fir tree(please protect) to all centre right routes.

routes.description: The next set of routes start off the ledge,  trail passes around large fir tree to get to base  I wouldn't try to scramble up to ledge super choss nothing was cleaned off that.8"Danger" STICK CLIP FIRST BOLT  Start in corner off ledge, leading up fun holds , route steepins and holds get smaller before pulling a final roof
routes.location: Turn down Powerhouse Spring FSR off of Mamquam fsr, head down hill , after road veers right you will see a wet land on your right side, just pass this you will see a large boulder 10m off road on your left, 0.6 km from Mamquam FSR. park here (this is the "classic rock" boulder field)HEad North through the boulders in the woods, trail meanders through the classic rock boulders  last boulder will be on your right (classic slab) and trail will continue left ,   winding up hill  once at top of hill the trail leads along side a very large boulder, . routes.description: Steep and savage looking roof with another difficult boulder problem over the lip.Info provided by Tyler Southam
routes.location: Bolted line right of Elitpisst and starts on and moves out left of The Sheriff's Vadge.

routes.description: Start in broken stepped rock at base of roof, head right steeply towards orange colored rock and giant "rest horn". good holds till there then steep difficult crux, easier climbing once you pull roof.  Great fun overhanging route. Belayer has some good photo vantage points.

description: Mt. Habrich is a granite horn east of Squamish. Despite a fairly lengthy approach, some routes on Mt. Habrich are quite popular with with multiple parties not uncommon on summer weekends. The rock is well featured and generally very good quality, and the views are spectacular both on route and from the summit.
getting_there: Access has improved in 2014 with the opening of the Sea to Sky gondola.ApproachBegin by reaching the upper gondola station, via one of the following:1. Ride the gondola. Check their website for prices and times.2. Hike the Sea-to-Summit trail from the gondola base. This adds 900m of elevation gain to an otherwise long day.3. Drive to near the upper gondola station via a network of forest service roads. Begin by turning east from Highway 99 onto the Mamquam River road (this is the road by the Apron parking lot). After about 4 kilometres turn right onto the Stawamus-Indian FSR, and then right again onto the Shannon Creek FSR after an additional 1.5 kilometres. A gate blocks the road about 9 kilometres from Highway 99, and about 2 kilometres from the upper gondola station. Park here, and walk/mountain bike the rest of the way. Note that a 4WD high clearance vehicle is required, though barring this mountain bikes would certainly save some time.From the upper gondola station take the signed Sky Pilot Valley trail. This trail follows a graded road for about two kilometres, then leaves the road via a left turn onto an old spur road. This junction is obvious and is marked. A small clearing on the spur road is reached after about 50-60 minutes of hiking in total from the upper gondola station. Often there is a cairn and/or a fire pit here, and this was a common bivy location in years past before the opening of the gondola. Mt. Habrich is visible high above the clearing on the left. To this point, the approach has consisted of very easy hiking but that is all about to change. An obvious trail branches left from the clearing and climbs very steeply through the forest, gaining about 500 metres in elevation (to a col just below the west face of Mt. Habrich.From the upper gondola station, the time of the approach to the west col is about two hours.Two routes begin from this col. Mt. Habrich's regular route meanders up a series of ledge systems and is mainly 4th class with a few low fifth class moves. Just left of this is the relatively new route Escape Velocity which has become quite popular.Just below the col, a fairly obvious trail branches climber's right (east) and passes by a clean looking wall with several routes. The trail leads around an arête/buttress to reach the start of the popular route Life On Earth in about 5 minutes. The trail continues, passing the south face route (4th class), and it is possible to traverse the ridge all the way to Sky Pilot with some scrambling and fixed lines.Note that the west col of Mt. Habrich can also be reached by following the signed Al's Habrich Ridge trail. The latter part of the trail is more of a route and consists of scrambling up and down over many sub-summits along the ridge leading towards Mt. Habrich. As an adventurous hike, this is very enjoyable and makes for a nice loop when combined with the regular approach. Keep in mind that this route is much longer than the regular approach. It took us almost 5 hours to reach the west col of Mt. Habrich from the upper gondola station going this way.DescentThere are several possibilities.It is possible to down climb the regular route, which is equipped with some fixed lines and is fairly easy to follow. Keep in mind this gets steep near the bottom and has some 4th or low 5th class downclimbing there. Otherwise the route Escape Velocity can be rappelled with a single rope and is equipped with chain anchors. The quickest non-sketchy way to descend to the west col is likely a combination of these two - down climbing the regular route to the top of the second or third pitch of Escape Velocity, and then rappelling that route the rest of the way to the col.It is also possible to rappel Life On Earth with two ropes.

routes.description: Five pitches of high quality crack climbing. North facing and high up, a good option for avoiding the summer heat.1. 5.12b burly steep crack climbing. Start near the arete and trend right hand traversing the flake to reach the crack in the shallow left facing corner.2. 5.13- The tips splitter that you came for. Place good thin gear and punch it to the top.3. 5.12a Move the belay left and climb the left of two splitter hands roof cracks.4. 5.9R Easy but runout slab climbing to the base of the steep headwall.5. 5.12+ More sustained steep crack climbing, save some juice for the top!6. Continue up ~180m of rambling 5.7 to the summit of Habrich. Descend down the West face/Escape Velocity.
routes.location: From Polar Dome walk left along Toad Hall Ledge then make two thirty meter rappels from bolted stations to access the base. Or climb Life in Space if you're really psyched.
