routes.protection: Micro cams, small offset cams, small nuts, triple .3, .4 and .5, double .75 and 1, single 2 and 3.

routes.description: A great addition to the numerous ways of summiting Mt Habrich. Well bolted and equipped with nice shiny chain anchors and lower-offs on excellent stances and incredible views of Sky Pilot. A day of alpine luxury out the back of the gondola. Glorious.P1: Up the hands / fist cracks and flake. Easily linked with P2. 5.8 16mP2: Corner crack rising right up into a layback on a bolt. Awesome! 5.10a (5.9?) 25mP3: Trend up and right on slabby face past bolts. Easily linked with P4. 5.8 15mP3 var: Alternatively trend left on harder face and crack past several bolts. 5.10a 15mP4: Cruise up the bolted slab face. 5.6 17mP5: Face climb up past several bolts. Easily linked with P6. 5.9 19mP6: More engaging slabby face climbing past bolts. 5.9 19mP7: Guess what? It's more slabby face climbing! 5.8 20mP8: Rising traverse right to pull a mini-roof on good holds, up into a cruxy stem box. 5.10a 22mP9: Charge up the flaring crack with bolts and good gear in the back. Fun! Easily linked with P10. 5.9 (5.8?) 30mP10: Cruiser. 5.3 17mFollow your nose to the summit of Mt Habrich. DescentThere are numerous scramble routes with rappels back down to the climbers trail including the SE Ridge, NW face regular route and Escape Velocity. Rappelling the route can be recommended and is easily done with a single 60m rope. The rappels are fairly clean and the stations well protected, but watch out for other climbers, loose rock and snarled ropes. With a 70m rope, experience and an abundance of caution it's possible to link some of the rappels.
routes.location: Approach is via the Mt Habrich climbers trail, route starts to the right of Life on Earth
routes.protection: Lots of bolts. Single set of cams BD #0.3 - 3.  8 x alpine draws, 12-14 if linking pitches.

routes.description: A nice route to summit Mt Habrich. Great view at the top. Some walking on bush ledges in between pitches.For detailed description see:https://web.archive.org/web/20230327072945/ jeremyfrimer.com/uploads/2/… (original website is down). Or you can find it in the here on page three. (link from https://www.seatoskyclimbing.ca/route-database)
routes.location: Route is located on the N-W face of Mt Habrich. Follow trail to Habrich. At the fork on the base of Habrich go left to the N-W side.
routes.protection: SR to 3", some pitches have a few bolts. Fixed stations

routes.fa: Colin Moorhead and Nick McNutt, September 2022
routes.description: Amazing 27-pitch rock climb up the Northeast face of the mighty Mount Habrich.The route is an extension of The Goldilocks Zone, on the Stawamus River Headwall. It is the longest climb in the Sea To Sky Region, and is among the top five longest rock climbs in the Southern Coast Range.Although at a relatively moderate grade the route is by no means a gimme and not only requires good stamina but also being efficient at moving on alpine multi-pitch terrain. Most parties will take 2 days for a successful ascent (approach and descent included), so don't underestimate it and plan accordingly.Great pitch by pitch description from the developers: Life In Space
routes.location: Approach via the Mamquam FSR. Follow directions for the Stawamus River Headwall and The Goldilocks Zone specifically.
routes.protection: Double set of cams from .3 to #3 + a single #4, nuts, 12-14 draws (alpine draws very useful). All belays are fixed to the top of pitch 21.

routes.fa: Robin Barley, Nick Barley, Kevin McLane, 1994
routes.description: Life On Earth is a fantastic 5 pitch route that receives a a fair bit of traffic despite the long approach. The route is very clean with well featured rock, and has great exposure and amazing views along its entire length. The route has some crack climbing but mainly consists of lower angle face climbing on small holds. Cruxes are often protected by bolts, and though there are definitely some runouts in general the route is well protected.  All belays are fixed with bolts. Pitch lengths and grades described below are estimates. Feel free to send me a message if corrections are needed.  See the Mt. Habrich page for details on the approach.  P1: 40m, 5.10b. From around the right side of the arête, climb to the top of a pedestal. Clip a bolt, then move right into the left-facing corner. Climb the corner, wide at first, for several metres until a line of bolts lead left and up to the belay.Beta:  I placed a BD#4 in the corner to protect a short section of laybacking, but this was the only place I used it on the entire route.   A direct start to pitch 1 begins left of the regular route and climbs directly up the arête at 5.11c.P2: 45m, 5.10c. Climb up the left facing corner on somewhat grainy rock through a bulge (10a) for a few metres until reaching bolts on the left face that lead left and up to the belay. The crux is near the end of the pitch.  P3: 50m, 5.10c. A mix of easier cracks and bolted face climbing lead to a belay on the crest of the arête. The crux is near the end, and consists of stepping left from a groove/corner and climbing a face protected by a bolt. Beta:  When I first climbed this route I used half ropes with double rope technique. With this I was able to clip a high piton in the groove on the right as well as the bolt on the left face while still avoiding rope drag. With a single rope you have to use long slings and still manage rope drag, or skip a placement and run it out.   P4: 55m, 5.10c. Climb straight up the face. The first bolt is very high - look for nut placements. Step left of the arête into a groove, then back right to face climbing that leads to a belay on the right side of the arête.P5: 45m, 5.10b. Climb left and up to a short crack, then up and right on a lower angled bolt protected face.The summit of Mt. Habrich is a short scramble from here.  DescentRappel the route with two ropes, right back to the packs you left at the base (recommended).Alternatively, from the summit make six rappels, up to 30 metres in length, down the route Escape Velocity to reach the col on the west side of Mt. Habrich. The first rappel anchor is just below the summit. All anchors are fixed.Alternatively, from the summit downclimb the regular route, skiers left of Escape Velocity. As of July 2014 this was equipped with some fixed lines, though a rappel or two may be necessary as you get near the west col. At this point the regular route is very close to both the second and third pitches of Escape Velocity, and it would be easy to use the rappel anchors on that route if necessary.See the link below for a topo of Escape Velocity that also shows the regular route. Note that this topo describes the regular route as a "bush thrash", but it seemed quite reasonable to me.  jeremyfrimer.com/uploads/2/…
routes.location: I brought a rack from green Alien to BD#4 along with a set of nuts. I placed the 4 just once, and the 3 maybe twice. There are a lot of bolts, and so just a single rack of cams is sufficient. There are many places where nuts fit great and cams do not.Bring at least 10-12 draws, including some "alpine type" draws.Double ropes are needed to retreat or to rappel the route.

description: A collection of boulders in the forest to the west side of the Murrin Lake parking lot. This area extends from the Sugarloaf crag on the south end to the edge of the Missing Boulders on the north end.
getting_there: Access the problems via trails on the west side of the Murrin Lake parking lot.

routes.description: Climb the crack starting with both hands jammed at the low lip. The left boulder is on for footholds.
routes.location: Near Warp Spasm.

routes.description: Start seated using a positive right-facing sidepull on the right side of the boulder. Traverse left around the corner and top out on the overhang left face of the boulder via a juggy horn.
routes.location: At the northwest end of the Murrin Lake parking lot, there is a trail that will take you directly west. The boulder is 20 meters into the forest and will be immediately visible.

description: Mostly vertical, shady wall sandwiched between Woodstock and Quercus. Seems little-climbed, but there is an assortment of about twenty routes, mostly trad and mixed, that run from 5.8 to 5.12d. If you have climbed any of these, feel free to share the route info.
getting_there: The middle area of the long segmented wall that begins at the short moderate clip-ups at Woodstock and ends uphill at Quercus Cliff. Approach as for Woodstock and continue right, past Wavy Gravy and Waiting on Dylan.

routes.description: Start under the low bolt just right of The Royal Flush and move up on good jugs with sparse pro. Follow 3 more bolts up and then slightly left before traversing a horizontal crack into a short vertical crack to the shared anchor with The Royal Flush.Good, but might be scary for a 5.10a leader with the spare pro down low.
routes.location: Just right of The Royal Flush and the big tree.
routes.protection: A handful of pieces, I placed a 0.4 down low and a 0.5 at the top.

routes.description: Skirt a toilet-shaped depression on the right side of the alcove, and follow the bolt line, supplementing with gear. The movement is fun, technical, and balancey. Tiptoe up a series of horizontal cracks and small edges leading to a fun traverse and exciting finish. It's a little overgrown and would really benefit from some traffic. Get on it!
routes.location: Find a shallow alcove uphill, shortly after rounding the corner from Woodstock. On its right side, pick out the bolt line that ventures straight up towards horizontal cracks.
routes.protection: Standard rack to 1", extra finger-sized pieces (tricams work great). 7 bolts

routes.description: Start in a shallow, ledgy corner and continue onto the face above. Work through a sloppy crux and finish on a short crack protected by gear.
routes.location: One route left of the Royal Flush.

description: A quiet area with quick access from parking lot. Some old, obscure gems.
getting_there: Take next trail north of Milkman's Wall approach. First wall encountered is Beginners Luck/Punisher area, walking north is the short, bouldery Wabbit Handcuffs, The next wall above houses The Baldwin Roof, from here an exposed trail left take you to Cruisin for Grins.

routes.description: A short little gem at a grade that's hard to find on Squamish Granite. A good first lead or kids route.
routes.location: Traditionally protected, bolted anchor, can not be top roped.

routes.description: Climb Beginner's crack until you reach the first set of chains, then move up over the awkward finger crack and then right to an anchor above.
routes.location: Above Beginner's Luck
routes.protection: Single set of cams to #2 Black diamond.

routes.description: Direct bolted start leading up into the punisher roof crack, climbs a burly and technical left facing micro corner feature, some good moves and makes for a much more sustained Punisher.
routes.location: Scramble up right to first bolt, belay in the regular spot.

routes.description: Easy climbing up flakes leads to 3m roof crack. Powerful finger,locking and acrobatic foot moves. The crux is getting to the lip.
routes.location: Spitting distance from the parking lot. This line was probably long mistaken for the obscure Baldwin Roof which actually lies 5 minute north.

description: This small crag is on the right side of the loop trail as it works uphill beyond woodstock. There are three distinctively different climbs, all of high quality.
getting_there: Same approach to the main woodstock wall but just further west uphill on the hiker's trail.

routes.description: Moderate face climbing leads to a baffling crux getting into the massive pothole. This feature is unique but the movement is very awkward and powerful.
routes.location: route furthest to the left with an obvious bowl or pothole feature

routes.description: Scramble up to the ramp to start. Boulder with difficulty past the first bolt. Steep laybacking and jamming leads to the top. Ethics aside, this line is a ton of fun.
routes.location: The right-most route and bolted crack feature

routes.description: Start as for Big Scoop but move right through a short yet power bulge. Share holds with Big Scoop up top.
routes.location: The middle route on the wall

description: The Block and Tackle area offers some burly crack and roof work in contrast to much of Murrin Park (Nightmare rock excepted!). Block and Tackle (5.11b) is the classic.
getting_there: This crag is just to the left of the south side of Sugarloaf (so just head up the trail right of the outhouses from the parking lot).

routes.description: Fun climbing up 3 bolts on the steep face right of Partners, not Lesbians crack. Crux is move through and above the 3rd bolt.
routes.location: A couple of cams if you want to protect the walking down low and a finger cam for the last move past the 3rd bolt.

routes.description: Unrelenting for its first 40', this packs quite a pump.  Start w/ technical stemming, laybacking and jamming to reach a fixed pin.  Move to the right crack and up to a roof/flake, plug a good cam or two (3/4 Camalot) then make a couple of overhanging layback moves to reach the roof where you may be dismayed to find nothing approaching a rest.  Clip a pin, maybe plug a green Alien, and summon what ever is left in your arms to move right a move that wouldn't be bad in isolation but seems pretty tough after what preceded it to reach the first foothold since you left the ground.  The climbing relents from here but you may be too wasted to notice.
routes.location: About 5M right of Orphan at a thin crack that leads to a fixed pin.
routes.protection: You don't need a lot of pieces but you do need the right ones.  I remember red Camalot, small nut, fixed pin, #5 Rock, 3 Camalot, 4 Friend. FP, green Alien and #2 Camalot. to get through the difficulties.  I placed a piece or two higher up but don't remember what they were.  Use runners judiciously as the climb weaves around roofs.

routes.description: Interesting steep route up a series of broken cracks and flakes. More fun than it looks. You can go left at the top and sling a tree or go right and run it out.
routes.location: Tough to find without a book I'd think. On the right of Block and Tackle, starts at the right of the big roof containing the Block & Tackle route itself.
routes.protection: Natural protection, with ring anchors at the top.

routes.description: A fun but short route up the prominent Right-Facing corner, with a neat hand traverse crux.
routes.location: This route tackles the obvious corner just to the left of "Block and Tackle" and a stone's throw left of the Sugarloaf area. Climb up cracks to a stance beneath the roof, and hand traverse out to the left, before mantling up and back right to the chains.

routes.description: Same start as Holiday in Cambodia but continue up the vegetated groove until you get to the headwall, climb along a good layback crack left with plenty of feet into a fun hand crack up and on the right.
routes.location: The groove right of Holiday in Cambodia.

routes.description: A string of "Tricky" moves with decent rests between. Placing and trusting the fiddly, small gear was the real crux for me. The rock at the top was of poorer quality than most of the rock found in murrin.
routes.location: Left and around the corner from Orphan. The obvious groove when looking back to the right that leads to the visible anchor above, just to the right of a bolted line.
routes.protection: Got a 0.75 in the pocket down low as my first piece, but after that almost all small nuts.

description: A short and small crag that will nevertheless always be popular due to its convenient location and climbs that are aren't bad.  The top of the crag can be reached from either side, but the scramble on climber's left is the better choice.
getting_there: Once you're in the Murrin Park parking lot, this crag is the completely obvious wall ten meters from the west edge of the lot.

routes.description: A decent sport route with a crux getting past the first bolt, then some cool moves up the arete
routes.location: To reach this route, scramble up to the right of Black Butterfly

routes.description: The crack line on the far right.  Harder than its neighbour, Veils of Illusion.
routes.location: The anchor is directly above Veils of Illusion.  Walk off possible.

routes.description: While this climb could be led, and even has a bolt at the crux (but not at the time of the FA apparently), I've listed it as a TR for two reasons: it would be a very bold lead (if you avoided the better holds and placements on the adjacent route), and because it's an eliminate.  You have to work hard not to use the holds on Veils of Illusion.   Despite all of that, it's a fun workout on a TR and has some thin and delicate moves of a style found in many places in Squamish.
routes.location: The face immediately left of Veils of Illusion.
routes.protection: To lead it would require dicey thin wire placements, I would think.  The bolt at the crux would take a big load off your mind.  I'm speculating since I haven't, and don't plan to lead it.  The bolts at the top of Veils work for this climb too.

routes.description: Some good offwidth moves at the start, but before long face-holds start appearing that keep the grade low.
routes.location: Hard to miss. It's wide and on the left.
routes.protection: It's not a very long route. I placed one #5 that I bumped up a bit, then a big nut above the big ledge. You could probably fit a #6 in there.  There's no anchor, I made a gear anchor around the corner with two #3s and a big nut.

routes.description: Fun face climb with bouldery moves at the bottom.
routes.location: Left side of wall, right next to Up From the Bog.
routes.protection: Protection is sparse. Usually top roped. Small gear if you attempt it.

routes.description: This is the best climb on The Bog Wall and is surprisingly tricky and awkward for the grade.
routes.location: This is the obvious left crack.
routes.protection: Small to medium nuts and cams.  I placed a 4.5 camalot, but there are good alternatives.  Protects well, but the crack shape makes some of the nuts fiddly.   There are two bolts on a wall set back from the top of the climb.  They are very convenient, but the direction of pull is more outward than downward, which is a little disconcerting.  This climb does get top-roped very often off these anchors if that's any reassurance.

routes.description: Some people find this climb easier than than Up From the Bog (which was previously listed as 5.8 in Squamish Select, updated to 5.9 in the 2020 edition). Some people find it harder.Pulling up over the initial block is entertaining. After that, some easy laybacking on a flake that seems destined to come off some day takes you to good incut holds. A smear here and a jam there and you're done.
routes.location: This is the obvious right hand crack.
routes.protection: There are lots of options available so a "standard" rack should be entirely sufficient.  There is one stretch in the middle where the climbing is easier and the protection is harder.    As with Up From the Bog, there are bolts on a wall set back from the top.

description: A 35 m crag with a small collection of excellent routes, several of which share the same start. Known for the excellent Poltergiest (5.12a) and No More Tears (5.12c). Gets shade until 3pm in the summer (longer if you're on the 5.12a Poltergeist, which is protected from the sun by the dihedral).
getting_there: Park in the Murrin Park parking lot (which fills up quickly on weekends). Across from the highway from the lake is an obvious small crag right on the road called Excitable Boy. To the right (south) of Excitable, halfway between it and a telephone pole, is a trail that leads up to the Browning Bluffs crags. Poltergeist is the first crag you come to, probably 7-8 mins from the highway.

routes.description: Surprisingly good and tricky route that gains you access to the stellar climbing above. Move through bulges on good holds to reach the chains on a sit-down ledge.
routes.location: The obvious route in the middle of the Poltergeist wall, with bolt lines splitting off above it.

routes.fa: FA Mike Tschipper, Bruce MacDonald 1982. FFA Dean Hart, Harry Kettman 1992
routes.description: Climb The Crying Game (5.11a) and continue through to the bolted line to the left of the dihedral. Looks like a slab, but doesn't climb like it at all, with a few tough moves and pump being a factor for some people. The crux is moving away from the corner and coming back into it, but the dihedral up top can be very punchy, especially for the onsight.This route is a full 35 m, so bring a 70 m rope.
routes.location: Start on The Crying Game (5.11a)—the obvious route in the middle of the Poltergeist wall. Three lines split off from that route, and Poltergeist is the leftmost, just to the left of the obvious dihedral in the middle of the face.

description: This cliff is located just above the parking area on the north side of the parking lot. It has a few good routes and not much traffic.
getting_there: From the middle of the parking lot, walk a little north and look for a small trail and some logs covering a muddy spot. Follow this trail up and generally right to Brunser. About 2 minutes.

routes.description: The crux is after the mantel getting into the corner. Follow a thin crack in the corner laybacking and doing face moves till you gain the arete then climb the slab to the anchor. Needs cleaning.
routes.location: Past the lower angled slab the wall steepens and there is an obvious horizontal crack running along the base of the wall, the route begins where the crack stops and the slab begins.
routes.protection: 0.6"-1" cams and nuts, one bolt. Bolted anchor with short chains.

routes.fa: FA Tony Cousins and Jim Sinclair, 1963  FFA Dave Loeks and William Putnam, 1975
routes.description: Climb the amazing, funky, and very three-dimensional left-leaning overhang/flake/roof feature.  Put on your thinking cap for this one (and maybe a helmet since the back of the neck and shoulders could be helpful for bracing yourself against the roof).
routes.location: The obvious left-facing and left-leaning flake/corner/roof/overhang feature in the center of the Brunser Area.
routes.protection: Standard rack with bolts at the top.  You might want to set a directional to reduce rope drag over a sharp corner if you're planning on setting up a toprope.

routes.description: A fairly good route with a pretty hard start. Up above lies interesting, engaging, and well protected climbing. There is no anchor- use the fixed line to the right of the route to descend.    Start slightly above the base of the dihedral and boulder up to gain the crack. Follow this up and right through some overhangs and a chimney to a tree.
routes.location: At the upper Brunser cliff, there is an obvious dihedral system that ends at a large roof. Just to the right of this is a thin crack that leans to the right (and bottoms in the dihedral).

routes.description: A short boulder move protected by the first bolt gets you onto the slab above. From here delicately move up the well featured slab to the second bolt and then to the horizontal break with a tree. Don't forget to sling the tree before continuing on up the upper slab to the third bolt. This is the mental crux of the route and it is run out. A decent small nut placement is possible just past the tree on your way to the third bolt. Easy climbing from the third bolt to the anchors.   The run outs on this climb are a bit spooky but both the upper and lower portions of the slab are well endowed with many well defined edges. The hardest move on this climb is pulling up and onto the lower slab.   A variation of this climb, Sunny Girl, goes left from the tree to another bolt. It is equally as run out but the potential fall isn't as scary.
routes.location: On the big slab on the very left-hand side of Brunser, there are two routes that follow the same first two bolts before splitting. This is the route that splits to the right bolt on the upper face. The route that splits to the left bolt is Sunny Girl.
routes.protection: 3 bolts, a tree, and a small nut.   Rap anchor at the top.

routes.description: Some run out slab, fine foot placements for most of the route though.
routes.location: On the big slab on the left-hand side of Brunser there are two routes that follow the same first two bolts before splitting. This is the route that splits to the left bolt on the upper face. The right bolt is Sunny Boy, same grade but an intimidating drop if you blow it on your way to the third bolt.
routes.protection: Three bolts. They say in Squamish Select that this is a mixed route, but I didn't take any gear, I just threw a sling around a tree to prevent decking at the third clip.

routes.description: An easy traverse of the slab that sits above the Milkman area crag. Start off the ledge on the right side of Brunser area, and traverse until you hit the anchors for Tourist's Delight.
routes.location: Right side of Brunser area.
routes.protection: A handful of cams, there are runout sections.

routes.description: Technical thin crack that feels pretty desperate at times. Nice and sustained difficulty from midway to the anchors. The holds are never quite as big as you'd like and the gear's a little fiddly and spaced.
routes.location: This is the obvious line on the wall, you see it on your left as soon as the wall turns vertical. To the left of the Brunser Overhang, starts above a horizontal break.
routes.protection: Finger-sized gear, you could get a #2 up top but the business is blue Metolius to purple Camalots. Chains at the top.

description: New crag with info provided by Chris Small here:  quickdrawpublications.com/w…
getting_there: Please consult the Chris Small topo.

routes.description: quickdrawpublications.com/w…
routes.location: 5 bolts

routes.description: Begin climbing through a hueco-like feature to a  tricky technical finish. Go right at the last bolt for full value.
routes.location: Bolts

routes.description: From the Chris Small topo:A tribute to a friend, stellar climber and awesome human Marc-Andre Leclerc (1992-2018). Fun face climbing on either side of right arête.
routes.location: 9 bolts

routes.description: quickdrawpublications.com/w…
routes.location: 6 bolts

routes.description: quickdrawpublications.com/w…
routes.location: 6 bolts

routes.description: quickdrawpublications.com/w…
routes.location: 6 bolts

routes.description: quickdrawpublications.com/w…
routes.location: 8 bolts

routes.description: can use gear to protect the start
routes.location: anchor

routes.description: quickdrawpublications.com/w…
routes.location: gear to 2", doubles in fingers
routes.route_name: Taste of Nuts and Honey, The

routes.description: has 2 bolts on the slab area
routes.location: anchor

description: The Commonwealth is a popular, new traditional area which offers a very high density of high-quality moderate climbs ranging in length from 15-30m. The approach is short and well developed, protection tends to be plentiful, all anchors are bolted with chains, and the rock has been cleaned immaculately. The crag faces south-east and is heavily shaded, making it very pleasant on hot summer afternoons.More information and full topos are available at  quickdrawpublications.com/w…
getting_there: From the murrin parking lot, walk along the shore of the lake until you re-enter the forest. Keep an eye out for a large boulder on your left and a trail will appear on your right (same as for pet wall). Hike up, then down for about a minute and take the first obvious right (flagged with orange markers). Two more minutes and you're there.

routes.description: Climb up an easy wide crack, and end up in a chimney-like feature. Sweet and varied.
routes.location: just right of Fanfare for the Common Man

routes.description: Quite easy for the first half, maybe 5.4. Climb up a selection of cracks and features to a small alcove, pull a jug and then you're into the real climbing.    The thin seam at the top provides some thoughtful moments for the 5.9 leader. Gear is solid though, takes great nuts. The face is featured enough to keep the grade down.
routes.location: On the (climber's) left section of the crag. You'll probably notice two thin seams on the upper part of the crag. One is above two bolts (It's Not Easy Being Green), the other is to the left of that one. Climb under the one to the left.
routes.protection: Anything you want for the bottom section, small stuff (wires, cams as small as blue metolius...maybe you could place smaller if you wanted). Chains at the top.

routes.description: Leftmost crack on wall.  Shorter yet still has a short crux.
routes.location: left most route

routes.description: Start under a small roof with a very positive left jug above it. Lock off, pull up and start into the seam. The gear in the thin is thinner than it looks from the ground, I didn't find a place for anything as big as a yellow Metolius until higher up. Small wires, small cams.    Distinct crux mid-height as you're passing a horizontal break with your feet. It's steeper and the locks are pretty thin. Like the rest of the crag, there are lots of rests everywhere including  immediately before and after the crux.
routes.location: The only route that starts below the head-height roof on the lower part of the crag. The thin seam is fairly distinctive.
routes.protection: Small gear from purple Metolius/green C3 to #1 Camalot. Doubles in tips/fingers pieces. Chains at the top.   Takes good small gear. I fiddled with small wires my first time up this, but climbed it again last weekend and didn't waste my time with any nuts, took solid cams at comforting intervals.

routes.description: A fun route that tackles bouldery moves in a dihedral down low to cruisey fingers and hands with lots of good rests above. Decidedly not sustained. Protection is good but you can't place it whenever you want to. Starts on the right of a large rectangular bay ("pop-sickle" takes the left side).
routes.location: Protects well with small cams and nuts, plus a 1-2" cam or nut for the top. The crux takes small gear (I used a 0 mastercam). Bolts and chains up top.

routes.description: The crag's sole mixed route, start up a fun finger crack to the very restful alcove then move onto the face above. Pass two bolts on thin, cruxy moves, punch it through 20 more feet with decent, but spacey protection to a short and very fun horizontal crack to top out.
routes.location: look for the bolts. Below them is a big, square, alcove. Start at the base of the crack which leads to the left side of the alcove
routes.protection: standard rack to 3" (only one large placement at the top) and two bolts. The first bolt can be clipped from a comfortable position if you're tall, shorter climbers will need to move into more insecure terrain to reach it. There are few placements possible between the bolts and the upper horizontal crack and I didn't find them particularly confidence-inspiring.

routes.description: A fairly straight-forward climb with lots of small ledges and no-hands rests. An interesting mantle at before the anchors gives the route its grade.
routes.location: The route is just to the left of the roof at the beginning of Groovy Guru. Begin up a wider crack, then up broken cracks in a roughly vertical manner.
routes.protection: Protects well with a single rack and some nuts. Chain anchor.

routes.description: Start in the right facing corner next to Hungry, Hungry Hippos climb to the end of the crack system, move right on edges and than back again to crack/edges. Crux is at the thin crack at the top. The crux can be bypassed using Rick’s Root on the left (10a).
routes.location: Start in the right facing corner next to Hungry, Hungry Hippos in the large rectangular hole.

routes.description: Climb the crack system past a small tree stump and through the right side of a large square hole, finish on nice finger/hand crack.
routes.location: Located to the right of It’s Not Easy Being Green. Rappel or walk off

routes.description: An uninspiring squeeze-job between Groovy Guru and Smells Like Chicken. Shares an anchor with the latter and shares holds with both.   Start in a weird alcove, rise above and make some finger moves, you'll be done before you know it.
routes.location: Mostly finger-sized gear, standard rack will see you through. Chains at the top, but like most routes at the crag the chains are slightly offset to make it difficult to equalize an anchor with two draws.

routes.description: Starts with a friendly jug-haul through an unprotected dihedral for a few moves. Good hands, good feet. Then up a hand-fist crack for a few moves, again with good feet. Pull up and stand, then traverse right to the anchor.    The FAists called it 5.8, but I'm not sure where the 5.8 part is.
routes.location: Starts with a small ramp to a right-facing dihedral, just to the right of Tastes Like Chicken.
routes.protection: I placed two .75s and a #3 Camalot. I'm sure you could switch it up. Chains at the top.

routes.description: Like many of the routes in this area "tastes like chicken" follows a series of discontinuous cracks separated by restful ledges. Starts with a few cruxy moves into a wide hands crack, a quick rest, then a burly-looking offwidth for 15 feet (easier than it looks, the crack is highly featured). Finishes on perfect hands. Could be great preactice for wide technique if you ignore the features in the crack.
routes.location: on the far right side of the crag, look for the wide crack about 15 feet up.
routes.protection: gear .5-5" (a #4 camalot is perfectly adequate to protect the off-width if necessary).

routes.description: Climb the crack system between “Otto Mattock” and Ancient Squamish Secret. As the cracks end trend left and finish at the “Otto Mattock” anchor left of a large block.
routes.location: Located to the left of Ancient Squamish Secret. Rappel on chains or walk off.

description: Southeast-facing backside of Commonwealth Wall. All routes except Team Anders are fully bolted. There are numerous cracks and pockets that would take gear, however. It would be a good venue for testing the quality of your placements; bolts are often to be found right next to bomber cracks. It's a fun, accessible crag with a high concentration of moderate clip-ups, directly opposite from the steeper slab climbs on Valley of the Lost Tribes.
getting_there: Approach as for Commonwealth. Walk around the right side; it's the wall on the left side of the gully. Valley of the Lost Tribes is opposite.

routes.description: Steep corner to an arete, mid pitch crux above the corner.
routes.location: anchors
routes.route_name: A Little Help From Your Friends

routes.description: Climb up a short block past a single bolt to a leftward sloping ledge with three tightly spaced bolts above. Face climb past the 3 bolts using friction, thin edges, and small crimps (crux).  Above this the climbing eases and continues up the broken slab to the chains with rings at the top of the wall.A 70 meter rope will get you safely to the ground but a 60 would be stretching it. Use caution lowering. The guidebook lists this route as 32 meters.
routes.location: 13 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor with chains at the top.

routes.description: This is a slightly odd yet fun route with variety and an early crux. I thought it was the most fun route I did on the wall. It shares the ledge with Loki's Hiding and sports an anchor for the belayer. Per the guidebook's suggestion, stick clip the second bolt off that anchor to protect the first move or two off the ledge: the first bolt isn't that useful. After this awkward move to gain the slab, follow (bolted) hand and fist cracks right, continue through a section of slab and finish on nicely textured stone slightly higher than the anchor for Loki's. I had a lot of leftover rope after lowering with a 70; despite the listed length it seems possible to rap to the ledge with a 60. Knot your ends!
routes.location: Scramble the ledge below the start of Loki's Hiding. Kakwa is the bolt line to the right, identifiable by the rap anchor at its base.
routes.protection: 12 bolts. Bolted anchors w rap rings

routes.description: Start is a crux. Moving off the first bolt (that's not the one at the knee level) to the second bolt is the crux with the left side pull. In the middle of the wall is a technical crimp crux too.
routes.location: Right of Where's Maddie. Belay off of the belay ledge. Shares the ledge with "Where's Maddie".
routes.protection: 10 bolts. This is a 30m climb. Might want to bring a 70m rope.

routes.description: nice climbing, its all there, holds open up as you need them to.  Well protected for someone breaking into this grade.
routes.location: 11 bolts to a chain or ring anchor

routes.description: Scramble up a short slab to a right-leaning dirt ramp. Mantle past this into some cruxy, delicate climbing. Finish easier.
routes.location: Bolted line at the very top of the gully.
routes.protection: 12 draws. You might not want to clip every single bolt.

routes.description: stem or crack climb
routes.location: Lower end of the Commune area. The deep corner between What Crag and the 5.9 uphill.

routes.description: slightly harder than route to the left, but also very attainable for the leader breaking into the grade.
routes.location: 8 bolts to rings or chain anchor

routes.description: bouldery start
routes.location: rappel rings on top

routes.description: Guidebook suggests clipping the first bolt then starting down and left and traversing in. I didn't see any particularly good places to do that, so I just went direct. It was a little bouldery but a fun way to get going. The foot traverse at the end is fun, and there's a little sting in the tail. Get on it
routes.location: 9 bolts, anchor w rings

description: West to north-west facing crag, 20-30m tall. Mostly gear routes, but they're sporty in nature. Gear is generally thin and finicky for the routes above 5.9.Listed in Squamish Select book as "Down Among the Cedars"
getting_there: Go to Pet Wall and follow it South until the end of the crag. Continue walking South along a level trail for 5-10 minutes. The trail will turn left slightly, and then bank right and downhill. At this point you should be seeing a 10m high mossy cliff on your left (South) and broken rock to your right. Continue downhill until you can see a cleaned, West-facing granite cliff on your right. Follow a drainage up to the crag for another minute or so.

routes.description: N/A
routes.location: 3 bolts and SR

routes.description: Lots of climbing on this route, thin but with jugs popping up out of nowhere when you want them.   Begin up a series of horizontal cracks and flakes up to bolts protecting a left-facing techy corner feature. Cruxy, thin moves up the corner lead to a jug out right, followed by a desperate (but bolt-protected) mantle. Follow the flake to the left and up over the small roof (more jugs), two more bolts and a generous (but easy) runout to the anchors.
routes.location: To the right of the middle of the crag there's a slabby bolt line that begins after a series of horizontal cracks. Bolts continue up a small roof. Same start as Batteries Not Included (10+).
routes.protection: Gear to #1 Camalot, 5 bolts & chain anchors.

routes.description: Stem and jam up the arch, pulling on jugs. Climb up and left to a wider ramp. Follow this line up and right to a tricky few moves before a mantle, then clip them anchors.    Soft for the grade, but it's the grade given by the first ascensionist. A one-move-wonder 10- continuation is possible above by climbing past the anchor (1 bolt) to the Feed The Rat anchors.
routes.location: Left (North) section of the crag. Where the crag first starts turning from West to North-facing there are two wider cracks. This is the leftmost one that begins up a left facing arch into a right-facing corner.
routes.protection: Gear to a #3 Camalot is sufficient, but you could place a #4 or a #5 if you wanted. Takes nuts beautifully. Rap rings at the top.

routes.description: Clip the first bolt of Feeding the Rat (10+) and continue up the ramp to the right (thin gear). At the ledge midway you'll encounter a finger crack that breaks up and left. Follow this to a mantle. Climb up and right towards a crescent hand crack below the anchor, finding the hidden gear placement (yellow metolius/yellow C3) before you reach it. Jugs to the anchor.
routes.location: Middle of the crag, begins under a left-facing basalt flake, sharing a start with the bolted Feeding The Rat.
routes.protection: One bolt, small gear to a #2 Camalot. Chain anchors.

description: A shady crag in the forest. The rock is well-featured and steep.
getting_there: Less than 1 minute. From the Murrin Parking lot, find Bog Wall. Still in the parking lot, walk about 6 parking stalls to the right and walk up a trail for 50m to the base of the wall.

routes.description: Climbing up good edges leads to a hard mantel.
routes.location: The farthest right climb at the crag.

routes.description: steep finger crack crux at the beginning of the double cracks; well protected throughout
routes.location: left of Genesis

routes.fa: Hamish Mutch, Ian Kennedy, 1961. FFA Unknown
routes.description: crack and face climbing with some cool moves. The crux is a little spicy. Bring small gear.
routes.location: right side of the crag. Boulder start.
routes.protection: small gear (including small nuts and 0, 00 TCUs) and all the rest to 3"

routes.description: a steep, juggy haul up a corner then face above
routes.location: left of Geneside in a left-facing corner

routes.description: steep, well-featured climbing diagonally up and right the whole way. Several cruxes... with the one at the final bolt probably the hardest
routes.location: leftmost route on the crag

routes.description: The bolted line left of Cain and Abel. The crux is reachy and balancy around the third bolt. Cross through Original Thin to anchors on the left.
routes.location: Between Original Thin and Cain and Abel.

description: Like most of the crags at Murrin Park, Lakeside in the Woods faces east and gets filtered, morning sun. The climbing is an eclectic mix, with plenty of easy and moderate climbs and some hard trad test pieces.At the south end of the wall are some moderate sport climbs (5.7-10d). The middle of the wall has the hardest climbing, including some very bold climbs: The Gunslinger (13d trad) and The Bull (14a R trad). The north end includes The Reacharound, a fantastic moderate that is included in Marc Bourdon's Top 100 Squamish Climbs.Directly across from The Reacharound is the Common Wealth, which contains a number of mainly easier traditionaly protected climbs and is quite popular.Two recently developed (2013) nearby crags are Quercus Cliff, which is a few minutes walk along the Murrin Loop trail, and The Valley of the Lost Tribe which is around the right side of the Common Wealth.Details on these new crags are available at  quickdrawpublications.com/ . See the Free Downloads page.http://vimeo.com/42090546http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=B5mlA3YuMtY
getting_there: Take the trail around the right side of Browning Lake. After the picnic tables, take a good trail that branches right, signed as of 2014 as the Murrin Park loop trail. Stay right at a junction for the Common Wealth, Lakeside in the Woods, and Quercus. See the map for details.

routes.description: Low crux, to the first bolt and between the first two bolts. Requires a committing move, look for side pulls in the right. A stick clip is quite helpful as the fall zone is not great. Relatively easy climbing after the second bolt. The upper section is a dirty slab covered in moss
routes.location: Up the hill from Whinging Wife, belay spot in front of a large broken off boulder

routes.description: No text - use the 'Improve This Page' link to add something useful!
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: A committing and reachy start gives way to easier climbing above. Safe with good gear placement (a small nut at the top of the flake crack and a finger sized cam below) and a fast belayer.
routes.location: Right of the bolt line of Under the Eye of Newtown, shares the same anchor.
routes.protection: Standard rack with small nuts for the crux start.

routes.description: Crux is getting above the 4 th bolt. Technical Bear hug to a crimp.
routes.location: Right of Thumbelina.
routes.protection: 7 bolts. Route does not have a dedicated 2 bolt anchor. Clip the last bolt with ring and move over to Thumbelina Anchor.

routes.description: Climb the overhanging corner feature until it roofs out. Make a nest of gear and head right on thin edges and bad feet. About V11 from the corner to the rest and next gear (Red C3). From the rest fire another V5/6 boulder problem and head to the top. Falling early in the crux is ok if your gear holds. Falling late in the crux is not advised.
routes.location: About 100ft right of Masses are Asses.
routes.protection: Small nuts to Green C4. Red C3 for crux placement is the money.

routes.description: A fantastic route that's not in the book- definitely worth doing.    This route climbs the large, gaping, right leaning crack/feature on the left side of Lakeside (right of the gully). Climb straight up for 3 bolts, then ride the crack up and right for 5 more to the chains. Very fun, engaging, interesting climbing.
routes.location: Right of the gully at Lakeside.

routes.description: A burly one-move wonder.  Climb the bolt line directly up from the start of War Face.  Sink your hands into the juggy rail, clip the bolt and contemplate the distance to the next jugs. There's a healthy runout on easy climbing to the anchors but you'll be fine, or bring a medium sized cam to protect it in the crack to the right.
routes.location: Starts on the big left-trending ramp of Show me your War face, but goes straight up through bolts.
routes.protection: 5 bolts, maybe a 0.75 cam, chain anchor

routes.description: The left of two sibling slanted crack routes on great rock. An easy start and good pro leads you along a good angling crack to a mini-crux. Weave your way through the jumbled boulders to a sit down rest in the alcove. Clip the first of 2 bolts over the roof and make tenuous stand-up moves and burl over the lip. Reach for it and watch your shins!
routes.location: Just left of The Masses Are Asses
routes.protection: Cams from .5" - 1.5" (doubles from .6" - 1"), small/medium nuts, 2 bolts

routes.description: Great variation to Tiffany Cuff Links where you cut right into a horizontal finger crack as you pass the lowering midstation on that route. Climb up on good slab following the bolt line to the same anchor as Tiffany Cuff Links.
routes.location: Same start as Tiffany Cuff Links, diverges right above the midway anchor.

routes.description: This route shares a first bolt with Freeloader. Since there is not a tree anymore to chimney to the first bolt, there is an .11a move just to clip. It is precarious and a stick clip is recommended.    Thin face leads to a fun 10+ layback. Quality.
routes.location: Shares first bolt with  Freeloader. Between MTJAPF and Freeloader.    Anchor.

routes.description: Chimney up the tree (yet another Squamish tree start) to the first bolt. Work your way up past 2 more bolts and a couple small cam placements to the last bolt and the sweet polished rock. The last few moves might make you think...
routes.location: Directly in between More Than a Pretty Face and The Burglar, at the tree.
routes.protection: Bolts and 1-2 each size Aliens or TCU's etc in the .6" & .75" range protect tricky moves.

routes.description: Climb up the 5.12+ overhanging corner feature until it roofs out. Go left on underclings and bad feet to the headwall, plant some gear and gun it for the top. One of the biggest prizes in hard trad in town.
routes.location: 100 ft or so right of masses are asses.

routes.description: Stem and palm, basically a wide chimney.
routes.location: inside the gully between "A Bachelor's Life Memorial Arete" and "More Than Just a Pretty Face"

routes.description: Technical feet, big reaches, good jams and locks and even a crimper or two...it's got it all! Getting the pro just right is half the battle on this stupendous route. Like the book says, the hardest moves are low but if you don't finesse all the way, it'll shut you down! Boulder out the start and lean out to place gear. A few of the placements, especially at the start are hard to spot and a little finicky and some brands work better than others. If in doubt, bring crash pads and/ or toprope first. A stout lead, especially the onsight!   I disagree with what the new guidebook says about this and the route to the left...Switch the descriptions I'd say. This rig might feel more sustained.    Also, this climb and its neighbor to the left may feel hard for the grade OR perhaps many other 12's in the general vicinity are soft...    Pro: Most will be psyched on a double set of cams from .5" to .75" with 1 each to 1.25".    This route is in the middle of the wall and the right of two crack/seam lines.    Do it!
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: A good line to climb if you're at the wall, probably not worth hiking in for despite the 4 stars given to it in the book.    Technical climbing- a bit bold between the 2nd and 3rd bolts, but safe. Probably not a route to jump on if 5.10 is your limit.
routes.location: Start in the gully on the left side of the wall at a shallow, right facing dihedral.
routes.route_name: More Than Just A Pretty Face

routes.description: Follow a steep hand and fingers crack in a right facing corner to just below a chimney/roof. Make a traverse right along a crack then climb up into the chimney. Climb cracks on the wall that lead out of the chimney to the top of the wall. A fantastic route, and very atypical for Squamish.
routes.location: At the north end (right side) of Lakeside in the Woods.
routes.protection: The route takes a variety of gear from Metolius 2 (yellow) up to Black Diamond 4 or equivalent. Double up on  mid-size (BD 0.5 to 1).

routes.description: Climb the obvious easy left-trending ramp to the right of the Reacharound, aiming for the chimney, but then finish on the anchors to the right of Reacharound.
routes.location: The giant left-trending ramp just uphill from reacharound.

routes.description: Start on the triangular flake to the right of The Reacharound crack and work right to the top of the block, pas the chains for Under the Eye of Newton, past 2 bolts working left onto a slabby face with tricky and thin gear.
routes.location: Immediately right of The Reacharound
routes.protection: Standard rack, small gear for up top (green C3 and black totem both worked well)

routes.description: the left most bolted line on the face
routes.location: anchors at the top

routes.description: This route starts above the ground. Climb either Under the Eye of Newton, or the start of Show me your War face to the first reachable anchors.  Clip one bolt and continue up left through a blocky small corner.  A nice jam crack then leads you back right to the anchors.  The whole thing can be climbed with a single 60m rope with a bit of cleaning on the descent, but only if you lower to the start of War face. Tie knots in the end and be careful!
routes.location: gear, chains for anchors

routes.description: The short, juggy bolt line to the right of The Reacharound.  Can be linked with other pitches higher up if you bring gear.  Named after the rough skinned newt who supervised the establishment of this climb.

The entire climb trends to the right. A fun juggy start leads to a mellow roof and then the serious climbing begins. Good hand jams lead to a very wide flaring crack, which is the crux. Afterwards pull past the tree stump and up into the notch at the top of the cliff. Currently there are no anchors so make your own off a tree at the top. The climb can be walked off by going left and following the trail to the gully that has "In the Doghouse". This climb was cleaned in September 2023 but a stuck cam at the top indicated it's been climbed before.
routes.location: The start of this climb is to the right of The Burglar and left of Mister Picklebits. Look for a large flake where the cave feature starts
routes.protection: doubles up to #1 Camalot, small nuts and alpine draws to reduce rope drag over the roof.

routes.description: Slabby climb up an interesting undulating corner. Lots of slopers to use while smearing on rounded but mostly textured features. Top section has some moss to deal with
routes.location: Down the hill to the left of the main Lakeside Area on the right side of a slabby bowl.

routes.description: Climb out towards the cool (fragile) mini handlebar-hold on The Burglar, work your way through the thought provoking technical moves to a separate anchor above.
routes.location: Bolts
routes.protection: This is the line of bolts straight up from the middle of The Burglar.

description: Leviticus is a landmark crag in Squamish.  This crag is home to some of the hardest crack climbs anywhere (5.12c, 5.12d, 5.13c/d and 5.13c).   Perhaps just as impressive, you actually see people on them sometimes.   There was a great deal of concern that the expansion of the Sea to Sky highway would result in the blasting of this cliff, but it seems that this danger has passed.  Its proximity to the road is one of this crag's biggest detractions and with the road widening and traffic increasing, it's not going to get better.
getting_there: Once you're in the Murrin Park Parking lot, you will see Leviticus across the road and just to the south.

routes.description: Lake of Fire is a direct  start that adds difficulty, quality and a bit of runout into Sixty-nine. Start by climbing Leviticus and traverse right into the base of a flare with a sawed of tree stump.  Climb up into the flare where you can place your last pieces of gear before getting into Sixty-Nine. A Grey Alien and green Camalot work well. Climb up and right into a faint seam with crimps on either side. The last few moves before you can get any protection are runout so make sure you have a good belay (or dont let go). This takes you into the start of the hard climbing on Sixty-Nine.
routes.location: same as for sixty nine plus a single set of finger and hand size gear

routes.description: This great route starts on easy terrain, then pulls a bulge to gain the diagonal flake and good rest. Sustained thin climbing on the headwall leads to an easier slabby finish.
routes.location: In the center of the Leviticus wall. Accross the road from the parking lot.
routes.protection: Finger size cams, one hand size piece for the flake, and many thin-medium wires. Gear is good, but fairly spaced, potential for big falls on small gear.

description: A short little gem of a wall nestled on the upper tier of the Quercus Cliff.  This wall features 6 bolted enjoyable routes.  For 42 years, there was only one route established in 1982, "Lost in Obscurity".  Over the years, this route and area had been lost to time, to be written out of the guidebooks.  All climbs are technical featured slab between 5.8 - 5.10c.  Now with more routes to climb, this is a nice spot to visit.  Offers a small private cragging perch to hang out at, with great views of Howe Sound.  This cliff gets afternoon sun, and evening shade to watch the sunset.
getting_there: Two ways to approach the cliff.     From below.  Hike past the Pensioners Wall on the right of the cliff.  Approach a fixed line that leads up a steep corner.  Don't go up this corner, find a trail on the right heading east.  The short trail brings you to the base of the cliff.   From above.  Hike to the lookout bench directly above the Quercus Cliff.  Walk to the southern aspect of the cliff, facing Howe Sound to find Lost in Obscurity.  Lower in, or hike down and right to merge with the main trail to the base of the cliff.

routes.description: Climb through a tricky move off the ground, and take in a big breath for the top.  A spicy variation could top out right to the neighboring anchors.
routes.location: Leftmost climb at the cliff.

routes.description: Clip the first bolt at chest height, then climb up the airy arete.
routes.location: Rightmost climb at the cliff.

routes.description: Buttonhead bolted in 1982, the original line at the crag.  This line takes an obscure path through the sheet of slab to exit right.  The bolts have been updated 42 years later, but kept to the same character.  A tad spicy.
routes.location: Third line from the right at the cliff.

routes.description: Climb the obvious line through flakes, underclings and rails to the anchor.
routes.location: Second line from the left at the cliff.

routes.description: Climb the short flaring seam.  If only it was longer.
routes.location: Second line from the right at the cliff.

routes.description: The tallest line at the crag.  Climb directly up the arching slab on great features.  Watch for the Easter egg pocket.
routes.location: Third line from the left at the cliff.

description: This wall, part of the Sugarloaf, Brunser, and Xodus group of crags, only contains  six or seven routes, but they were  some of Squamish's 1980's testpieces.  One exception is the easier route The World's Toughest Milkman.
getting_there: Head west from the parking lot on a trail right of the obvious Bog Wall. Curve left around the Genesis wall and then up and right along the base of the Xodus wall.  The Milkman's Wall is really just the right hand side of the Xodus Wall.

routes.description: Follow bolts traversing right on large holds. Save some juice to power through the crux sequence pulling out to the vertical face from the overhang.
routes.location: Farthest right route on the lower wall.

routes.description: Short, powerful route with a reachy move 2/3 up.
routes.location: On the far, lower left side of Milkman Wall.

routes.description: Starts on the overhang under the arete. A few powerful moves and it's over.
routes.location: 4 bolts

routes.description: An excellent companion route to Horrors that offers arguably better face climbing.  This is a fairly serious lead and would be an incredible on-sight for someone with the sufficient mental and physical strength.    The climbing is typical Milkman wall stuff - slightly over-hanging with some long reaches between good holds.  Start with hard moves off the deck to a bolt at about 15' (don't fall getting to it).  From the bolt, some more steep crimping takes you slightly left to a jug with good feet.  This is the best rest and allows you to place good gear from a nice stance.  Move up and right through a tough overlap to the Horrors Cave and then back left to a decent rest and another opportunity for gear.  You probably want to double up on the pro at this point since this is all you get.  The next few moves getting established on the head wall are pumpy but all there.  Keep a cool head and continue up on small but positive crimps -  the climbing eases off as you get higher but the run-out will keep your attention
routes.location: The route starts just right of Mr. O'Clock (about 10' left of Horrors)
routes.protection: a single rack to 2" is plenty.

routes.description: Quality climbing on steep rock. Crux hits you at bolt 3.
routes.location: Directly to the right of Jugs not Drugs (5.8) and left of a dead tree on the ledge.
routes.protection: 3 quickdraws. The anchor is 2 bolts each with a segment of chain.

routes.description: Climb past two bolts to a small cave in the middle of the wall.  Move up right into a crack to finish.
routes.location: 2 bolts, standard rack.

routes.description: Follow huge jugs on flakes up to a more technical finish.
routes.location: Farthest left route.

routes.fa: Royal Robbins (I think)....not sure who got the FFA
routes.description: Yet another classic Milkman Wall route.  This climb takes the rising, rightward crack line starting at the layback feature at the bottom of Tourist Delight.  Climb easily up on juggy flakes, passing Mr. O'Clock until you merge into the crux of El Indio.  Follow the right trendign crack into the Horrors cave and finish as for that route.
routes.location: Starts immediately after the 3rd class scramble
routes.protection: Single rack from BD .3 to 2, with doubles of .4, .5, .75

routes.description: This route follows obvious right-facing flakes up to a stance at a shelf.  A small cam protects the pull over the bulge and into the shallow left-facing corner system, then a traverse left on cool jugs leads to a mantel and the chains.
routes.location: Directly above the flat rock on the left side of the Horrors of Ivan zone.  This is the second route left of HoI, identified by the right facing flakes at the start.
routes.protection: C3s, nuts or other small gear for the bottom and left-facing corner, and a bigger piece in the .5 camalot range to protect the finish.

routes.description: Starts with some fun layback moves.  Focus on good foot placement going up the corner, and look for a good hold up to the left near the anchor.
routes.location: Standard Rack (SR)

routes.description: A worthy linkup. Start by clipping the first bolt of "The Pass", then move up and left clipping a couple of bolts on the way into the "Horrors of Ivan" cave. Keep traversing left along the horizontal until you can move upwards, finishing on "Mr. O'clock".   PUMPY
routes.location: left of "... Milkman", starting on "The Pass"
routes.protection: 3 protection bolts, cams to 2", bolted anchor

routes.description: While considerably more overhanging than your average 5.8, a series of excellent flakes provide great holds and protection.  The final mantel on a great jug will make you smile.
routes.location: Some medium to large nuts and a single set of cams up to 3 inches should be fine.  A 3.5 camalot can be used at the finish if you want to sew it up.

routes.description: Start past a low bolt and climb up and past a fixed pin to your left. Climb past another bolt into the crux with a tiny crack that will take a Green C3, pull over the arete and up the slab.
routes.location: After the scramble to the Milkman area, right above the big half buried section of granite on the ledge.

description: In the trees off the North end of the parking lot
getting_there: Park at the Murrin Park lot and take the trail that heads north off the the north end of the parking lot.

routes.description: Start on the crimp rail in the middle of the boulder (standing the smaller boulder below) and then make a few slabby moves up the mossy face.
routes.location: On the Pasted boulder

routes.description: Start low with both hands on the obvious small ledge about one meter off the ground
routes.location: First group of boulders as you walk along the trail

routes.description: Start standing right of the tree matched on a thin undercling. Climb straight up to the horn on the lip, and up onto the slab to the left.
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Start with left hand on an arete fin and a right hand on a crimpy triangular horn.
routes.location: Just uphill and west of the Pasted boulder

routes.description: Sit start with left on a sharp undercling and right on a slopey sidepull/edge. Head up and right with some sharp crimps.
routes.location: One of the first few boulders in the Missing Boulders.

routes.description: Sit-start with right hand on a low pinch and left on a high edge on the face. Move up through flakes and traverse left on the rail below the lip, to a committing mantel top-out.
routes.location: Same boulder as Missing in Action V8

routes.description: Fun little problem on the small boulder connected to the Paste boulder. Can be a bit swampy on the ground, but sit start on great underclings into huge jugs.
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Sit start with a good incut left hand side pull and your right hand in a v-notch (pinch). Make your way up using a nice rail and a less nice rail before hitting a super sharp hold.
routes.location: From the Murrin Park Parking lot, head north passing Prime Time on the left for about 2 minutes.

routes.description: Start immediately right of Missing in Action, fully seated under the small roof. Begin with your right hand on the good pinch edge and your left hand on the edge just beside it. Finish as for Missing in Action. A bit crunched at the start for taller folks.
routes.location: Walk two minutes north from along the trail at the north end of the Lake Murrin parking lot. The boulder will be on your left.

routes.description: A fun problem starting on the arete with a left hand crimp, high foot and throw for the good edge and then up and over. Don't blow the finish or have a spotter.
routes.location: The backside of the first main boulder to the left of the trail as you come in from the parking lot.

routes.description: An awkward start involve palming the arete, with a small crimp sidepull and a slabby right foot smear. Push onto the foot and bad intermediate moves into a jug.
routes.location: Same arete as Pasted, starts with a foot in the scoop.

routes.description: Start on the jugs in the middle of face and boulder up and right
routes.location: Obivous overhanging boulder to the left as you walk up the trail

routes.description: Start low with an incut for your left hand and a shelf for your right. Really fun and powerful.
routes.location: sit start of Prime Time

routes.description: Start matched on the good sidepull and throw out left to the arete, then go for the lip. Awkward landing.
routes.location: High side of the Pasted boulder

routes.description: Sit start.  Good landing.  Start low on good arete jugs. Move left to a good edge and slap up right to the top.
routes.location: pass Shakeup and located on boulder at fork where you turn left for Prime Time

routes.description: The problem climbs a short arete.  It's easy from a standing start and tricky from a sitting start.
routes.location: to right of Catamite's Delight

routes.description: Start with left on vertical rail and right on obvious crystal, left foot on step. Stepping into the slab is above a slide so you get a thrill. Step up and reach for a small ledge then stretch or step to top.
routes.location: Right around corner from Head and Shoulders

routes.fa: Jeff Thomson, Jeff Hunt, Jack Fieldhouse, 2002
routes.description: Climb the tall slab from a standing start
routes.location: Trail facing slab directly right of Shakeup

description: An east facing cliff close to the road (somewhat noisy) that has a good selection of routes 5.10 and above.  Bonus:  many of the pitches will stay dry through the first phases of a Squamish rain siege.
getting_there: Nightmare is on the west side of the road, about 400 meters north of the Murrin parking lot; its large roofs are visible from the road.   Either park in the parking lot (and pay) or, at least during the current state of construction, the paved should directly in front of NR is wide to allow parking directly in front of the cliff.   A trail leaves the road near the south end of the cliff and takes less than five minutes.

routes.description: Sustained climbing up the arete
routes.location: Far right side of the wall. Walk along the ledge right of Claim Jumper to the far end of the wall. The belay is a bit sketchy.

routes.fa: Les McDonald (Free Solo up and down) c.1962
routes.description: The crux comes after the first bolt. It feels a bit exposed getting to this bolt but the arete is really grippy. After you clip the second bolt the climbing gets pretty cruisy so the run out to the anchor doesn't feel too bad. It's a great little route with some fun climbing.
routes.location: Arriving at the crag it's the route on the right of the huge flake leaning against the wall under the roof.
routes.protection: 2 bolts. Anchors at the top with drop in fixed biners for lowering off.

routes.fa: Jim Baldwin, Jim Sinclair, July 1962. FFA: Peter Croft, Tami Knight, 1981
routes.description: Same start as Grand Daddy Overhang on the 5.9 corner, but go straight out the roof, with a bolt at the lip (crux).  More fingercrack above.
routes.location: huge roof, and out right.

routes.description: A short route that is great for a rainy day.  I did this on a day when it was pouring rain, but never got wet.
routes.location: Located about the middle of the wall, in between a bunch of large boulders.  Climbs under the roof to a set of fixed anchors.

routes.description: Claim Jumper is another Nightmare classic, as are most of the routes there.    Claim Jumper starts just to the right of Perspective on at a steep slab with a couple of bolts. Ascend to just below a steep crack with a fixed pin. The crux is just after the pin, although getting to the pin is an ordeal in itself. Hope that the pin doesn't pull if you whip on it. After the crux, climb to the left into a thin crack that appears much more difficult than it is and ascend to the shared  anchors of Perspective.   There are a few ways to climb Claim Jumper. The new McLane guide gives this route .11d....and some of the old guides give it .12b. Depending on your height and how you do it, it could be either, therefore I'll suggest .12a.
routes.location: Just right of Perspective starting on the smooth, angular feature with two three obvious bolts.
routes.protection: Nothing bigger than Camalot #1. Heavy on small cams and stoppers. Draws for the start.

routes.description: Zig Zag crack direct start to Morpheus.
routes.location: Starts on a dirt landing right of the rock slab that goes to the top of Hypertension. Look for the left traversing crack

routes.description: Trend right up the easy diagonal crack, but back clean for rope drag. Then follow the the long right facing corner. No hands ledge up high and then power up the left facing corner. You can do a direct start up the bolted corner of It's a Potpourri.
routes.location: Scramble up the slab that is the top of Hypertension/Presto. Pull up the fixed line to gain the start.

routes.fa: Dick Culbert, Eric Lance: 1967  FFA : Peter Croft, Tami Knight   1979
routes.description: Start on the 5.9 ramp in the corner under the huge roof, then traverse left via tips underclings.  Anchors at the lip.
routes.location: under the huge roof.

routes.description: Fun mixed route that starts on the face between the grand daddy ramp and sentry box. Starts with a couple of boulder problems on bolts, then traverses left on underclings and finishes as for grand daddy ramp. It's not very long, but packs in quite a lot of good movement.
routes.location: Just look for the chalked-up line following bolts directly underneath the giant roof at nightmare.
routes.protection: 4 bolts, a small cam or two for the undercling (red or green c3), a few cams in the range from #0.5-#2 c4 for the finish. Sport Anchors.

routes.description: A beguiling, I-think-I-can-do-that offwidth that seems to prove most people wrong.   Start w/ 5.9 hands to fist.  Then a one move transitional pod, and finally about 12' of overhanging, leaning perfect 4.5 Camalot.  Ends with a couple of easy moves and chains.  If you have fat knees, this climb could be pretty tough, though at least they won't be bruised the next day.
routes.location: The obvious wide crack on the southernmost, lowest section of Nightmare Rock.  This is the first part of NM one encounters on the trail from the road.
routes.protection: Camalots: 1-#2, 2-#3, 1 or 2 #4, 1 #4.5.  A #5 C4 would probably work instead of the 4.5.  A #6 will not fit throughout most, if not all, of the crux.

routes.description: A long, technical line to the top of the Dream Wall section of Nightmare Rock. It links varied sections of climbing through 6 small roofs, ending in a 5 foot wide slot at the top. The two cruxes at the last two roofs have fixed quick draws, as the clips can be difficult. This route will not succumb to brute force. A technician's delicate problem solving skills are required!
routes.location: Begin in the corner between Morpheus and Who's Your Daddy? on a pointy boulder. After 10 feet, pull around the corner to the left, and follow the well bolted line to to very top.

routes.description: Hard stemming up the bolted corner, gain a ledge. Then look for a bolt on the left bulge, a boulder problem over the bulge and then take the crack up the edge of the arete. Great position.
routes.location: On top of Presto/Hypertension, look for the bolted corner

routes.description: Tricky face climbing up the blunt arete. A couple of small pieces fill the void of bolts. Crux pull through the small roof and weave up on wonderful edges.
routes.location: Behind the big rock at the top of the trail. Look for bolts up the blunt arete

routes.description: Begin on Who's Your Daddy. After a few metres of moderate crack climbing at the bottom (single #.5, .75, 1 cam), avoid the normal traverse out to the right on WYD, and climb straight up through the left side of the roof on some 11a moves. The route rejoins WHD for a few metres before the new mid-wall anchor on the left. For Paternity Test, continue past the mid wall anchor, through one powerful, and one deviously balancy crux to an anchor at the top of the wall. Route grade is up for discussion.
routes.location: .5, .75. 1 camalot for the bottom, 10 bolts, fixed carabiners on chain anchor.

routes.description: Perspective is yet another Nightmare classic. Start in a pumpy overhanging corner and climb through a physical, cruxy bulge above. Continue up to an adequate rest a few meters below the technical crux which is just below a small triangular roof in a little flaring corner. Sustained and aesthetic.It's possible to top-rope Claim Jumper from the shared anchors with Perspective. You can also reach the anchors of Sentry Box with an exposed traverse out left on a ledge system.In the past the FFA was attributed to later climbers but an eyewitness account shows that Les McDonald freed it c. 1964!!! Crazy!
routes.location: Nightmare rock is at Murrin park
routes.protection: Double cams from fingers to hands....one #3 camalot is useful. Stoppers

routes.description: Presto is the nice bolted line in the small corner just left of Hypertension on the far left side of Nightmare Rock. Easy climbing past three bolts gets you to a good jug rest. From the jug, sustained hard climbing past three more bolts gets you to the anchor. A fun route with cool moves and perfect rock. Climb careful in the beginning as the first bolt rather high up the route.
routes.location: six bolts

routes.fa: Jim Baldwin, Ed Cooper, Oct. 1960. FFA: Eric Weinstein, 1976. Direct: Peter Croft, Tami Knight, 1982
routes.description: The classic hard finger crack at Murrin.    Ascend a steep 10a crack on the face above some blocks and past an intermediate anchor. Traverse to a stance below a right leaning splitter finger crack on the headwall. A short, but thin and technical crux(12a) lies above. Fight on to the chains. Watch for the rope getting stuck in the crack to the left of the mid-height ledge.   Do "Sentry Box Direct" for, in my opinion, a better, more sustained version, but beware of the difficult gear placements. There is serious ground fall potential in the first 5m of this variation.
routes.location: Nightmare rock is at Murrin Park
routes.protection: singles to #2 Camalot,doubles of yellow and green aliens, stoppers.

routes.description: Further down the wall from Big Daddy's Ramp, this climbs a short south facing wall.  Start by stepping over a gap, and climb the nice crack in the middle of the face up to the roof and a rap station.  This also stays dry in the rain, I climbed it on a rainy day, but there is some water that seeps at the top.  Not an issue though.
routes.location: Work around the boulders to the right hand edge of the big roof.

routes.fa: J. Howe, P. Delaney, G. Ross '02
routes.description: A tricky and technical route, makes for a good warmup when coming to the cliff. Start in the obvious crack to the left of the large flake below the Grandaddy Overhang. Go up the crack, step right when obvious, then up past a bolt to the anchor of Grandaddy Overhang.
routes.location: Just left of the large flake below the massive overhang.
routes.protection: Pro to 3" ought to do it.

description: A slabby paradise hidden above Woodstock? If you aren't used to climbing slab or crack for that matter continue at your discretion. Dries fast and gets good views once you are at chains of climbs.
getting_there: Follow signs for Woodstock. As you pass Woodstock watch for a trail directly to your right and leads up the steep hill.

routes.description: Start in front of a pancake flake. Beware the spicy start before the first bolt - contrary to squamish select the start is not easy.
routes.location: 3rd route from the left

routes.description: Layback to a crack to a delicate finish.
routes.location: 4th route from the left of the right clif

routes.description: Left most line of the left cliff.
routes.location: Left most line on the left clif.

routes.description: Climb the crack then swing left onto the face. Good luck.
routes.location: First climb on the left of the right cliff. (Directly to the right of the tree stump)

routes.description: Finger crack on the east face of the right cliff side. Sharp...
routes.location: Lonely climb on the east side of the cliff.

routes.description: Finger crack.
routes.location: Second route from the left on the right cliff.

routes.description: Slab climbing to a crux at the top - beware the bulge.
routes.location: 4th climb from the left.

routes.description: This thin finger crack packs a punch. Highly technical and bouldery right from the ground until right near the anchor. Takes mostly small nuts/offset nuts with the occasional small finger sized cam placements.Harder than it looks and incredibly sharp - bring tape.
routes.location: From Pensioner's Wall, find a faint trail climber's right to the edge of a cliff, walk along it to the left and the wall comes into view. One of the best spots at Murrin for solitude and views.
routes.protection: Nuts and offset nuts. BD .2 to #1. Purple DMM offset RP useful to protect the move to the glory handjam but not necessary, if you're able to find anything else around.
routes.route_name: In the Eyes of a Frog

routes.description: Crack left of the arete.
routes.location: Crack left of the arete.

routes.description: Second climb from the left.
routes.location: Second climb from the left.

routes.description: Climb the blank slab to a strange bulge feature. Once your are above this, the climbing gets easier - not as easy as one may think.
routes.location: The middle route of the cliff.

routes.description: Use the stump to start. Positive holds lead to an awkward move at the top. Great views once at chains.
routes.location: Final line for this side - literally at the stump.

routes.description: Slabby face climbing leads up the arete. Don't use crack for 10d grade doing so makes this easier??
routes.location: The line on the obvious arete.

description: The Petrifying Wall feels unique in Squamish. It's a long crag of rope-stretching, dead vertical climbs on super compact fine textured granite. The climbs are mostly sport, but a few of Squamish's best trad lines are here. The sheer number of high quality hard sport climbs on this one crag is impressive: at least 6 at 5.13, 25 at 5.12, 21 at 5.11. Several newer 5.10s have been added to this cliff more recently to warm up on.
