The climbing style here - technical climbing on small edges with long reaches.The easiest climbs at Pet Wall are Heavy Petting Action and Cougar One Bite Brownie, both 10a, at the far western end of the cliff. Among the most popular Pet Walls climbs is Pleasant Pheasant at 5.10d. Burning Down the Couch at 5.11d is considered one of the best. Flingus Cling gets high marks as an introductory 5.12b and Flight of the Challenger is a trad testpiece at 5.12c and you might well see people on it.
getting_there: Walk along the trail around Browning Lake, past the picnic benches and past the trail leading up to Zoe.  There's a fairly obvious trail that heads west to the south of Zoe, goes over a little rise and the curves south.  You'll know when you've arrived.  It's about 15 minutes from the parking lot.

routes.description: Warm up, some fun jug pulling with some delicate moves mixed in. It's listed as a mixed route by Marc Bourdon and also the FAist because of an ~15 foot section after the last bolt that would accept great pro (.75-#2 Camalot) if you're sketched. I did it without and thought it was fine. The juggy flake at that point supplies huge hand holds and after a metre past the bolt feet start appearing too.    FAist called it 10a, and I do too. Not harder than Zoe.   Shares an anchor with Heavy Petting Action, so you can use that anchor for TR if you like.
routes.location: It's currently the (climber's) left-most route on the crag, though I saw a fixed rope fifteen metres down so maybe it won't be for long. Bolt-line directly left of Heavy Petting Action.

routes.description: Climb easily up a small left facing corner, which peters out after 5 meters or so.  Pull up onto the face and crank on small crimps through the blank section.  The broken rock at the bulge above will surely provide a rest.Think again...continue with 5 more meters of powerful climbing on slopey holds and sidepulls.  This culminates with an awesome mantle on a sloping ledge with no hand holds and a bulge above!  Clip the chains after the mantle.
routes.location: Starts up the small left facing dihedral 5 meters right of Pleasant Pheasant.  Finishes at chains approximately 2/3 height.
routes.protection: 8 draws or so should do it.

routes.fa: Brette Harrington, May 2018. Prep Chris Small
routes.description: Bouldery and sequential movement at start (stick clip recommended) leads to a bolt protected hand traverse. After the traverse, Climb a short crack to reach a alcove. Climb over alcove to end on the first two bolts of "Family Ties". Anchor is above the prominent right trending ramp traversing Pet Wall. Route is line B in photo below. The route name "An Audience with the Emperor" commemorates the late Marc Andre Leclerc's (1992 - 2018) reflections soloing the Emperor Face of Mount Robson.
routes.location: Right traversing line under large roof midway down Pet Wall. Anchor is just right of Large roof.
routes.protection: Gear to 0.75". 5 bolts. Chain anchor with lower off Lockers.

routes.description: Hard start off a big sidepull/pinch. Sustained.
routes.location: Behind the belay slab.

routes.fa: Kon Kraft, Jon Wurflinger  FFA Bruce Kay, Howie Richardson
routes.description: This route follows a corner system that runs the height of the crack, and requires a combination of laybacking, stemming, and jamming to surmount the blocky corners.
routes.location: Look for a large corner left of the DOA wall.
routes.protection: Cams, nuts, and some bolts higher up go to bolted anchors atop pitch one (which ends almost at the top of the crag).

routes.description: Black Water ascends the steep, black water-streaked wall to the right of the Pleasant Pheasant area. Climb up a ramp to the start of the hard climbing or direct at .12c. There are perhaps three distinct cruxes on Black Water. The route is thin, crimpy and sustained. A super classic and solid at the grade. Usually wet until July.
routes.location: Black Water is located at the bottom of the stairs, just to the right of  the Pleasant Pheasant area at Petrifying Wall.

routes.description: Of the many classics at the Pet, this one is among the most classic.  A long, dead-vertical line with cool moves, tricky sequences, and some good fall potential as the bolts get more and more spaced near the top.   A bolt station for the route to the left can be used to shorten the route, you'll still have to climb 11c, but you won't get the full experience.
routes.location: This is the second bolt line left of the break where the cliff base drops twenty feet.  Descend the stairs and take an immediate right and the little trail will put you almost in front of it.  Also the second bolt line left of The Flingus Cling.
routes.protection: At least ten bolts to a two bolt anchor.  A stick clip for the first bolt is recommended and a 60m rope is necessary.

routes.description: Climb a ramp and then boulder up left through a tough overlap. Surprisingly fun.
routes.location: 5 bolts

routes.description: Another awesome line at Pet Wall! Bolt line just left of Rocket. Cool, balancey boulder at the start into some classic crimping higher. Originally done into Off the Couch (12b, missing a hanger on one of the bolts as of May 2024), but you can also stay completely independent of Rocket and reach low and right to clip Rocket's anchors after you've manteled and traversed back right. Thanks Tom! This one rocks :)
routes.location: Immediately left of Rocket.
routes.protection: 4 bolts to Rocket anchors. Maybe 6 - 8 more for Off The Couch.

routes.description: Looking for a route to cut off 2 other climbs and piss everybody off? Not to mention murder whatever climbers on Elastic Man with a pendulum whip of doom? Look no further!
routes.location: Starts left of Pleasant Pheasant. Join that route for the middle section and, up high, traverse right through Air BC Direct to anchors on the smooth wall below the big ramp feature.

routes.fa: Kevin McLane, Dave Lane, Dean Hart, 1986. FFA Peter Croft, 1984
routes.description: DOA is one of the classic trad lines at Pet Wall. Located a few meters to the left of the Pleasant Pheasant area.Start up a balancey ramp, clip a bolt and angle up and right towards a steep left-facing corner. Small wires protect this corner well. Traverse directly right after the corner and then up and towards a pin...a bit run out until you reach this pin, but there's gear to be found....balance through this section and up to another rightward traverse on a big flake. Enter another shallow left-facing corner and climb this to the top.Double rope technique recommended, other wise put long-slings on every piece. Rope drag can make the upper section a nightmare.
routes.location: Look for the high first bolt with a right leaning diagonal above it

routes.description: Two routes left of Pleasant Pheasant, start about 8' below an obvious shelf, climb up through several bolts and sustained, intricate, and delicate climbing to the chains of Pleasant.    An extremely high first bolt guarded by cruxy moves makes this route a very bold lead, despite being very well protected after that bolt is clipped.
routes.location: Two routes left of Pleasant Pheasant.

routes.description: Steep climbing off the ground quickly leads to a blocky horn and small slab (bolted anchor).  From the left-facing-corner above the slab, follow cracks and a surprising number of face holds, passing one or two small overhangs. Step leftward ~25 feet before the top of the wall into a new crack which leads to the chains. This route requires a bit of every type of technique. The beautiful ocean view from the top is well-deserved. Although given only 2/5 stars in the Select Guide, this route is a classic. McClane gets it right in his book... "a tour-de-force of 5.10 climbing".
routes.location: At the far left end of the Pet Wall, a few small roofs and obvious clean cracks mark this route. It is also immediately left of the bolted "No Name Road".
routes.protection: Double set of cams, and a set of nuts. RPs or offset cams can be used.   With a 60m rope, you may need to use the slab anchor ~10m off the ground, in order to get back down. Definitely have your belayer tie into the rope if you're on a 60m.

routes.description: Climb a cracked and bulgy face up
routes.location: Left of Plumb line.

routes.description: One of the more classic trad routes in Squamish and not to be missed by those climbing at the grade. Very atypical for Squamish in its steepness.Seen from back a bit, The Challenger is the obvious rising crackline that begins down low in the overhang and rises up to the right into the crack/flare at the right-most end of the Pet Wall. Aesthetic and unmistakable.The Challenger can be broken into two distinct sections, first a steep, juggy section, reminiscent of a sport climb without any bolts. The second section requires a more technical approach in the shallow flare above the overhang. A couple more big moves near the top deliver a final sting in the tail.Start from a sharp boulder and pull onto the very steep wall on good sidepulls to a jug. Power through some big moves on jams and slopey rails to a big flake and a decent rest. Another big move from the flake gets you established below the lip on a jug. Transition into the crack above the lip on powerful, and sometimes painful, fingerlocks.The crux for many...continue up the shallow flare with a very thin seam in the back, an experiment in balance and footwork that eventually eases off into a hand/fist crack and another decent rest....but its not over yet. A couple more big moves from the top of the hand crack see you to the end.
routes.location: Far right end of Pet Wall.
routes.protection: Cams and Nuts....single set from #3 Camalot to .5 (possible to place #4 as well) and a selection of small cams. Small-Med Stoppers. 6 slings/draws. Fixed 'biners on the chains. Those not on-sighting are encouraged to scope the gear, which is not always obvious (in the overhang anyway).

routes.description: This is probably the most climbed 12 at the Pet Wall.  It's often called a good first 12b.  It's probably not a soft 12b, but it's one that can be worked more easily than others because it gets easier as the sequences are learned.   Two really solid cruxes are joined by sustained climbing and a slightly slopey finish make this a very fun outing.
routes.location: This is the leftmost climb on the upper tier of the Pet wall.  From the rock outcrop that overlooks the lower tier, scramble down to the stump against the base of the wall and step left off the stump to start.  Be careful, the first move is a bit balancey.

routes.description: At 11b, this is one of the easier climbs at the Pet, but it's solid and the first bolt is too high for most stick clips.  The crux comes between the first and second bolt, but the route stays sustained the whole way.  There's one spot where you could probably "cheat" by going a bit right, but staying on the line is rewarded by good climbing, and it doesn't change the overall grade.   This area of the Pet wall can get some welcome shade from trees while the rest of the wall roasts.
routes.location: This route is roughly in the middle of the upper tier of the Pet wall.  Its distinguishing feature is that it's the only climb in the vicinity that doesn't look like a 12.
routes.protection: Five bolts and a two bolt anchor.  A .75 camalot sized piece before the last bolt is nice but not absolutely necessary (definitely recommended if this grade is close to your limit).  As mentioned above, the first bolt is too high for most stick clip.  The climbing is probably 5.8 to the bolt, but you would be looking at an ankle breaking fall or worse if you blew it.

routes.description: Classic Milton sandbag, a few hard moves over the first overhang gaining a horizontal break at mid height. some balance moves get you set up on the wall above the break then its puzzling moves on very thin holds finishing on a jug mantle. This thing a totally sick but never gets climbed. Route video:
routes.location: Right of animal

routes.description: This route is an alternative, more direct finish to Dead on Arrival. Climb the ramp and the hard to protect dihedral of DOA.  Traverse right to the angle piton, and instead of continuing right, head straight up. A series of finger cracks and seams above offers great climbing with several cruxes. Pro up high can be finicky, but there is a glue in bolt backing you up. There is a bolt to your left up high that is part of Rampage, you will be about 5 feet away from it.
routes.location: Starts on DOA
routes.protection: Rack to #1 Camelot, heavy on small cams and nuts. There was a great 0/1 offset placement, but other options as well

routes.description: A romp through some interesting moves followed by no-hands rests. Very well protected.
routes.location: At the far end of Pet Wall, second bolt line from climber's left. Denoted by a dog tag on the first bolt with the name and grade.
routes.protection: 13 (!) bolts that supply plenty of rope drag by the time you get to the top. Skip some bolts or bring long (or alpine) draws. Bolted anchor, shared with A Cougar One Bit Brownie

routes.description: Climbs the near vertical on patina like micro edges. Eventually gaining a ledge then follow the right leaning water polished crack line.
routes.location: Starts just left of youth gone wild.
routes.protection: 6 bolts, gear from fingers to tight hands. +1 #5 or #4

routes.description: Very boulder. Merges into Animal about halfway up.
routes.location: First of four routes that start from the open slab with the ring bolt on top.

routes.description: Bolt Line midwall  ending at chains under mid wall big roof. Bouldery start with rough landing- Stick clipping first bolt recommended. It is Line A in photo below.
routes.location: Directly under Large roof in middle of Pet Wall.
routes.protection: 5 bolts, Anchor chains with Lower off locking biners.
routes.route_name: Lost Art of Keeping A Secret, The

routes.description: Good 5.12ish crimping leads to a good rest in the middle of the route. A hard to reach clip then into the crux which climbs the blank, slightly overhang section of rock and involves very small crimps strange body positions and movement. After the crux some more low 5.12 to the chains. This is another great route which is seldom done due to the puzzling moves and it having the wrong grade assigned to it.
routes.location: Between couch and rocket.

routes.description: Traverse left and head up sustained and technical climbing. Try not to fall, it might be big.
routes.location: Traverse left off a big stump on left side of Upper.

routes.description: No Name Road is an outstanding route with a bold feel to it due to some slightly runout sections and a high start with no pro.  Start up the route where Even Steven and several other routes begin and traverse an easy ramp (5.7 or 5.8) right till the ramp ends and a bolt can be clipped on the right face.  Continue straight up the face past a few more bolts and the crux to an intermediate rap anchor.  Climb past this anchor to a big roof and make some gymnastic moves to the top.  Clean the route down to the first anchor and then re-thread the rope to get down with one 60m.
routes.location: This route has the same start as Even Steven up an easy corner to a right angling ramp.
routes.protection: There are 9 or 10 bolts on this route and two anchors, one at the top and one for rapping back down with a 60m rope.

routes.description: Probably the most climbed route at the Pet, and while it's a good climb, its popularity is more due to it being the easiest bolted route and therefore the warm up for everything else.  Warm up or not, this is Pet Wall 10d, which mean vertical, pumpy, and not always obvious.
routes.location: It's in the lower (left) area of the Pet wall and starts by going up a ramp and then breaking out onto the face left before the ramp becomes a cave.

routes.description: While short, this is a nice climb to enjoy in this very civilized section of the wall.  There is a nice bench nearby, some trees that provide shade, and a flat and level base.   One very fingery crux defines this route at about mid-height.
routes.location: Roughly in the middle of the upper tier of the Pet wall, at the left edge of the distinct section that also contains Food Frenzy, right of a much blacker section of the wall.
routes.protection: Four or five bolts and a two bolt anchor.

routes.description: Start up the corner cracks (gear required). Continue the long right line to the top.
routes.location: gear and bolts

routes.description: Good climbing up polished rock. There is a variation using a bolt to the right before anchors.
routes.location: 4 bolts to anchors

routes.description: Cryptic face climbing leads to the roof out right. Anchor's just above the roof. The complete route goes past the anchor into a brutal crux which makes it 5.13b.
routes.location: On the blank looking face just left of The Lost Art.

routes.description: Same start as Grizzly but follow the left line of bolts through a small roof.
routes.location: bolts

routes.description: Technical masterpiece first half is 12+ with a beautiful sequence off the large flake to the fault. An awkward rest here can let you recover for a downright awesome crux on the headwall above positive and pumpy climbing get you to the chains. The hardest moves on this are easier then Force 10 but as a whole this route is more difficult in my opinion
routes.location: Left of second nature

routes.description: Route with some very fun and tricky moves at the beginning and end, sandwiching a few thoughtful moves in the middle. Start up the (bolted) finger crack and crank through some fun moves, then along easier ground left to a thought-provoking section mid-way. Delicate but easier moves up to a roof, shake at a no-hands rest. Pull into a horizontal crack up to some powerful roof moves with a small flake and a crack, then jugs to the anchor.
routes.location: Third bolt line from the far end of Pet Wall, noted by the crack at the beginning and the roof at the top.

routes.description: The right side of the upper tier of the Pet wall is overhanging and stacked with 12+ and harder routes.  This route, at the left of the edge of the overhanging section, is one of the few exceptions.  Several dynamic moves to start, and some heel hooking later make this a gymnastic and fun climb, and contrasts sharply with the majority of the other routes 12a and below at the Pet, which tend to be vertical edging affairs.
routes.location: Located at the left edge of the overhanging section of the upper tier of the Pet wall.  The climb starts with a little throw to an obvious edge.
routes.protection: Five bolts to a two bolt anchor.  Stick clipping the first bolt is recommended (you can clip the second one too...).

description: An absolutely smashing wall stacked with approximately 12 routes, some of which are extensions. The wall has it all...100% gear, mixed and fully bolted lines up to 13+. With only one singular 5.10 route, this is not an intermediate climber's wall, it caters to 5.12 and harder climbers. Quercus Cliff sits in an idyllic location perched up above Lakeside in the Woods, just off the new Loop Trail in a well cleared out nook.
getting_there: Follow the orange diamonds up the Loop Trail just before Lakeside in the Woods, passing The Commonwealth cliff. Hiking further past Quercus takes you to Up Among the Firs.

routes.description: Devious corner cruxes with intriguing moves and a tricky roof on perfect rock about sums it up! A must do! Start out with some techno stems and meander up to a weird section where if a certain hold were not to exist, we might have a heinous 5.13ish despo crux. Don't let the location of one bolt fool you...  The roof move is a thinker. Don't bash yer shins!
routes.location: Middle of cliff, leftmost left-facing corner with lots of bolts.
routes.protection: 9 bolts, 2 pins equalized with a tied runner (which needs to be replaced; a double-length runner will work)

routes.description: A bit of a strange one, start on the finger crack on the far left side of the Quercus and make some interesting moves onto a dirt ramp. Bushwack up the steep dirt ramp pulling on shrubbery to get to the midway anchor. Turning this into a two pitch route here is probably the smart thing to do for less change of decking past this point, otherwise clip the anchor and start climbing rock that doesn't see much traffic for 15 or so meters to the chains at the top.Interesting climbing above the ramp but weird getting to it.
routes.location: Leftmost side of Quercus
routes.protection: Standard rack, save some small pro for up high (green C3).

routes.description: The route's name is a cool mash-up of the FA's last names...   This is a fun, short exercise in laybacks and underclings. At the start, good gear will be had but you'll need to go up a bit to get it (be mindful of that big hollow sounding block you're putting pro in). As the line arcs left, obvious underclings with good footwork take you to the small ledge and the anchor. If you want more, there's a mixed gear/bolts extension to another anchor (Four Inches Radder, 5.11).
routes.location: The rightmost left-facing dihedral on the wall.
routes.protection: Gear to 2" but some people may want doubles around finger sizes...

routes.description: Good route with interesting variety, could use a bit more traffic to clean up. Follow cracks past a few ledges to a tree and a bolted arete. Make interesting technical slab moves up a few bolts.
routes.location: Left side of Quercus after the last sport line on the left.

routes.description: The first half of the Querculator (stop at the anchor halfway up the wall). Delicate, then burly.
routes.location: The leftmost bolt line at Quercus.

routes.description: Pull past a roof onto a right leaning crack leading to a stance below the polished face. Climb through the improbable looking bulge, and pull past horizontal cracks and edges to the top. Avoid the temptation to traverse right onto Prince of Thieves as it is an independent line. Similar in nature to The Oracle, just a bit harder. The gear on the upper face is a bit tricky but generally good.
routes.location: Left side of the wall, just left of A Prince Among Thieves. Independent anchor
routes.protection: Singles BD 00 to 4”, RPs, small/med stoppers, several runners.

routes.description: Sick technical near vertical face climbing. Starts off with some technical 11+ climbing then it’s full on technical foot work and tiny hand holds to gain bigger holds after the crux but a tricky section just after this could spit you off. Sonnie did the FA and graded it 5.13+, then Steve Townsend broke a hold at the crux which he says made it harder. Marc Bourbon later did the 3rd ascent and proposed 14a then the next year I did the 4th ascent and confirmed 14a. Video Here
routes.location: Right of vorpal

routes.description: This is a fantastic and devious all-gear line of discontinuous arching seams and edges. The route brilliantly pieces together with just enough pro to keep you off the deck (as soon as you get your first pieces, that is); luckily you can stand on your feet a lot to figure it out. The gear is not totally obvious at times and needs exact placement. It's all there for a compitent leader but even still, an onsight lead could potentially become "R or X" rated if you don't pro it just right. Great movement on interesting, less than vertical rock with a couple defined cruxes. There is a big run out section up high but on easier terrain. If in doubt, toprope first...
routes.location: Just right of A Prince Among Thieves
routes.protection: A set of cams from .4" to 2" including extra .6" to .1" (I found green to red Aliens to be a nice fit), small to medium nuts/offsets, some runners, attentive belayer

routes.description: A very fun line on great rock climbs halfway up Channeling Your Wheaties and with a long reach bust out right through the roof past a bolt. Clip a second bolt and using good footwork and body positioning brings you to a hold at a horizontal and sets you up for the engaging shallow crack section. Work your way up the seam, making sure you eye the proper spot to place the correct piece "just right", and up to another horizontal. Finish it off to the top of the sloping ledge and then the anchor.
routes.location: Same start as Channeling Your Wheaties
routes.protection: Gear up to 2" for starting the corner. Above there are 2 bolts and available placements for a small cam down to a medium offset brass nut. The book says SR but I took some doubles which I was happy to have.

routes.description: Apparently the name (with proper pronounciation) might be a spin-off of a classic Yosemite pitch on the Rostrum...   Interesting climbing past some cool polish takes you past 5 bolts to a shallow left facing corner where an optional small cam could be placed. Either clip the intermediate chains and call it a 5.10, or crank out a cruxy move clearing the overhang to some crimps and a tricky clip. (I believe this may have been an abandoned route from years ago and the bolts only were replaced?) From the ground, this upper part looks super run out but it's really not bad at all and the bolts protect the hard moves and in between it is way easier. Another optional cam may be placed before clipping the last bolt. Finish with some cool and funky moves up a shallow layback and then up to the anchor.
routes.location: Leftmost route on the cliff.
routes.protection: 7 protection bolts, intermediate and upper anchor.   Optional cams from .5" - .75"

routes.description: Techy off-vertical (slabby) crimps up a clean wall.Near the top, traverse a horizontal to reach a vertical crack out left, gaining the ledge.5-ish bolts
routes.location: Near the right end of the cliff, just right of a left-facing corner. Merges with a mixed route that climbs said corner and exits right on bolts (Overdose)

description: The Shaman is an often overlooked crag despite its relatively short approach and good quality climbing.  This might be because it's shady to the point of being dark (not a bad thing in the middle of the summer) and because its climbs are neither sport nor trad.  They are "adventure sport" or whatever you want to call routes that are bolted, but only every twenty or thirty feet.   Despite all of that, if you're climbing at Zoe, which only has a few routes, you're almost at The Shaman, so why not give it a look?
getting_there: From Zoe, head up and right for a few hundred feet.  The crag should be the obvious wall on the left.

routes.description: The first pitch of this climb has only three bolts.  Before the first bolt, a good nut is obvious, but after that, fiddling with gear probably isn't worth it.  Despite that, while the climbing requires thought, it feels reasonably secure and enjoyable.
routes.location: Starts in the middle of the crag where several routes start, near two large trees.  It heads up and left from there and then back right after the first bolt.
routes.protection: Quickdraws and medium sized stoppers for p1.  Not sure about p2 as we didn't do it (but I'll go back get the dirt on it).

description: The lower end of the Splitsville crag.
getting_there: Either follow the approach described in the Splitsville page and then walk down past the upper section of the crag to the bottom, or, while on the approach go left at the short mossy rock step to circle around the north side of the small bluff instead of walking over it like the main trail does. This will bring you to the bottom of the Splitsville crag.

routes.description: Start up the ramp. Seems to have alternate starts, both following the inside crack, or the outside crack at the front of the ramp wall. The outside crack seems more pleasant and easy though. Move up into a right facing corner with a seam to the right. Follow this up and left to the anchor.
routes.location: On the left side of the crag, look for the big ramp going up and left
routes.protection: Gear from 4-5" down to 0.1. Chains at the top

routes.description: Bolt protected face climbing leads to a high ledge, with a tricky few moves leading off of it up shallow discontinuous finger cracks.
routes.location: This wall has a large obvious dyke system high on it. This climb starts on the left edge of this wall, at the base of a ramp that goes up and left for a different climb.

routes.description: Climb up blocky corners to a nice ledge with a zig-zagging crack system and some large pockets. Climb up into the crack, and then out onto textured slab past a few bolts. The transition to the slab might give you pause, but is bolt protected.
routes.location: Starts in a corner at the base of a left trending ramp.
routes.protection: Basically only small cams, like doubles of Metolius 0-2 or BD .1-.3. + 3 bolts.

routes.description: Some easy climbing to a finger crack up a bulge.
routes.location: At the lowest wall of the crag, this route goes up the obvious finger crack.

routes.description: A few moves take you into an easy left-trending ramp, which brings you to the base of a vertical crack up a bulge. The crack climbs easier than it looks and with good gear.
routes.location: The left edge of the large lower fall that features the high dyke.
routes.route_name: Why Does it Hurt When I Pee?

description: This area is approximately 50 m south of Upper Splitsville across the Petgill Lake Trail. It is visible from Splitville and  has 11 routes on it. Location on map is correct.
getting_there: Approach as for Splitsville and when you see Upper Splitsville, More Splitsville will be on a separate crag to the right (2 min walk) and slightly uphill.

routes.description: The awesome overhanging left facing corner above A Night's Entertainment. Easier than it appears from the ground. Probably best to belay the second pitch from the provided anchor though as the crux is blind from the ground and additional rope stretch from more rope out could have a lifetime of repercussions to the leader.
routes.location: Gear to 4".

routes.description: This  first pitch of the 2 pitch route, A Night's Entertainment, A Lifetime of Repercussions is the obvious twin cracked left facing dihedral and is an excellent warm up for the pitch above or as a nice well protected moderate or beginner climb.
routes.location: Obvious left facing dihedral in center of More Splitsville.

routes.description: Bouldery start leading into classic hand jamming
routes.location: gear ro 2"

routes.description: Face climb right of arête to small overlap. Move right under the overlap to a left leaning finger crack. A lot of great climbing is packed into this route.
routes.location: Gear to 1"

routes.description: The Patron Saint of Relationship Dysfunction?. Climb the right crack of A Night’s Entertainment, past the cedar tree on the ledge. Step off the large boulder on the ledge; pull through an overhang into a right traversing thin crack.
routes.location: Gear to 3"

routes.description: A thin grasp on reality and marginal footings are the crux of this smear campaign. Technical!!!
routes.location: Starts on Blunt arete right of Smoke...

routes.description: Fun hand jam for beginners. Right now the crack is clean but a bit webby.
routes.location: Listed as the 9th route on Quickdraw Publication's topo.

routes.description: Initial pre scrub impressions were that a continuous splitter finger crack would form this route. But “hey, sometimes things don’t work out”. Climb finger crack through initial small overlap and continue up discontinous pods and finger cracks on slab above.
routes.location: Gear to 1"

routes.description: A committing start with some better jams above
routes.location: Gear to 2'

routes.description: The start looks simple enough….” Famous last words. The name refers to atmospheric conditions so poor as to conceal an incredibly bold 2020 act of sabotage.
routes.location: Tiered roof marks start

description: The far right of the crag (the higher end), off the left of the main trail.
getting_there: approach is listed in the Splitzville area (20-30 minute hike on the Petgill Lake trail)

routes.description: The Bum’s Rush: def. Forcible ejection from an establishment. Climb The Silent Treatment to a right trending seam (bolt) leading to a massive flake.   Trend along the flake’s left edge to the crack splitting the smooth cheeks of the bum like roof.  Forcible ejection is possible in a couple locations.
routes.location: Gear to 4". one bolt.

routes.description: Scramble up wide chimney and face to cedar then follow the obvious blocky groove to the squeeze chimney.  Often wet but that just makes it more fun.
routes.location: Wide Chimney just right of group of 5 very large Cedars is base of route
routes.protection: Gear to 4” with one very long sling. One bolt. Chains Anchor
routes.route_name: Closest Thing to Intimacy I am Going to Get, The

routes.description: Very high-quality technical face climbing following a small rock shoulder climbing on amazingly textured rock.  Starts in the large scoop at the base.  4 stars.
routes.location: Approximately midway along the base of the cliff is the distinctive large scoop defining the start of the route

routes.description: Linking The Cold Shoulder with the upper half of “The Silent Treatment” gives a long route with multiple thoughtful cruxes requiring numerous climbing styles and techniques. This route is a full-on rope stretcher rappel with a 70m rope.  2 Raps are required with a 60m.
routes.location: Large distinctive scoop feature at base of route midway along cliff.

routes.description: Full value climbing that requires 5.9 proficiency in many sizes and techniques, going from thin techy tips and face, to fingers, hands, a little OW, an optional squeeze, and some stemming and chimneying to round things out. Get on it!
routes.location: Starts at the top of a small dirt ramp in the middle of the crag. The progressively widening crack with a dead stump about halfway up.
routes.protection: Gear to 3", tiny cams for the start
routes.route_name: Do I Look Fat In This?

routes.description: Climb a right leaning finger/hand crack up into an alcove below a roof. Unlock a sequence that gives way to a beautiful dihedral above and left of the roof. Save a hand sized piece for this final push to the anchors.
routes.location: On the ledge with 2 belay anchors. Easier accessed from the right.
routes.protection: Standard rack, doubles from .5 to #2 useful.

routes.description: Head right through the roof, finish up hand crack above.
routes.location: SR to 3"

routes.description: Up an easier and slightly mossy crack to the base of the off-width. Clip a bolt out right, head out onto the face and into the right-leaning thin hands crack.
routes.location: You'll see a large 'A' shape on the wall. Start at the base of the right side of the A.
routes.protection: SR to 3", one bolt, chains at the top.

routes.description: Just to the right of Payback (10d), follow the left leaning ramp then up a right facing corner to a ledge on the left. Enter the crux with a shallow flaring hand crack and crimps. Work up the shallow flaring crack with creativity and balance. Be mindful of your gear as a fall here could put you on the big ledge below.
routes.location: Same start as Seven Habits (10c traverse), to the right of Payback (10d)
routes.protection: Standard Rack to 3", small cams and nuts (esp. black Totem and/or yellow DMM offset nut, YMMV)
routes.route_name: Lonely Adventures of Hand Solo, The

routes.description: up parallel cracks, two ways to get through the crux; layback or face climb further right. Good gear before and after the crux, poor to no gear mid-crux. Continue up finger to hand crack to finish.
routes.location: far end climbers right. Obvious parallel cracks, left of bolted line.

routes.description: Start up a crack and work over a bulge to the right, into a wide right facing crack.
routes.location: The wide right facing crack near the left side of the crag, but not completely at the end of the wall
routes.protection: Gear up 4-5", chains at the top

routes.description: also numbered route 22 on the topo. Twin crack system in the middle of the crag at the base of a couple of large trees. The route goes straight up but it's important to note there are 2 other variations: routes 24 and 25, both 5.8 that go up and right, or up and further right. There's also a 5.11- route that goes up next to this route and crosses over the other two variations.
routes.location: also numbered route 22 on the topo. Twin crack system in the middle of the crag at the base of a couple of large trees.

routes.description: Climb a right facing corner through a variety of styles. It starts tight hand crack, but changes in character after a mid-pitch ledge, and then again at the top.
routes.location: Near the right side of the crag is an obvious left-trending ramp where a few climbs start. Payback starts on the next crack left of that ramp.
routes.protection: Many people will appreciate a double rack on this from BD .3-3, and one .2, 4.

routes.description: The obvious diagonal crack going up and left across the face of Upper Splitsville. Pull a move off the ground to gain an easy ramp. Approach the bulge, sink your hands in, and move up and left across the face with good jams and gear. Pull through the bulge (crux) back onto another ramp and continue up and left to the chains of Smile... or continue straight up any of the variations. Burly hand jams! Fun!
routes.location: Start ~15ft to the right of Payback and continue up and left
routes.protection: Standard rack. Doubles in hand sizes.
routes.route_name: Seven Habits of Highly Annoying People

routes.description: The initial left facing easy corner leads into the highly esthetic, gently narrowing, left leaning twin crack system. 35 m Rope stretcher rap.
routes.location: Gear to 4". One bolt

routes.description: Left leaning crack (number 26 on the topo downloaded from quickdraw publications)
routes.location: A slightly left leaning crack toward the right side of the crag, the base is near a small step.
routes.route_name: Smile... And No One Will See How Broken You Are Inside

routes.description: A tricky corner (with some potentially uninspiring gear) leads to a small roof and then into a splitter hand crack. The route can seep a bit at the top of the first corner, and just below the chains, but it seems there are options to avoid the wet spots. This is a good climb with basically a perfect long hand crack guarded by the opening corner.
routes.location: Look for a large blocky roof at mid-height on the wall. This route starts up the corner that goes to the right edge of the roof. It starts on ground lower than the neighbouring climbs on the right.
routes.protection: A standard rack to BD #3, doubling up on 1s and 2s.
routes.route_name: Splitting Up is Hard to Do.

routes.description: Work a right leaning finger and hand crack for a few meters, then veer left and reach a beautiful but shallow hands splitter. The obvious crux awaits as the crack gets thin below the anchor.
routes.location: This climb along with Going Separate Ways start on the ledge which has belay anchors on it. It is easier accessed from the right.
routes.protection: Standard rack, doubles of 0.75 and #1 are helpful. Small nuts and offset nuts will make you happy.

routes.description: Follows Blunt Arete left of On the Down Low.
routes.location: See description

routes.description: This thing is a long, wide,  off width and definitely harder when conditions are wet, which is often the case as it often seeps.  The FA used a 9 " cam, though the route can be done with just a # 6 ca only.
routes.location: Start on bolted station just left of start of Stitch and Bitch base anchor.
routes.protection: Gear to 9". Can be done with a 6 only with proper spacing but the Valley Giant was certainly nice to have.

routes.description: Climb “One Thumb Up” to first small ledge. Stem across to the right diagonal traversing crack on Two out of Three. Hand traverse along this diagonal crack to an intersecting straight up finger /hand crack. Follow this to the anchor.
routes.location: Start on One Thumb up
routes.protection: Gear to #3 Camalot. Doubles in 0.5 to 2" range. Black totem or similar size protects beginning moves of traverse

routes.description: Nice mixed route, with a bouldery crux right at the beginning. The rest is a pleasant crack that is certainly below the grade. Favors taller climbers.
routes.location: Adjacent to the One Thumb Up, on the left. Shares the same anchor.

description: This very popular crag offers two different faces to the world.  A south side with six routes from 5.4 to 5.8, combined with access to the top and bolted anchors, guarantees that you will not be alone here if you can find  a free climb at all.  A great place to learn to climb or lead trad.  The north side has much harder and more interesting climbing.  Again, the access to the top ensures that there are often top-ropes on these although most are good leads.
getting_there: From the Murrin Park parking lot, head up the trail found a few car widths right of the outhouses.  After a few minutes of uphill forest you'll pop out into a clearing and the wall will be obvious on your right.

routes.description: Headpoint lead ascent of this old Dave Lane top rope. Great moves up a blunt arete on perfect Murrin granite.
routes.location: Between "Thriller Off the Void" and "Hotwire"
routes.protection: Used several 5-6 tiny brass nuts in the very incipient seam #0 and 1 RP's and a couple of the smallest metolius aid nuts. Placements are very specific and were rehearsed on rappel, an onsight attempt would probably be better off just ditching the rope altogether. A ground fall would be ugly with many tilted boulders, I used several crash pads just in case.

routes.description: Climb the Arete between Little Spark and Lieback Crack. Starts with bouldery moves then continues up the left face. Slightly mossy.
routes.location: Start at the rock on the ground at the tip of the arete between the Little Spark and Lieback Crack. To the right of the electrical tower, above.
routes.protection: Shares top rope anchors with Lieback Crack. Not easily protected with trad gear.

routes.description: I didn't really find there to be any crux in this 5.4 walk up. Nice fun place to come if you are just starting out to lead on Traditional Gear.
routes.location: This route is found by standing at the base of the wall around the corner from the sugurloaf north face, looking up at the hydro tower, Flat Battery is the second crack line from climbers left on that wall. You can walk off or be lowered back down.
routes.protection: Traditional Gear to a bolted anchor above

routes.description: Starts in the "hole" as for Hot Wire but immediately busts right by way of a tough boulder problem to a thin crack. The climbing above is fun and technical, with excellent movement on great rock. Eventually meanders right to join up with Stairway.
routes.location: On the north side of the sugarloaf, climber's right if hiking up from the parking lot. Look for the chalked-up basalt hueco. This route climbs up through the large, triangular alcove.
routes.protection: Small nuts and cams. A tiny nut and green C3 protect the boulder problem. Nothing larger than a  #0.5 camalot is needed. Gear is very good, but is often strenuous to place.

routes.description: Follow a flake and crack up and leftward, through a  blocky scoop and passing abulging overhang. Small cams and nuts can be placed, but gear requires some finesse and thought. Eventually, face climbing on positive edges leads to lower-angle terrain at the top.
routes.location: This route is on the Sugarloaf wall, around to the far right side. From the large group of easier climbs, head right, and just past the thin crack/seam "Thriller off the Void".
routes.protection: Small cams and nuts. Build a gear anchor at the top, and refrain from using the hydro tower.

routes.description: Grapple through a small roof. Climb direct to the top.
routes.location: SR to 4". Fixed top anchors.

routes.description: At the far right-hand edge of the South Wall is a steep corner with a flake on the left, followed by a wide crack.   Go up this to a great hand crack above.     Without big gear, the wide section is very runout.  However, the climbing is easy, past mantles on the right.  A groundfall is possible here without gear to 6 inches (or more).  Large gear would eliminate the "R" from this route.  It is good either way.   The crux is right off the ground (unless you decide to throw yourself INTO the wide crack instead of opting for the mantles).
routes.location: Pro to 3.5 inches, or to 6 inches (or more).  Requires a GEAR ANCHOR on top.  Walk off straight back along the right-hand edge of the cliff.

routes.description: A groove with a low, wide crack and a bulge near the top.
routes.location: SR w/ fixed top anchors.

routes.description: The route is a fairly sustained easy climb.  There are a couple of larger steps that have to be made in the middle.  In all, it's a fun route that can be used either as an introduction to traditional lead climbing or to perfect gear placements.  Essentially, just follow the cracks to the right of the white slab up to the top.
routes.location: Located beneath the big power-line tower.  Descend climbers right on a rocky trail.
routes.protection: There are two bolts at the top for an anchor.  There are many opportunities for protection.  A set of nuts and Camalot C4s .5-2 would be adequate.

routes.description: The Mechanic combines face climbing with inconsistent crack moves, for an occasionally heady 5.7 lead.
routes.location: The Mechanic is found to the left of Flat Battery (the leftmost obvious 5.4 crack) on the central section of the Sugarloaf. There's a lovely walk-off to the north.
routes.protection: Gear is present but rarely a gimme on this climb. A single rack will do. Bolt anchors at the top.

routes.description: Power Smart is steady, technical face climbing, good at the grade, and bold enough to keep you sweating. Keep your wits about you, and it's a great climb.
routes.location: Power Smart ascends the face between Flat Battery and Magnet (the left-most and second-to-left 5.4 crack systems) on the central Sugarloaf wall. Look for a vertical white streak at the top to confirm you're in the right spot.
routes.protection: Single rack, including some small gear. Protection is thin and far-between on this climb, unless one uses the adjoining major crack systems. Climbers can use the bolt anchors right or left of the top-out if they're not already in use.

routes.description: Very engaging and enjoyable climbing on edges and crimps. Exceptionally good movement on steep terrain for the grade. A nice first route for those making the transition from the gym to the outdoors.
routes.location: On the far right end of the north side of the sugarloaf. Meander up the broken slab before stepping left onto the main wall.
routes.protection: Gear is sparse, but good. Small cams or nuts with nothing bigger than finger-sized. Most choose to top-rope off the easily accessible hydro tower.

routes.fa: FA (Top rope) Royal Robbins, Jim Sinclair 1971, FA Dave Lane 1978
routes.description: The Bourdon guide unaccountably designates this pleasant pitch a super classic.  Far easier in the grade than the nearby Block and Tackle.   On the north side of Sugarloaf, climb left facing corner with a wide crack.  Pull up onto the face and climb an 80+ degree face with some fingerlocks past three bolts; the crux moves between bolts two and three are pretty easy if you identify the footholds before launching into the sequence.  Belay off the power tower.
routes.location: On the north side of Sugarloaf.
routes.protection: Three bolts, maybe and nut or two and a #3 and/or #4 Camalot for the start.

description: Giant boulder at the south end of the parking lot with a crack that traverses all the way across
getting_there: Park in the parking lot for Murrin Park off 99. Boulder is 10 feet off the south end of the lot, along side the main trail.

routes.description: Start on the Ripper and traverse the polished horizontal crack.  Step of at Star of the Sea
routes.location: same as the Ripper, second problem from the far left tree

routes.description: Dyno to a flat ledge
routes.location: Right side of the boulder, obvious jugs for start hand holds, ledge is up and to the right

routes.description: Climb the finger crack trending right
routes.location: Right side of the Traverse Wall

routes.description: Start under the small roof, one meter left of Zero (V5). Get hands on the juggy rail, go for a long left pinch, and then some techy feet to get right hand to a sidepull. One last tough move gains a good white edge halfway up the wall. Easy climbing to a top out from here, but it’s quite a highball so don’t relax quite yet.
routes.location: Start under the small roof, one meter left of Zero (V5)
routes.protection: Pads. The hard moves are very safe with good landings, but the top out is high.

routes.description: The horizontal crack the runs along the entire boulder making the Traverse Wall a traverse.  Start on Carmel.
routes.location: The only long horizontal crack spanning most of the boulder

routes.description: Climb the obvious features right of the crack
routes.location: second problem from the left

routes.description: Climb straight up through a horizontal crack to a small cedar shrub.  Start on a flat two-handed edge.
routes.location: to the right of Carmel.

routes.description: Climb the obvious crack feature
routes.location: Vertical crack feature on the left end of the boulder

routes.description: Climb the obivous crack up to the tree
routes.location: directly under the tree to the far left side

routes.description: Climb blocks to a smooth bulge and continue up the polished wall.  Finish by throwing left to a flat horizontal shelf.
routes.location: Middle of the Traverse Wall

description: A beautiful crag above the Petrifying Wall.  It feels a little more remote as the highway noise is almost completely damped out and is in a pretty forest.  It has a pretty even mix of trad and sport.   Some highlights include "Wicker Cranium" (5.9 trad) "A Little Testis" (5.10b trad) and "Totally Clips" (5.10b sport).
getting_there: From the Petrifying Wall, take the gully up and right of the "Flight of the Challenger" area.  Follow the fairly distinct but unmarked trail.  Maybe ten minutes past the Pet Wall.

routes.description: Visit Up Among the Firs for this climb, stay for the other climbs.  Start up a fairly easy corner, a few awkward moves in a flaring crack lead to a beautiful left facing corner crack.
routes.location: The trail that takes you to Up Among the Firs pretty much exits in front of a feature called "The Pie" as there are cracks that section the face the way a pie would be cut into six pieces.  The right side of this area is bounded by a big left facing corner which hosts this climb.
routes.protection: Medium nuts and cams will get you through the initial corner and flare.  The upper crack takes hand sized gear, but note that it widens a bit inside, so choose your gear wisely: what enters the crack may tip out once it's inside.  Don't let  that comment worry you too much, the protection is excellent.

routes.description: start on the block, move left, then climb the rt side of the slab arete.
routes.location: starts on large block separating left and right sections of Up Among the Firs

routes.description: start as for Road Rash, right at the final bolt, move up and right as for Zeasi.
routes.location: same start as Road Rash, alternative finish really to a tough 10d  of Road Rash.
routes.protection: 3 bolts plus gear to one inch

routes.description: After stepping onto the berm to find the starting holds, execute a series of challenging moves to progress past the first bolt. Then, trend up and left on the featured slab.Faces South down Howe Sound and gets lots of Sun.
routes.location: To the left of Usual Panic there is an upper terrance. This climb can be accessed via rapping off the anchor for Usual Panic/Wicker Cranium or walk around to the top to rap in using the Jurassic Ridge trail.

routes.description: Arete right of A Little Testis. You can skip the mossy slab by hiking around.
routes.location: 8 bolts

routes.description: enjoyable little pockets to a finger crack
routes.location: just right of Zaesi, shares anchors with Chokin' a Grogin
routes.protection: two bolts plus gear to two inches
routes.route_name: Nostalgia Aint What it Used to be

routes.description: I wasn't sure whether to call this trad or sport as it's entirely bolt protected except for one placement.   The semi-intimidating arete left of A Little Testis.   Slab past the first two bolts of Unusual panic which will seem like the crux if you're dialed in to Squamish slabs.  After the 2nd bolt, veer right towards a crack where the slab meets a bolted arete at a left facing corner.  Place a #2 Camalot sized piece (w/ runner) in the corner then continue up the corner until you can clip the first bolt on the arete.  Transition onto the arete and enjoy clean face climbing (w/ holds) until you top out at anchors.
routes.location: A few feet left of the Testis corner.
routes.protection: About 7 bolts and one hand sized piece.

routes.description: climb the left side of the slab with difficulty passing the final bolt.
routes.location: left most bolted line on slab of rock at Up Among the Firs.
routes.protection: 3 bolts plus gear to one inch

routes.fa: Jason Lin and Marilyn Geninatti,  August 2011
routes.description: Start as for Road Rash on mossy 5.7 slab heading left and up to crack. Roof protects with a couple nuts or up to a #2 cam and then cruise the nice crack to shared anchors with Collet a Day and Road Rash.
routes.location: Far left of Up Among the Firs
routes.protection: small to medium passive or active gear. Upper crack widens, so a #3 could be used.

routes.description: Climb the bolted slab up the left side of the main wall past 10 bolts to a bolted anchor (you will probably want to extend the anchor with slings to TR). Crux is up at the top. Low angle but small holds makes you trust your feet.
routes.location: Left of Wicker Cranium. Uses the same achor.

routes.description: Thin slab leads to super thin pure friction.
routes.location: First bolted line to the right of Wicker Cranium. Shares the same anchor.
routes.protection: Bolts. Maybe a finger cam for the runout. Anchor.

routes.description: This is a fun route, and one of my favorites in Murin Park: the finger locks and hand jams are sweet, it eats gear, and like a lot of classic 'squish routes, the crux comes...  Well, I'll let you find that one out for yourself.  Rest assured, this is a very safe route.   The lower half of the crack can be very wet after rain or during any month not named June, July, August, or September, but after hiking all the way up there, you're going to climb it anyway, so who cares, right?
routes.location: This route is the obvious dogleg on the blank slab to the left of A Little Testis and just to the right of a line of shiny new bolts that terminate at the same anchors.
routes.protection: TCUs, cams to 2.5", set of nuts.  Fixed anchor at the top, from which you can rap or TR with a 60.

routes.description: This climb looks promising from below and does have a cool gear protected finger and hand traverse, but its character changes completely to a low angle but brutally thin friction affair.
routes.location: Left of "The Pie" area, but before the next smooth wall there is a rectangular alcove.  Start up the right side corner.
routes.protection: Gear from nuts to a 3" cam for the initial corner and traverse.  Quickdraws for the second half.

routes.description: Follow a broken/inconsistent crack up the center of the slab on the left face. The first bolt protects a difficult-to-protect move on the lower crack. The second bolt protects the slab at the top and leads to the finish ramp. Zeasi shares an anchor with Road Rash and Toasted Testa Rossa.
routes.location: center crack line on left slab
routes.protection: one bolt plus gear to one inch

description: A small, less-than-vertical crag around the corner from Commonwealth. 14 routes, mostly gear/mixed with one sport route.    Topo can be found at  quickdrawpublications.com/w…, and as of August 2016 there are still laminated copies of this topo posted both at Commonwealth and Valley of the Lost Tribe.   It's recommended to bring doubles down to grey Metolius for this crag.
getting_there: Take the Loop Trail to Commonwealth. Walk climber's right to the end of the crag, and follow a trail for ~2 minutes left and up a gully.

routes.description: The overhanging corner. Starts on the ledge above the main trail. Stellar and easier than it looks.
routes.location: Standard Rack

routes.description: Pretty straight-forward bolt-clipping up a low-angle face past several horizontal breaks that act as pleasant rests.
routes.location: The sole sport line at the very top of the gully of Valley of the Lost Tribe.
routes.protection: 5 bolts, bolt anchor at the top. My partner was squeamish and plugged a yellow C3 between a few bolts, but I thought the spacing was fine.

routes.description: Climb crack of Game of Dog and Squirrel to first bolt then traverse right to the crack on the arête and climb to the top. With careful planning +the proper paw work sometimes the cat gets its mouse.
routes.location: Standard Rack - Mixed
routes.route_name: A Game of Cat and Mouse

routes.description: Flirtatious teasing and Chatter leads to a vigorous chase ending in bewilderment and lots of barking up the wrong tree. analogous to the first ascentionist’s attempts at relationships with female climbers.
routes.location: Standard Rack - Mixed
routes.route_name: A Game of Dog and Squirrel

routes.description: No Paleo dieting required here. Climb the crack right of corner and follow the hand jam crack after the big ledge.
routes.location: Standard Rack
routes.route_name: All you can Eat pasta Buffet

routes.description: a thin and twisted line. At the shallow roof follow the shallow paired seams and crimp your way up the blank slab to the Sad noodle anchor.
routes.location: Standard Rack - Mixed Route

routes.description: To quote Super Mario “Them meatballs are a little spicy!” The left traversing crack then turn right up shallow break to climb up face straight up.    Bring 2 Double 00 cams and save them for the top.
routes.location: Trad, Bolted anchor with chains at the top

routes.description: Happy Noodle takes the right branch of the Y shaped crack in the middle of the wall, the left branch is Sad Noodle. Climb the shared crack to the overlap, then following the right crack to the top.    Gear is good but small and a bit tricky to place near the overlap.
routes.location: Standard Rack

routes.description: Sad Noodle takes the left branch of the Y shaped crack in the middle of the wall, the right branch is Happy Noodle. Climb the shared crack to the overlap, then following the left traversing crack to the top.   Gear is good but small and a bit tricky to place near the overlap.
routes.location: Standard Rack

routes.description: A light snack. Tasty but ultimately not that satisfying. Pity it wasn’t a lot longer. An alternate way to access the ledge above. Belay off trees on the ledge.
routes.location: Standard Rack

routes.description: Begins with a very cool boulder problem on the arete (protected by 2 bolts) that leads to a small roof encounter where it joins "A Game of Cat and Mouse" for crack climbing to an arete finish past another bolt.
routes.location: Standard Rack - Mixed

description: A very friendly crag - nicely spaced bolts make it good for the novice leader (in my opinion). Starting at the left of the crag, you will find 5.8 & 5.9's and moving right they get harder with three fun 10d's towards the end. Late morning winter sun.   This is a link to Quickdraws website with the free topo:   quickdrawpublications.com/w…
getting_there: Walking around Murin Lake, past all the picnic tables, take the trail on the right (same one as to Pet, Quercus, etc).  Take the trail past Pet wall towards Up Among the Firs. This trail goes right past Woodstock.

routes.description: An awkward ramp leading up right and a balancy step to the left make this a fun route.
routes.location: Just to the right of Weathermen, bolt line follows the obvious ramp
routes.protection: 7 bolts, bolts with chains and 1 locking biner at the top

routes.description: Crux at the first overhang.
routes.location: Not in the topo. Bolted line left to S.D.S.
routes.protection: 8 bolts and chain anchor; belay from either the trail, or anchor just above on ledge.

routes.description: Crux is getting past the 2nd bolt. After that, it's an easy walk in the park.
routes.location: Most left route on Woodstock. You'll be belaying off of the path.

routes.description: Interesting, naturally protected start up a shallow dihedral and flake system. A difficult step right (bolt) into a large crater followed by excellent cranking up a vertical wall past 3 more bolts.
routes.location: Immediately left of Wavy Gravy.
routes.protection: A small selection of cams up to #1 BD. #00 C3 provides excellent protection for initial corner. 4 bolts.

routes.description: Slabby stairs. This is a good problem for beginner leaders. Good warm-up route on Woodstock.
routes.location: 2nd most left on Woodstock

routes.description: A fun blocky start leading to what felt like a staircase. Balancy moves and delicate footwork near the finish
routes.location: Right of Yasgur's Farm
routes.protection: 8 bolts anchor with bolts and chains at the top

routes.description: Climb up a face with features throughout.
routes.location: Left of Weathermen.This route starts the same as Weathermen, after clipping the first shared bolt, head out left.

routes.description: Waiting for Dylan is a 5.10d sport climb at Woodstock, with about 10 bolts in 25 metres.   A reachy start leads to a steep jug haul followed by a tricky move left. Some easy ground in the middle section leads to a very thin crux section at the end. Very well bolted and without the ledge fall potential of some of the other routes at the crag.   I thought the route was a bit of a sandbag at 10d. Though most of it was straightforward, the finish felt like V3-4 to me. Maybe others can weigh in.
routes.location: Watiting for Dylan is the rightmost route at the crag, right before the routes at Altamont begin. It starts just a few metres right of the bench seat (as of Aug. 2015)

routes.description: A burly start leads to more delicate climbing above.  Very well protected with bolts everywhere you might want them.
routes.location: The obvious steep corner at the right side of the crag.
routes.protection: 11 bolts, anchor with chains at the top.  As you approach the top (i.e., are at the tree) head left to find the anchor.

routes.description: Bouldery start leads to nicely spaced bolts.
routes.location: This route is probably easiest to identify by finding the 5.9 route Back to the Garden, made obvious by the ramp you follow up and right.   Once you locate Back to the Garden, this is the bolt line to the left of it.      This route starts the same as the 5.8 route S.D.S, after clipping the first shared bolt, you head out right and up a steep section.     Find the topo here:  quickdrawpublications.com/w…
routes.protection: 6 bolts, bolt anchor at the top

routes.description: Short and bouldery in a small corner past two bolts, then left to easier climbing up a series of rails and ledges.
routes.location: The short route to the left of the obvious wavy gravy corner.
routes.protection: 3 bolts with a bolted anchor 30 ft. up. The anchor is placed just out of reach of a very comfortable ledge. Apparently there used to be a large block here which was trundled, explaining the now-awkward placement.

routes.description: Fun! Interesting moves at the horizontal crack (around the 6th bolt)
routes.location: Bolt line right of Back to the Garden
routes.protection: 8 bolts, anchor with chains and 2 locking carbines to clip

description: A great little crag with some high quality routes.
getting_there: Walk partway around Browning Lake. In the area with the picnic benches, look up the hill and you should see the crag about 100 ft. up the wooded slope.

routes.description: A nice route with thoughtful moves over steep but small roofs.  Amazing this wasn't claimed before 2012.   Climb the dihedral to the right of Zoe all the way up.  It's quite easy for 25 feet until you hit the first roof.  There's no bolts before this point, so you need a small rack (up to 1" pieces) to get here.   Clip the first bolt and surmount the first roof with good stemming for your feet.  Cruise to the next roof, clip bolt, and crank over it (crux).  Relatively easier climbing from there to the top chains.
routes.location: small rack to 1".  3 bolts.  rappel chains.

routes.description: Start just left of Zoe and work through progressively thinner edges.  Your footwork will be tested here. A couple of big reaches take you to a very difficult transition from being splayed out on the wall to underclinging while leaning back to keep your feet smearing on a smooth vertical wall.  Work your way along the undercling until it curves up into a layback.  The final headwall is easier but the glacier polish isn't forgiving if the earlier sections have left you pumped.
routes.location: Well bolted, chains at the top.

routes.description: nice positive ramp of slab.   crux is some fancy footwork in the middle of the route, trust the friction...i would imagine the entire face is 'on' seeing as the bolts run around the centerline.
routes.location: at your 3 o'clock if you're facing Zoe.

routes.description: A very short 4 bolt climb, consisting of several good, bouldery moves.
routes.location: This route is located a bit left of the big arch for Jeff and the Giant Reach and Breathe, on its own separate section.  It's the only route.

routes.description: start up Staples and after a few bolts veer to the righthand bolt line.  A sweet rightward rising crimpy hand traverse leads to more challenges above.  Really fun movement!
routes.location: right of Staples

routes.description: Really fun route. I liked it better than Zoe as the challenges are a little more sustained and interesting. Staple scars are still quite bad though, bit of a shame. Climb up the dihedral right of Zoe for 4m, branch left to a tech corner and then above to steeper terrain.
routes.location: New bolt line directly right of Zoe.

routes.description: When standing at the base of the crag, it should be obvious which route this is. It's the only one that looks like a vertical, bolted 10a.A vertical route, similar in style to what you find on the Petrifying Wall, but at a grade not found on that wall. Creative moves make this very enjoyable route more about technique than anything else.
routes.location: Bolts to a chain anchor.  If 10a is your limit you may feel uncomfortable reaching and clipping the first bolt.

description: A small, very easily accessible sport crag just a couple minutes up the road from Smoke Bluffs. Great for quick hit sessions or escaping crowds. All routes are bolted.    Bring bug spray as the mosquitoes are usually out in force.
getting_there: The crag is at 49.720935, -123.131711, drive East on Raven Drive until the road would turn south, and there is a dirt parking lot on the left. Park here and walk east into the trees for 50 meters.

routes.description: A great techy slab route with interesting edges and nubbins. The crux can be tricky to figure out but is good, and afterwards the climbing eases just a little.Climb over the initial bulge and then up the slabby face.
routes.location: At the left side of the wall, just left of the large left-facing corner that is Pan's Sword.

routes.description: The right most route at the crag, it features a high first bolt after some easy scrambling up blocks, followed by fun movement through the corner system.
routes.location: The right most route at the crag.

routes.description: Climb the left leaning streak of blocky rock, sharing the same first bolt as Captain Hooked. The bolts are awkwardly out to the left and so the clipping is not always that comfortable, but they're not too bad.
routes.location: Far right side of the wall, just left of the obvious corner that is Captain Hooked.

routes.description: Steep climbing past bulges leads to a tenuous slab. The route might share a few holds with its neighbour to the right.
routes.location: The leftmost climb at the crag.

routes.description: Techy face climbing weaves up the wall through some nice features. Short cruxes and decent rests.
routes.location: In the middle of the crag, one or two routes left of the base of the log stairs. Moss borders the climb on the left

routes.description: Follow the obvious left leaning corner system to a hard crux and then easier climbing up top.
routes.location: Third route from the left, obvious left leaning corner line.

description: The leftmost crag in Paradise Valley. Park outside the hatchery and follow the hiking trail through the bouldering area. Keep trending up and left until a faint spur takes you directly up to the crag.Names of the climbs and FAs are courtesy of Marc Bourdon’s excellent book, Squamish Select 2021. You should buy it and support local developers and authors. This information is the bare minimum to get there and know what route you’re on.Seriously, buy Marc’s book.
getting_there: Approach is no more than 15 minutes. If necessary, head straight up the talus blocks and trend left along the base of the cliffs.

routes.description: Fun climbing leads to a good rest, work rightward through the crux to the exit groove.
routes.location: 8 bolts

routes.description: Easy climbing up to the first crux on very clean (for the crag) stone. There’s another crux higher up that requires a little less muscle but some thoughtfulness. Easier for taller folks.
routes.location: Find the cleanest line at the crag.

routes.description: P1 - 11aP2 - 10cP3 - 10cP4 - 10aThe climb doesn’t see a lot of traffic and can be a bit dirty. P1 sees some traffic, the rest less so. There is loose rock the higher you go, so it’s best to walk off rather than rappel.
routes.location: Start on Served on a Cedar Plank for P1 and continue upwards.

routes.description: Tricky climbing on awkwardly slanting edges. It’s all there, but requires some body English. Can be wet after a rain.
routes.location: Leftmost line at the crag.

routes.description: Sharp edges and decent pockets throughout. Very technical and a big step up in difficulty from Here Today, Spawn Tomorrow.
routes.location: 9 bolts

description: A newer cliff across from the DFO hatchery.   Features long pitches on textured granite. The climbing is protected by a mix of bolts and gear. Some sport routes, some trad.   Gets sun around noon. Fast to dry if windy. Avoid on warm days or get there early.
getting_there: As for the boulders, but after the bridge, take a left and head towards The Fridge. After that traverse high across talus and pick up a trail in the forest which leads to the cliff. 20 minutes.

routes.description: An excellent pitch which works its way through multiple tricky sections. Make use an assortment of hold types to figure out pumpy and technical moves. An intense crux guards the anchor.
routes.location: Left of the big chimney in the middle of the cliff. Start up on obvious ramp and follow bolts up.
routes.protection: 12 Bolts. Chains and lower offs at the top.

routes.description: The crag warm up. An easy start leads to a tricky crux around the arete. Excellent rock up high.
routes.location: Just left of where the approach trail meets the cliff. Starts up a blocky basalt infused face.

routes.description: A technical line with very balancy arete moves. Tenuous.
routes.location: Start at the toe of the buttress, up blocky terrain shared with Bend It.

routes.description: Overhanging line on great rock. Tough crux just before the line dekes right to join Send It Like Beckham. Upgraded from 12b.
routes.location: The first line in the gully on the overhanging wall.

description: One of the best hard sport climbing walls in Squamish. Gently overhung.Similar to the Big Show this wall allows for easier progression through link ups allowing you to swap in boulder problems to move up the grades and difficultly rather than learn an entire new route.Classics here include: queen bee, spirit quest and spirit of the west
getting_there: Park at the fish hatchery. Hike along the road and take the second left. Continue up into the steep scree field trail. You really can not miss the head wall.

routes.description: Absolute classic route.No move on this is harder than the crux of Face the Music. The entire route is kind of like climbing FTM 8 times.Having only been up it once here is the detailed break down:Start on easier but sequential 5.12 climbing up to the small roof. Here you get a very good shake and power up for the early crux. Using good underclings and finger locks bump your way over the bulge.The climbing sticks with you as you make some big moves through the next couple clips. Quickly change styles into thin Gaston/ side pull tech traverse to gain the large rail and the mid way rest of the route. To here the route is around 13b and you’ve certainly done the hardest moves of the climb.But it’s not over as you still have a long 13a ish section of climbing above you. Power lay backing, a small down climb, more lay backing on a crazy tuffesc jug flake leads you to one last v2/v3 crux that could definitely spit off the desperately pumped and undeserving challenger right before the chains. Know that you shouldn’t fall here and scream some profanities because you need to let everyone at the crag know you fell because you got unlucky not because you didn’t do enough endurance training.Clip the chains and rejoice that you’ve finally completed the easiest route on the wall.
routes.location: Fixed Draws

description: The cliff is directly below the River crag on the right of Paradise Wall.
getting_there: Hike down from the base of Paradise Wall or hike right from the area approach trail, midway through the talus.

routes.description: Cryptic crux just past halfway. The rest is comparatively easier, though a small run out over a sharp ledge keeps you on your toes!
routes.location: Between "The Redd" (5.11a) & "Keystone Species" (5.11c/d)

routes.description: Good crack climbing leads to a ledge before the crux. Labelled 10a in 2021 select but update says 5.9.
routes.location: Bolts

routes.description: Some reachy pulls on good holds leads to a tricky sequence and more long pulls between good pulls. A rest just below the small roof lets you get some back before a powerful and thin crux to establish under the roof. Continue up on easier terrain as the angle backs off. Weaving left then back right to the more interesting climbing.
routes.location: Start on the just right of the arête that splits the gully and west facing part of the wall.

routes.description: A hard to read lower crux leads to a rest and then a second crimpy, powerful crux.
routes.location: Route starts at the huge flake on the ground.

routes.description: Beware the pump. Didn't feel there was too much of a crux to this climb
routes.location: Between "Alevin and the Chipmunks" (5.11c) & "Anadromous Fish" (5.10a)

routes.description: Well protected climb, especially around the crux section which is closer to the top of the climb
routes.location: Between "Salmon in your Tallons" & "Recommended by the Sturgeon General"

routes.description: Start as for On The Hook (10a) up juggy blocks and flakes to a mossy ramp below a set of chains. Traverse left over this ramp to a fun undercling sequence then move up through the corner to the top.
routes.location: Around the corner to the right of where the path hits The Redd, second bolted route from the left.

routes.description: Powerful and technical climbing on interesting blocky terrain leads to a sting in the tail crux right at the anchors.
routes.location: Bolts

routes.description: Second climb from the left.Follow some fun crack jams, going over a cruxy bulge onto juggy flake, and a bit of face climb a couple of bolts before the anchor.
routes.location: 11 bolts

routes.description: Interesting, wandery crack climbing leads to a slabby, crimpy crux at the top.
routes.location: Leftmost route at the Redd, starts with zig-zaggy cracks.

description: A small cliff just up and right from Paradise Wall. Some excellently built platforms and ladders provide some much needed safety and erosion control on the upper part of this wall.
getting_there: Easy to find, just a few meters to the right of Paradise Wall.

routes.description: Work your way up easy terrain to the mini roof at the third bolt. A fun compression sequence and some face climbing bring you to an offwidth on the right. Move left to the "banger" crux in the middle of a smooth section. Navigate the crimps and lack of feet to a bomber jug, then keep it together to the top.
routes.location: The first bolted climb on the left side of The River, lots of chalk.
routes.route_name: Lox Stock and Two Smolts on Bagels

routes.description: Awesomely pumpy hand crack. Steep, this climb rewards good jamming technique, with some burliness near the top.
routes.location: Obvious hand crack at the top of the final platforms. Bolts to the right of crack.
routes.protection: 7 bolts. Ring anchor at the top.

description: Quiet, secluded, and surrounded by large moss covered trees, the Enchanted boulders are home to some Squamish classics such as Tai Fighter (V4) and the highball Enchanted (V4).
getting_there: This is the first bouldering area reached in the Paradise Valley boulders, right after the pedestrian bridge.

routes.description: Start just right of the seam matched on the lowest part of the slanting shelf. Climb up and right to a good rail and the top.
routes.location: The right side of the first boulder on your left when you cross the bridge.

routes.description: Start with opposing sidepulls low on the arete. An awkward move or two leads to a juggy middle section and then a though provoking and intimidating top out.   Tall and scary, Enchanted is a Top 100 climb and a proud send.
routes.location: The Enchanted boulder itself is on the right as you enter the Enchanted boulders, and is obvious as the tallest boulder you see.
routes.protection: Though the landing is flat, Enchanted is a true highball and requires a calm head, careful climbing, and a lot of pads and spotters.

routes.description: From the start of Little Dragon, link left into Underminer's Daughter. Good moves on generally positive holds. Surprisingly pumpy given the diminutive size of the boulder.
routes.location: On the Little Dragon boulder.Ascend the steps in between The Giant's Bose and Enchanted. Continue ~20m uphill and then cut right above the Enchanted boulder. Weave through the talus, staying below a large fallen log, and the boulder will quickly come into view up to your left after ~40m.

routes.description: Start on obvious holds down left of the large shelf. Work through the shelf and to the lip on crimps and pockets. Save a little summin' for the mantle!
routes.location: Up the trail (and stairs) from the enchanted boulder and down through the ensuing scree field.
