routes.description: Start with a sharp left side pull in a seam and a blocky right sidepull lower down. Pull on and throw for the lip with your left hand.
routes.location: The first boulder on your left when you cross the bridge.

routes.description: Start with your left hand on the blocky right hold of The Mirror Left and a fat pinch-block on the right. Throw for the lip with your right hand this time.
routes.location: The first boulder on your left when you cross the bridge.

routes.description: Starting as far left as possible, traverse right along the lip of the entire boulder to finish next to the curved cedar tree, same as for Butterfly Stitch.
routes.location: The first boulder on your left when you cross the bridge.

routes.description: Start using a left seam pocket and a low, right shelf edge. Make a powerful cross into a seam gaston and then continue to the lip.
routes.location: The first boulder on your left when you cross the bridge.

routes.description: Start crouching using two slopey holds, hit a left sidepull and then up to a good edge. Exit left of the funky curved cedar.
routes.location: The first boulder on your left when you cross the bridge.

routes.description: One of the coveted Top 100, Tai Fighter is a classic and is highly recommended.    Start matched on a shelf on the left side of the arete. Follow the arete to a fun top out, using a combination of crimps, pinches, slopers, and heel hooks.
routes.location: Visible as a pointed prow from the bridge, the Tai Fighter boulder is approached by either following the trail around to the right over a short set of stairs, or by scrambling left and up from the bridge.
routes.protection: Though you are never very high above the ground, Tai Fighter can be a bit scary because of the hole above the start and the sloping boulder below you. Most will want about three pads, and perhaps a spotter.

routes.description: Start seated under the arete using a slanted left shelf and a tight sidepull pocket in the crack. Head straight up the arete using interesting features.
routes.location: On the Little Dragon boulder.Ascend the steps in between The Giant's Bose and Enchanted. Continue ~20m uphill and then cut right above the Enchanted boulder. Weave through the talus, staying below a large fallen log, and the boulder will quickly come into view up to your left after ~40m.

routes.description: Start using a high, slopey V-shaped pinch and edge just to the left. Prepare for some powerful slaps up the overhanging prow.
routes.location: Directly underneath Tai Fighter. On your left and straight ahead once you cross the bridge.

description: Collection of boulders in the forest and talus north of the Enchanted Boulders
getting_there: Hike up on top of the Simply Paradise boulder until you see Tai Fighter (V4), go north on a beautiful winding trail for 5-10 minutes through the forest. A bit scrambly in places. You should soon see the Fridge boulder off slightly to your right.

routes.description: Start matched on a good, slightly left facing edge and climb straight up on crimps and pinches. Committing moves up high, but luckily the lip holds are really good
routes.location: West facing side of the Fridge boulder
routes.protection: Tiered landing, so bring plenty of pads and spotters

description: The Rock Lady boulder is a bus-sized boulder that sits right on the Tenderfoot Creek. It is stacked with excellent vertical crimpy and technical lines in a beautiful setting. Sunlight filters in through the trees in the afternoon. Access is a serious privilege here and it is on private land. Do not bring your dogs. Do not block the hatchery gate. Do not park in the campground or access the boulders via the campground. Stay off the tracks and out of the water. Be respectful of the area and understand that abuse could result in closure.
getting_there: Walk a few minutes south from the Enchanted Boulders and follow the trail along the creek, passing the fish trap along the way.

routes.description: Sit start in front of the small cave matched with your left hand on a good pinch/grip.Make tenuous moves up the arete until you can get to the juggy crack in the seam.Try not to dab on the spiky rock below.Beta Video:  youtube.com/shorts/6tsq3YdY…
routes.location: Left most side of the boulder that houses “World’s Best Boulder Problem”

routes.description: Start using a left pinch on the arete and a right edge beside it. Follow enjoyable, scooped edges to the top. Great movement for a V2 on very nice rock.
routes.location: Past the main Rock Lady boulder. Cross the log over the small river and walk downstream 20 meters.

routes.description: Begin with a left gaston, a nearby right crimp and a high right foot to gain the sidepull flakes right of Sushi Special.
routes.location: Left side of Rock Lady.

routes.description: This huge, one move dyno starts on the furthest right aspect of the Rock Lady boulder, just left of the gigantic tree. Start sitting on crimps and then make your way to the obvious, incut jug at chest height. Paste your feet and heave to a huge sloper jug at the top. Victory!
routes.location: Left of the obvious gigantic tree on the right most aspect of the Rock Lady boulder.

routes.description: Start seated using crimps and climb the dihedral. A bit awkward for the tall.
routes.location: Past the main Rock Lady boulder. Cross the log over the small river and walk downstream 20 meters.

routes.description: Start low in the depression matched on a flat edge.
routes.location: Pads

routes.description: Sit start on right facing side pulls. Head straight up.
routes.location: South end of the Rock Lady boulder, between a couple of trees.

routes.description: Start as for The Empire. When possible, move left on small edges and then trend back right to top out at the boulder's apex.
routes.location: Right side of Rock Lady main wall.

routes.description: Climb straight up the wall starting with a left pinch-like sidepull and a right crimp.
routes.location: Right side of Rock Lady main wall.

routes.description: Start matched on a good, small shelf hold. Climb up through a difficult, reachy crux to gain an incut hold at the lip and a final jug.
routes.location: Left side of Rock Lady.

routes.description: Start seated using a diagonal edge. Climb to a good square hold and then press up into the square-cut undercling. Top out straight above.
routes.location: Middle of Rock Lady main wall.

routes.description: Start seated using crimpy sidepulls below a positive basalt flake hold. Make a large move to the flake and then trend up and left to finish.
routes.location: Right side of the Rock Lady main wall.

routes.description: Stand start on positive edges right under a fallen cedar that looms over the top-out. Make powerful moves straight up towards the top with some technical footwork and a lunge for a jug. Probably easier for taller folks.
routes.location: Close to the middle of the Rock Lady boulder directly under a fallen cedar tree that hangs over the top-out.
routes.protection: 1-2 pads. The landing is nice and flat.

routes.description: Top 100 in the Squamish Bouldering guidebook.Start seated with a right sidepull and a small, left gaston edge. Throw for the good shelf and then blast off for difficult slopers on the lip. A variation begins on edges down and left. Use a good foothold at ground level to reach the regular start.
routes.location: Past the main Rock Lady boulder. Cross the log over the small river and walk slightly right and away from the river. The face of the climb is facing away from the river.

routes.description: Lives up to the name!
routes.location: Paradise Valley Boulders

routes.description: Left of G-force Accelerator. Start using horizontal rail and good feet. Move up and right to a side pull and a series of small crimps. Finish near the top of G-force accelerator.
routes.location: Between Maui Wowie and G-force accelerator. Obvious horizontal edge for starting hands around 4’ off the ground.
routes.protection: Excellent flat landing. A pad or two should be enough.

description: This area has two main sections, the forest and the talus, all info is in the Squamish bouldering book
getting_there: Drive north on highway 99 past Squamish, when you see mnt fun base camp, it will be the next powerlines that cross the highway. you can park under these on the side of the highway and follow them into the forest. see Squamish Bouldering book for better detail.

routes.description: start far right after the bulge on the big shelf, travers left and mantle onto the second shelf.
routes.location: you can find this climb between the Hemingway roof Boulders and Kinesthetic Boulders. Pg 383 in the guide book

routes.description: Start on undercling shelf and slab up.I gave this a name and grade because I couldn't find any info on it. but it looks like it was climbed by somebody before me.
routes.location: this is the slab just left of "stickman Press"

routes.description: This is a fun little climb, start on right sidepull and any of the 2 left crimps. go up!Looks like somebody cleaned it, but couldn't find any info so I named and graded it for now.
routes.location: Same boulder as "Stickman Press" just go left past the slab.

routes.description: Start seated with left hand on left arret hold and right hand on the right arret side pull. bump right to good sideways jug then struggle up with a crimp on the face before hitting jugs. There is a possible low start in the crack below if you are small.
routes.location: follow the trail from "stickman press" towards "no mo poe", its the first boulder on your left.

routes.description: Start seated on 2 edges, in the little pit. avoid the arret down low and use crimps to hit a juggy topout.
routes.location: You can find the climb on the same boulder as "Larch travers" on the downhill side

routes.description: Start matched on a low fin and climb up and left through underclings and slopers to an easy but airy topout.
routes.location: Emerging Dream boulder. Massive boulder just off the trail, you can't miss it.

description: This is a recently developed area between Slhanay/Squaw and the Chief.
getting_there: Park as per Slahany/Squaw on the Mamquam Forest service road and start up the trail to Slahany.  The pullout on the right about 1.5km past the Apron parking   After a few minutes on the trail (shortly after scrambling up a short steep bit), look for a trail going to the right.  As of 2017, it was marked with a white sign referring to Pox Wall/Disaster Response.

routes.description: Great route that climbs steeper than the usual Squamish 5.10.   Thread on Squamish Climbing Form:   squamishclimbing.com/squami…   P1 - Start on the right side of the base area and move towards the bolt on the left below the thin crack.  Climb the crack to the belay ledge.  This pitch doesn't see much sun and is a bit mossy.  The belay bolts are to the left, but look for the rap bolts about 50' to the right and remember to hit those on the way down. 20m pitch.   P2 - The money pitch.   Take either the left hand/fist crack or the right thin crack.  We took the left crack.   It's steep, solid jamming all the way to the undercling roof.   I had two #3s and one #4.   If you want to sew it up, bring another #4. There is a horizontal crack midway which helps with the gear.  The steep crack just below the crux undercling is #2/#3 camalot size, so save one of each for that section if you want to sew it up.  Bust out the undercling (crux for me) and pull around the roof.  Easy climbing leads to the bolts directly overhead. 25m pitch.   P3 - Move the belay down and to the right.   Launch up the gently overhanging handcrack for 40 feet (sweetness!) to the bolt protecting a weird step left.   Climb overlaps/underclings to the anchor, which is way up there. 30m pitch.   Descent:  Rap the route with a 60m route.   Hit the rap anchors about 50' of the belay bolts atop P1.   I almost missed them coming down, so keep your eyes out.
routes.location: See area description.  After hiking up you'll end up below the Pox Wall.  Before hitting the wall take a faint trail to the right and follow it for 10 minutes.  The route is pretty far right.
routes.protection: We did the fist crack version and a comfortable rack would be double crams from fingers to #3 camalot.  I had one #4 camalot, but two would have sewed it up.   Finger crack version looked like it took good great from small to green camalot.

description: A modest south-facing crag with 11 routes ranging from 5.6 to mid-10. The two major landmarks are the two central easy-looking handcracks in the middle - the left one is Doodles (5.6) and the right one is Squiggles (5.7).  Despite appearances the climbing is actually kind of interesting, though often the placements are a little technical so bring your stoppers. The experience is currently marred by the anchors, which comprise of a single rock staple atop each route. I recommend bringing a cordalette to equalize between adjacent rock staples, but as for cleaning routes you're on your own.
getting_there: This is tricky and best described in the 2020 Squamish Select by Marc Bourdon. (Honestly, you should buy it anyways to support quality guidebook writing.)Drive to the top of High Creek Drive in Valleycliffe and park. This is a residential neighbourhood so do not park on the street or in the cul-de-sac and use the various parking bays along the street. As you walk to the cul-de-sac at the top of High Creek Drive, there is a path on the left that travels up a hill, then up around the back of the homes on the west side of the street. After 2-3 minutes you should see a path that shoots up and right, this is the mountain bike trail Equinox. You are essentially going to follow Equinox for another 10 minutes or so uphill past a viewpoint until Rampage Rock appears on the right. Bourdon recommended using a mountain bike trail app to find and follow Equinox - I downloaded Trailforks and found it was very useful as the trail branches in several places. When you see a 15m tall half-dome of mossy cracks facing south behind a few trees, you've found it.

routes.description: The climbing is quite straight-forward, but there is not always gear exactly where you'd like and a 5.6 leader may find protection a little sneaky. Despite this, it can be protected safely without crazy runouts.
routes.location: The left of the two main wide splitters at the crag.
routes.protection: Gear. Anchor is one single staple - bring a cordalette to equalize with an adjacent route's anchor.

routes.description: Climb horizontal pockets up to a big ledge, then up jugs and a big crack left of a perched boulder at the top of the crag.
routes.location: Start to the right of Oscar Takes a Stroll, below some obvious horizontal incuts.
routes.protection: Gear. Anchor is one single staple - bring a cordalette to equalize with an adjacent route's anchor.

routes.description: Interesting climbing. Despite appearances from the ground it's all there, there are many little edges and mini-jugs to take you through the upper section. I'd suggest taking your nuts.
routes.location: In the middle of the wall here is a wide hand crack that wanders off right. Climb this, but depart straight up before this crack merges into a shelf. Climb up until you are on a big ledge, stay right of the big hallow flakes (I believe these belong to Roughness). Find the mini-jugs, gear thins out up here but the holds are all there.
routes.protection: Single rack, including nuts. . Anchor is one single staple - bring a cordalette to equalize with an adjacent route's anchor.

routes.description: Quite good climbing - hand jams and edges for the first half, then jugs when it steepens.
routes.location: The right of the two main hands splitters at the crag.
routes.protection: Gear to 4". Anchor is one single staple - bring a cordalette to equalize with an adjacent route's anchor.

routes.description: A series of seams up the wall with good edges between. Engaging climbing that feel steep and thin but rewards you with good edges and good protection where you need it. Nutcraft helps, but you don't need to be that wily about it.
routes.location: Start up Squiggles, then after a few moves transfer right into the thin broken seams.
routes.protection: Small gear from a red C3 to #2, with some nuts. Anchor is one single staple - bring a cordalette to equalize with an adjacent route's anchor.

description: Good overhanging sport climbing that you would otherwise have to continue halfway to Whistler to find.  5.11 and 5.12 only in this area, unless any projects have turned into 13s.  Go warm up in the West Wing if necessary.
getting_there: The trail the parking emerges at the left side of this crag, so it's not tough to find.

routes.description: Start up pleasuredome and move left on the ramp. Tricky climbing to a lip encounter, if you pull the lip it may be hard on your rope coming down. There is a hard direct start, unsure of the grade.
routes.location: Same start as Pleasuredome but then goes up left.

routes.description: This is rumored to be the best climb at the sanctuary.  The climb tackles the obvious seam on a crescent shaped wall, getting progressively steeper toward the top of the climb.  The crux for me was a long move near the last bolt, although maybe the pump had something to do with this being the hard part.  The route seems to pack quite a punch for it's relatively short length.   This is rated 5.12b in the squamish select book, but definitely felt harder to me.  Some of the holds seemed a bit crumbly, so I would not rule out the possibility of broken holds in the past or future.   I am surprised that the guidebook gives this climb 5 stars, especially in squamish, where there are loads of excellent climbs.  Fun route, but nowhere near 5 stars in my opinion.
routes.location: On the far left side of the sanctuary, locate the obvious bolted seam on a wave shaped wall. This is the crescent.

routes.description: Sustained climbing leads to tough deadpoint or dyno to the lip. Hard to hang the draws
routes.location: Right end of the wall, goes through the obvious roof.

routes.description: Up the arete on the left, start just right of the boulder
routes.location: bolts
routes.protection: Boulder start up the blunt arete. Redpoint crux through the small roof. Pretty sustained.

routes.description: Hard line if you don't get it right. Crux at the top.
routes.location: Rightmost route, angles up and right.

routes.description: Hard start leads to tarzan like moves. Find the good rest and fire the lip.
routes.location: Middle of the wall goes through the dome like feature. Start off a small stump.

description: This area is up and right of the basement.
getting_there: Follow the trail up out of the forest. Follow the treeline up for a while until you move back into the forest. The wall will be in view in 3-4 minutes.

routes.description: Fun climbing on holds that are sometimes hard to find.
routes.location: middle of the wall

routes.description: Arete climbing on the right.
routes.location: bolts

description: The right side of the cliff gets full sun. Just a small handful of fun routes.
getting_there: The trail for Sanitarium branches left from the path to basement after you cross a creek bed.

routes.description: Climb up the right side of the arete. Crux is pulling over the upper bulge.
routes.location: mid-wall on the right of the arete.

routes.description: Varied climbing that gets better once you get above the first ledge.
routes.location: 10 bolts

routes.description: Climb up the left side of the arete.
routes.location: 8 bolts

routes.description: Excellent climbing up the middle of the face.
routes.location: Left line of bolts.

routes.description: Zig zag a bit on the line all the way on the right.
routes.location: bolts

description: The easier area in the Sanctuary.  It still has some solid 5.11s and a 5.12, but it also has three 5.10s that are all fun.
getting_there: From the Basement, head left up the trail that switch-backs up a gully for a few minutes.  The crag will be on your right.

routes.description: Bouldery start, then move right and then up.Crux reach in the middle of the route. Nice long finish.
routes.location: Dead center of the wall.

routes.description: This is the arete that divides the cliff into the   "smooth" section on the left with harder overhanging routes, and two other 10s on the right.   Start from a terrace up and left of the first bolt.  Traverse right to the bolt and then head up.  Watch out for a loose toaster-sized block (marked with an X in 2005).
routes.location: seven draws, rap anchors

routes.description: Tricky start to a couple of crux bulges.
routes.location: Right beside the huge Douglas Fir.

routes.description: Easy to the big ledge, sustained after that.
routes.location: Left of the two routes that gain the big ledge.

routes.description: Sustained up the gently overhanging wall. Techy face to a crux pull on pockets through the bulge. Sustained up above.
routes.location: Near the bottom of the wall just right of the bush in the wall

routes.description: Linkup between Morpheus and Home Invasion. Start up Morpheus to the 7th bolt then cut left following 3 bolts to join into Home Invasion at its 6th bolt.
routes.location: 14 draws

routes.description: Right of the arete of Into the Blue are two climbs that go easily up to a ledge and then up a vertical face.  Pigpen is the left of these two routes.  The section above the ledge consists of very tricky climbing for the grade.  It's all there, but you really have to think your way through it.
routes.location: eight draws, rap anchors

routes.description: Same start as Morpheus and branch right through a big pocket. Very tricky crux pulling the bulge.
routes.location: Same as Morpheus

description: The climbing here is good, but the setting is spectacular, though you may have to contend with trains.  The crag itself sits just above Howe Sound.  Hanging belays at high tide are not to be missed.  Seals and otters frequent the cove as well.  Out the traverse, best to belay the second from the top and rap back in from the tree.  Two ropes may be needed otherwise, with the real possibilty of dropping them in the water.
getting_there: About 10 KM from Squamish, and 2km. south of Murrin Park park in the wide pullout with the mining information sign.  Walk up the road towards Squamish wide  until across from the Welcome to Squamish sign.  It is possible to stay left of the road barrier for safety.  Drop down to your left following flagging tape down and right to the old road, and follow this to the crag, which is below and left. Rappel with one rope on the slings on the tree.  It is a stretch, but possible. It is possible to follow the road and flagging tape up to the railroad tracks and cross these above the crag, but avoid walking on the tracks.  The climbs on the right of the slab must be accessed by doing the traverse first.

routes.description: Traverse out along the Seal Cove Traverse. Establish a gear belay at the base of the rising crack (before the bolted anchor for Sole Mate). Follow the crack as it ascends up and right. Finish on the last two bolts of Sole Mate.
routes.location: A third of the way out on the Seal Cove Traverse.
routes.protection: Gear to 2" plus the last two bolts of Sole Mate. Ends at a bolted anchor. Follow climbers trail left across the top of the face to a bolted rappel anchor.

routes.description: Slab on right side of Seal Cove. Access it by scrambling up and right of the top of Swept Away. Sustained friction on a fairly steep slab. Graded 11a in the guidebook but felt a lot harder than other slabs of the same grade in Squamish. It probably doesn't get much traffic and it seemed a little dirty.
routes.location: Bolts and some cams for a horizontal

routes.description: Follows the diagonal crack rightward across the face. Enjoy the undercling, slabby spot, rampy crack up top, and the view out to the water in the direction you're facing! Tree anchor at the top.
routes.location: Same start as Whanu and Bubble Buddy - a few feet downslope of the trees.
routes.protection: several bolts; SR for the second half

routes.description: Work past the large scar, then follow a crack up and right, then clip bolts for some slabby face climbing.
routes.location: Start at a bolted anchor on the far left of the face.

routes.description: More face/slab climbing.  Some runout, but very fun.
routes.location: Just past the iron ring on the traverse; the first two bolt anchor you come to.

routes.fa: Glenn Payan, Jeff Thomson, Shannon Price, Jack Fieldhouse
routes.description: Start on Seal Cove, and traverse out a ways. Then go up a big flake and continue straight up to cracks and bolts.
routes.location: Starts out on Seal Cove.

routes.description: Climb straight up the slab (crux) and cracks until you can traverse horizontally to the ledge on the left, finish straight up the slab. Variations are possible through the low angle corner or starting on Sea Puppies (both 10a).
routes.location: Rap from the top anchor or do the extended Seal Cove Traverse.To find the top anchor, walk climbers right on top of the cliff until you can step up the slabs left to reach another trail. Continue a few meters to the first anchor.
routes.protection: 12 bolts and take a small rack to .75. At the top and bottom are two-bolt anchors.
routes.route_name: Heads I Win, Tails You Lose

routes.description: A long traverse that is a good addition to Barknuckles.Jeff Thomson did the second half of this pitch in his Reverse Traverse (See www.seatoskyclimbing.ca).
routes.location: From the top of Barknuckles or Sole Mate, traverse out to the left and follow that crack all the way to the anchor of Bubble Buddy.

routes.description: Climb up the left hand side of the slab past bolts and a bulge to small cracks where gear can be placed. Belay from the top and rappel of the slings on the tree below.
routes.location: Left hand side of the slab.  Not necessary to traverse out, and possible to belay from terra firma.

routes.description: This is a flaring chimney through a roof which is on the other side of the cove from the other Seal Cove routes and faces them across the beach.   The start is dependent on low tide and is covered by up to 2 m of water at high tide. Don't get stuck belaying at the base while the tide comes in, as on the first attempt.   The chimney both flares and leans and is best climbed left side in. Wriggling leads to a palm-and-elbow, knee-and-heel opposed section to the top. A fun and challenging width to practice on.
routes.location: When you hit the beach at Seal Cove, this route is about 40 m north of the other climbs and faces them on a south-facing craglet forming the other side of the cove.
routes.protection: Gear to 4". The crack in the back slowly widens so one of 1" to 4" should do it.   No bolts on top. Tie off a tree and salal bushes than scramble down to the east.

routes.fa: Jeff Thomson, Will Stanhope, Jeremy Blumel 2005
routes.description: A nice slab route with a difficult section at the 2nd or 3rd bolt, easing off thereafter.  Similar climbing to the other routes here.
routes.location: This slab route start close to the water (right of Lost Horizon) and trends gently right, crossing Bikini Bottom towards the top.
routes.protection: 8 bolts with a few small pieces of gear (to 1")

routes.description: Traverses the face out to swept away.  Just above the water and feels very thrilling.  Big hardware along the way for the faint of heart.
routes.location: Start where the ground meets the water!

routes.description: A great fac/slab climb, with good moves from a belay above the water.
routes.location: The first belay bolts on the traverse.  Possible to do this from the ground, but better if the belay is on the face.

routes.description: Face climb at the far end of the slab.
routes.location: All the way out the traverse, which can be as exciting at the climb itself!

routes.description: Start the same as Bubble Buddy and Bikini Bottom.  Move left early in the pitch.  Crux low.
routes.location: 8 bolts.  Small pro.

description: The AMO Wall is a fun area with excellent moderate multi-pitch slab climbing.  The Advanced Military Operations (AMO) Wall is north (left) of Shannon Falls and is approached from the same parking area, but follows a path toward the falls  and past the gift shop, whereas the Shannon Falls area is approached by walking south out of the parking lot. Routes on the AMO Wall are mostly bolted and multi-pitch with fixed anchors, but are difficult to see due to the forest of trees and lush vegetation.
getting_there: From the Shannon Falls parking lot hike past the gift shop and turn left at the fork. Continue north to another fork in the path and take the gravel path, toward the Chief. Look for a faint climbers trail just north of the dry streambed, marked with orange tape. Follow the trail through the forest as it curves around and eventually leads south to the base of the AMO Wall.

routes.description: At first glance most of the routes on the right side of the AMO Slab appear to be about 5.8. At least that's what we thought as we started up A Balancing Act between rain squalls. Scramble up the initial apron, avoiding any moss that might be adhering to the slab. Move right onto the prominent dike that snakes its way up the steepening slab. Follow the dike as it trends up and right. The choice is yours, but one can either utilize the dike for handholds or footholds. We opted to crimp the edge of the dike to climb the slab past 8 bolts.
routes.location: N/A

routes.fa: Chris Lawrence, Brian Jones, Andre Ike, 2000
routes.description: AWOL offers an alternative to the 5.6 second pitch of Relish Route. From the belay in the scoop (not the low hangers-only anchor by the stump), traverse right through a steep slab with small dimples to gradually easier terrain. It's easy to go too high after clipping the first bolt and miss the edges you're meant to follow. The book rates this as 5.10a while noting that it is hard for the grade, which I would agree with--it's a great exercise in techy traversing. To me it felt noticeably harder than Women in Comfortable Shoes, and the features are reminiscent of One Scoop or the last pitch of Hairpin. Adding The Beaten Zone, which begins just above the end of this pitch, makes for a better value multi than just sticking to Relish Route. Get on it!
routes.location: Climb pitch one of The Relish Route to the higher set of anchors in the scoop, with the rap chain. AWOL is the bolt line trending right from there. It finishes just below The Beaten Zone.

routes.fa: Chris Lawrence, Brian Jones, Andre Ike 2009
routes.description: Excellent diagonal pitch.  Gains the summit and provides a nice view of Shannon Falls.  Rappelling down is clean but you have to watch your rope ends VERY carefully with a 60m rope.
routes.location: Start off the upper ledge just right of Petra.  AMO Wall

routes.fa: Chris Lawrence, Brian Jones, Andre Ike 2009
routes.description: This is the left-most pitch off the upper ledge and is about 10m left of the third pitch of The Relish Route.  Technical and fun traversing dyke feature.
routes.location: AMO Wall.  (Advanced Mountain Operations)

routes.description: P1 - Paddle up the mossy and gritty slab to an anchor on a vegetated shelf.   P2 - Work up on the glassy smooth slab to the right end of a ramp-like feature below a headwall. Pull the awkward headwall and continue up and left through a gap in the vegetation to the anchor, in the middle of an expansive slab.  P3 - Continue up the slab and pull over a short, vertical wall on bouldery moves.   P4 - Pull through a low crux and paddle up the slab to the anchors, at the top of the cliff.
routes.location: Right side of the AMO Wall. 50 feet left (north) of "A Balancing Act."
routes.protection: Bolts & chain anchors (P1 - 5 bolts, P2 - 7 bolts, P3 - 4 bolts, P4 - 7 bolts).

routes.description: This route climbs off the upper ledge about 15m right of 3rd pitch of The Relish Route.  It can be done in one pitch but in keeping with the spirit of the wall , it's been set up as a multi-pitch.  It's good training for managing traverses.   Pitch 1: 5.9, 6 bolts, 66 feet.  Difficult moves passing the first bolt lead to easy padding.   Pitch 2: 5.7, 3 bolts, 49 feet.  Traverse right , step up to top of wall at first opportunity.
routes.location: AMO Wall

routes.fa: Chris Lawrence, Brian Jones, Andre Ike 2009
routes.description: This popular climb scales the wall in 3 pleasant pitches.  It's a good multi-pitch climb for beginners, especially when combined with the last pitch of The Beaten Zone.   Pitch 1: 5.7, 8 bolts, 92 feet.  Tricky move between bolt # 1 and 2 followed by easier climbing along a crack.  Move up and left towards a stump and then climb the glassy slab above to a belay in a scoop.  *They have added a bolt to create a station for those who wish to break this into two pitches to avoid rope drag.  **A variation Muchel onto Ehrr 5.9 veers right at bolt #3, surmounts a cruxy slab then heads left back into The Relish Route.   Pitch 2: 5.6, 4 bolts, 72 feet.  Follow bolts up and left, staying right of the dark streak.  Belay on big ledge.   Pitch 3: 5.8, 7 bolts, 72 feet.  Climb directly above the chains.  Tricky mantel around a short steep wall completes the route.  Either rappel or take Shortcut 5.4 to reach the hikeout.
routes.location: Amo Wall

routes.fa: Hamish, Katie & Jeff Thomson, Jeremy Blumel, 2012
routes.description: Bolts added above The Relish Route to avoid mossy scramble to get to hike out.
routes.location: Above The Relish Route Amo Wall.

routes.description: I haven't climbed this in ages, but I'm adding it because this route should get more traffic since it's quite good. If anyone reading this can fill in more details, chuck them in the comments or use the "Suggest Change" feature.I climbed this back in 2015 during my first real season in Squamish. My memory of it isn't super clear, but what I do remember is that this was my favourite slab route from that summer. After having some really marginal experiences on other slabs (I'm looking at you, Local Boys!), doing something challenging but well-bolted was a real pleasure. If you enjoy the slabby traversing on Born Again or the Spirit of Squamish, you'll probably like this.P1. 5.8 - Straight up the slab.P2. 5.11a - Go right. Enjoy the relatively tight bolting.Rap with a single 60m rope.
routes.location: Next to Into the Mystic.

description: This steep angled cliff lays to the right of Shannon Falls Wall.
getting_there: Continue on the approach trail past Shannon Falls Wall following fixed lines. Near the far right end of the wall look for a trail branching sharply to the left.

routes.fa: Sean Pickersgill, Bryan Kent, Joel Beckmann, Taran Ortlieb
routes.description: Fantastic new addition. Steep, varied climbing and a nice departure from the usual Squamish corner. All bolted anchors.P1 - Easy face climbing leads to a short, steep tight hands/finger crack. 5.10-. Small ledge for the belay.P2 - Fun chimney/slot with good gear. Felt about 5.9 tops to me. Huge belay ledge.P3 - The money pitch. Climb the steep finger/hand crack until the little roof. While it looks like it should go up the corner, the climb tackles the short tight hand crack that angles right up the headwall. As that crack ends, step left onto a small ledge. Continue stepping left into the corner. The move stepping into the corner is a bit committing with your gear down and right of you (be sure to use slings). Find gear near the rock scar and make a face move out of the corner and slab up past a bolt to the top. The topo shows the crux as the face move exiting the corner, but I thought the crux was the angling hand crack. A long pitch, though the final 50' is easy.More details available at Squamish Climbing Forum
routes.location: Continue right past Skywalker for about 10 minutes until you come to a nicely made belay platform just left of the trail.

routes.description: This route is really good. Its getting dirty and needs more traffic so go and do it.Theres a chimney, good jamming, and even some jugs!!
routes.location: Starts in the big obvious chimney to the left of Chewbacca.pull on the fixed line to get to an anchor and a belay seat(stump).start from there.
routes.protection: Good pro all the way, double rack is more than enough.

routes.description: A spectacular and very sustained climb with great movement on face and crack.  Can be done in one long pitch with good rope management.   P1. 5.10b Climb the initial crack onto a platform.  Make slabby moves left to the base of a steep dihedral.   P2. 5.11b Climb the technical dihedral to the roof, traverse right towards a block making sure that your pro has long enough slings to avoid rope-drag.  Layback up the very strenuous right-facing dihedral clipping three bolts along the way.  Finally, power up the relentless corner crack.   Note that McLane's 2005 book has the route numbering mixed up with Hunter's Moon.  Hungry wolf is number 332 on the topo and Hunter's Moon is 231.
routes.location: This is near the south end of the wall, before it curves to face south.  As you are scrambling uphill towards the base of Man of Leisure, a side trail breaks up and left to head back north.  A quick scramble takes you to a little platform below a wide crack.
routes.protection: Many small to medium nuts and finger to tight hand cams.  A double set to hand size is advisable.   To descend, with double ropes you can rap the route or Man of Leisure, otherwise walk down east and then south.

routes.description: To the left of Hungry Wolf is the somewhat improbable line of Hunters Moon. Same start as Hungry wolf, but continue out left past the big ledge below Hungry Wolf p2 to the arete. A hidden dike will appear on the arete just after the tricky slab move and offer temporary sanctuary. Clip the single bolt in the dike. From the awkward dike continue out right and up the thin crack that becomes a seemingly impossible flare. Some creative thinking sees you through this short but interesting section. Continue on up a slab to a treed ledge below a 5.10 face crack(p2-often dirty), ascend this to the shared anchors of Hungry Wolf.
routes.location: Gobsmacking Wall. See Hungry Wolf description.
routes.protection: Doubles to #1 Camalot, one #2. Much thin.

routes.description: share the start with Hungry Wolf to the first belay stance located in the dihedral below the staircase of awesome roofs! Lycanthropy starts by stemming up the beautiful dihedral until met with the first roof, lean out and clip a shiny bolt and get ready to become a WOLF MAN! Smear, layback, hand jam, knee bar and pinch your way up the roofs past another couple bolts which reward you with a final section of stellar crack climbing on deep secure locks with a great position as you crest the wall. From the fixed station either rappel back down to the ground in two rappels ( 60 meter rope works fine) or scramble to the top of the wall and walk south back to your gear.
routes.location: starts from the same ledge as the rest of the classics. Never Say Never, Hungry wolf, Flying squirrel to name a few. a fixed line or short easy scramble helps you gain the initial belay ledge.
routes.protection: 3 bolts and a single rack from .4 - 2 will be more than enough, an extra .75 could be useful.

routes.fa: Glen Payan, John Thompson, Jeff Thompson
routes.description: A long, high-quality route on beautiful stone.  It has some friction moves, some crack, some traversing on an intrusion/dyke, just about everything except an overhang.
routes.location: The far south end of the wall at Shannon Falls curves around to face more towards the south.  Walk along the base of the cliff from the falls area until it curves up and around to a very nice clearing below a smooth face.  The route up the cracks in the face is Poultry in Motion, the more rounded buttress on the left is Man of Leisure.  The trail isn't heavily used, so it may take some false starts to get there.
routes.protection: Mostly bolts but a small selection of finger and hand sized nuts and cams is necessary.  Descent by rappel (but note that the route is longer than 100 feet) or by walking around to the east then south.

routes.description: A sublime route.   A bit more technically difficult and heady than its bolted neighbor Hungry Wolf  (even though they share a similar grade in the guidebook),  Never Say Never may be one of the finest routes at the grade in Squamish IMHO. Start on a slab and into a corner that quickly steepens to overhanging. The crack begins as hands/fists and  narrows to fingers. The crux comes near the top of the corner as the locks become flaring, spaced out and insecure. Above the crack the difficulties continue...angle up and to the right on face features with finicky protection. Bolted Belay.   A thought provoking and demanding pitch. The gem of the crag.
routes.location: Gobsmacking Wall. See Hungry Wolf description.
routes.protection: Doubles to #2 Camalot & one #3. Small to Medium Stoppers and small cams(small alien off-sets are very nice)...heavy on fingers and smaller.

routes.description: From a belay bolt shared with Man of Leisure, move up and right into the finger crack. A long reach and delicate moves up and right bring you into another splitter hand and finger crack, which is followed to a slabby (bolted) topout.
routes.location: The far south end of the wall at Shannon Falls curves around to face more towards the south. Walk along the base of the cliff from the falls area until it curves up and around to a very nice clearing below a smooth face. The route up the cracks in the face is Poultry in Motion, the more rounded buttress on the left is Man of Leisure.
routes.protection: One set of nuts and doubles in cams from fingers to 1"

routes.description: Thin left facing corner with bolts and some small gear placements in the crack.  Some face climbing below then laybacking the thin crack and stemming the corner/some slab moves.  The crux is at the 3rd bolt.  Fun route that deserves more attention.  Longer than 35m so you won't be able to lower even with a 70m rope (not to mention it's just a tree with no tat at the top).
routes.location: The route to the right of Poultry in Motion/Man of Leisure.  You should see numerous bolts from below but be sure to bring some gear too.
routes.protection: #2 if you want to protect before the first bolt & small cams for above (I used an x4 .2 & c4 .4) + 5 draws and something to wrap a tree up top.

description: This new area holds lots of moderate pitches, ranging from a 2-pitch 5.6 crack up to 5.12a. Morning sun, afternoon shade. The backside has a great ambiance with the sound of Shannon Falls nearby, and no highway noise.The “Corner Unit” area has long pitches, a 60m just works for some but a 70m is needed for Condo Crack. If you want to climb Condo Crack with a 60m, walk off along the ridge to gain the descent trail from the frontside climbs back to your gear at the base.The backside has another 2-pitch 5.8 as well as some harder climbs 5.11-5.12. “Glacial Facial” is the standout pitch. “Baby Bum” 5.12d (Peter Croft roof crack) is just left of the “Groove Tube”.
getting_there: From the parking lot, take the Papoose Descent trail (left up short rope pull just after gravel steps, going right takes you to the frontside) for 5 mins. Take the obvious left fork below the base of the Corner Unit area. For the backside, continue 2 mins further along the base of the wall. 5-7 min approach from the car.

routes.description: The bolted line just left of "Call An Arborist" has a defined crux up high. Shared anchor with that route.
routes.location: Bolted line just left of the deep crack splitting the wall.

routes.description: Thin climbing that will feel hard if you're too far to the right. A good route for those thinking about trying friction climbs on the Apron such as "Slab Alley" or "Banana Peel" where trust in your shoes is a required prerequisite.
routes.location: Left most line on the wall

routes.description: Start climbing the obvious crack splitting the wall. Straight up, past a couple horizontal cracks and a tricky move left past a bolt (climbing too high will feel harder). 2 more bolts and gear to the top. Shared anchor with "Bidding War".
routes.location: The obvious deep crack splitting the wall

routes.description: Nice features through the slab lead to a thin crux at the 3rd bolt. Easier cracks above to the top.
routes.location: 3rd route from the right side of the wall

routes.description: An excellent novice multi-pitch crack climb with easy jamming, good gear, and fun movement.p1- Follow the obvious crack for 34 meters to a big ledgep2- Move belay 10m left to a bolted station at the base of the second pitch. Fun finger cracks climb past a couple horizontals to a ledge with unique views of the Chief.Rappel twice with a 70m rope (you'll need to reverse the ledge walk in between rappels) or walk off south along the ridge to pick up main descent trail.
routes.location: Backside of the Papoose. Follow the main descent trail for 5 mins to an obvious left fork just below the crag.
routes.protection: SR to 3", 70m ropeSome may find extra cams in the #.75-2 helpful.

routes.description: The right-most climb on the wall. Start up the crack and climb the long arête to a bolted anchor. A 60m rope just works, tie a knot in your rope.
routes.location: Backside of the Papoose. Follow the main descent trail for 5 mins to an obvious left fork just below the crag.

routes.description: Climb past two bolts to some easy, pleasant cracks up the rest of the wall. A thin friction move at the second bolt requires some trust in your shoes!
routes.location: Two routes over from the deep crack of "Call an Arborist"

routes.description: Nice climbing though face features and small cracks leads to a tricky move at the 3rd bolt. More broken cracks and a bolt lead to the top. Shared anchor with "Blown Budget"
routes.location: Second route from the right side of the wall

routes.description: The nice crackline to the left of "Condo Crack". Can be linked into that route, or finish at the independent station.
routes.location: Just left of "Condo Crack" on the other side of the tree.

routes.description: Climb easily up to a thin, bolted slab. Once above, take easier terrain up and left to a shared anchor with "Priced Out"
routes.location: Starts of the right edge of the highest belay platform. Two routes over from the obvious landmark of "Call an Arborist"

routes.description: Excellent face climbing on beautiful stone.Climb the short finger crack and mantle past a bolt. From the ledge, climb the steep headwall using crimpy pockets and seams in the smooth glacier polish. Move up and left over the bulge across an easier slab to the anchor. Save some finger-sized cams for after the last bolt.Can be top-roped by climbing "The Groove Tube" and moving right past the mid-way anchor.
routes.location: Backside of the Papoose. Follow the main descent trail for 5 mins to an obvious left fork just below the Corner Unit area. Continue past it for 2 mins to reach the backside climbs.
routes.protection: Bolts, SR to BD#1. A couple extra finger-sized cams may be helpful.

routes.description: Can be climbed as one long pitch (55m) with a few extra extendable draws.P1- Climb the polished, featured slab to a ledge. Over a bulge, up "the groove" to a tricky move past a bolt. Move right to the anchor on a ledge if breaking up pitches.P2- Continue up the handcrack until forced back right. Climb through some bulges to an anchor at the top of the wall. 2 rappels with a 60m get you back to the base.Alternate pitch- From the P1 anchor, climb up right through a steppy hand crack and some slabby bulges. Move back left to the anchor. 5.7
routes.location: Backside of the Papoose. Follow the main descent trail for 5 mins to an obvious left fork just below the Corner Unit area. Continue past it for 2 mins to reach the backside climbs.
routes.protection: SR to 2", a few extra pieces and extendable draws if linking into one 55m pitch (recommended)

routes.description: Takes the line of bolts up the steep, featured slab. at the 5th bolt, move left into the small dihedral system and a bolted anchor below the big ledge. A 60m rope just works from this station, tie a knot in the rope.
routes.location: Backside of the Papoose. Follow the main descent trail for 5 mins to an obvious left fork just below the crag.

routes.description: Climbs a direct line to the attractive handcrack. 3 bolts protect the moderate climbing to a ledge. from here, tricky slab climbing using pockets and dike holds gains the easy but fun crack. Pulling on the quickdraws at the crux brings the grade down into 5.10 A0 if you cant get your shoes to cooperate...A variation moves left from the hand crack to gain a separate finger crack and keeps things a little more sustained.
routes.location: Backside of the Papoose. Follow the main descent trail for 5 mins to an obvious left fork just below the Corner Unit area. Continue past it for 2 mins to reach the backside climbs.
routes.protection: Bolts, a few cams from #.75-2 for the crack

routes.description: Climb past a bolt to the short hand crack. Bolts and gear lead up the nice featured wall above.
routes.location: One route left of the Down Payment crackline.

routes.description: Friction climb past 4 bolts to some easier gear-protected moves. Face climbing up the steep wall past 3 more bolts leads to the anchor.
routes.location: Backside of the Papoose. Follow the main descent trail for 5 mins to an obvious left fork just below the Corner Unit area. Continue past it for 2 mins to reach the backside climbs.

routes.description: Climb the lightning-bolt shaped crack to its top and an exciting move to a horizontal. Two bolts climb through awesome pockets to the top. Great climbing for the grade!
routes.location: Starts to the right of the obvious crack line of "Call and Arborist"

routes.description: Climb the low-5th groove past a stump to a ledge. From here, move up left into a finger crack, avoiding the chimney. Be careful as rock quality in the chimney system is poor.Alternatively, from the ledge, climb further left protected by a small but bomber TCU to reach the nice handcrack of "Just Wanna Jam", but at a more modest grade of 5.9-ish
routes.location: Backside of the Papoose. Follow the main descent trail for 5 mins to an obvious left fork just below the Corner Unit area. Continue past it for 2 mins to reach the backside climbs.
routes.protection: SR to 3" include a small 0.5" TCU (green c3 or equivalent)

routes.description: Clip a bolt above the ledge and follow a short finger crack to its top. A small cam (green alien) protects moves above the first bolt. After this, bolts lead up the cool, pocketed slab above to a shared anchor with “Income Suite”. A 60m rope just works from this station, tie a knot in the rope.
routes.location: Backside of the Papoose. Follow the main descent trail for 5 mins to an obvious left fork just below the crag.
routes.protection: Bolts, light rack to #1 including alien-style cams

routes.description: A good test of your ability to believe in your shoe rubber comes at the 3rd bolt
routes.location: Fully bolted line, black bolts

routes.description: The righthand variation to Not To Slabby. Delicate, tricky, fun face climbing past two bolts. High quality; let me know if you have any info on this climb and I'll update this page.
routes.location: Just right of Not Too Slabby. Approach as for that climb.
routes.protection: Bolts. A hand sized cam at the top of the initial slab and a sub-finger sized cam between the top of the slab and the first bolt on the steep face. Might want a hand sized cam for the top part of the route.

description: This is the area you come to from the standard (only) approach. A relatively tall wall with lots of moderate cracks and slab climbing, with some steeper and more technical options interspersed between the obvious weaknesses.
getting_there: Head right just after the gravel steps at the trailhead. Going left is the descent trail and access to the backside crags.

routes.description: Three pitch climb up the middle of the Papoose. A classic route with high quality climbing and good variety.   P1. Follow finger cracks and groove trending left  (bolted) to a belay on the narrow, treed 'Moccasin Ledge'.   P2. Perfect hand jams up a groove on the left end of the ledge and through a small roof lead to wild stemming and twin finger cracks. From here, mantle up and left to the belay.   P3. Follow a delicated slab (bolts and small gear) to the top. This pitch is more runout than the first two.  This climb takes a line to the left of a major left-facing corner syst
routes.location: This route begins in the center of the Papoose and climbs to the left of a prominent left-facing corner at the same height as P2. The quick and easy walkoff (8 minutes) goes down and to the right. It's possible to rappel the route, but some shenanigans are encountered with a 60m rope, and you will likely bother other climbers.
routes.protection: Cams to 3" and a set of nuts

routes.description: Same start as Survival Enhancement but break out Left towards bolted rap station for Papoose One. I found there to be 2 cruxes:1st @ the start b/w B1 & B22nd (harder) near the top of the pitch, thin vertical slab, protected by 0.5 & 0.3. Clean fall, delicate slab footwork and technical sequencing.
routes.location: SR, rap station

routes.description: P1-P2 : Mercury Vapor and Transit of Venus traverseP3 : Clip the bolt just off the station, slight down climb and left  past 2 charcoal bolts. Clip another bolt and follow and horizontal crack until you find more charcoal bolts. (10b, 35m)P4: Foot traverse with a few bolts. (5.7, 30m)P5 : Foot traverse, from the last bolt slightly left and up to join the chain of Hanging Garden. (5.8, 20m) It's easy to link P4 and P5https://quickdrawpublications.com/wp-content/uploads/topos/Shannon_Falls_Forgive_Trespasses.pdf
routes.location: Start at transit of venus, far right of the Papoosehttps://quickdrawpublications.com/wp-content/uploads/topos/Shannon_Forgive_Trespasses.pdf

routes.fa: Tim Auger, Dan Tate, 1965. FFA: Don Serl, Vern Coulomb, Greg Yavorski, 1978
routes.description: First pitch (5.8) is a very interesting left traversing crack, and a wave like rock.Second pitch (10a) is the crux, a beautiful 10a thin hands/finder crack that goes left, up, and then right.Third pitch (5.9) goes straight up from belay through a 5.9 bulge/roof, then up and left.Standard fourth pitch (5.6R) goes left and up on unprotected 5.6 slab until gaining 5.6 cracks and moving back to the right.Alternate fourth pitch (5.11a) goes straight up on bolts,                     .Fifth pitch (5.10a) follows bolts up a slab.To descend, walk off north (climbers left) on well maintained trail.
routes.location: The route starts near the center of the Papoose. Look for the obvious traversing first pitch. It is very striking and hard to miss.
routes.protection: 2.5 inch and smaller. You will need some runners for the first pitch.

routes.fa: FA John Coope 1965, FFA Kris WIld 2012
routes.description: An old aid line scrubbed with love by Kris Wild last year. Unfortunately, despite it being completed months before the publication of the new Select guide, it didn't make it in (for space reasons, I heard). Three pitches, each characterized by mostly straight-forward 5.8/5.9 crack climbing and distinct slabby crux sections that have a bolt at eye-level. If you aided each of the three bolts I'm sure it would go at 5.9 A0.    P1 (10-): Easy climbing up and left along some left-leaning crack systems. Mantle up into a no-hands rest, move up and left, then directly right underneath the bolt to some face moves. There's a positive water dimple you can get a few pads in, but my 5'6" girlfriend had a harder time than I did reaching it. Felt 5.10- to me, 5.hard for her. Mantle and scramble up and right to chain anchors below a handcrack.   P2 (10+): Left-facing corner. This is the reason you're climbing this route, because you love plugging gold Camalots in slammer hand cracks like a boss. Some great jamming for the first half, then a tricky traverse left past a bolt, then up a thinner crack up and right to chain anchors. This is the crux pitch, the traverse again was really hard for my short partner, she had to aid past the bolt.    P3 (10): Start up and right through some easy climbing up a low-angle dihedral, grab some jugs and clip the bolt. A technical section follows up and left through some shitty finger locks and pinches up to a mini-jug. Onwards and upwards through easier ground and then up through an offwidth (I used a #4 Camalot, but it looks like there are bolts to the right you could mess around with up some features if you don't have anything wide.) Up some face moves to chain anchors.    We rapped off (3 raps with a 60), but apparently you can walk to the left from the anchor and join up with the descent trail. I can't testify to how easy that is, it didn't look particularly well-trodden today.   Good fun, obviously a ton of work went into scrubbing this route. That being said, the combination of some larger trees up high (which need a chainsaw) and the low traffic due to not being so well advertised is leading to a slow buildup of pine needles and leaves in the cracks. This needs traffic so it doesn't get overgrown again before the new McLane guide, so go climb it as a public service to all.    You can read a trip report and check out some photos here:  supertopo.com/tr/Hanging-Ga…
routes.location: The first obvious route you see when walking along the Papoose approach trail. The p2 handcrack stands out and screams at you that it's being neglected and that you need to climb it.
routes.protection: SR from blue metolius to #4 Camalot, doubles from .5 to #2 were nice. Chain anchors.

routes.description: A cruxy thin start leads to an enjoyable hand and finger crack above.
routes.location: This crack is right of Mushroom. We approached it via Mushroom by following a faint trail through blue berry bushes.

routes.description: I've described this climb using a 'new' 1st pitch (as opposed to P1 of Survival Enhancement)   P1 (10d):  Use some fancy footwork to finesse a seam past two bolts until a reachy move secures a great finger lock.  Continue up easy crack to a 3rd bolt and trend hard left to the anchors (same ones as those of Survival Enhancement). 20m   P2 (11b):  Climb easy cracks for about 40' until you can clip a bolt in white, smooth rock.  Make a tough move through a small roof and continue up on good finger locks to a 2nd, larger roof.  This roof is actually easier than the first - there is a rusty old pin under the overhang but a huge jug allows you to place a bomber cam over the roof.  Another 20' of easy climbing gets you to the anchor (35m)   P3 (10a):  Continue up the crack as it trends left, eventually it peters out and a bolt protects a face move to the anchors.  The guidebook has this pitch at 10d but there is no way....it is 10a at the most.  (25m).   P4 (10a):  move right from the station and climb past 4 bolts to the top.  10m   Descent:  either walk off to the north or locate the anchor atop Centrefold and rap as for that route
routes.location: Starts 5m left of Centrefold
routes.protection: I'd recommend a double rack to 1" and a single yellow and blue camalot

routes.description: Yet another fun linkup on the Papoose!   P1 is Mecury Vapour.  Start of the belay platform about 80' to the right of Centrefold. There was a fixed rope in 2013, though it is certainly not needed.  Two bolts and gear will get you the anchors, which are annoying placed far higher than the ledge.  Not sure why....   Crazy fun and LONG traverse for P2.  Very sustained climbing at 5.9.  You definitely want your second to be comfortable at the grade, though it is protected fine for leader and follower.  Skip TWO sets of anchors and belay at the base of the corner.   Entering the corner was the crux of the pitch for me. Seemed 5.10a.  Of course, my wife just stepped left and made it easier.  I guess I missed that option.  Good gear and relatively easy climbing (5.7/5.8) to the anchor.   Run up the slanting crack past gear and two bolts and eventually clip the final bolt on Centrefold.  Gently pad left on the glacier polish up to the sloping small ledge, and then back right to the anchor.  These whole final section is definitely run-out, just a heads up and be solid at 5.8/5.9 slab.
routes.location: 100' right of Centrefold.
routes.protection: Standard rack to #2 camalot.  I placed a #3 a couple of times, though one could probably do without.  I placed lots of offset nuts (medium size) on the p3 corner.

routes.description: Fun, sporty single pitch right of Centrefold. Pitch of the day for us, a pleasant surprise. I went with some gym climbers who all agreed it was easier than Mushroom, though I disagree. Neat moves do all seem quite gymnastic and balancy rather than jam-intensive.   Start up and right past two bolts through some balancy, well-protected moves. Trend straight upwards along the crack through a short but thought-provoking roof, then haul your way to the anchors through big holds.
routes.location: Starts twenty meters right of Centrefold around the boulder. Fixed rope takes you to the base of the route, maybe five meters above the trail.
routes.protection: Two bolts then standard rack to a #3 Camalot

routes.description: Mushroom is the splitter thin hands crack on the far right side of the Papoose. Not to be missed if climbing at this crag. It's difficult for the grade if you aren't used to pure jamming and no face holds. Sustained at a thin-hand/ringlock size, it could be thought of as the easier twin to "Hand Jive" at the lower malamute.
routes.location: From the base of the Centerfold, Papoose one, etc follow the only trail for a couple minutes further to the right, and this obvious crack will come into view.
routes.protection: Many pieces in the .5 and .75 camalot size. You would probably be ok with doubles if you are comfortable with short runouts. Singles of smaller cams and a #1, and #2 (BD Sizes) will round out the rack. There are nice new  fixed carabiners at the top of the route, don't run endless TR laps through them though.

routes.fa: J. Howe, R. Barley, G Woloski
routes.description: Really fun new addition to the Papoose.  As good as any of the other routes there in my opinion.   All the traverses are well protected for leader and follower.   P1 - Start up Centrefold and at the first bolt start traversing left.  Skip the intermediate anchor and go all the way to the nice ledge below the chimney/slot pitch of Papoose One.  Two bolts plus a variety of gear.  I placed a #3 on the way to the last bolt, but a #4 could be placed a bit higher.  Some fun "walk the plank" moves!  I ended up approaching the last bolt from below rather than foot traversing, but I'm not sure it was the easy way.     P2 - Great pitch of intriguing face climbing.  All bolted until the final short crack to the Hairpin anchor.   The moves across the traverse are really cool.     P3 - Easy 5.7 hand crack to the right, past the Papoose One belay, up to a new belay above the small roof.   P4 - Enjoyable and well protected face climbing all the to the top.  After the last bolt head up and trend right joining the finishing moves of Centrefold.  Gear is required getting to the first bolt and a green camalot can be placed in a final horizontal at the top to protect the second and take the sting off the final Centrefold 5.7 runout.   Topo and details available (2013) Quickdraw Publications
routes.location: Start up Centrefolkd but traverse left after the first bolt.   We rapped Centrefold with a 70m in three raps straight down.  A 60m route would NOT make the first rap, as a 70m just made it.
routes.protection: Plenty of bolts, but a rack is required.  Most climbers could get by with a single rack from finger size to #3 camalot.  I was happy to have two #1s and #2s camalots on the first pitch.

routes.description: P1 - Start at for 'Hairpin', climbing the first traverse pitch. 5.8   P2 - climb the 'Hairpin' crack about halfway to a small alcove, then make a tenous traverse left into a hard leaning fingercrack. Battle your way up the crack with decent locks but bad feet until you reach a belay below the obvious roof/overlap feature. 5.11b   P3 - Clip a bolt and pull a V5/6 boulder problem to gain good locks near the lip of the roof/overlap. Swing your foot up over the lip, look down at the ground, let out 'whoop' and pull the wild moves over the lip! A short easy crack leads to the belay. As short pitch. 5.12b   Rap from here, one 60M rope will do. Or continue up another dirty looking pitch of 5.7 A2? as for 'Hallucination'.
routes.location: Starts the same as 'Hairpin' in the center of the Papoose. Look for a roof like feature with a thin crack. That is the crux.
routes.protection: Gear to 2 inches. Heavy on the small sizes.

routes.fa: Fred Beckey, Eric Bjornstad, 1961. FFA: Eric Weinstein, Anders Qurom, 1974
routes.description: A nice option if Centerfold is busy. Shares the same start as Centerfold,P1 (easy 5.10a).P2 (5.8) traverse left and climb an awkward crack.P3 (5.10b) climb up an awkward chimney protected by a bolt.P4 (easy 5.8) traverse left then right, or alternatively climb a 5.11a bolted face straight up                     . P5 either go straight up on slab (5.9) or follow the dirty crack (5.10a).
routes.location: Shares the same start as Centerfold.
routes.protection: Up to 2 inches, full set of nuts. There is a bolt on p1, p3, and a handful on the p5 slab variation pitch.

routes.fa: FA (via right start) Ed Cooper, Dave Hiser, 1961; FFA (via right start) Don Serl, John Witmayer, 1978; FFA (p1 direct) John Howe, Blake Robinson 1980;
routes.description: Great alternative to Centerfold that includes more crack climbing. The 4th pitch described here is not part of the original route, but appears to have been bolted as part of a newer route called Mercurial Crossing (or The Transit of Venus in other places).p1: (same as Centerfold p1) climb cracks to a thin bolt protected crux corner, then more cracks to a ledge. Gear anchor. 5.10b.p2: (first 2/3rds same as Centerfold p2) climb an easy hand vertical hand crack (5.8?), and then a crux flare followed by a hand traverse left a few feet and and a mantle. Surmount a bulge and then trend right up an easy ramp to a bolt anchor under a roof. Beware the gigantic hollow flake on the ramp; you probably don't want to place pro behind it. 5.10b.p3: clip a bolt up and left from the anchor, then face climb left to good holds then up and back right to gain left leaning corner. Climb the corner to bulge with a bolted anchor above. The corner looks intimidating from below, but there are lots of face holds for feet, making it mostly ~5.8 after the crux start. 5.10a.p4: (not part of the original Pin Up route, but definitely recommended) climb left slanting thin crack first on gear and then three bolts. After the last bolt, follow the path of least resistance left, up, and then back right on an easy ramp. This last part is unprotected ~5.7R slab, and is the end of Centerfold p3. 5.9.
routes.location: Shares the first pitch of Centerfold.
routes.protection: Standard rack to 3'', with small cams very useful on p2.

routes.description: Survival Enhancement is yet another excellent route at the Papoose, offering a well-protected variety of crack and slab climbing.   P1 (11c): Climb a crack to a bolt at about 10' and make a tricky mantel move.  Link discontinuous cracks for another 30' until some thin slab takes you out right past a couple of bolts.  Trend slightly left to the anchor. (20m)   P2 (11b): Climb the hand crack for about 40' until you can clip a bolt located in a patch of very smooth white rock.  Move up to a horizontal break on good holds and make a long reach to a so-so finger lock that is used to pull the mini-roof. Once over the roof, move right onto the face in an airy position and climb past two bolts to join the top of P2 of Centrefold.  A great pitch (30m)   P3 (10a):  Climb the 3rd pitch of Centrefold.   Descent:  either walk off to the north, or 4 30m raps will get you down
routes.location: The start is located 10m left of Centrefold.  It is identified by a single bolt at about 10'.  Note:  there is a new climb about 5m left of Centrefold (with 2 bolts down low).  This pitch goes at about 10d and will also get you to the top of P1
routes.protection: A single rack from blue Metolius to #2 Camalot, with doubles for the finger size stuff

description: Marked by the obvious, large roof feature, this wall is passed on descent from any of the main climbs on the Papoose. 100m uphill from the fork that leads to the Corner Unit area and the Backside climbs.
getting_there: Take the descent trail uphill for about 5 minutes. Where an obvious trail leads left, continue straight for 100m to the wall. Or, stop by on your way down from a climb on the frontside.

routes.description: The bolted shallow crack-groove line provides a great, moderate sport route. A quick tick for those in the area and a nice warm-up for the other routes here.
routes.location: Just uphill of the big roof feature

routes.description: Start up “The Apprentice”. At the third bolt, climb left across face features past two more bolts to reach the awesome, aesthetic undercling traverse. Move left along it for 5 meters, clip a bolt, and mantle up through two overlaps. Easier cracks lead to the anchor above.
routes.location: Climbs the right side of the giant roof feature, starting on The Apprentice

routes.description: This line climbs through the centre of the obvious roof. Start up a well-featured face past 2 bolts to gain the crack that splits the overhang. Much easier than it looks from below!
routes.location: The centre of the big roof on the descent trail

description: Home to the classic "Enter the Crackn'"
getting_there: Walk along the entrance road from the parking lot, cross the creek and find a trail that heads south in the wood. Follow the well established trail until it's blocked with trees. Instead of heading left as for Skywalker and Spirit of Squamish, walk over the blockage and keep following the trail. At a fork keep left and you should see the boulders on your left.

routes.description: The obvious offwidth roof. Start at the back of the cave and use a handstand position to get started.
routes.location: As for the area or use the coordinates 49.6675470, -123.1617320

description: The obvious slab face to the right of Shannon Falls, home to many Squamish classics.
getting_there: From the Shannon Falls parking lot walk back long the road towards the highway looking for a trail to the left just after the bridge.

routes.description: Climb the obvious slab and cracks gaining the left facing corner groove.  Bolts begin where the hand crack ends.  Fun stemming up a grooved slab.  Finish at the rap anchor or climb through to top of pitch 6.
routes.location: Pitch 5 of Spirit Of Squamish.  On the far right side of the wall.

routes.description: Aladdin's Magic Lamp starts 10 meters right of Skywalker and ascends a dike that trends up and right, then goes vertical. The dike is great fun and goes at 5.10-; the rest can be aided to the top. It's a bit dirty, but would improve with traffic. Well bolted.
routes.location: 7-8 bolts

routes.description: A bonafide legend of Squamish climbing, Carl Austrom pioneered much of the terrain around Shannon Falls, The Apron and more while leading onsite, hand drilling his way up into the unknown. He had placed hex-head rivets from free stances or hooks, requiring wired nuts to be slung over them as pro. A bold, unique style that most can only imagine as much of the stone was likely (even back then) covered in lichen and needed brushing, all while on the sharp end. While never reaching the top of this section of the wall he did indeed find some truly excellent climbing, primarily on dykes, in a picturesque setting and for that we all owe our respect. This route has humbly been established using modern top-down tactics, searching for the best free-climbing line with a respect to the style of the wall. As far as locations of bolts, typically they are placed from good stances, and not as often on easier ground.Carls rusted rivets on the second pitch, part of a climb he called “I Wanna Be Teased”, were replaced one-for-one with modern stainless bolts. Start on a perfect granite ledge above the river.Pitch 1 (10d, 5 bolts + gear) From the ledge, climb up past a bolt to a horizontal break. Mantle up and climb a sustained, excellent dyke past bolts to the anchor.Pitch 2 (11c, 6 bolts + gear) “I Wanna Be Teased”  Continue up the beautiful dyke on easier ground to where the wall steepens. Move right to a good stance, clip a bolt, and pull the bouldery crux on small edges. Continue past a couple more bolts to the anchor. Carl had rated this pitch 11a when he did it in 1984, but a large broken flake stance at the crux has bumped the grade.Pitch 3 (10b, 3 bolts + gear) Climb dykes to the right and link into the “Dark Matter” finger crack. Finish as for that pitch.Pitch 4 (11b, 12 bolts) Climb left along dykes across the wall to an increasingly exposed position above the falls. Sustained movement through amazing small pockets and edges on the face above lead to the top. Fully bolted, leave the rack at the belay.Rappel trending climbers right to reach an intermediate anchor, and rappel the rest of the route back to the base or to the Klahanie area. A 60m rope works well.
routes.location: From the bottom of the log steps just before you arrive at the Klahanie Crack area, a new trail leads left along the base of the wall to reach the start of "Liftoff". Just beyond, a perfect granite ledge is the base area for this route and "Cafe Direct"

routes.description: This 50m pitch of face climbing holds one of the best dyke features on the wall. The last 10m were again established on lead by Carl Austrom in 1984 as part of a route called “Cafe Flesh”. His rivets were replaced one-for-one with modern hardware. Starting on P1 of “The Austrom”, once at the horizontal break, traverse the crack out left until its end. Mantle up and pull a thin move past a bolt to gain the immaculate dyke and follow it upwards. As it fizzles out, face holds appear and provide sustained climbing up the steeper wall to the anchor. A great pitch! Rappel twice using the P1 anchor on “The Austrom”. Bring lots of draws and mindfully extend pieces, as the bolt line wanders slightly near the end. Include some small gear.
routes.location: Shared start with "The Austrom"

routes.description: A nice hand crack. Worth a little more attention than it receives. Could use a litle cleaning in the crack but still fun as is.
routes.location: Just left of a steep treed gully, about 15 feet to the right of Klahanie crack. Starts up an easy left facing corner then up into a hand crack.
routes.protection: Cams .5 to #2 Camelots and nuts. Save a #1 or #2 for the top. Can be rapped to a treed gully above and to the right of the start with a 60m rope.Copied from comments below so people don’t miss it: “TIE KNOTS AT THE END OF THE ROPE IF YOU PLAN ON BEING LOWERED OR RAPPING”

routes.fa: Jean-Marc Savoie, Ryan Larkin, Paul Greenwood - 2015
routes.description: New multipitch that starts on Cardhu Crack and keeps going. A mix of different styles and difficulties.This could use some traffic. It was fairly dirty when we climbed it, though I imagine we were one of the first parties of the season. Plenty of pine needles and detritus caught in the cracks, so take a nut tool as you climb.P1: Cardhu Crack. You'll want to climb past the Cardhu anchors up to a ledge with rap rings. (5.8, 45m)P2: Climb up and right, then traverse left along an easy hand crack on a ramp. Tree anchor. (5.6, 15m)P3: Climb right up a diagonal finger crack. The FAist describes this as a hand crack, but you'd need pretty small hands for that to be accurate. Balancy and tough - will get easier when it cleans up with more traffic, but will get harder again when the stumps eventually fall out. When clean, this will be a very nice line. Bolt anchor, belay in a hole. (5.10-, 25m)P4: The crux pitch is a beautiful and sustained line with tough, engaging climbing. Traverse right, clip a bolt, chimney up through easier ground on larger gear. Clip two more bolts as you begin tackling the main feature: a thin seam in a little mini-dihedral (like two inches of left-facing corner) . Looks improbable for the grade as the seam is almost slammed shut, but eventually the crack does open up slightly to take some small gear (yellow C3s to purple C3s). After your first piece of gear, tips locks and eventually a finger lock or two begin to reveal themselves as the angle eases up. The crack peters out at the top, so slab climb past 2 more bolts at a mid-10 grade.This pitch is very balancy and technical in nature. I'd read that you could easily aid through the thin section, but I don't know - you probably could aid through it with enough RPs, but this isn't a french-free-through-a-few-moves sort of pitch. Bolt anchor. (5.11-, 40m)P5: Climb a short, steep and juggy right-leaning crack to a tree above the belay. Slab and a cool dyke traverse up to the bolt-anchors. 2 bolts, and few cracks for gear every now and then. (5.9 - 35m)P6: Walk into the forest, then climb a fun, long and easy pitch. Starts off sporty, with many jugs and foot holds and lots of different gear options. As you climb higher, the pitch becomes lower angle and slabbier in nature. Near a bolt there is a 5.8 slab move. I think there was 2 bolts on this pitch, but there may have been 3. Bolt anchor. (5.8 - 40m).To descend, traverse left, then right up a ramp. From there a faint trail leads south to the Skywalker walk-off.
routes.location: Start up Cardhu Crack, the rightmost crack in the Klahanie Crack neighbourhood.
routes.protection: Double rack from red C3 to #2 Camalots, single #3 Camalot, green C3 and purple C3. Slings for the upper pitches.

routes.description: A great addition as a short yet worthy cragging route, climbing the obvious, well-featured finger crack that starts above Jeannine Ledge. Two rappels get back to the base area.Pitch 1 (5.8, 3 bolts + gear) As for Interstellar P1.Pitch 2 (10b, 2 bolts + gear) Climb the fun finger crack up to face moves at the top past 2 bolts. Lower down and belay from Jeannine Ledge in comfort.
routes.location: Start up "Local Girls" p1 and continue to the obvious Jeannine Ledge, left-most route at the Klahanie area, or by climbing "Liftoff"

routes.fa: Jan Wasylyk, Bryce Bateman, Paul McSorly - 2000
routes.description: Slanting left, wider route that branches out left from the start of Cardhu Crack and blazes its own less fun trail. When I did it last week it was quite wet inside the crack, with thriving bryophyte ecosystems deep within. Climb Cardhu instead if it's an option.   Oh, and watch the ends of your rope when you lower as the route's pretty long (shorter than Cardhu, but the ground below the anchors of Dirty Dickey is lower than it is under Cardhu). You might want to lower off to the right, even with a 70m.
routes.location: Start as for Cardhu, climber's right of the crag. Branch left to the obvious wide crack line after three or four meters.
routes.protection: It gets wide, but you don't need wide gear because when it's wide it's kind of flary and unprotectable anyways.
