Descent: From the top, move right about 20m to a rap station.  5 raps with 60m will get you down
routes.location: Follow the normal trail up to the Slahany, but branch left before reaching the main part of the cliff.  The route starts just left of a bolted pitch (start of White Feather).  If you hit Photophobia you've gone too far
routes.protection: A SR to 5" with doubles of purple/green/red camalots

routes.fa: pitch 1: Robin Barley, Peter Shackleton, Dave Jones, April 1983. Pitch 2: FFA: Peter Shackleton, 1984
routes.description: I am entering this route for the first pitch, which is 10a.  I had wanted to wait till I completed the second pitch, but the first pitch is so good, you have to do it.  The start can be wet and it is good to have a 70m rope.  The crux is the obvious roof, protects well.   The 2nd pitch is the 11a, and looks dirty.
routes.location: just left of Jungle Warfare.
routes.protection: A long pitch ( 35-40m) so lots of gear if you want to sew it up. A double rack to #2 camalot would do, with a set of nuts. The bulk of the pitch is finger size.  There is a good bolted rap station.   The 2nd Pitch has 2 bolts as well. It traverse up and right from the belay, runs into corner of Jungle Warfare in about 15-20m.

routes.description: A nice route easily identified by the large roof near its top. Climb the crack below the roof (a little dirty) to the roof, burl out the roof, then finish up the crack above to the anchor.
routes.location: A little way to the right of Godforsaken Land and where the trail from the road meets the cliff.
routes.protection: Gear to a #4 camalot ought to do.

routes.description: Fun link-up on the west side of Slhanay.P1 (10b) Climb Zig-Zag Crack. The crack is a bit dirty but the route provides good stemming. It's getting better as you go up. (~35 m)P2 (5.8) - p3 of the Jungle Warfare - go up and left up a ramp to a tree belay.P3 (5.10b) Move up underneath a roof and traverse right past a couple of fixed pitons to a bolted anchor on a ledge around the corner. This pitch is a bit dirty but still fun.P4 (5.10d) Face climb up past several bolts to a horizontal fault. Traverse right to a belay at Flight Simulator. This pitch is great!P5 (10d) A short vertical finger crack leads to an easier climbing. Quality!Finish as for Jungle Warfare and walk-off.
routes.location: Located between start of Jungle Warfare and Flight Simulator. Hard to miss.

description: While not endowed with a large number of climbs, this crag has several good, vertical to overhanging cracks.  This is a nice feature considering that the vast majority of Smoke Bluffs climbs aren't overhanging.   The classic "Split Beaver" (5.10b) is the main draw but don't miss the two 5.9s.
getting_there: Split Beaver is above the left side of Penny Lane.  It's reached by going up the stairs near Pixie Corner and taking a side trail to the right at the top of the stairs.  After a few hundred feet a small trail will break of to the left at which point the crag ought to be visible.  If you missed the left, you'll know you've gone too far if you end up at Ronin's Corner.

routes.description: Pull over an initial bulge and start jamming up a gently but continuously overhanging and continuously widening crack.  As it widens the usual difficulties transitioning from hands to fists are encountered, but it's when the fists get rattly that you earn it.   Apparently it can be done with fists only if you have very big hands.  I needed two fist and palm stacks to finish it.   Once you're through the widest part there's a ledge with an anchor, or you can continue up another 20 ft of easier climbing to another anchor.   Mike Hengeveld used to have a good write-up and pictures of climbing this route, but his website seems to be off the air now.  UPDATE: it's still around, just at a different address
routes.location: Once you're at the crag, there is no mistaking which climb is Split Beaver.
routes.protection: This crack will take one or two every size of cam from .75" to 5" but it's not so long that doubles are warranted. You can gauge it from the bottom.  Bolted rap anchor.

routes.description: This climb has been cleaned fairly recently and stays fairly dry even when other things are seeping.  The climbing is mostly moderate and the protection fairly straight forward.  Be mindful however, of the rope length when lowering with a line shorter than 70m.
routes.location: This route starts near the low point of the Split Beaver formation, down at it's lower right end.  The climb follows the crack system that ascends left of the blunt arete on a left-leaning crack system.
routes.protection: A double set of cams and nuts and a some long slings will get you to a bolt and chain anchor that can be lowered off of with a 70M rope.  A 60M is also reported to work, but I did not try it.

routes.description: Surmount a weird block and head up the right hand crack until it's possible to switch to the left hand crack and continue to the top.
routes.location: In the groove left of Orifice Fish (i.e. two climbs left of Split Beaver).
routes.protection: Standard rack, primarily the finger sized pieces.

routes.description: This is your warm-up for Split Beaver since the "other" climb here, Heavenly Ladder, isn't as physical.   There's no confusion about where to go, just head up the crack and be prepared for some contorted jamming despite the seemingly obvious nature of the crack.
routes.location: The is the obvious crack left of Split Beaver.
routes.protection: A standard rack will be entirely sufficient.  Bolts at the top.

routes.description: Steep slab about 15 meters to the right of Asleep at the Wheel
routes.location: 7 bolts + 2 anchors

routes.description: This climb is a little too short, but is good quality.  The detractor of height can be mitigated by clipping the anchor with a long runner and continuing onward into 'Asleep At the Wheel' at a rather consistent and continuous grade. Step up off of the ground (crux?) and into solid jams and cams onto the ledge with a chain anchor.
routes.location: This climb lies own 20 meters low and right from the Split Beaver Namesake climb.  A hand-crack splits a short section of off-vertical wall to a good ledge with a set of chain and ring anchors.
routes.protection: A single set of hand and wide hands cams... more if continuing onto 'Asleep At the Wheel.'

description: A very short cliff with some nice routes.  Very close to nearby residences.
getting_there: Go as for Burgers and Fries, but keep going to the far right-hand side.  When you get to the residence, take the stairs down.  When the trail gets to some rock slabs, look to your left.  The wall below the electrical tower is Alexis.

routes.description: The leftmost of three pleasant hand-cracks that form an "N". Very short, making the comfort level high. Gets you acquainted with a few wide fists, a few hands. Follow the diagonal all the way to the top for full value.
routes.location: Depends on which crack you choose, but there is gear up to about 4 inches on some.  Two sets of 2-bolt anchors at the top.  Rappel off.

routes.description: There are three pleasant hand-cracks that form an "N" are Alexis Cracks. This is the one on the right. A variation is to climb the diagonal to the top left.
routes.location: Go as for Burgers and Fries, but keep going to the far right-hand side. When you get to the residence, take the stairs down. When the trail gets to some rock slabs, look to your left. The wall below the electrical tower is Alexis.
routes.protection: Single rack. Two sets of 2-bolt anchors at the top. Rappel off.

routes.description: A bouldery start leads to several discontinuous cracks which lead to the top.
routes.location: Standard Rack

description: Shaded in the morning, but only worth the visit if better crags like Supervalue are too crowded.
getting_there: Easily accessed by scrambling past Supervalue and Boulder Gully, which are the first crags along the trail.

routes.description: Climb the crack-like feature in the middle of the wall.  Clip a low bolt and place a good cam in the horizontal crack 2/3s up.
routes.location: Middle of the wall.
routes.protection: 1 bolt, anchors. Nuts and cams to 1".   In addition, you can clip bolts belonging to the route to the left.

routes.description: Varied face climbing to a mantle 3/4s of the way up.
routes.location: Rightmost route.

routes.description: A little contrived as it is squeezed right next to Auntie Gravity. Avoid being lured into the crack.
routes.location: 3 bolts

description: This area seems to get a little less traffic, but is still very close to the trail and parking lot. It's a good choice on a weekend.
getting_there: Above and right of Upper Crag X. Cross the bridge, climb the stairs and hang right. After the short fixed rope you are there.(No fixed rope on the approach anymore, replaced with ladder.)

routes.description: Starts on the route Isaac Air Freight which is mislabeled with Chronicle Small Beer in the 2018 Squamish Rock Climbs. Climb the aesthetic hanging corner of IAF until you can pull out left on a thin crack on  the white, vertical wall. Get established on the slab above and crank/finesse through insecure moves along the vanishing crack. Good gear but the crux is obligatory. Climbed headpoint style but worthy of an onsight attempt with good gear and rests. Bring small cams and the jewelry. Big thanks to everyone who gets stoked on our new climbs and continue to encourage us. Much gratitude those who have contributed some of their hard earned dollars to the Sea to Sky Route Development gofundme campaign. Funds go directly to high quality bolts and anchors used on routes such as this.https://www.gofundme.com/seatoskyroutedevelopment
routes.location: Located on the independent crag left of the routes Joe Hill and Slipping Clutch left of The Black Zawn proper. Approach as for Black Zawn but pull up fat rope up a steep gully to a spacious ledge above the Sunny November sector.
routes.protection: Small cams up to .5 BD Small to medium nuts, offsets seemed useful.

routes.description: Much like 'Token Brits Direct’ Perfidious Albion is somewhat non-typical for Squamish. The rock on this wall tends to have pronounced angular features that lend more of a sport climbing style than the usual toe crushing, cuticle wrecking Squamish splitters.Begin up a dark slab with a crack feature with pods. This can be a little dirty, but not too bad. About 25 feet up is a large ledge and a well defined left facing corner on the right side. Crank some fun moves until you can roll over a bulge and traverse up and left into a steep right facing dihedral. The climbing here is very fun with technical athletic stemming. A final puzzle gets you up to the bolted anchors.
routes.location: this route starts just to the right of 'token brits direct'.  at the base of the wall, approximately in the center, there is a bit of flat staging area where the two routes start.  perfidious albion begins up a dark slab that has a poddy, leaning crack in it.
routes.protection: small stoppers/cams to hand sized pieces.  there is a fixed pin in a small opposing corner at the upper dihedral.  a good selection of slings is helpful.  bolted anchors.

routes.fa: Kevin McLane, Dave Lane, Bruce Kay
routes.description: This climb is unique for the area.  It is steep but has excellent holds.  The gear is good, but involves looking around a little more than other routes in the bluffs.  The bolted crux is balancy and tricky to onsight without knowing what the holds are like above.
routes.location: The left side of the Black Zawn wall.  Scramble up to the steep right-facing corner.
routes.protection: 2 bolts at the crux, chains at the top.

description: This is the crag that is directly above the the main parking lot.  It's sometimes overlooked in peoples' urgency to get to Penny Lane or Neat and Cool, but it's a good crag with some excellent climbs and cooler temperatures on the hottest days.  Supervalue is particularly good!
getting_there: From the south end of the parking lot, near the message board, take a short trail up to the base.  There is also a trail that comes in from climber's right from Crag X.

routes.description: The climb is a little less clean and less obvious for pro at the bottom where the climbing is easy, but offers more locks and clings up top than almost any other crack I've done, foot for foot. A great climb to learn finger crack technique and protection on, with great stances to get rest or gear placements.
routes.location: Perhaps 15 meters right of the popular 'Supervalue' crack there is a short low angle arete (Triage Arete) and then a northwest face that stays shaded until about 4PM. The left margin of this starts as a corner and turns into a good fingercrack with locks edges and rests. A very good climb overall.
routes.protection: A rack of small cams to 2" and a set or two of stoppers and 10 draws or slings gets you to a bolt and chain anchor.

routes.description: Crouching start.  Matched on the low protruding nose-shaped feature.  Reach left along the wall to a small crimp and from there up the overhanging wall above.
routes.location: North of Boulder Gully crag and West (below) Auntie Gravity crag in talus field.

routes.description: A 5.7 dihedral to the left of Triangle arete and Cold Comfort. A  bit dirty with some sections with dead leaves in the groove, but still a fun climb with funky chimney moves and stemming. About a third of the way up it splits left for the 5.9 and right for the 5.7. It's hard to see the anchor or pro as you get through the crux section, but it's all there. A little awkward but fun!
routes.location: Anchor with rap rings

routes.description: Climb the short slab on the left wall.
routes.location: Base of Supervalue left of Refrigerator

routes.description: Start with the obvious undercling crimp in the middle of the boulder and a crimp above, go straight up.
routes.location: Middle of the boulder.

routes.description: Start gripping the smooth, right facing corner feature.  Follow it up to the top.
routes.location: right of The Nose

routes.description: Hand and finger cracks that wind around the arete to the right of cold comfort.   Traverse right on easy edges to the right of cold comfort and lust. Gain the finger to thin-hand crack and continue upwards to a comfortable, sandy ledge on the west face of the arete.    Lieback thin cracks and flakes up a dihedral off the ledge, then traverse left and up to the shared anchor with cold comfort.    A fun route that seems overshadowed by its proximity to cold comfort and supervalue.   Two bolts protect a slab variation off the ledge which feels more like solid 5.10.
routes.location: Standard rack of cams and nuts, focusing on small fingers to thin hands. I managed to place a #3 camalot in a pod near the top but you probably don't need anything bigger than #1

routes.fa: N. Jones, T. Holwill, B. Noble, 1992
routes.description: Good climbing, but not terribly aesthetic. There are several ways to do this climb, all about 5.10 or 5.10+ The crux is at least above the 4th bolt no matter which is chosen.  Climb past 4 bolts on chunky but solid rock to reach a set of thin cracks, seams, and pods on the left (steep) or to pull around right and continue up a slab with two bolts and a crack...  Both options feel like 5.10-something and the right side is probably the better protected- and sunnier.
routes.location: This is the bolted line on the north-west face of the wall just right of the 'Supervalue' crack and is a few feet right of the fingercrack 'Cold Comfort' which can be used to set a TR if the grade has you wanting a TR.
routes.protection: Some draws and nuts or small cams. A two-bolt anchor and chains are up top.

routes.description: Grabe a high pinch on the arete.  Pull onto the wall, hit the lip and mantel.  Short!
routes.location: Boulder is right where Boulder Gully trail forks off from main trail.

routes.description: Climb the very short, but nicely featured slab left of the Tick-tack-toe wedged block.
routes.location: base of Supervalue

routes.description: A fun climb, but not very sustained and soft for 5.9.  The crux is a very nice tight hands corner crack that is supplemented by some convenient holds on the arete of the left wall.  Protection opportunities decrease along with the difficulty.   With a 70m rope you can lower down Supervalue placing some directionals so that climb can be toproped.  (Supervalue is so good that while it's a great and well-protected lead, it's worth toproping if you don't feel up to leading it).
routes.location: In the corner right of the Supervalue buttress.
routes.protection: Tight hands to hands.  You don't need much as the crux is short, and the rest is either solid jams, or very easy, or pinched off so it doesn't accept pro.  It's still a reasonably protected climb unless you're maxed out at 5.8.

routes.description: Reachy.  Start squatting stretched between the two aretes (if your arms are long enough).  Slap upward.
routes.location: Base of Supervalue

routes.description: "An athletic problem starts stretches between a high left edge and high right incut. Slap powerfully up the steep face to the lip."

The bolt line that starts about 6 feet to the right of Supervalue. A small open corner that transitions into a left trending undercling. After the undercling the route joins Supervalue and follows it to the top.Balancy, strenuous and interesting moves. A good cam can be placed to protect the move to the first bolt.
routes.location: Bolts, SR

routes.description: Lots of action here.  Start with an undercling traverse left (~5.9).  Then up a pretty easy left facing corner until you can traverse right to a series of bolts which diagonal up and right.  Face climb past the bolts (10-) with a long clip at the 3rd or 4th.  After the bolts, follow a crack until it seems easier to move right to a parallel crack; switching cracks is the crux.    Follow this crack to the top where you can either traverse right to a set of anchors or belay from a power tower support cable.  At the start be  conscious of future rope drag when placing your gear.    A 70M rope is required to lower from the fixed anchors, but I believe one can rap from here w/ a 60M, though I not sure so tie your rope ends together and use your own judgement.
routes.location: The left most climb on the west facing portion of Boulder Gully.  Start below the right end of a small arch.
routes.protection: Standard Squamish rack, small nuts to hand size cams.  Some long slings and/or double ropes.

routes.description: Talking Holds follows a finger/hand crack straight up the steep wall and then left, with some juggy broken blocks to grab for variety.  Fun, overhanging and pumpy.
routes.location: In the Crag X area, just around the corner left and uphill from Supervalue.
routes.protection: Standard trad rack to 3".  Anchor is bolted and a 60m rope is long enough to TR.

routes.description: Sit down start.  Start seated at the base of the right-hand arete.  Slap up and to the left.
routes.location: right of Lean on Me

routes.description: Sit Down Start.  Start seated matched on a small wedged block.  Crank up and slightly to the right.
routes.location: Base of Supervalue left of Kitchen Confidential.

routes.fa: Kevin McLane, John Howe, Chris Murrell. As a sport route: Kevin McLane, Barry McLane
routes.description: A nice technical climb up the arete with good rests between bolts. The bolts are spaced about 15 ft apart and may feel a bit runout for some climbers.
routes.location: The route climbs an obvious arete between Picket Line and Cold Comfort.  Rap from the chains with a 50m rope.
routes.protection: 4 bolts with a 2 bolt anchor and chains at the top.

routes.description: Thin sporty start to an improbable transition to some thin slab.
routes.location: To the far right of Supervalue rock, left of Picket Line

routes.description: A slightly overhing face climb, this is a fun little route, not to be missed. A short but devious crux (bolted or fixed pitons) low on the route leads to easier gear-protected climbing and the obvious fixed anchors.
routes.location: Just left of "Talking Holds", located around and to the left from more popular climbs visible above the parking lot. From the base of "Triage Arete" or "Supervalue" (just above the parking lot), continue up and to the left, and just out of view of the road.
routes.protection: A single set of cams, with small gear most helpful. 6-8 Quickdraws.

routes.description: Visible from the parking lot above and left of the supervalue arete is a striking offwidth dihedral. The business is a 4.5-6.5" crack in the back of a a large slot, leading to stellar exit moves and then easy flakes to top out. Either hike a few feet up a gully for the munge-y direct start, or traverse up hand cracks from the left. Is it a chimney, offwidth, or stem-box? You decide.
routes.location: Up boulder gully, about 20m up the trail (climbers' left) from talking holds and turbocharger.
routes.protection: Single BD #5 and #6 for the slot. A few hand-size pieces (BD #0.75-#2) for the beginning and exit. An extra #5 will protect the last 15' if you feel the need. Bolts with rings at the top.

routes.description: Sit down start.  Start crammed in the alcove between the small boulder and the cliff.  Odd chicken wing action in the slot gains the top of the little block.
routes.location: Base of Super Baked.

description: A nice, recently cleaned, cliff left of Penny Lane and right of Pixie Corner.  This area offers some shade and numerous climbs in a wide range of difficulties including a few hidden gems.
getting_there: From Penny Lane head left towards the Pixie Corner stairs.  Bughouse Heights is the crag on the right side of the trail.

routes.description: Tackles the broken cracks at the far south (right) end of bughouse heights. Start on an awkward wide crack behind a large detached flake. Head up to an alcove, then out and left by way of underclinging and laybacking to the anchors.   Packs in a good variety of climbing on several nice features. Unfortunately it is not very consistent in difficulty or quality. Short, aesthetic cruxes are interrupted by easy scrambling up unappealing rock.    The book calls it 5.8 but I'm listing it as 5.9 based on my and my parters' experience and the spray on the web.
routes.location: On the far right end of bughouse heights. It is the system of cracks immediately climber's left of the fixed lines up to left Penny Lane.
routes.protection: Good pro. Standard rack to 4", but you can fit a #5 camalot to keep you off the deck at the start.

routes.description: A heady start up the angled cracks with only a small nut for pro early on gets you to two bolts along a balancey ramp.Not a good lead for a 5.9 leader.
routes.location: Right of the bolted line next to Skullduggery.
routes.protection: A couple of small cams, a #5 nut and two draws. Pretty minimal pro.

routes.description: A fun slabby climb. I found the crux to be at the top of the first block as the rock turns more vertical.
routes.location: Looking at Skullduggery (the obvious off-width), this route is on the far left.  It is comprised of two large blocks.
routes.protection: 5 blots. Found it tricky to start so put in a piece of gear and also put gear in the horizontal crack up near the top of the first block. this piece was pretty much all mental.  Anchors with chains at the top.

routes.description: Chimney on right side of detached slab.  Follow right hand arete on the triangular wall above.
routes.location: SR

routes.description: The gaping crack.  The crux is first getting into the crack - a bolt protects here.  The unmistakable gaping wide crack at Bughouse Heights. A low-angle, shallow crack with marginal protection grants access to a comfortable ledge below the offwidth. Yes, it really goes at 5.10-.
routes.location: It is pretty hard to miss the large off-width crack at Bughouse Heights. It's the humongous crack on the trail up to pixie corner.
routes.protection: Contrary to the guidebook description, this route is x-rated without at least one #6 and one #5 cam. The initial crack will take a 1" piece and something small (#2 c3). A bolt protects the first move into the squeeze. From here the crack runs from tipped-out #6 to #4. It is possible to place a #.75 to protect the final moves. Bolts with rap rings at the top

routes.description: This is one of the newly scrubbed (2023) routes on the right side of Bughouse Heights.As far as I have been able to tell, there has been no information published about who put this route up or what it's called, but it's great and well worth climbing. If anyone has the proper name or FA details for this, please let me know.Start by traversing right along the fault ledge into the first crack, and move into fun jams that sometimes flare onto a second fault ledge. Make a couple of steeper bouldery moves off the ledge and to the anchors.Felt like it was in the 5.8 to 5.9 range.
routes.location: Right side of Bughouse Heights. See photo.

routes.fa: Dave Jones, R Miler, D. Hutchinson (1990)
routes.description: Climb the obvious crack in order to get to the upper block of slab above. Pull onto the block and climb the right bolt line on the slab above. The bolts on this slab are spaced fairly far apart.    The initial crack start is shared with the Tail Wind route.
routes.location: Bughouse Heights Center

routes.fa: Dean Hart, Dave Jones, Randy Atkinson (1990)
routes.description: Climb the obvious crack in order to get to the upper block of slab above. Pull onto the block and climb the left bolt line on the slab above. The bolts on this slab are spaced fairly far apart.   The initial crack start is shared with the Sting in the Tail route.
routes.location: Bughouse Heights Center

routes.description: Follow the start crack on the slabby face for Too Pink to Think then branch left at the roof and climb through the Wide crack variation to the left.Psyched to scrape up your shins, bloody up your knees, fist some choss and sketch out on slightly runnout crumbly rock? Then boy oh boy is this the climb for you.
routes.location: Climbs the wide crack on the broken roof just left of Too Pink to Think on the wall by the scramble approach to Penny Lane. The wall is just right on the path to Pixie Corner from the playground. If you hit the splitter offwidth of Skullduggery, then you've gone too far.
routes.protection: Standard rack up to #4. You COULD bring a #5, but it'd likely just get in the way.

routes.description: Follow the thin crack up the slab to the obvious broken roof. Jam and pull big moves between good holds. Solid gear can be found, you just have to look around.    The wide crack variation over the roof to the left is Too Blue to Screw 12a
routes.location: Climbs the broken roof on the wall to climbers left of the hand lines up to Penny Lane.   Two routes to the left of Fata Morgana.
routes.protection: The bolts mentioned in the Bourdon book have rightly been chopped. Standard rack up to hand sizes.

description: Burgers and Fries is among the most popular areas as Smoke Bluffs, with easy top rope access, a selection of moderate lines, and a quick-drying western aspect that gets lots of sun.  This area can be a zoo, but there are some nice climbs here, particularly easy ones.   There is a whole slew of houses crazy close to the top of the crag.  To prevent issues with the homeowners, don't loiter at the top.
getting_there: Hike the road from the parking lot, following signs and avoiding turns to the base of Burgers and Fries.  ~5 min.

routes.description: Climb the slabby shallow white corner to the top. The corner is slick and some interesting stemming possibilities can be used.
routes.location: On the Burgers & Fries descent ramp.

routes.description: Start off ledge next to Over 60 With Asian Assistance.Go up the short crack.
routes.location: Burgers and fries left.

routes.description: Climb the arch to the left Burgers & Fries and continue up the slab above.
routes.location: Burgers & Fries Main Wall

routes.description: Smear up the blank face on the left side of the arete. Very challenging friction moves from the 1st to the 3rd bolt.
routes.location: From the Burgers and Fries main wall, walk right along the base towards Jammers Delight and Councillor's Groove, you'll find a short bolted arete in between the trees, just before the trail meets those routes.

routes.description: Starts with awesome gear and is clean. It is pretty awesome climbing with a sort of awkward move to get off the ledge about 2/3 of the way up, and its well protected. The Squamish Guide book says this route is 5.8 and I thought it was a little soft even for that rating. Regardless, it was really fun.
routes.location: South of the Main Wall of Burgers and Fries. Head up a small side trail through the trees, and go right at the wall. You will come to a left-facing groove/dihedral. This groove is the start for Gollum/Sour Grapes (5.7). Just to the left is the start for Bilbo Baggins. Around the corner to the right is Frodo's First Step.
routes.protection: Gear to 3 inches, rap rings at top

routes.fa: John Manuel, Ed Spat, Brian DeHertog, 1980
routes.description: Toward the left side of the wall is a crack that goes up and ends below what appears to be a blank face.  There is actually a horizontal crack above, that is invisible from the ground.   Above this horizontal crack, there isn't any more pro, and there are still a few slabby moves ahead.
routes.location: Standard rack.  Two bolts at the top.  No rappel anchor.  Walk off left.

routes.description: A mix of face climbing down low, connecting with cracks and corner features up top.   Fun route that climbs quickly.
routes.location: Located just right of Wise Crack, and left of Catch Me Quick.   Rappel route with a single 50m rope, but, mind your rope ends.
routes.protection: Two bolts protect the start, then a mix of gear to the top.

routes.description: Start up a finger crack that leads to the crux, and the only 10b part, 7m off the deck. The rest of the climb is more of a 5.9 with various finishes, the mantle finish is more exciting.
routes.location: Smoke Bluffs - Burgers and Fries
routes.protection: You can protect the crux with a orange Metollius cam, or a DMM walnut.

routes.description: Catch You shares it's start with Move It On Over.  Fairly easy moves to the first bolt lead to thin, sequency friction climbing before you gain a flaring finger crack.  The climbing eases in difficulty from here and varies between flaring cracks and face climbing.
routes.location: At Burgers & Fries, just left of Move It On Over.
routes.protection: Bolts and thin trad gear.  Small offset pro may be helpful.  Anchor is bolted and a 60m rope is long enough to TR.

routes.description: Deep broken cracks.
routes.location: The groove right of Jammer's Delight.
routes.protection: 1 set of nuts, Cams from 06-3.5 . Bolted anchor at top with rap rings.

routes.description: Left-leaning crack system.  Route starts above stacked flakes at the base of the wall.  Trends left.  Fun route with good protection.
routes.location: Left of Wisecrack. Starts above stacked flakes at the base of the wall.
routes.protection: Single rack to 2". Bolted anchor. Walk off.

routes.description: Climb the blocky corner up to a vegetated ledge and finish left or right.
routes.location: The big blocky groove to the left of Split Personality.

routes.description: Step up blocky granite steps.  Climb a hand crack to a ramp.  Follow ramp left to anchors.
routes.location: 13 feet right of Split Personality.
routes.protection: SR. 2-bolt anchors with rappel at the top. So you can rappel off or walk off.

routes.description: Climb the easy crack until it ends, here head up a thin L-shaped crack on the low angled rock.
routes.location: Located on the descent ramp from the top of Burger & Fries.

routes.description: Crux for me was getting to the first bolt.  Pick your evil - go up left with technical balancy moves or right with bouldery moves.  I like the left. The slab climbing above has good edges, perhaps more so than the 10a beside because it doesn't get climbed nearly as much.
routes.location: To the right of High Boltage Line.
routes.protection: 3 bolts, bring small cams for the top (book says to 1.5"). Bolted anchor.

routes.description: This short crack is a good intro climb for new leaders.  This may be a better way to get to the hand crack on Gollum.
routes.location: South of the Main Wall of Burgers and Fries. Head up a small side trail through the trees, and go right at the wall. You will come to a left-facing groove/dihedral. This groove is the start for Gollum/Sour Grapes (5.7). Just to the left is the start for Bilbo Baggins. Around the corner to the right is Frodo's First Step.
routes.protection: Small rack to 2 inches.  Two bolts at the top, though I recommend a directional if you are going to top-rope the route (to keep the rope out of the crack).  You can walk off right (with a spotter at the bottom), or rappel off of trees.

routes.description: trad
routes.location: trad

routes.description: Follow a large ramp up to a bolt. Clip this bolt and delicately move across into a left leaning finger crack. This is the hardest crux of the route and the climbing is easier above. This crack ends and there is one more easier crux getting onto the slab above. The rest of this route is pure slab climbing and is very similar to the top of the neighboring route Peaches and Cream.   Climbing straight up to the first bolt ups the grade on the route. Staying high on the ramp and traversing over to the first bolt is probably what the was original intended at the 5.11a grade.   Bring some gear to protect the cracks.
routes.location: Main Burgers & Fries wall between Peaches and Cream and Dusty Eyes.

routes.description: This is a great 5.7 hand crack. Start up the deep dihedral to to an obvious hand crack just past the wide ledge on the right (~2/3rds up).
routes.location: South of the Main Wall of Burgers and Fries.  Head up a small side trail through the trees, and go right at the wall.  You will come to a left-facing groove/dihedral.  The dihedral is the start for Gollum. The groove to the left is the start for Bilbo Baggins (5.9, another great hand-crack).
routes.protection: Standard Rack to 3 inches.  Belay off trees, or (with a directional) off the two bolts to the right (above Bilbo Baggins).

routes.description: Right of an obvious, brushy gully to the right of Predator lies a nice, fully bolted line. High Boltage Line scampers up initially easy ground to the first bolt above a bulge, then tiptoes up steep, thin ground to the top. Precise footwork required.
routes.location: Bolts.  Anchor from trees to belay from the top.  Walk off.

routes.description: A nice finger crack.  This climb isn't a total bomb, but it is quite short, and it is too easy to step off the crack to ledges at the top.  The fingers in the middle of the climb are good though, and it protects well on nuts.
routes.location: This route is in the trees to the right of the Burgers and Fries Main Wall.  There is a trail up into it.  Head left when you get to the wall.  The crack is just to the left of a groove and shallow right-facing dihedral.
routes.protection: Nuts and cams to 2 inches. Rap rings at top.

routes.description: From the descent ramp, climb up the initial thin slab and mantle up and onto a slight ledge. From there follow the remaining two bolts up the hard slab/face to the top. The crux is just above the last bolt.
routes.location: Located on the descent ramp from the top of Burger & Fries.

routes.description: A great 5.7 hand crack.  The start is tough, especially when wet.  I used a belayer's shoulder.  One could also A0 through the first 5 feet.
routes.location: Take the Valley Trail south from the Burgers and Fries Main wall until you come to a residence, the carapace of an old pick-up truck, and stairs down.  This route is to your left, the stairs down lead to Alexis Cracks, the residence is a good reason to stay quiet, and I can't comment on the truck.
routes.protection: Mostly large nuts and cams to 3 inches.  Bolted anchor at the top.

routes.description: This short route climbs the thin slab past two bolts.
routes.location: Located on the descent ramp from the top of Burger & Fries.

routes.description: At the right end of the Main Wall are parallel cracks that don't quite make it to the ground.  This is Movin' on Over.  Fingers to hands.   There are bolts on both the left and right of the route (on other routes).  Either one can be used to protect the opening moves into the crack, if you are so inclined (though I'm pretty sure both were added much much later than the FA).  The crux is getting established into the crack.     At the top, there is a right-facing dihedral.  You can go right or left here.  The left is better.
routes.location: At the right-hand side of the Main Wall.
routes.protection: Gear to 2 inches.  Two-bolt anchor.  Walk off left.

routes.description: Climb the bolted line up slab just to the left of Jammers Delight.
routes.location: Approach as for Burgers and Fries, follow base of the crag far right past Sweet and Sour around the corner and look to the left side of the next cliff.

routes.description: Climb up the streak on the virgin slab directly between between High Boltage and French Leave. Better climbing than both of these routes as the slab hasn't been polished. Stay off the crack system of French Leave and climb it as a pure slab route all the way to the top.This route is top rope only so climb either High Boltage and French Leave first, either set of anchors can be used for a top rope anchor.
routes.location: Burgers & Fries right.
routes.protection: Top rope only, use High Boltage or French Leave anchors

routes.description: This is an interesting route that requires a tough pull to get off the ground. After making crux moves to get going, make another hard move to step right to an easier groove, move more easily up to another crux (layback), and finish up on easier cracks. The protection is plentiful and easy to place from good stances.   (The route name and first ascent information were obtained from "Squamish Select" by Marc Bourdon.)
routes.location: This route is about ten feet right of Libya Sucks and right before a fence demarcating private property. Look for an off-fingers crack at the start with poor feet.
routes.protection: Standard rack. I used medium nuts and cams from a blue Alien to #3 Camalot. There is a bolted rappel anchor at the top.

routes.fa: David Hutchinson, Joe Wong, Eric Chan, 2015
routes.description: Interesting slab, micro features lead to some thoughtful footwork. A tad run out to the anchor.
routes.location: Left of Asshole of November

routes.description: Climb up the hard slab with only a few bolts for protection. The "mental" crux of this route is going between the second and third bolt. The route gets easier here but is substantially run out.    Most choose to top rope this route as it is a bold lead.
routes.location: On the main Burgers & Fries wall, the obvious slab between Catch Me Quicker and Catch You.
routes.protection: 3 bolts, also some possible protection near the top.

routes.description: A straight up, slabby climb. On the lower angle sections your handholds are little pebbles. You will learn to love these pebbles.
routes.location: As you approach the Burgers and Fries wall from the left, this is the third climb. A straight up, slabby climb.

routes.description: Climb a good hand crack until it fades out near the top. At this point transfer into another great left leaning crack that continues to the top.
routes.location: Near the descent ramp for Burgers & Fries.

routes.description: Climb the desperately thin slab that is immediately to the left of Burgers & Fries. The difficulty eases as you get higher.
routes.location: Burgers & Fries Main Wall

routes.description: Right of Smeagol, climb the face to reach a left leaning hand crack.
routes.location: SR

routes.description: The right most route on the large slab. This route is a bit vague as to when you should start using the crack on the right.
routes.location: Burgers and Fries Right

routes.description: Cracks so deep you almost fit in. A great novice climb.In the Squamish Select as "Sarah's Crack".
routes.location: Standard rack.

routes.description: Crack to the left of Jims Jam. Guide gives it 5.9, but it's worth doing if you can't climb that grade since it's easy to cheat to the right
routes.location: Follow the path to the right of Burgers and Fries right half, down some stone stairs and you will quickly find it.

routes.fa: Bob Wilson, Terry Spurrel, Barry Wiseman  1980
routes.description: The short crack about three meters to the right of Swan Song. Follow it up and left to finish on Swan Song.
routes.location: the right side of burgers and fries left.

routes.description: I found the crux to be at the bottom, an awkward move or two that is harder than it looks.
routes.location: The right-most crack on this small wall.  You can walk off to the right.
routes.protection: SR - I don't remember there being an anchor at the top, but there is a tree.

routes.description: Start up a short piece of slab to reach a curved finger crack.  After the break in the crack is a well protected water polished re entry to the end of the finger crack.
routes.location: 13 ft left approx. of Exit Stage Left

routes.description: Climb the bolted slab between Split Personality and Exit Stage Left. The slab is steep and smooth with several well needed defined edges and pockets.
routes.location: Burgers and Fries Right.

routes.description: Climb the tricky slab past four bolts into the top crack system. A small lonely crack can be used for protection between the first and second bolts. Crux of the route is at the last bolt where it gets very thin.   This route protects nicely and is not run out like it's neighboring hard slab route Over Forty.
routes.location: Main Burgers & Fries wall between Move it On Over and Short and Sweet.

routes.fa: Kris Wild, Fern Webb, Robin Beech  2003
routes.description: Follow up the cack just right of Short and Sweet up to a bolt and a small ledge. Proceed right up the corner to another bolt and then up slab to the anchor.
routes.location: Far right of Burgers and Fries left.
routes.protection: 2 bolts, 1 set of nuts, standard rack.

routes.description: Climb a line of 4 bolts up the slab. At the second bolt there is a bulge, stay to the right of the remaining bolts. As the route steepens there are several useful edges.   The crux is at the third bolt. Don't be tempted by the big crack on the left (False Friends route) when getting to the first bolt.
routes.location: Located on the descent ramp from the top of Burger & Fries.

routes.fa: E Chan, T Sanwald, A Douglas (2015)
routes.description: Climb a cool short hand crack to the top. A great lead for beginners.
routes.location: Near the descent ramp for Burgers & Fries.

routes.description: Leads up a wonderful corner crack with a fun bulge about halfway (don't side pull folks /s) There is a bolted mid-station for multi-pitch practice.
routes.location: far far right burgers and fries, to the left of Libya Sucks
routes.protection: 1 set of nuts and cams from 0.6-3.5"

routes.description: Use good edges and a finger crack to climb the relatively steep first half. Walk across a ledge past an optional midway anchor (or use it for multi-pitch practice) and finish up the short but fun hand crack in the left facing corner to the actual anchor. Good movement and great pro, perhaps soft for the grade.
routes.location: Just left of Truck Stop Jamb. Follow the Burgers and Fries trail until you reach the last section of the cliff before the private fence cuts you off. White Line Fever is the leftmost of these cracks.
routes.protection: Standard rack. Takes everything fingers to hands, no doubles needed. Bolted anchors with chains.

routes.description: The left most route on the large slab. There is no gear until high up so most people top-rope this route. Bottom is starting to get polished from heavy use.
routes.location: Burgers and Fries Right
routes.protection: No bolts, small gear high up

routes.description: On the open slab to the left of Split Personality there is a thin diagonal crack that disappears into the slab. Climb this crack until you can clip a bolt, then smear your way up the remaining short section of slab.
routes.location: Burgers and Fries Right

routes.description: Thin face climbing up to a short shallow crack up high.  Crux is right off the deck.
routes.location: Right side of the crag.  Between Who Needs Bolts and Predator.
routes.protection: The crack will take small cams but it is high up.  No bolts.

routes.fa: B. Wiseman, B. Wilson, T. Spurrell 1980
routes.description: Wisecrack is one of two popular 5.7s at Burger and Fries.  Begin left of Carch Me, and right of the gentle ramp, Dusty Eyes.   Climb some left angling cracks to a small tree stump halfway up the face.  Move right to a flake, and layback unttil making a few easier moves to the top.       The initial moves into the flake are disconcerting and the gear is small.
routes.location: Gear to 2".  #3 microcams protect the inital moves onto the flake.

description: A clean, west-facing crag offering a variety of traditional and mixed lines. The area has a bit of everything, including face, thin cracks, and some wideness.
getting_there: Go south on the gravel trail from the main parking lot.  Look for Zombie Roof on the left. Skirt the base of the roof and head left towards the Laughing Crack area. The trail forks. Follow the sign, heading left and uphill towards Cabin Boy's Office.

routes.description: Start up either side of the large detached block in the center of the wall. At the top of the block clip a bolt to the right and make a tricky traverse up and over to a left facing corner crack. At the top of the corner crack, climb to the very top of the thin flake and clip another bolt. A few slab moves and a mantle get you onto a large ledge. Finish by climbing the overhanging crach above the cave.
routes.location: Standard rack, 3 bolts, rap anchor.

routes.description: Climb up the right hand side of a large flake past a lone bolt. Climb past a horizontal crack onto another smaller flake into a section of face climbing above protected by two bolts. This is the crux of the route and it can be avoided by climbing to the right of the bolts in the dark groove. The climb finishes above with some more face climbing and a layback finish protected by one final bolt and some gear.
routes.location: The giant flake to the right of Peaceful Warrior.

routes.description: Start up either side of the large detached block in the center of the wall. At the top of the block continue straight up through broken cracks.    The crack that trends left at the top of block is another route called Peaceful Warrior.   Top seeps a tad after rain, a good novice lead.
routes.location: The middle route on the Cabin Boys Office wall.
routes.protection: Standard rack, no bolts, rap anchor.

routes.description: Fun climbing starting up the left side of the big flake (with an awkard squeeze behind the tree) leads to the top of the flake and a bolt. A couple of slab moves and then onto a big ledge, with a couple more moves up and left to the anchor.
routes.location: Obvious large flake on the right side of the crag. Has a tree at the base of the flake.

routes.description: Balancy moves head up a series of bulges. First bolt is high and the moves to get there feel insecure (to me).
routes.location: The bolt line to the right of the obvious finger crack (Zigidy Zag).
routes.protection: A few bolts. You could maybe put a small piece of gear between the 1st and 2nd bolts if you wanted.  Shares the anchor with Zigidy Zags - bolts with chains.

routes.description: Fun moves out a nice finger crack lead to some thinner climbing and a crux at the finish.    Start up either side of the large, detached block in the center of the wall. At the top of the block trend left, following a finger crack.  Eventually the crack peters out, leaving a few moves of face before topping out.
routes.location: Begins at a detached block in the center of the wall. Trend left out a finger crack for Peaceful Warrior (.9).  Taking the direct finish is Dugh! (.8).

routes.fa: Mike Duffy, Dave Gauley & Kristen Gauley. 1998.
routes.description: A nice mix of splitter fingers and technical face.    Start up a left-leaning finger crack. Clip a bolt and move through a series of balancey overlaps to another short crack. A second bolt protects the finishing moves on the face.
routes.location: Look for the finger crack left of the wide gash in the middle of the crag.

routes.fa: Eric Hamel and Celine Gelinas in the 90s
routes.description: This is the long left facing open book on the far right side of the wall.  The crux comes in the last 30 feet with sustained fun jaming and chimneying in the flare.  I suspect the route has been recently cleaned and will grow over if it isn't climbed again.  Up top the rock is oddly chalky from all the water, but the pro is still good.   Great route.
routes.location: Far right side of the wall.
routes.protection: Solid pro the whole way, despite appearances.  The crack up top is bigger than it looks and I was able to place cams of all sizes.   Bring a standard rack with all sizes of cams and nuts and you'll be fine.  I actually placed two #3 camalots (one at the dog leg and one higher up).

routes.description: Finger cracks zig zag up to balancy face moves at a bolt.
routes.location: Far left of the wall, finger crack noticeably zig zags.  Look for the lone bolt above.
routes.protection: Small gear, one bolt. Anchor with chains at the top.

description: Small low angled crag south of Funarama. Many well featured easy climbs.
getting_there: On the trail to Funarama. Approach via smoke bluffs loop trail.

routes.description: Buster climbs the crack twenty feet left of the right side of the wall to a slab split by a thin crack/seam.
routes.location: Right side of the wall. Twenty feet left of the right end of the wall. Begin below a large triangular block that protrudes from the wall at mid-height.

routes.fa: Pam Cook, Lynn Gillespie, Chris Lawrence Steve Smaridge, Grame Taylor (1992)
routes.description: The large crack on the far left side of the crag, leads up into a V slot.
routes.location: Single Rack

routes.fa: Pam Cook, Lynn Gillespie, Chris Lawrence Steve Smaridge, Grame Taylor (1992)
routes.description: Follow up the cracks to the right of "Chopper Malone" that lead into a wider slot.
routes.location: Single rack.

routes.description: This route is not in the 2012 version of the Squamish Select guide book, but is found as an update release on Quickdraw Publications' website in 2018. This line starts out on the slab to the right of Pee Wee. Follow the furthest right crack up to the ledge and finish up the same line as for Pee Wee.
routes.location: To climber's right of Buster/Pee Wee. Rightmost crack on the slabby section.
routes.protection: Similar to Pee Wee - details unknown

routes.description: LeRoy begins in a finger crack at the right side of the wall. Pull onto the face via the finger crack and a good hold created by the top of a large flake on the right. Continue up the face past a horizontal and a bolt that protects a face move onto a smooth sloping ledge. From the ledge climb onto a block on the left and stem up to another bolt that protects the steep, thinly featured slab and the final moves to the top.
routes.location: Right side of the Call It a Day Wall. Ten feet right of the start of Buster & Pee Wee. Begin in a left leaning finger crack.
routes.protection: LeRoy is a mixed route containing two bolts which can to supplemented with a yellow Alien or similar sized cam, small HB Offset or similar sized nut, a 0.75, #1 or #2 Camalot, and a couple quickdraws.

routes.description: Start in the crack as for Buster, but traverse under the large triangular block and climb the blocky upper face and crack.
routes.location: Right side of the wall. Twenty feet left of the right edge of the wall. Start below a large triangular block protruding from the wall at mid-height.

routes.fa: Pam Cook, Lynn Gillespie, Chris Lawrence, Steve Smaridge, Graeme Taylor, 1992.
routes.description: Climb any of three short cracks in the middle of the wall up to the horizontal break.  Aim towards the base of the right-leaning ramp feature, and climb up that to the top.
routes.location: Middle of Call It a Day cliff
routes.protection: Protection is somewhat sparse and wandering, depending on what you choose to climb.

routes.description: Start by climbing Clean Streak, then cut right to the finger crack between it and Ramp-O-Rama.
routes.location: Shares anchor with Clean Streak

description: The cliff just right of Boulder Gully, visible from the designated climber's parking area.  With its quick approach, and open faces, it's a good place to go when you're trying to salvage a couple of PM pitches after the rain stops.   When routes are shown sorted L to R, the lower crag is first, then the upper crag.
getting_there: There are a couple of different trails in to Crag X from the dirt road that leads south from the parking area to other Smoke Bluffs areas.

routes.description: Thinner climbing at the bottom of the climb follows a thin crack up and trending right to a large ledge. From the ledge, climb a really nice hand-size crack trending up and to the left to the anchor. Limited holds outside the crack make hand and foot jams a must!
routes.location: Farthest right climb in the higher section (up and right) of Crag X. Climbs a great and prominent hand crack on the upper right side of the wall that trends up and left

routes.description: Juggy, with good protection.
routes.location: Around the right corner of Upper Crag X.

routes.description: Fantastic crack line starting up the center of the main Crag X lower wall, immediately to the left of Center Street. There are two challenging sections, one is in the main crack about half way up the climb. The other was a tricky move out of the starting crack into a larger crack that runs up the left most arete to the finish chains.
routes.location: Lower Crag X wall, the crack line immediately to the laft of Center Street.

routes.description: This climb takes the most prominent of the left angling cracks in the face of the lower Crag X wall. A cruxy finger crack is passed before the cracks zigs to the right and up to a ledge.  This ledge has a chain belay, but the climb continues for another 30 feet so you have the choice of doing it as one pitch or breaking it up.   Either way, the climb gets harder at this point and the corner crack above the ledge doesn't take good pro until you have made a few moves, but you can protect the moves off the ledge with a .75 camalot in a crack to the right of the corner.   Very strenuous climbing, but with good, if tough to place, gear finishes the climb up the corner.
routes.location: Start on a nice little terrace at the base of the lower wall of Crag X, just left of the stacked blocks that form the short crack climb Gord's Block.
routes.protection: A standard rack, with a few doubles of cams in the finger to tight hand sizes and a good selection of small to medium nuts is sufficient.  There is a two bolt rap station at the top.  Double ropes will take you down, otherwise go to the chains on the ledge and make a second rap.  Watch then ends of the rope, even from this intermediate station.

routes.description: Slab climbing a bolt and thin crack lead to the intermediate anchor of the Gloaming
routes.location: Obvious thin crack with a bolt on the right of centre street
routes.protection: Single up too 0,75. double on the small size and small nuts

routes.fa: J. & M. Coope, C. Doig, J. Campbell, P. Croft 1979
routes.description: A fun crack to the right of the main wall of Crag X. The new trail passes right under it so you can't miss it.
routes.location: Small rack to #3 Camalot

routes.fa: Robin Barley, Peter Shackleton, 1983. FFA Kevin McLane, Jim Campbell, 1983
routes.description: This route climbs the awesome left-leaning finger crack on the upper wall. A few variations exist for accessing the base of the crack. The original route follows the flake-like feature a few meters left of 'Up From Despair'. Protection is good throughout.
routes.location: Cams, nuts

routes.description: Good climbing follows a thin crack up to easier climbing above.
routes.location: Starts at the bottom right of a large left facing feature in the rock. Climbs up following a small crack (not the right side of the feature) before trending left to the anchor.

routes.description: Scramble to a ramp above and right of the start of Centre Street. Clip a black bolt (5.10a) then climb the crack above, eventually trending right to a chain anchor on a ledge. Rap from here or climb the seond pitch crack (5.10b) that leads to the summit.
routes.location: SR

routes.description: Very short but sweet thin hand crack. Gymnastic and strenous moves with great protection, slightly overhanging and burly right to the chains. Possible to top rope by scrambling around to the back side of the large block.
routes.location: Starts a bit to the right of Center Street on a big semi-detached block.
routes.protection: Chain anchors. Two #3 Camalots and one #1 Camalot... you could bring more I suppose.

routes.description: Mantle onto a ledge and then work a thin crack to an overhanging corner.  Bolted anchor on the slab above the roof.
routes.location: The far back (damp) corner of the Grunt Wall.

routes.description: Climb the bolt line to the left of Easter Island. A tricky bouldery sequence to start and then two hard mantels, an easier but balancy finish.
routes.location: Left of Easter Island

routes.description: Climb a leaning groove just left of the Virgin Soil crack to a small roof. Turn it and then slab climb left into X-Ray.
routes.location: Upper Crag X

routes.description: Climb a variety of cracks with positive hand and foot holds to a bolted anchor.
routes.location: Starts on the second, larger, crack to the left of the Grunt corner, which aligns with the edge of the ledge.
routes.protection: Standard rack.  Bolted anchor at top with rap rings.

routes.description: Climbs the obvious short groove on the left, some fun movement near the top of the groove.
routes.location: The groove immediately to the right of Gord's block/

routes.description: An interesting route with varied climbing. Starts up the slab just left of Gord's block past a single bolt, over the small roof and right onto technical face climbing across a couple more bolts into an easy left trending crack to the bolted anchor.
routes.location: Just left of Gord's Block.
routes.protection: Standard rack, bolts protect the crux.

routes.description: Boulder problem at the start to low angle climbing.
routes.location: The obvious bolted route just off the climbers' access trail.

routes.description: Climb up a groove up and left, before traversing right to a bolted anchor (shared with Affordable)
routes.location: Farthest left climb in the higher section (up and right) of Crag X
Upper Crag X

routes.description: Beginning at the crack for Out to Lunge, traverse left along a straight left-leaning crack into the final moves of Easter Island. Fun movement, consistently positive & bomber handholds. Smear below the crack.
routes.location: Purple (0.5) to Blue (#3) Camalots. Placed two red and two green. Bolts with chains at the top.

routes.description: Out to lunge is the higher of the two traversing cracks to the right of easter island. It starts with a brief right-leaning crack with one move of 10-, then traverses left to its own anchor, independent of Easter Island.
routes.location: Bolted rappel anchor up top.
routes.protection: Gear up to 1", maybe two .75s for the traverse. Small nut protects the crux well.

routes.fa: Kevin Duck, Robin Barley, 1981. FFA Peter Croft, Richard Suddaby, 1981
routes.description: Climb the right-trending undercling until you can mantle up and clip a bolt on the slab. Continue up the slab and cracks to a wicked roof crack finish.
routes.location: 2 bolts, standard rack

routes.description: Climb a short 5.8 hand to finger crack and mantle onto an enormous ledge. Clip a bolt on the left side of the arete and then make bouldery moves off the ledge, firstly on the right side of the arete, but moving left to the crest of the arete at the top. Pull onto a slab and climb easily up to the top ledge. Sling trees for an anchor.An obvious line but spoiled by the huge ledge midway up which basically turns it into two separate boulder problems. Bolt exists only to prevent groundfall from the second boulder problem if you pitch leftwards off the arete. It doesn't do much to keep you off the ledge, so a pad there can help if you're unwilling to commit. Originally done as a solo with no bolt.
routes.location: Far right side of Easter island, right of Out to Lunge.
routes.protection: Bottom crack takes gear in the 1" range. The bolt will keep you from grounding but the climb is basically a boulder problem off the upper ledge so you might find a pad on the ledge as useful as the bolt, if not more so.

routes.description: On the main Crag X wall, climb up the pie shaped piece of rock using the large crack between it and the main wall. At the top of this pie shaped rock is an anchor with rap rings. Past the anchor is another route called Side Street that continues to the very top.
routes.location: Located on the Main Crag X wall.

routes.description: Probably not popular because of the awkward, short bolted ending between two great crack climbs. Can be done as a top-rope variation if you've already put up Baby Lizard.   Start as for that route then step right into the Center Street crack. Climb this - fun laybacking - until it cuts right. Continue up and left following the bolts along a dyke. This cryptic, slabby climbing is obviously a stark contrast to the lower bit. The last move is a very balancy step pretty much level with the anchors.
routes.location: Center of the main face of Crag X

routes.description: Technical slab and arete climbing for 4 bolts.
routes.location: The bolted slab/arete just left of the groove.

routes.description: This is an extension to Piece of Pie (or PoP is a truncated version of this) on the left side of Crag x.Full: right facing dihedral, step right to hands/fist shortie forming the pie, clip the anchors, and step right. It is 5.8 to there. Now continue up the discontinuous finger crack up and right through a short steep section before it eases off until the anchors.
routes.location: Left side of Crag X, belay from ledge
routes.protection: Doubles 0.2-0.75 and nuts. Single 1-4. 3 and 4 can be left out if you're confident at 5.7 fist/hands for 6 ft.

routes.fa: Randy Atkinson, John Howe, Allen Tate, 1979
routes.description: I found the roof section of this climb to be really fun, and well protected.  The crack widens as you go up into more of an off-width.
routes.location: After walking by Easter Island area, take the first trail to the left. Continue to veer left, and scramble up a couple rocky sections. Carry on going this way until you get to a treed ledge (where there are anchors for the climbs below - new ones, not sure yet what they are).  At this ledge, there are two parallel 'roof' cracks - Sniffler and Snorter.  Sniffler is the right-hand crack.
routes.protection: Anchor with chains, shared with Snorter.  I'd bring some large cams - BD #3,#4.  I placed a #4 at the roof section and then wished I'd had it higher up.

routes.description: In my opinion, easier of the two parallel cracks.
routes.location: After walking by Easter Island area, take the first trail to the left. Continue to veer left, and scramble up a couple rocky sections. Carry on going this way until you get to a treed ledge (where there are anchors for the climbs below - new ones, not sure yet what they are). At this ledge, there are two parallel 'roof' cracks - Sniffler and Snorter. Snorter is the left-hand crack.
routes.protection: SR, anchors with chains at the top

routes.description: The obvious corner on the far upper right of Upper Crag X where the trail meets the wall. Crux is a bit perplexing down low and significantly easier up top.
routes.location: Standard rack.

routes.description: Interesting crack climbing into some good jams up high.
routes.location: The crack in the middle of the face.

routes.description: Climb the shallow curving dihedral on the left of the arete. Thin laybacking and delicate footwork with some tricky gear. There is much to despair.   Route is on the Upper Crag X wall, head up the new staircase that starts the new smoke bluff connector trail just past Lower Crag X. Upper Crag X area is only 100 feet from the main smoke bluffs trail.   Starts on the right-most arete on the upper crag X wall, near the trail.
routes.location: Small nuts and small cams. Bolt anchors.

routes.fa: Alan Stevenson, Brian Moorhead, & F. Vie 2014
routes.description: Easy climbing up the arete for 3 bolts.
routes.location: The bolted arete to the right of Snorter/Sniffler.

routes.description: I nice but slightly tricky hand crack starts the first third of the climb. Followed by a large blocky roof off-wide, this can be climbed directly on the right or around to the left. From the top of this block starts a nice finger crack that climbs up the main face and over a slight bulge, I thought this was the crux.  The guidebook says that the route is 22m long, if you climb the easier cracks to the top of the crag it's a full 40m+.
routes.location: Route is on the Upper Crag X wall, head up the new staircase that starts the new smoke bluff connector trail just past Lower Crag X. Upper Crag X area is only 100 feet from the main smoke bluffs trail.  Starts in the obvious hand crack on the left side of the main upper crag X wall.
routes.protection: A full assortment of cams and nuts up to #3 C4.

routes.description: Ramble up the left side of the crag alongside the fixed line, step right into a thin crack under to under the roof, traverse right under the roof (crux) and follow the corner up to the anchor.
routes.location: Left side of the crag, starts in the corner next to the fixed line.

description: This is a relatively obscure wall that houses a number of good slab routes.  Despite being close to the parking lot it is rarely climbed.
getting_there: Head up the main trail from the parking lot and turn left at the sign to Crag X and Lumberland.  Once you reach the handrail you are there.

routes.fa: Colin Moorhead, Will Dorling, Nick Watts
routes.description: This is one of the best slab/face routes in the Bluffs.  It takes a proud line right up the middle of the Crystal Wall and the 2nd pitch is pretty sustained at 10+/11-.   p1.  10c:  The 1st pitch climbs the lower tier of rock, starting up a crack and then onto a slab past a couple of bolts.  There is a decent runout to the anchors.  This pitch an be avoided by scrambling around to the right   p2. 11a:  This is the money pitch.  Make a tough high-step move to get to the first bolt and then another difficult move pressing out left onto the slab.  Run it out a little to a good ledge and clip the 2nd bolt.  The crux of the route is probably the next 15 feet but the entire route keeps coming at you and doesn't relent until a cool mantle at the very top.
routes.location: smack dab in the middle of Crystal Wall

routes.fa: P1+2 Robin Barley and Joe Turley, 1983; P3 Brayshaw and Beech 1990s
routes.description: A short multipitch on the left side of the Crystal Wall. It's a little scruffy and probably doesn't see much traffic, but the movement is nice. Anchors are bolted. Rappel down Beware the Mooron.P1 -10c - Scramble up the boulder chimney and move onto the slab. Follow the shallow corner past a bolt and some small gear to a big ledge above.P2 - 5.9 - Follow the corner on the left up and past the steepest part, moving left onto a sloping shelf, and continuing to the anchor.P3 - 5.9 - A move or two up and past the anchor brings you to the fissure in the rock. Follow it to the top. Easier as you go, but somewhat sparse protection.
routes.location: The left end of Crystal Wall has an obvious boulder chimney. The route starts at the base of this.

description: Quiet and somewhat secluded.  You won't see many people here.
getting_there: Continue past Ronin's corner about 20 metres.

routes.description: A similar route to Elephantiasis.  Maybe climbed less because it starts out dirty, but is a great hand crack.
routes.location: on the left side of the wall, just right of the arete that forms the left end of the crag.
routes.protection: A long route, so maybe double up on hand size cams.  Bolted anchor

routes.description: The bottom 10 feet will almost always be wet.   However, the moves aren't very hard and you'll get a piece in before your feet are 5 feet up.  Many people skip this climb because of the wetness, but the crack above is outstanding.  Steep locker hand jams all the way to the top.  Plenty of rests but all rests all slightly strenuous.
routes.location: The diagonal crack about 5 metres right of Elephant's Arse
routes.protection: Bomber gear the entire way.  1s, 2s and 3s are all handy.

routes.description: mostly a diagonal crack going right up to and around the arete.  The bolt and thin crack are Senate Seat (12a)
routes.location: starts off in a triangular pod on the right end of the crag.

description: Very shaded by heavy growth.
getting_there: This area is close to the trailheads for both the Blind Channel trail and the Valley trail.     For Blind Channel, you can see the lower wall (Fatty Bolger) right away as you walk south along the trail.  The left wall of Fatty Bolger has several easy/moderate sport routes, the right wall has several 5.11 slab routes.  Ferret's Folly is up and left, and has a couple of decent moderates.   From the Valley trail, you will pass a steel hydro tower on your right just before a small wooden bridge across a stream.  The hydro tower is at the top of Ferret's Folly.  There is a faint trail that heads down just the right of the stream, and then across to the base of the wall.

routes.description: The Crux for me was getting past the first bolt. Trust your feet, grab tiny crystals, and keep your weight from going to both feet at the same time and you will really find this climb a true delight! Top gets a tad easier but still in the 11a range. Do in the shade. Book: A desperately thin slab move off the dirt leads to easier climbing above. Bring some TCUs to supplement the bolts.
routes.location: This route is off of Channel road just below Ferret's Folly crag. The start to the climb is the third bolted line from the arete as you are going left. Walk off or be lowered down.The best landmark one can find below the first bolt there is a left leaning thin/slopey ramp that you can use to start the climb.

routes.description: A right-facing corner with a nice crack in it.  This is a good intro climb for new leaders.  Plenty of protection.
routes.location: Right under the large steel electrical tower.
routes.protection: Standard Rack up to 2 inches.  Gear anchor at the top.  I suppose many tie off to the tower above, but I think that is verboten.

routes.description: The Crux for me was just getting off the ground. This is a great slab climb that is a real test piece to lead. Trust your feet, grab tiny crystals, and keep your weight from going to both feet at the same time and you will really find this climb a true delight!
routes.location: This route is off of Channel road just below Ferret's Folly crag. The start to the climb is the second bolted line from the arete as you are going left. Walk off or be lowered down.
routes.protection: 6 Bolts protect the route plus one section half way up the climb for some pro. Bolted anchor at top.

routes.description: This wall has a black streak flanked by two white streaks.  The route follows three bolts to the left of these streaks.   The right-hand finish (5.9, FA: Ostrander, Oliver, 1988) is better, and is more direct.
routes.location: Right below the large steel electrical tower.
routes.protection: Three bolts.  Gear anchor at the top.  There are bolt holes indicating the once-presence of bolts, but none now.  I suppose many tie off to the tower above, but I think that is verboten.

routes.description: The crux is at the very top where you have a technical bulge to climb before reaching the anchor. I made it through the climb well until I got to this section and found it really hard. I would change the rating of the climb to an 11d due to the bulge move. I have yet to climb this through clean and don't plan on leading it any time soon!
routes.location: This route is found off of Channel road just below Ferret's Folly crag. You find the start by looking just right of Fatty Bolger 11a to the obvious line of bolts going up the arete. The initial wall on the right of the arete has no climbing routes as another indication that your there. You can walk off this climb or be lowered back down.
routes.protection: 6 bolts protect the entire route...there could be a few more if you ask me. Anchor is bolts at the top.

routes.description: The left side of the Fatty Bolger crag has four lower angle sport climbs.  They are all good introductory leads.  This is the hardest of them and can be quite tough if you make a conscious effort to limit yourself to holds along the bolt line.  It can be made easier by straying left and right at times.  These are some of the best and only introductory sport climbs in the area, and although they are fairly low-angle, they are worthwhile.  Despite being low-angle, they aren't the friction slabs that are so common in this area; there are holds.
routes.location: Left side of Fally Bolger crag, second line left of the gully.

routes.description: This climb starts with a pretty mellow crack, gets a little more intense when you have to leave the crack to a bolt, peaks with a fun pull over a bulge and then lets you down easy with a twenty foot runout on easy friction.  A very fun climb.
routes.location: This is the first climb right of the mossy gully that divides the two halves of Fatty Bolger.
routes.protection: A few finger to hand-sized cams and nuts for the initial crack, then two quickdraws.  There's a two-bolt anchor at the top (no rap hangers or chains), and a straightforward walk-off.

routes.description: Climb the corner to the first bolt, then break out left up the arete
routes.location: Bolts

routes.description: I found the climb so sustained that I couldn't begin to feel for the crux specifically. The top gets a bit easier. The climb as a whole is exceptional and I highly recommend doing it.
routes.location: This route is just right of Rumours 10a it follows the bolted line that goes up and to the right a bit before going straight up. It is the first line of bolts right of the crack start for Rumours. Lower down or walk off
routes.protection: 7 bolts protect the route with an anchor at the top

description: A pleasant little crag with four nice moderate routes and a steep bolted face climb.  Very close to Ronin's Corner.   Bring a standard rack for the moderate cracks here, possibly doubles of 1" and 2" pieces.
getting_there: This crag is above Penny Lane, and there are a couple of ways to get there:   From Penny Lane: go up the East Gully at the far right-hand side of Penny Lane.  There is a cool fallen tree that has been turned into a staircase about halfway up the gully.  Above the gully the trail splits.  If you go right, you will get to Ronin's Corner.  Continue up left to Fern Gully.   From the Loop Trail, east end:  If you take the Valley Trail past the turn off for Penny Lane, and keep going for a bit, you will eventually get to the second turn for the Loop Trail.  Take this up, past new staircases.  When you can turn left at a rock (Ronin's Corner), do so.  Follow this left to the top of the East Gully of Penny Lane, and then continue up.   Total approach time from the parking lot ~15 minutes.

routes.description: This route is on the right-hand side of the wall, up the obvious hand-sized cracks, past a large tree.   The start is on a ledge (dirty), and traverses left into the cracks.   The direct start takes a thin crack straight up, and meets the action at the ledge (5.8).  This is the better start.   Another route (Rampage, 5.8) traverses left on the rounded ledge about 2/3 of the way up, passing a bolt and up to the top of Fern Gully.  This variation seems quite contrived, and isn't really all that interesting compared to Christa's Revenge.
routes.location: Standard rack (maybe as large as 3 inches).  Two bolts at the top.  Walk off left, or rappel Fern Gully.

routes.fa: Sean Williams, Mike Pascoe, Rosaria Mandaione  1988
routes.description: A great left-leaning crack.  Starts thin and balancy, then fingers to off-fingers, thin hands to sinker hands.
routes.location: At the far left-hand side of the wall, just to the left of Fern Gully.
routes.protection: Standard rack, though doubles of 1" to 2" are nice to have.  Belay at the bolts for Fern Gully.  Rappel the chains or walk-off left.

routes.description: A very fun route for this grade.  Great cracks toward the left end of the wall.  This is an excellent choice for new leaders; there are ample placements, and solid stances.
routes.location: Standard rack to 2 inches.  Two-bolt anchor with chains.  Rappel or walk left.

routes.description: A bouldery start leads up to some nice cracks that traverse up and left to the anchors.
routes.location: Gear to 2.5".

routes.description: Climb up the thin slab just to the left of Rampage following the line of bolts. At 2/3 height cross directly up over Rampage and over the cracks of Christa’s Revenge to gain the upper slab.
routes.location: Bolted slab immediately to the left of the Rampage finger crack.
routes.protection: 7 bolts, 2 chain anchor, an extra .75-1” piece could be placed where the route crosses over Christa’s Revenge

routes.description: Climb the short crack (gear optional) to some very tough slab moves to get past the first couple of bolts. A bit runout at the top as well.
routes.location: The left bolted line at Fern Gully.
routes.protection: 5 bolts and a cam or two for the lower and upper sections without bolts.

description: This crag has it all: bolted sport routes (from 10b to 12b), top rope anchors, and trad routes (from 5.8 to 12a).A bit more shaded than the cliffs above so great for hot and sunny days.
getting_there: From the Smoke Bluffs parking lot, hike up the main trail a short ways and cross the small bridge; hold right to head into the trees onto a shaded wooden walkway. When the trail ends at the Blind Channel (about 0.1mi), head left and walk along the water amongst the trees, past Jug Slab, The Zip, and Sidecar, until at least you reach Free and Easy (about 0.33mi).

routes.description: Start under the lone bolt on the wall immediately right of the Free and Easy roof, pull an easy boulder problem, cross into Insta-Graham aiming for the second bolt on the slab up and right of that crack. Transition onto the slab and make some delicate technical moves (crux) to the anchor.
routes.location: Just right of the Free and Easy roof.
routes.protection: A couple of cams will protect the short crack section between the two bolts.

routes.description: An inclined slab, not using the crack to the left.
