routes.location: In between the two cracks on the face.
routes.protection: 7 bolts with rappel rings and anchor on the top.

routes.description: A very chill warmup slab in between the iron ladder and Marjorie Mae. A few somewhat frictiony moves, but generally everything is well textured. Excellent stances make this a great route for beginner trad leaders – just remember to extend your gear.The small juggy ledge near the top is on, but the crack is off (except for pro), and obviously the ladder is off. Shares the same anchor as Marjorie Mae, Tenacious, and The Cagemaster.
routes.location: Right between the iron ladder and Marjorie Mae (5.5 crack) at the high upper left side of the crag.
routes.protection: SR to 1.5", extended. If top roping, you may want to redirect with a draw affixed to ladder rung two or three down from the top. But DO NOT use the rungs to lead this as a sport route! The ladder rungs are not rated or designed for climbing; falling on a rung could result in serious injury. Lead it with gear, or just use the ladder to set up a top rope.

routes.description: A interesting meandering line on the far right side of the crag. Start a bit uphill and around the corner of the main wall to reach a horizontal crack, follow it up across a couple of fun moves for the grade to another horizontal hand crack, which you follow to the chains.
routes.location: Far right side of Free and Easy, first route uphill of the main face.

routes.description: Climb up a short right-trending hand crack (same start as Proudly Canadian) to a ledge on the other side of the arete with a large hand-rail moving right. Follow this hand rail to a short vertical section up to another ledge before moving back left through two small flakes to the shared anchor with Proudly Canadian.
routes.location: Start as for Proudly Canadian, starts lower on the left side of the arete before moving right around and then ultimately back left at the end. Shares anchor with Proudly Canadian.

routes.description: This is the left of two cracks in the face.  Quite pleasant, takes a variety of gear, but mostly in the 1" and up range.
routes.location: Varies in width. SR to #3 BD should do it. You can put a #4 but it's not strictly necessary.

routes.fa: Alan Stevenson, Erica Olson, and friends 2015-2017
routes.description: Follow the obvious hand crack up to a few slab moves to finish at the bolts.
routes.location: The right hand of two parallel cracks on the main face of Free and Easy wall.  This one has a small chock stone ~5ft below the horizontal crack.
routes.protection: Two bolt anchor at top.  Gear to 3"

routes.fa: A. Burkovsky, A. Stevenson, E. Olson, 2018
routes.description: Easy slab climbing with somewhat featured rock and ledges.
routes.location: Either climb up from Free & Easy area to the large ledge, or rap in from High cliff area. The trail listed in the book that goes around to the right of Free & Easy no longer exists and is private property

routes.description: Thin gear in the seam protects a stout runout.
routes.location: Follow the thin crack above/left of the first bolt on Range Ball Wrecker then move slightly right following crimps and a horizontal.

routes.fa: Erica Olson, Adam Stevenson, A. Burkovsky 2018
routes.description: Slab climbing with a short finger crack finish at the top. This is the middle route of the Free & Easy upper tier.
routes.location: Either climb up from Free & Easy area to the large ledge, or rap in from High cliff area. The trail listed in the book that goes around to the right of Free & Easy no longer exists and is private property.

routes.description: Ascend the finger crack up in under the roof.  Reach out to jam the crack at the end of the roof and pull through to the upper section of the route.
routes.location: Leftmost crack still under the large overhang on Free and Clear
routes.protection: Fingers to hands; bolted anchor at top

routes.fa: Alan Stevenson, Erica Olson, and friends 2015-2017
routes.description: Ascend the corner crack just to the right of the large roof (not under the roof).  At the horizontal crack mid way up the ledge begin to work left to the upper left crack.
routes.location: Bolted anchors at top.

routes.description: This is the leftmost route on the upper tier of Free & Easy. It's directly above Dance Eat Sleep Repeat and can be added to said route with good rope management. The Fluffy Clouds finger crack is a fun alternate finish to the right.
routes.location: Approach from the right, or by climbing one of the routes in the vicinity of Dance, Eat, Sleep, Repeat.

routes.description: This route starts on the rounded arete between Range Ball Wreckers and the Free n Easy roof.A difficult boulder problem uses a thin vertical crack feature to gain a bulge with a deep horizontal crack (optional cam placement). The route continues up the slab with two more bolts and a good jug between them.
routes.location: Bolts, single cam

routes.fa: Alan Stevenson, Erica Olson, and Friends 2015-2017
routes.description: A low crux on thin holds leads to easier climbing after traversing back to the right.
routes.location: The slab left of Cragger

routes.description: The corner to the right of Trippy Squirrel.
routes.location: Gear

routes.description: Cruxy down low, cruisy in the middle, then a bit cruxy again up high. It climbs similar to Appmaster (the 10b slab to the left).
routes.location: To the right of Trippy Squirrel, in the left face of the dihedral on the lefthand side of the crag.

routes.description: Start up some fun juggy moves protected by a bolt into a rambling low angle (essentially walking) corner until you get to the 5 meter finger crack in the steep headwall (crux). Be aware that a fall off the headwall wouldn't be great as you'd be hitting the low angle ramp below.
routes.location: The obvious low angle corner groove next to Shimmering Crack.
routes.protection: Standard rack and 1 bolt down low. Crux takes small gear.

routes.description: Climb up an easy corner ramp up to two parallel hand cracks just right of a large roof. Transition left above the roof to two parallel cracks, and into the left of the two up to the anchor.
routes.location: Starts under the right side of the large Protein Eater roof, and climbs up and right of this roof before transitioning back left to above the right side of the roof.

routes.fa: Alan Stevenson, Erica Olsen, and friends 2015-2017
routes.description: Start up the fine hand crack past the horizontal ledge.  Clip the one bolt on the face which protects the 10b face move up and to the anchors.
routes.location: One of the two main cracks on the Free and Easy wall; left of 'Dance Eat Sleep'
routes.protection: Hand crack size; one bolt; bolted anchor at top

routes.description: Climb up a short, cracked slab to crank through the obvious roof cracks on mostly bomber jams.Using the ledge to the far right puts the grade at 10+.
routes.location: The obvious roof at Free and Easy, just right of the crag's namesake route. You can't miss it.
routes.protection: BD-sized cams .5-3 should do it. Protects great, just don't get your cams sucked into the crack!

routes.description: Fun climb with only a couple hard moves
routes.location: Could be done on bolts, option of adding two cams.  One low down and one right before the bolt

routes.description: Left leaning crack that thins out to tips, moves right to a tricky mantle move on bolts
routes.location: Gear to 0.75, 2 bolts

routes.description: A tricky highstep from an easy slab leads into a finger crack in a corner that quickly steepens.Pull around the lip and romp to the anchor, clipping a bolt on the way.
routes.location: Hanging LFC to the left of the obvious crack pair of Cragger/Trippy Squirrel.
routes.protection: Thin gear protects the crux moves. Hand-sized and a bolt after the corner.

routes.description: Feeling like all the cool new climbing adventures are way out of your league?Want to turn a normal day cragging into a silly outing? Say no more!May we present to you The Smoke Bluffs Interconnector! A 12 pitch multi that ties together some classic crags and lesser known pitches from the Blind Channel all the way to Nighthawk Lookout!All crag and route info can be found in the new guide book, and there are more than a few variations at most crags to turn this novice route into something a bit more spicy.Climbing isn't always about huge objectives and crushing hard sends. Sometimes its just about being silly and having fun! So get out there, mix it up, and have fun, fellow weirdos!Much Love, Erica Harvey and Ryan Thomas PierceRoute List from Original Topo:Sub Par Intelect (5.9)The Chairman (5.8)Unearthly Delights (5.9)All Mine (5.7)Dance Eat Sleep Repeat (5.8)Leftie's Arete (5.8)Unnamed #2 (5.7)Wisecrack (5.7)No-see-um (5.9)Phlegmish Dance (5.8)Gobbledegook (5.9)Pixie Corner (5.8)
routes.location: Route starts at the Free and Easy Crag. Summit is accessible via various mountain bike trails in the upper section on the bluffs. Descend via Upper Loop Trail.
routes.protection: Standard double rack to BD #4. Variations could effect this.

routes.description: The first bolt line to the right of Dance, Eat, Sleep, Repeat. Tricky friction slabbing continues up past the horizontal break and up a ramp to the anchor.
routes.location: 5 bolts plus an anchor with rappel rings

routes.description: The wide but low-angle crack splitting the face to the right of Cragger.
routes.location: SR to 4"

routes.description: Very slabby climb that starts with a few nubs that will hold decently.Initial bolt is kind of high, 3rd bolt is kind of reachy from the right,Harder route (11b/c) is to go at the slab head on.Easy route (11a) is to avoid the slab and go right.Climb a thin finger crack on the right of the bolts as you get sucked into the offwidth cave between the rocks that allows decent fist jams at the crux.Climb up to the 4th bold for a bouldery move to a bowl-shaped sloppy area where the 5th reachy bolt is at.Continue climbing up right for small edges and bouldery moves to the anchor.
routes.location: In front of some shrubs between two rocks.Look for two "nubs" on the bottom that stick out of the slab as decent foot holds, and another nub sticking out above in arm's reach.
routes.protection: 5 bolts with the bolted anchor with rappel rings

routes.description: After pulling through the initial steep part and clipping a bolt, the corner rocks back. A few low fifth class moves bring you to two options. Option 1: (harder), take the crack on the face on the right-hand side of the corner. Be careful not to disturb the tree frogs that reside there. Option 2: continue up in the corner, and then step right to find the anchor.
routes.location: This is the dihedral right of "unknown a" in MP.

description: Freshly scrubbed (2009), this formerly obscure area is now a fine little destination.  As with most Smoke Bluffs areas is less-than-vertical, but it offers some excellent finger cracks along with undulating slabs.  Some of the slabs are testpieces of the genre.  It is broken into an upper (left) and a lower (right) area separated by a short stretch trail.   There appear to be quite a number of new routes here too recent to to be in the 2005 McLane guide book.  Most are on the lower crag, although there is one very grim looking bolted slab on the upper crag.   New route descriptions are likely in the new route binder at Climb On on Squamish.  One new route is on the left side of the lower crag and is distinguished by being just right of the dirty gully and having two or three bolts in the thin and slabby upper half.  It's reasonably fun and goes at about 10c.
getting_there: This area is just off the Loop Trail between the Elephant's Arse area and the Octopus's Garden.  A sign post beside the trail points the way.

routes.description: Two bolts start is the crux edging on tiny crystals plentiful enough to make up for nearly non existent hands. Climbing goes up to a finger crack through a small roof, then more bolts on the face with lower angle moves on more crystals. Not sure how the FA did the finish, but I linked into another crack up to Squatters rights to top out as it seemed most logical.
routes.location: Immediately right of squatters rights
routes.protection: Mostly bolts, single rack would be more than enough. Climbers confident at the grade could lead with just some finger size cams as the top out left is only low 5th

routes.description: Climb the nice steep finger crack with some technical movement, one bolt at the top after the crack fizzles out. Can easily be top-roped by walking around to the left.
routes.location: Far left side of Funarama crag, on an independent cliff with one striking finger crack on it.

routes.description: Bourdon gives this a 10b, but I didn't think it was any harder than Sunshine Chimney, the p2 squeeze chimney on Rock on or the chimney on Birds of Prey, all 5.8. Lots of ledges and rests, only a few moments of real chimney moves. A fine activity, but nothing noteworthy.
routes.location: The obvious chimney left of all the rest of the climbing.
routes.protection: 1 bolt and standard rack to a #1 C4. Raw bolt hangers at the top, so the second will want to walk off (climber's left).

routes.description: Mellow climbing up the stepped crack. Can be accessed for a top rope via a fixed line around the right.
routes.location: Right on the trail, middle of the short climbs.

routes.description: A high quality crack that takes great gear.  The start is the crux and looks harder than it is.
routes.location: This is the very obvious crack right in front of the trail that joins the crag to the loop trail.
routes.protection: Finger to hand sized cams and nuts.  Bolted anchor.

routes.description: Climb the finger crack to the left of Fun (the stepped hand crack).  More climbing, and more secure, than it might first appear.Anchors abound on the ramp above the slab at the top, and can be accessed by a fixed rope to the right.It's a short route, but worth a run up while you're waiting on a nearby route.
routes.location: More gear than it appears from below, though it is not generous; mostly finger-size.

routes.description: Immediately left of Funarama is an obvious right-trending diagonal ramp. A few face moves get you onto the ramp, which is climbed easily to a junction with Funarama on the ledge where that's route crack dead-ends. The original finish of this route is the same as Funarama's crux, up the bouldery continuation of the ramp. The new finish cleaned by Harry and Robin takes a left-trending diagonal crack that veers out left from the junction ledge to a new bolted anchor on another ledge about 8m left. Going this way keeps the grade to a more consistent 5.8
routes.location: Just left of the straight-in crack of Funarama at Funarama Left.

routes.description: Follow a straight in quality thin crack to a ledge at the point where the ramp of Funarampa joins in from the left and where the crack you have been following suddenly ends. Move left slightly and work up and back right to the top, technical and cruxy to finish.
routes.location: At the left end of Funarama Left, the obvious vertical crack.

routes.description: Slabby arete climbing.  Worth doing in the neighborhood.
routes.location: Slabby arete just left of a big gash.
routes.protection: 4 bolts.  Anchor is all the way at the top and doesn't have chains.  Rap the anchor to the left.

routes.description: Mellow climbing up the obvious crack until a very distinct and a bit awkward crux.
routes.location: Left side of the short climbs on the trail.

routes.description: Climb in & around a stepped hand crack that leans a bit left.  Bolted anchors abound on the ramp at the top, and can be accessed by a fixed rope to the right.Short, but worth a quick run up while you wait for things nearby.
routes.location: Middle of Funarama:  there are several short slight left-leaning, stepped cracks.

routes.description: Start left of Juneuary below a bolt. Clip the bolt then move right to a crux with a diagonal thin crack. Climb this thin crack to where it meeta another thin crack diagonalling back left. Follow this (same as the later route Juneuary) up and left to a ledge just below the top of the cliff. Here, and this you must do to claim the tick of Futurama, step out onto the blankish headwall to the right with smooth foot cross-throughs on a couple of flaring seams (second crux) and on up to the top. Very footwork dependant on the last few moves, not much to pull on with your hands.
routes.location: Right in the middle of Funarama cliff. Used to be just right of a giant burnt log but Hevy Duty removed the log to squeeze more climbs in.   Now just the second line right of the deep corner dividing Funarama Left from Funarama Centre.   Rap anchors on top.

routes.description: Start up left leaning seam before clipping two bolts on the face. An easier section at two cracks leads to more bolts up and left.
routes.location: Quickdraws, some small cams for before the first bolt.

routes.description: Start up a thin seam that trends right, clip a bolt, and then up the left trending finger crack. Crux is at the bolt.
routes.location: Gear is good the whole way, despite appearances.  Nothing bigger than a #0.5 camalot needed.  A purple C3 went in nicely towards the top.  There is a 5.6/5.7 unprotected move to gain the anchor.

routes.description: The furthest right route at Funarama, protection can feel a little spaced but is there when you need it. Begin at a slabby ramp and climb past the first bolt on the right then straight up on intermittent cracks and ledges with a few face moves past two small gear cracks and a second bolt. The crux is the last moves above the second bolt up to the welcome jugs of the belay ledge.
routes.location: The farthest right and farthest downhill route at Funarama Right-Hand
routes.protection: Two bolts plus a medium wire and a 3/4" cam. Two bolts at top for anchor, traverse climbers left on ledge to First Class rap station for descent.

routes.description: Primary a crack climb, there's a point in the middle where it becomes blank (hence the name).  The various cracks you link up take textbook gear placements.
routes.location: In the upper section of the crag, this route starts just right of a stump, directly below a series of three diagonal cracks at the top of the crag.  The route, as done in the FA, goes more-or-less straight up at the top, touching all three of the upper cracks.  Recent scrubbing and anchor placement might draw you left on the first of those cracks, but that take the grade and the fun out of it.
routes.protection: Eats finger sized nuts and cams.  A few hand sized pieces can be used.

routes.fa: D Brayshaw J Ford C Fleet 1999
routes.description: Climb the opening moves of Funarampa and pull out left over a bulge on finger flakes. Climb up thin cracks and ripples past two bolts. Where the features blank out, tenuous slab moves lead to an upper ledge. Climb a short double hand crack to the top and rap anchors.   Originally climbed as a boltless headpoint by the FA team after they forgot the drill; the bolts were added the following spring.
routes.location: At the left end of Funarama Left, straight up from the bottom of the Funarampa ramp. A newer route called Pliocene Ape climbs between Funarampa and Ramapithecus and features similar climbing at a similar grade.
routes.protection: Gear to 1" - include some RP sized nuts and thin cams - and two bolts

routes.description: This climb is something of a one-move-wonder, but is still fun.  The move at the bolt is surprisingly difficult and most would agree harder than the grade of 5.10a given in the guide book.  The right-trending crack after the bolt is easier to walk across, but hand-traversing it is fun and ups the grade to about 5.10d.
routes.location: Just right of Point Break on a wavy slab, easily distinguished by the single bolt below a right-trending crack.
routes.protection: One bolt plus some finger-sized cams for the horizontal crack.  A few nuts and hand-sized pieces for the rest.

routes.description: Climb intermittent hand cracks left of Squatters Rights to a very small roof. step up over this and face climb, zig-zagging past two bolts to gain a upper ledge and a short finishing crack. Good varied climbing with interesting route finding at the crux.
routes.location: Immediately left of Squatters Rights and right of the Backhoe Chimney at the uphill side of Funarama Right

routes.description: A long straight crack at the left end of Funarama Right. The crux moves are off the ground with some face holds and intermittent cracks, then it is a long hand to fist crack to the top with great jamming and plentiful protection opportunities.
routes.location: Left end of Funarama Right about 1m right of the deep chimney dividing Funarama Right from Funarama Centre

routes.description: Climb the discontinuous left leaning cracks to the right of Point Blank. When the cracks end, clip a bolt and continue up the smooth slab split by a horizontal crack. Two additional bolts provide protection above the horizontal crack. Exit the slab onto an easier hand crack that leads to the top.   The crux of this climb is at the second and third bolt on the slab. Note that the start of this climb is shared with the climb September Song.
routes.location: Funarama, to the left of Point Blank

routes.fa: FA D Brayshaw M Buda 2002  FFA John Millar D Brayshaw 2003
routes.description: Begin up First Class and move left on a left-arching crack/ramp to a ledge (a newer route called Armspan 5.12b/c or 11- A0 crosses through here). Climb cracks off the ledge to a cruxy bolted slab move to another ledge (short 11a/b crux), then up a leftward diagonalling crack. Where it ends, finish either left up a short corner or take the original finish right a few meters and up to the top.    The route is consistently 5.9 except for the crux past the bolt and can easily be done as a 5.9 A0 by pulling on the bolt.
routes.location: At the lower end of Funarama Right, left of the straight in thin crack of First Class. A newer mostly bolted line called Armspan climbs directly up to the lower ledge, crosses WC and then climbs between it and FC to the top. Another mostly bolted new route called Classless (10d) climbs left of WC and immediately right of Squatters Rights.

description: RECENTLY CLEANED!!!! Across the trail from the far far left of Funarama. Many moderate, low angle, short routes to warm-up on, or to go with a beginning leader. The wall also can be set up for top roped. Follow up the main trail then keep an eye out on the left for boot path to go to the top of the wall.
getting_there: Follow directions to Funarama, and then look across the trail from the far left of the main Funarama crag.

routes.description: Start in crack Left of Crouching Squirrel, then move up and right joining with Crouching Squirrel, then move back left to finish.
routes.location: Standard Rack, Bolt anchor with no rappel ring. Walk off climber-right

routes.description: The crack on the far right of The Nursery.
routes.location: Standard Rack, Bolt anchor shared with Cheeze the Cat. No rappel ring, walk off on climber right

routes.description: Easy crack on the far left on The Nusery. Do not fall to temptation and veer right as that is 5.7 route called the Hopper. Stay left and finish up the easy crack.
routes.location: Standard rack. Bolted anchor with no rappel ring. Walk off climber right

routes.fa: FA: Bryan Kent, Alana, Zavier Derouche (2010)
routes.description: Start up "The French Maid", then veer right up the fading crack past bolts.
routes.location: Left side of the crag, across from the far north part of Funarama.

routes.description: Fist / Lieback crack on the left side of The Nusery. Felt very easy for 5.7.
routes.location: Left side of the Nusery
routes.route_name: Silly Hippie Handrilling is for Fools

routes.description: Climb starts up the diagonal left crack as for "French Maid" and "The Hopper" then moves out onto the face up the bolt line.
routes.location: On the left side of The Nusery.

routes.description: Start by a tree in the middle of The Nusery. Basic short, low angle, crack climb.
routes.location: Middle of The Nusery.
routes.route_name: Things To Do When It Rains

description: A fantastic little bouldering area directly above Neat & Cool containing about a dozen boulder problems, mostly moderates with great flat landings. Highlights are Winding Down (V0) and The Past Is Present (V1).
getting_there: From the playground take the main trail left and uphill towards Pixie Corner, taking the first left possible will lead you to the Gravity Train area in about a minute.

routes.description: Up the middle of the face to an exciting reach to a jug at the top. Excellent!
routes.location: Across & downhill of the Gravity Train area, below(SE of) the utility poles

routes.description: Start on a thin flake and make a few insecure moves with tough feet up to a groove crack.
routes.location: The leftmost route up the hill.

routes.description: A stellar and long hand traverse across the diagonal crack. A bit of a spicy and insecure finish, but easy to downclimb out of if you get spooked.
routes.location: The obvious long diagonal crack that traverses the face.

routes.description: Start above the small cut stump and climb the shallow groove up, finishing on the right.
routes.location: Above the small cut stump on the far right side.

routes.description: Start left left of the log step using the right side of the ledge to get up to good crimps on the face.
routes.location: Just left of the log step.

routes.description: An absolutely stellar finger crack highball. Incredibly secure fingerlocks on thin feet give way to big jugs and a stress free finish. Highly recommended!
routes.location: The obvious finger crack as the ground starts to trend uphill.

routes.description: Start on a chalked crimpy seam with a good left hand sidepull and pull up and left.
routes.location: The right most route in the area.

routes.description: Climb the left most crack of the group of cracks.
routes.location: Left most crack on the group of cracks left of the obvious large groove/corner.

routes.description: An absolute classic. Hand jam your way up this perfect boulder crack. Not to be missed!
routes.location: The obvious right leaning hand crack.

description: This is a small, long overlooked, wall that sits between Krack Rock and Cabin Boys Office. It has great ambiance during the summer as it is sheltered from the sun until just before sunset. It is a great place to climb when the sun is cooking the other crags in the Smokebluffs.    This crag will seep for some time after significant rain but this is not an issue during the summer months.   All routes are have easy top-rope access.
getting_there: Approach is via Krack Rock or Zombie Roof.    If approaching from Krack Rock, keep walking past Krack Rock towards Cabin Boys Office and Zombie Roof. The crag is at the furthest end of Krack Rock where you can access the top of Krack Rock via a fixed line in a groove.   If approaching from Zombie Roof, keep walking past Zombie Roof and Cabin Boys Office towards Krack Rock. The crag is visible from Cabin Boys Office.   Fastest approach from the parking lot is via Krack Rock.

routes.description: Just to the right of the groove, climb up a diagonal crack to a bolt, from here move right and up to the large platform. Step up over the overhang and follow the bolts up strange white streaked rock. Mantel to finish.   To clean this climb, you can either walk off using the two fixed lines on the left or you can rappel off of the Made of Clay anchor.
routes.location: 6 bolts, bolt anchor at the top    To clean, use rap rings at the top of Made of Clay.

routes.description: The namesake route on the wall. This is a long forgotten route that was recently re-scrubbed.   Belay from the small ledge (top of the groove with the fixed line) or at the base of all the climbs
routes.location: Standard Rack, currently no anchor at the top.

routes.description: This route goes up the middle of the wall and exits in a shallow corner just to the right of the white streak.   There are 3 distinct crux's, one at each bolt.   Use the rap station at the top of this climb to clean all of the climbs on this wall.
routes.location: 3 bolts, Standard Rack

routes.description: Climb the prominent diagonal finger crack to the large horizontal and then finish on either Blockheads (5.10b) or Made of Clay (5.10d).   Excellent finger locks on the starting moves!
routes.location: Bolts, Standard Rack

routes.description: At the far right of the wall, a lone bolt protects a shallow corner, above the big horizontal, with a few small discontinuous face cracks.    The actual start of this climb is unknown, it could be the crack start of Pokey's Variation or it could be the large corner.
routes.location: Bolts, Standard Rack

description: A shady little crag below Burgers and Fries that has some good climbs and seems to be a little less crowded than more classic crags at the Bluffs. Stay on the path downhill and to the north to reach Island in the Sky and The Zip.
getting_there: This crag is below Burgers and Fries. Walk the main path a few meters south then go downhill at a sign. You will see the dihedral of 20 Minute Workout.

routes.fa: Bill Kipper,Harry Young, and others Aug 1996
routes.description: Left to right diagonal crack, to face moves. Left most climb at lower high cliff crag.
routes.location: A little tricker then most of Squamish at 5.9 single rack, anchors at the top.

routes.fa: Bill Kipper, Derek McGuire, John Smith. 1995
routes.description: Climb the arete right of Twenty Minute Workout. There is a bolt high up the arete. Might be able to get in some small gear in a horizontal before that but basically the bolt is the only gear on the pitch.
routes.location: south end of High Cliff, right of Twenty Minute Workout.
routes.protection: draw up to anchors. rap or walk off

routes.description: Easy climbing up to a slightly overhanging finger crack.  Jam or Layback (easier) the crack to get over the bulge and climb easily to the top.  The upper portion of the route can be dirty, but it shouldn't cause any problems due to the easy nature of the climbing.
routes.location: A few metres right of Run like a Thief
routes.protection: Cams from tips to thin hands, a single set should be fine, with maybe two .75s. chains at the top.

routes.description: Climb the pleasant face crack on the slab left of the arete. Finish either left or right (or both) at the top.
routes.location: SR, top anchors are chains

routes.description: Climb moss to some overhanging crack moves.  Finish up more crack.
routes.location: Right of bolted 5.11 slab.  Just around the corner, left of Loony Fringe.

routes.description: Climb flakes through incipient gear up the arete left of Twenty Minute Workout. Cool position and good climbing. This pitch is worth doing if you've alreay done lots of the classics.
routes.location: Arete left of Twenty Minute Workout. Kind of bouldery start to first gear.
routes.protection: Double rack of thin hands - hands. Single rack of fingers (doubles opt). Nuts. Bolts for anchor.

routes.description: Climb the face with small crimps and lieback flakes just to the right of "Twenty-Minute Workout."
routes.location: 4 bolts, top anchor is 2 bolts

routes.description: Traverse up and right along a tricky crack. Climb up past two bolts on the slab above to finish. A mix of physical and techy, cool route!
routes.location: Right trending crack below a slab just left of the Miner Matters scoop.
routes.protection: Finger-sized pieces for the initial crack, draws for the bolts, another piece or two for the end (it gets easier).

routes.description: A fun climb through a series of scoops then trending slightly left to stay 10a
routes.location: 20'? left of Red Nails.

routes.description: The crux is early. Painful skin splitting moves lead to the piton. The slab climbing at the top is in the low 5.10s.
routes.location: Only climb on cliff with a piton.
routes.protection: Standard single rack plus Small gear blue, green alien to protect the slab at the top. Piton. Anchors at the top.

routes.description: Kind of a one move wonder but a wonderful move. Broken flakes lead to a large edge. The crux is the right facing corner off the edge with easier but interesting climbing beyond.
routes.location: 20' right of Rednails
routes.protection: Single rack. Anchors at the top.

routes.description: Climb starts on the south side gets up on to the arete. Up curving grove then across to the bolt on the slab.  Around the corner is a direct start (12b G.Hanzel G.Henning 2bolts)
routes.location: Goes up the corner between the south and west side of the crag.
routes.protection: Single rack, anchors at the top

routes.description: A fun climb starting with an overhanging crack leading past a tiny granite tufa. Easier climbing on wider cracks leads to the top.
routes.location: Just right of Red Nails.
routes.protection: Single rack to 3". Anchor at top. Choice between a little rope drag and falling on a rock at the beginning.

routes.description: Big, deep crack with an almost-overhang in the middle.
routes.location: Just left of a bolted 5.11 slab (often mossy).
routes.protection: SR to 3".  A #3 or #4 cam is nice to have.

routes.description: The highlight attraction at the High Cliff right off the trail. A little scramble up a ramp to a clean dihedral for about 30 feet. Fun 5.10 locks in a corner that's a little harder than it looks.
routes.location: Obvious, starts on the trail on the south end of High Cliff.
routes.protection: double set cams yellow alien to .75, a #1 and a #2 (opt shallow placement). Nuts.

routes.description: Start on either right or left crack
routes.location: SR, mostly larger gear 1”-3”. Anchors up top.
5 bolts

routes.description: Discontinuous cracks
routes.location: 5m left of Beware the Frieds of Starch

description: This small wall is located to the south and slightly uphill of The Zip, between that wall and Car Jack crag. Easily recognizable by the long corner with the #3/#4 camalot twin crack start (Fissureman's Friend) and a short, left leaning off fingers crack to ring bolt anchor followed by bolted sport pitch. Seems like a less traveled crag that could offer some solitude on busy days in the Bluffs.
getting_there: If walking the gravel path from the parking lot to the Zip (walk out the parking lot to the road, past the company then left onto the path, heading south) take the left past the Zip and head uphill following the path to the first wall. Alternatively, you can get here from above by going downhill on a small path below Burgers and Fries and then North past High Cliff and Car Jack Crag.

routes.description: The cool, long corner at Island in the Sky. Start up the baggy #3s crack or the splitter #4 crack just right of it to a ledge (tough start for the grade). Continue up the low angle crack to the main dihedral. Continue to place somewhat difficult to find pro and bear hug up a fun flake to a bulge. Pull through to another ledge and one last splitter corner to the chains.
routes.location: Starts right off the path, to the right of the short, left leaning crack to two ring anchor.
routes.protection: Take at least doubles of .75camalot to #2 camalot. And at least a #3. You could take 2x #3 and 1x #4 camalot too. Also bring a set of nuts and some finger pieces (although you don't need to place finger gear if you dont want)

routes.fa: J Brown, B Matheson, D Sulina (2000)
routes.description: A short (50 foot) left angling off fingers splitter to a bomber ring bolt anchor. This pitch, although short, is a really awesome crack at 10a This route leads to a bolted slab called “This” 11b Follow the bolt line to anchors and lower with a 70m. Rope stretcher don’t forget a knot at the end of your rope!
routes.location: just left of fissureman's friend. Good to do both real quick on the way past this crag to other classics.
routes.protection: P1. All that is required is a yellow, grey, red alien and a .5 camalot. You could also drag up a #1 and/or a .75 and or a second yellow alien, but it's not runout to do the whole pitch on 3 - 4 pieces of gear.  P2 has bolts.

routes.description: Climb the gently left-leaning 5.7 crack system finishing at a chain anchor to the left once you come over the top. Feet will be mostly slab features for the first 2/3rds of the climb. Crack starts shallow but gets deeper after a few moves.     At the time of posting this, the crack was a bit dirty--the area is still clearly under development. Definitely a hidden gem of a climb.
routes.location: From the parking lot, walk past Burgers and Fries to the next trail on the right. Marked sign will indicate to High Cliff. Follow trail down and past high cliff. First developed area you come to is Island in the Sky.     The Kip is located just to the right of Fissureman's Friend (found in the guidebook).  To get to the base of the climb, scramble up a gully lined with cedar trees.  Belay will be on the ledge to the left.   Face also has a bolted slab climb, not in the guidebook. Felt 5.9/10a.  Perhaps a local could tell you.
routes.protection: Gear to 2", there are bolts and chains for the anchor

routes.description: Fun slabby sport climb, shares anchors with The Kip. As I am not a local, tough to grade but 5.9 or 10a seemed right.    Follow slab face straight through the bolt line, pulling over the bulge to the anchors on the left.    Crux is before the first bolt on thin, but good edges.  Bolt is high, so if nervous bring a stick clip.
routes.location: Take marked trail to High Cliff and continue past to next developed area, Island in the Sun. Climb will be to the right of Fissureman's Friend; access by scrambling cedar tree lined gully at right. Belay ledge will be on the left (shares ledge with The Kip).
routes.protection: Quickdraws; 5 bolts to the anchor; bolts and chains at anchor

description: A small just south of Funarama, and north of call it a day.
getting_there: Approach via smoke bluffs loop trail as for Funarama.

routes.description: The big burly short crack.
routes.location: single rack

routes.description: Follow up the diagonal crack that splits the crag from left to right. When it widens move on to the face above past 2 bolts traversing right along the dyke and ramp.
routes.location: Single rack & 2 bolts

routes.description: Follow up a slanting right arete with cracks.
routes.location: Left side of crag.

description: Krack Rock is a trailside crag with numerous cracks ranging from 5.6 to 5.10c.  Top ropes can be set by scrambling up on the left (dirty 4th class).
getting_there: Follow the main trail from the parking lot for several minutes keeping an eye out for a smaller trail heading into the trees on the left.  The crag is visible from the trail and is easily recognized by all of the left leaning cracks.

routes.description: Start off with a short, fun, and perhaps sandbagged crux with great hand jams and awkward body position. That's where the good times end... The second half of the climb is dirty, tedious, and the rock quality is poor. Rotten roots and grime clog the wide cracks and it seems no amount of cleaning could save this thing. The anchor bolts are easy to miss (far out right on the upper slab. If you make it to the trees, you've gone to far).    Some users on other sites have made the case that the start of this route is much harder than the guidebook proposes. It definitely requires some solid hand crack technique. While I wouldn't argue with an upgrade, it's certainly no harder than 5.7
routes.location: Left side of Krack Rock. Starts up the fine-looking hand crack just before the trees.
routes.protection: Standard Rack with an emphasis on large hand size pieces. Easy to protect throughout, except when the crack becomes clogged with roots and grime. Crux protects beautifully. Two-bolt anchor at the top right, easy to miss.

routes.description: Lower half is the crux. the holds and gear appear as you go.I noticed that many of you are saying this is 5.8 or 5.7. I downgraded it to 5.9 from 10a in a older book, I didn’t want to sandbag someone but I agree it’s more like 5.8.
routes.location: lower center of Krack Rock, right of Lonely Thunder, left of Popsickle.
routes.protection: standard rack to #3, extra in small cams (optional #4).Shares anchor with Popsickle

routes.description: a worthwhile 5.8/5.9 if you have not tried it.  Starts in big black streak, leans left, finish on Fairy Ring anchor.
routes.location: left of Koko crack, right of corner with thin finger crack- which is quite good for the little inside corner-maybe 10b.

routes.description: Climb a finger crack to a ledge then stem and lie back up the obvious left-facing corner through the crux. Finish on easier terrain.
routes.location: Left side of the Krack Rock, first route that climbs to the obvious big ledge 10 feet up.

routes.fa: Peder Ourom, Jens Ourom & Harry Young, 2013
routes.description: A fun hand crack splitting the face to the left of Fairy Ring (5.6). Bottom section can be a tad seepy adding to the challenge low-down.For a 10a finger crack variation, cut right about 1/3rd of the way up.
routes.location: Left side of Krack Rock

routes.fa: Peder Ourom, Jens Ourom, Harry Young, 2013
routes.description: The finger crack variation of the left leaning diagonal crack. This variation seemed so seperate from the route it shares a start with, I felt it needed its own page. Once at the first little ledge, head right towards the splitter finger crack. Great gear, great locks and sustained until the ledge. The best route at this crag in my opinion!
routes.location: Climb the left leaning hand crack of On Sight Inc. until you reach the finger crack.
routes.protection: The splitter eats BD .3 to .75. Doubles in those sizes were useful for the whole climb.

routes.description: a decent 5.7 crack, mostly hands. The long angling left one that is right of Koko crack.  This name spelling is in 90's guide, it is popsicle in the select book.
routes.location: right of Koko crack. Same anchor
routes.protection: standard rack, extra in hand size.

routes.description: this is the next crack right of Fairy Ring and finishes on that one.It is mostly a hand crack leaning left ( like all the cracks on this lump) You will find better routes near by at the grade- laughing crack, cat crack and corner crack. But if it's all there is it's ok.Winning remark here: Shitty, hard , awkward, hated it! Ha ha .
routes.location: right of Fairy, left of a finger crack through a roof.
routes.protection: mostly hand to fist size cams, and some smaller cams work.

description: Secluded, shady crag on the trail from Nubile Woman to Black Zawn/Crystal Wall.
getting_there: From the parking lot - follow the trail to Black Zawn then continue up past Crystal Wall and turn the corner.    From the stairs above Pixie Corner, hike back towards Nubile Woman and take the trail heading left off the loop Trail just past the right hand fork to Split Beaver. Follow it down to the crag in 5 minutes.

routes.description: The 2 bolt line just left of Birthday Girl
routes.location: 2 draws and a couple of cams.

routes.description: Follow big holds up the right side of the short face.
routes.location: Right of Masquerade

routes.description: first start option, Left crack just to the right of Erica.
routes.location: 2 meters right of Ercia

routes.description: Climb through a small, cracked groove just right of It's a Roller. At the cut out bay, climb up the right side corner to a face climb to the anchors.
routes.location: 1 meter right on It's a Roller.

routes.description: Attractive crack to a committing bulge half way up. The bulge is the crux, rely on good finger locks and footwork to pull through.
routes.location: In the middle of Lumberland there is a burnt out tree stump, Erica is just to the right of it.

routes.description: This climb is on the left side of the crag. Start up easy ledges to a short corner. at its top, move left onto the slab and climb past a staircased series of horizontal cracks/seams to the top.    The GMB refers to the "Good Morning Boner" or "morning wood" in a continuation of the naming theme for the crag.
routes.location: Left side of the main crag.
routes.protection: Originally a gear climb with 2 bolts. Additional bolts were added by the FA party in the early 2000s - there are now a total of 3. Some additional gear can be useful, particularly a purple (#0) TCU or #3 Rock, and red Tricam.

routes.description: Face climb past a couple of bolts to reach a square cut bay. From here, follow a shallow, right-facing corner past a bolt to the top.
routes.location: Start just right of Lumberland
routes.protection: Mixed protection. Small sizes 0, 1, & 2's for trad.

routes.description: Thin crack just left of Check Mark. No cheating and using the Check Mark crack.
routes.location: in between Erica and Check Mark

routes.description: Start on the right of the crag. A couple moves along a sloping shelf (foot traverse much easier than hand traverse) lead to a straight-in finger crack that is followed to the top past a short thin section with good fingerlocks.Named for the ancient collapsed shack found near the base of the crag.
routes.location: Double bolt anchor on top placed in 2005 replaces the old rotten stump anchor. Rap from the GMB chains or walk off easily in 1 minute back to the base.

routes.description: Climb the left arete of the south face, staying on the right (south) side of the arete.
routes.location: Sharp rock in landing area which will easily cut or wear a hole in your bouldering mat if you let it.

routes.description: The Lumberland Boulder is a large boulder located just downhill of the Lumberland crag.Norwegian Wood climbs the right arete of the south face then handrails left along the top of the south face to the summit and a mantel finish.
routes.location: Good landing, pad helpful but not mandatory.

routes.description: This is on the west face. Climb the slabby left side of the arete that Morning Wood climbs the right side of.
routes.location: Sharp rock in landing zone.

routes.description: Climb the slabby left-hand arete on the west face, left of Wood Eye. Friction-dependent with few real holds so best on cold days.
routes.location: Better landing than the adjacent problems.

routes.description: The original start was directly below the double cracks and bouldered up to the sloping ledge. This has mossed over somewhat as of 2009. Currently the best start is to begin up the GMB and move right at the sloping ledge about 12 feet up.   From the ledge, climb up double thin cracks to a mantle onto a diagonal crack. Shuffle left a few feet then climb diagonally right across the slab above past two bolts to gain larger faceholds just left of the upper crack of Lumberland.
routes.location: In the centre of the crag between the GMB and Lumberland.
routes.protection: Gear to 1" and two bolts. Bolted anchor shared with Lumberland. Rap GMB or walk off to descend.

routes.description: Climb left side of a short face past a bulbous flake. Bouldery moves.
routes.location: Face next to Check Mark (5.6)

routes.description: Clip a single bolt on the rounded arete. From here move up the left along a broken crack. staying left of the bolt line for GMB.
routes.location: left of The GMB.

routes.description: Awkward start to left leaning diagonal crack.
routes.location: Left most crack on Lumberyard.

routes.description: Use a short, V-shaped groove to access the ledge below the crux on Just Jackin'.  From here, follow the ledge right to a traversing crack (shared with Kristen) until it's possible to finish up a cracked groove right of the Business Time finishing slab.  A 5.8 variation, Boobie Salad, climbs straight up from the ledge along a crack to finish on Colleen.
routes.location: Starts off The Hilton Ledge (the long shelf that splits the crag into upper an lower halves).

description: This small area has five short but reasonably good climbs.  Four are bolted (5.9 to 5.11c/d) and the one 5.6 has good gear.  While certainly not a destination, it's a good overflow for when Neat and Cool or Penny Lane are packed.
getting_there: Continue past Neat and Cool and turn left up the trail towards Pixie Corner, this crag is on the steep wall to the right, shortly after turning up towards Pixie Corner.

routes.description: A very short crack.
routes.location: Higher Lunch Break Wall

routes.description: Fun, short warm-up on good edges. The bolting is a little exciting, so be confident at the grade before leading.
routes.location: Turn left from the playground as for Pixie Corner or Lumberland. This route is just uphill from the two mossy, wet sport climbs and the 5.6 crack Bernie. Dries fast.

routes.fa: P. Hill, M. Immerwahr, F. Vaugn, J. Brown, T. Brown, 2003
routes.description: A fun route with two good thinking cruxes.  An initial slab takes you to a good side-pull flake which leads to a ledge that heads left.  When the ledge ends, head up the undulating slab to the top.   This sort of footwork intensive route isn't your typical sport route which makes it a worthwhile tick for someone looking to round out their skill set.
routes.location: This is the third bolted route from the left on the lunch break wall.
routes.protection: Five bolts, carefully placed to preserve a little tree, take you to a two-bolt anchor with quick-links.

description: Neat and Cool is a very popular crag both because it's not a long walk and because it has fun easy trad leads with bolted top anchors.   The 5.5 to 5.8 range here is often too crowded to bother with, but there are great 5.10s and beyond that are often available.
getting_there: Walk south from the climbers' parking lot until the gravel road forks.  Go left, past the outhouses, and follow the curve of the path right.  You will pass several crags including Krack Rock and the Smoke Bluff Wall (big roofs).  When you have a nice big crag on your left and houses on your right, you've found Neat and Cool.

routes.description: Just above the top of the fixed approach rope is a small face with three cracks. Start under the rightmost crack and traverse to the far left left and up leftmost one. Climb the crack till it fades. A tricky face move leads to the anchor
routes.location: Far left upper left of the area above raging duck and pink flamingo.

routes.description: First part is a scramble to a set of chains. Continue up to the dyke and face climb through four bolts to the top chains.
routes.location: In the clean starts area
routes.protection: Four bolts, gear to 2", chains at the top.

routes.description: Start at the bolt to the left of stumps, follow the horinzontal and diagonal cracks trending left to the arete. Finish up a finger crack by the tree.Second walks off.
routes.location: To the left of Stumps on the upper ledge, start at the bolt. Trend left.
routes.protection: Bolts, gear, extra from purple camalot and smaller.

routes.description: Start up the wide dyke of Pink Flamingo and then step left when possible into the crack along the left side of the face. Follow this crack up to the ledge.   A easier link-up that avoids the crux of "Barefoot in China Town" and provides an enjoyable route to the cat crack ledge.
routes.location: Face under Cat Crack in the lower left side of area.
routes.protection: Set of nuts and cams to 3". Dodgy .3 c4 placement on the dyke.

routes.description: Start up the crack left of Pink Flamingo with a tricky low move, then jig left.
routes.location: Face under Cat Crack in the lower left side of area. Crack to the left of pink flamingo.
routes.protection: Set of nuts and cams to 3"

routes.description: Im not sure if this already has a name but i encountered a bat in there when i first did it so here goes the batcave.Start in layback flake and when you can, enter behind the flake to exit into cornflakes. Follow cornflakes to the top.I dont think bringing a rope here won't do you any good cause it would probably get stuck behind the flakes. So not quite a safe climb but if you're confident in your climbing its a really fun little variation.
routes.location: none?

routes.description: Start between Neat and Cool and the offwidth to the left and make thin face moves over the bulge and directly up to the break. Place some gear in the break then move straight up on obvious holds and balance up into the scoop above. Bouldery moves gain the sloping arete and a weird mantle leads to easier ground above. Cryptic and exciting!
routes.location: A couple hand size peices in the horizontal, there are tonnes of bomber placements to choose from.
routes.route_name: Bruce Lee Vs. The Kiss Army

routes.description: A great hand crack.  Plenty of protection for new leaders.  Popular.   Just to the right (squeezed) is a bolted face climb.  Maybe .10b?
routes.location: At the left end of Neat and Cool, there is a large ledge above Pink Flamingo, 5.10b and Raging Duck.  Cat Crack starts up here.  This crack is left of the big flake/arete forming The Edge.  To get to it, you need to mantle up onto a boulder (awkward with another boulder above it).  Then climb the corner to the ledge.  Many do this unroped, but you can also belay this.  There is a two-bolt rappel anchor on the ledge (top of Pink Flamingo).
routes.protection: Gear to 2 or 2.5 inches.  There are placements for larger gear, but there are also small placements right next to those.  Two bolts at the top.  Walk off right to get to the main trail, left to get to the big ledge system.

routes.description: Just above the top of the fixed approach rope is a small face with three cracks. Start  under the rightmost crack and traverse left and up the middle one.
routes.location: Far left upper left of the area above raging duck and pink flamingo.
routes.protection: set of nuts and cams from .6-2"

routes.description: Fun finger cracks lead up a corner to a nice ledge.  The crack to the left is 5.8-.
routes.location: Far right side of Neat and Cool 75 ft past the blasted wall.

routes.description: Climb the splitter finger crack. A great route for learning finger technique.
routes.location: the obvious splitter finger crack on the far right side of the neat and cool formation

routes.description: Follow the finger crack right beside the tree into the dirt groove, passing the tree in the groove and finishing on the crack on the right of the groove.
routes.location: Immediately left of the second dirt groove on the ledge.

routes.description: The right-facing corner, left of Flying Circus.  Mostly hands.
routes.location: Gear to 3.5 inches.  2-bolt anchor with chains at the top.  Rappel, or walk off straight back (slightly left) from the top of the route.

routes.description: Scamper up the jumble of blocks and flakes to the right of the really large flake (Lieback Flake, 5.9).
routes.location: Standard rack.  Two bolt anchor at the top.  Walk off, down the trail just to your left.

routes.description: Climb onto the large block between Mouse Trap and Corner Crack. Once on top, face climb past three bolts to the left of the arete. Avoid any temptation to use the Mouse Trap crack. Finish up using either the two cracks above.    The first bolt of off the large block is somewhat high and unprotected if you start up using Corner Crack. If you instead use Mouse Trap to start, you can place a high piece of gear in the crack and then step over to the block or alternatively face climb over to the first bolt from the crack.
routes.location: Standard Rack, 3 bolts   Two anchors at the top, one with rap rings and one without.

routes.description: The crux of this climb starts after you clip the last bolt.
routes.location: Same as the beginning of Flying circus, go up the crack then climb on good feet  (R) to first bolt. Rap from anchors on top.
routes.protection: a few nuts and some med. size cams, after the last bolt there is a gear placement at the exit move's--- gray ? red alien.

routes.description: This is a sustained fingercrack and a great climb. Its often toproped but I found it to be a fine lead. Its rock is rather polished from TR traffic.
routes.location: Its on the main wall of neat and cool left of the overhang and right of the dihedral the crack looks awesome splitting the face.
routes.protection: Nuts, smaller cams.. you'll figure it out.

routes.fa: Don Serl, Jim Campbell, Dave Harris
routes.description: a nice climb up cracks to a hard face more that's protected with bolts.
routes.location: right side of N&C middle of the face with the horizontal crack.

routes.description: Thin .4 bomber finger crack. The start to reach the first lock is the 'crux' . Then its a short sequence of bomber locks. No bolts as anchor. But the crack continue on the top so a gear anchor is doable to clean. But seriously, just bring a crash pad ans solo it:)
routes.location: Right next to the stairs to go down to Burgers and fries from the main trail, between mosquito and neat and cool. Cant miss.
routes.protection: No anchors. All small gear .4 and smaller.

routes.fa: Robin Barley, Chris Murrell, Howie Richardson 1981
routes.description: Start up the opening cracks of Geritol. Keep moving up and left to hit the traverse ledge at the arete. Go around the corner and make an awkward step down into Neat & Cool just above the crux overlap of that route. Continue up Neat and Cool to the top.
routes.location: Pretty obvious but seldom climbed because of the way it traverses through parts of three other routes, avoiding the cruxes of all of them. Descend as per Neat & Cool.
routes.protection: Trad rack to 3", mostly finger to hand size. Bring a few longer slings or (as on the FA) use double ropes to manage rope drag.

routes.description: The crux comes reaching the first bolt and getting established on the upper wall. There is a bit of ledge if you fall but at least you get a couple bolts. Follow Gross Incompetence until the ledge then trend right following the bolt line. Tricky face climbing on edges and crystals. Finishes with some lay backing on a mini arete feature.
routes.location: Starts off the right hand corner of the giant block right of Neat and Cool. There is a gap you step over and then swing into leftward cracks that traverse the wall. You can also start off the ground further right where there is a little block and a more vertical crack.
routes.protection: Trad gear to the little ledge then two bolts to a bolted anchor with rap rings. Mostly tips to finger size cams with a couple thin hand and hand size pieces up to BD #1.

routes.description: Climb up the slabby face just to the right of TreeBeard past a low bolt, to faults and a high bolt.
routes.location: On the ledge above above pink flamingo, just to the right of TreeBeard and a couple meters left of cat crack.

routes.description: This is a short route with perhaps twenty feet of 5.11a climbing right off the deck followed by another ten feet of 5.8.  Despite that, the climbing is good and worthwhile.  The crux is sutained finger-tips with tough laybacking and stemming.   This route is often cited as a good first 5.11 gear lead.  I think that it is, as long as the leader does place adequate protection (since it's tough right off the deck).
routes.location: This is the right-facing dihedral immediately right of the drill holes from where the cliff was blasted.
routes.protection: Small finger-tip-sized Stoppers and a small cam or two for the crux. A few medium Stoppers to finish. Bolted anchor with chains can be found near the top of the cliff.

routes.description: Thin fingers and feet up, minimal rests, small gear
routes.location: To the right of There you go Andy is a thin continuous seam up to the top
routes.protection: Gear - fingers at mostHangars at top

routes.description: The left side of the obvious flake right of the Flying Circus. A heady route with limited pro- climb the flake to the top, clip a bolt, then climb straight up to the top.
routes.location: Gear (not much, a cam and a couple of nuts will do)

routes.description: The obvious off-width to the far right of Pink Flamingo. Named after one of the the FA's favorite off-width in the creek, "The Big baby"
routes.location: The far left and lower face of Neat and Cool wall, to the far right of Pink Flamingo

routes.description: the finger to hand crack between Cat Crack and Corner Crack. A good beginner lead. Crux near the top.
routes.location: standard rack

routes.description: Long boulder problem on the right side of neat and cool. Power endurance problem. Approachable for the grade as it does not have any really hard moves.
routes.location: Overhang cave on the right of neat and cool

routes.description: Lieback corner above Clean Starts.
routes.location: Far right side of Neat and Cool 75f. past the blasted wall.

routes.description: This route climbs the steepest section of the Neat and Cool crag and is named for the now barely readable graffiti at its base.   The steepness of the route, the slippery start and fiddly initial protection makes this route a stiff lead for the grade.  It initially diagonals up and left on a finger rail, then traverses back to the right on big holds.  At the end of this traverse an underclinging jamming crux leads to a fine but all too short hand crack.
routes.location: A couple of medium nuts and finger sized cams (maybe even tricams) protect the start.  Hand and fist sized  cams for the remainder.  Bolted anchors are easily found at the top.  The bolts are set up for belaying, not lowering, so walk off the back side.

routes.description: This is the splitter, short fist crack that marks the corner between Neat and Cool and Corn Flakes. "Neat and Cool Offwidth" is the unfortunate name given in the McClane guidebook, but it's really solid fists through the business, nothing offwidth about it.    After the nice start, continue rambling up the easy and vegetated corner. The climbing is fun  and the protection is adequate. Near the top the crack becomes caked in munge and it may be best to step left into Corn Flakes (or bring a shovel).
routes.location: The obvious,straight-in corner on the right side of the Neat and Cool crag.
routes.protection: One or two 4" cams protect the start. The rest of the route takes an assortment of hand-sized pieces. Shares an anchor with Corn Flakes.

routes.description: Follow up the thin seam in the centre of the face to the right of Pink flamingo and "Who needs apps"
routes.location: The far left and lower face of Neat and Cool wall, to the right of Pink Flamingo
routes.route_name: On My Way To The Liquor Store

routes.description: This route follows an obvious easy dyke to an overlap onto a bolted slab. The first bolt is 15m+ high above easy climbing with one technical slab move to put the bolt in reach. Many will bring a #1 and/or #2 to protect the last move to this bolt.   It is possible to trend high, unprotected, and slightly off route left to a tree (dirty and broken), sling it, then traverse right onto the slab at the second bolt. Decent option if you forgot the cams.
routes.location: You can find this route to the right of Raging Duck at the far left and lower face of Neat and Cool wall. Look for the in-cut dyke.
routes.protection: #1 or #2 cam. 3 quickdraws to top out anchors with chains. This climb tops out on the Cat Crack ledge.

routes.description: The scoopy arete 15 meters right of 'Kangaroo Corner'. Start on the ramp and move left onto the arete with tricky smearing and balance moves. Climb up the arete to an easier top out.
routes.location: Right of Kangaroo corner 15 meters.

routes.fa: Ivan Christianson, Rolf Rybak, Todd Guyn  1986
routes.description: Follow 5 bolts up a steep slab with two overlaps. Crux may be getting to the first bolt. Some may want to stick clip. A combination of technical slab and and two mantle/lock-off moves will see you to the chains on the Cat Crack ledge.
routes.location: This route is the leftmost route at the Neat and Cool wall found just below and left the main face. This climb tops out on the Cat Crack ledge.
routes.protection: 5 quickdraws to chained anchors. Optional #1 or #2 may fit the first horizontal crack.

routes.fa: Kon Kraft, Jon Manuel, Debbie Schildt, 1979.
routes.description: Just above the top of the fixed approach rope is a small face with three cracks. Start under the rightmost crack as for Chalk up Another one and instead go up following the rightmost crack.
routes.location: Far left upper left of the area above raging duck and pink flamingo.
routes.protection: set of nuts and cams from .6-2"

routes.description: A great finger crack, to the left of Cat Crack.
routes.location: Just to the left of Cat Crack is a V groove with lots of vegetation (Treebeard, 5.7).  The next crack to the left of this is Sally Five Fingers.  Past this is another good crack, Stumps, 5.7.
routes.protection: Gear to 1.5 inches.  Belay off tree at the top.  Walk off the wall to the right, or back down to the ledge to the left.

routes.description: Hands and fingers.
routes.location: To the left of Sally Five Fingers, on the same ledge as Cat Crack.
routes.protection: Gear to 1.5 inches.  Belay off trees or blocks at the top.  Walk left to get back to the ledge, or right to get to the bottom of the wall.

routes.description: Tales From the Gripped is the harder direct start to "Psychopath". Start in the small white dihedral just left of the arete and make fun technical moves to pull into the seam and arete of 'Psychopath'.
routes.location: Right of Kanagaroo Corner 15 meters.

routes.description: Just right of Kangaroo Corner. A very thin seam leads to an easy flake. Bouldery.
routes.location: The obvious thin seam just right of Kangaroo Corner.
routes.protection: one bolt at the crux, optional thin gear for the flake finish.

routes.description: A wide, dirty v-groove between Sally Five Fingers and Cat Crack. An unusual challenge with fun chimney-ish moves.
routes.location: SR; bolted anchor

routes.description: Start up neat and clean then step left onto the thin slab and follow the bolts to the top.
routes.location: Far right side of Neat and Cool 75f. past the blasted wall.

routes.description: To the right of the Stumps crack.  Three bolts leading up the middle face.  Passing the second bolt appears to be the crux with thin slab moves gaining the thin crack cutout feature above the bolt.  From there move up into the xenolithic section above (much easier).  The rating depends greatly on how much you stay or stray from the bolt line to use the crack on the right.I don't have any primary information about the development of this route.  If anyone has that info please let me know and I'll update it accordingly.  Thanks.
routes.location: three bolts

routes.description: Start on the left end of the blast grooves and fire up discontinuous crack systems and heady climbing at times to the horizontal break. Traverse hard right along the horizontal break (no pro except for maybe a small tricam) to the arete. Climb the easy slab on the other side of the arete to the chains.
routes.location: Left most side of the blast grooves.

routes.description: Climb the crack immediately to the right of Pink Flamingo. Awkward moves in a grove lead through a bulge into a neat upper crack.
routes.location: The far left and lower face of Neat and Cool wall, to the immediate right of Pink Flamingo.

description: After you've gone up the stairs just before Pixie Corner, heading towards Octopus Garden you'll see a short crag on the left, with an obvious (climb me!) crack splitting the wall.    This is Nubile Woman, as described as a "minor crag" in the McLane guidebook.
getting_there: Follow the stairs (or the crag-top) from Pixie Corners, east and north, up hill, towards Octopus Garden.  Nubile Woman should be obvious on the left, within 5 minutes.

routes.description: As you're walking towards the Octopus Garden, you may get sidetracked by this short splitter finger crack on the left that cries out "climb me!  climb me!".  It's a worthwhile stop, and fairly soft at 10a - a great first 10.
routes.location: On the left, when you're approaching Octopus Garden from Pixie Corner.
routes.protection: Small gear to 2";  some easy runout to bolted anchor.  Rappel with one rope from chains.

routes.description: Bolted face climb immediately left of Nubile Woman.  Somewhat reachy.  A reasonably fun and quick tick.
routes.location: 4 bolts (may be reachy to clip);  runout easy climbing to anchor.

description: A wonderful moderate climbing area, mostly 5.8 and 5.9.  If you're coming up here to lead these (and they are nice), you might consider bringing a set of hexes and/or some larger cams (up to about #4 Camalot).  Many of the climbs can be led on a standard rack, but two or three are    w   i   d   e.   Because of the ease of top-roping (most climbs have rappel anchors), this place can be crowded on weekends.  Also a bit "buggy."
getting_there: Follow the trail past Neat and Cool, and turn off at the next main junction (signs).  Follow up and up, past stairs and several switchbacks, until the Loop Trail crests, and then descends more stairs.  Then you are almost there.  The trail will lead directly to the wall, and you cannot possibly miss it when you are there.  ~20 minutes.   If you need to get up to (or down from) the top of the cliff, there is a trail that ascends a root-filled gully on the left side past Harry's Crack, 5.8.

routes.description: The wide, blocky corner crack. Ramble up the bouldery blocks to a ledge. Stick to the wide crack on the right, inside the dihedral. Anchor up to the right, however you also could try moving left to a couple slab moves and finish on the hand crack leaning left (the end of the 10b route beside it).
routes.location: The wide, left leaning crack in the dihedral, on the wall that's left of the main Octopus Garden area.
routes.protection: Anchors (just bolts, no rings) up right. To the left (the 10b route) is an anchor with chains. But using the lefthand anchor makes it really hard to clean the 5.8 on rap.

routes.description: Start up the hand and finger crack through a slightly steep section.  Continue left up the diagonal crack to keep it 5.8, or go straight up through the small roof for a fun 5.9 offwidth finish.
routes.location: 20 feet left of Edible Panties.

routes.description: Hand crack on the left side of the wall. The start is a 5.9 boulder move just off the ground, then the rest is solid 5.7 with good jamming. Ends after moving right, out of the crack, towards the top.
routes.location: Left of Octopus' Garden

routes.description: A beautiful route with several cruxes and good gear. Be bold on this one, though, as one of the lower cruxes has groundfall potential and the upper one has big air potential.    This route is easily top roped by climbing any of the routes to the left and moving the rope to the anchors on top of this route.
routes.location: The obvious thin crack system on the right hand side of the wall.

routes.description: Starts by a horizontal slot - press up to clip first bolt. Keep climbing.
routes.location: 3 bolts + SR

routes.description: Climb up the leaning hand, and finger crack. As the crack peters out difficult face climbing leads past 4 bolts. There are several cruxes featuring desperate crystal pinching, crimping in tiny solution pockets, and difficult high steps. The penultimate crux is stepping across to regain a final crack and easier slab move to the arete and the anchor.Big thanks to everyone who gets stoked on our new climbs and continue to encourage us. Much gratitude those who have contributed some of their hard earned dollars to the Sea to Sky Route Development gofundme campaign. Funds go directly to high quality bolts and anchors used on routes such as this.https://www.gofundme.com/seatoskyroutedevelopment
routes.location: Located a few meters right of Electric Balls.
routes.protection: A few cams up to .75, medium nuts, quickdraws. 4 bolts and a fixed lower off anchor.

routes.description: Another great hand crack.Climb up a block to gain a ledge which rises from right to left. At the left side of the ledge is a hand crack that goes up and slightly left. Follow this to the top. The crux may be getting in the crack itself.Anchor at top.
routes.location: Left of the main wall.  There are other routes on this part of the cliff, but they were overgrown when I was there.
routes.protection: Gear to 2 inches (though there is one placement that could take a 3 inch piece if you've got it).

routes.description: Sustained, thin and painful but so worth it.
routes.location: This is the obvious slab directly between Edible Panties and Octopus Garden in the Shade

routes.description: Like Unearthly Delights, this route has a spooky move that can be well protected. Not as sustained or difficult as its neighbor, but good fun nonetheless.
routes.location: Start up the crack just left of Unearthly Delights, then step left across the slab to another crack system and follow that to the top and an anchor.

routes.description: Perfect hands.   Start on the left side of an arrowhead-shaped flake (pointing up).  Jam to the top.
routes.location: Toward the left side of the face.  To the right of this route is a crack (Pipe Dream, 5.8) with a large tree in it, and the left is another crack (Edible Panties, 5.7) with a smaller tree in it.

routes.description: Fun hands, fists, and stacked hands.  If you stay in the wide crack the whole way, the crux comes near the top.  Otherwise you can hand traverse right at a horizontal crack into Monkey Quotient to an easier hand crack.
routes.location: The wide crack with the large tree in it, just to the right of Octopus Garden in the Shade.  Rappel the route off two bolts.
routes.protection: Big gear to #4 Camalot.  Though there are lots of smaller placements to be had throughout.

routes.description: A direct wide crack left of Unearthly Delights.  This has some good OW practice. There are quite a few face holds and smaller cam placements so it's not all wide drudgery. But if you are not used to OW you will want a #4 for the lower wide part, and a #5 for the upper part. It is a good place to practice fist to hand stack or the butterfly hand stack.
routes.location: Middle of the wall, Pipe Dream is the route with tree in the crack that starts left of this. Monkey has same start as this, veers left. Unearthly is to the right.
routes.protection: Mostly hand size cams and larger, but there are a few smaller cracks for nuts and smaller cams.  Bolted belay.

routes.description: A really fun route that will be a little spooky for new 5.9 leaders, but is very well protected the entire way. Sustained and fun, probably the best route at the grade on the wall.
routes.location: On the right hand side of the wall there are two obvious wide cracks. This route starts up the right crack and steps right into a crack at mid height, then right again at the top.

routes.description: Tricky start off the ground on the bulge-y wall leads to easier climbing on a thin chunky seam above. I forget the route name, maybe something about the sun or stars?
routes.location: Anchor at top

routes.description: A thin left leaning crack leads to an unprotectable seam below a bolt, then a few slab moves to a hand crack. Move left to an anchor with chains.
routes.location: Located the right of Harry's Crack. Start rambles up some boulders to a wide crack on a ledge.

description: A relatively uncrowded area with 9 climbs ranging from 5.7 to 5.11d. All routes can be TR'ed by scambling around on the right.
getting_there: From the top of the Pixie Corner stairs continue on the main trail towards Octopus Garden.  Once you pass Nubile Woman (a small crag visible on the left) keep an eye out for a smaller trail leading left.  Follow this to the base of the crag.

routes.description: Left of the main dihedral this route starts up a right leaning finger crack and finishes up a left leaning hand/fist crack.
routes.location: Gear to 3"

routes.description: The bolted arete left of Finger, Fist and Hand.
routes.location: Bolted

routes.description: A left leaning crack that transitions to face climbing past one bolt. A tad runout at the top but there are good ledges for your feet so it's not too bad.
routes.location: To the left of Sparkletoast, on the same part of the wall.
routes.protection: Trad, 1 bolt. Anchor at the top (malleons or bolts, I forget)

routes.description: The thin crack system just left of the main corner starts with some thin moves and mediocre pro leads to easier but sustained climbing above.
routes.location: Gear to 1.5" mostly smaller

routes.description: Starting up a short dihedral, climb a tricky slab sequence to a rest under a roof.  Easy climbing through a juggy block leads to steep technical slabby face climbing.
routes.location: 10m down and left of The Jitter Bug.  The lowest section of One Toque wall.  Pingu crosses through Scorpion.

routes.description: A vague crackline about 15m left of Sparkletoast.  Tricky moves low down, then easier climbing above.  Go up right to finish.
routes.location: Single Rack

routes.description: Start about 10m down and left around the corner of Finger, Fist and Hand.  Leftwards traversing crack through a hanging boulder.  Continue traversing left to top out.
routes.location: Single Rack.  2 x 2" - 3"

routes.description: A nice finger crack with a steep slippery start leads to easier climbing above.
routes.location: This is the right most route and is around the corner from the main area.

routes.description: From the main corner, climb a flake rightward to an awkward finish.
routes.location: Single Rack

description: New wall developed by Aaron Kristiansen‎ that boasts trad climbing from 5.6 to 5.10.
getting_there: This wall is literally located just off the parking lot.

routes.description: "An interesting and thoughtful slab climb"
routes.location: rightmost bolted route on the leftmost section of the wall

routes.description: Some very fun hand-jamming up a pair of left-leaning cracks up to a bolted finish up an arete. I climbed to the left of the bolts and found it was quite pleasant, my partner went right of the bolts and it looked like the climbing ended for him a little earlier.
routes.location: Climber's right of the 4-bolt line "Bed Time", shares an anchor.
routes.protection: Hand-sized gear, then 2 bolts. Chain anchor.

routes.description: Quite a fun little cruiser line - easier than it looks. Easier climbing at the bottom to the first bolt, then clip up 4 close bolts while marching up on decent edges.
routes.location: Climber's right of the obvious splitter hand crack "Definitely Not Dawn Wall".
routes.protection: A mid-sized piece and 4 bolts. Bolted anchor.

routes.description: The hardest route at the crag and a short technical crux. Start up the easy crack and then follow the line of 6 closely spaced bolts up the steep slab.
routes.location: Just where the boulder ramp flattens out there is a large low angle left trending crack, above it is the obvious 6 bolt line of this route.
routes.protection: 6 draws, the first bolt is fairly high up although the climbing to get to it is trivial, could plug in gear below if needed.

routes.description: Climb the very furthest left section of slab on the Parking Lot Rock. Good intro to slab technique.
routes.location: Leftmost line on Parking Lot Rock.

routes.description: A great hand crack
routes.location: Anchors at the top
