routes.description: An easier start that runs parallel to The Isolator, start left of that route with thin hands and feet past two bolts and then merge into the same finish/anchor as The Isolator.
routes.location: The two bolt line immediately right of the blocky corner.
routes.protection: 2 bolts and a cam or two.

routes.description: The right crack. SR to 3.5
routes.location: Dirty crack.

routes.description: Well protected 5.8, that has a few fun moves protected by bolts
routes.location: Far left side of the wall

routes.description: A couple of thin moves to a bolt gets you into easier climbing to the next bolt and then a romp to the anchor.
routes.location: Middle of the white slab left of the 3 major crack systems, 2 bolts on the lower half.
routes.protection: 2 bolts, and cam or two for the upper 5.4 part if you want.

routes.description: Climb the blocky corner to the top.
routes.location: Left side of Parking Lot Rock; follows the obvious, low-angle corner.

routes.description: The left most crack.
routes.location: No anchors. walk off or rap off tree. Trad to a BD 3

routes.description: Bit of a squeeze-job, but has it's own flavour at the beginning. A chill-time crack with a rightward traverse into hand-jamming fun times.
routes.location: Climber's right of the bolt that marks "Pole" on top of the crag's giant boulder.

routes.description: A slabby technical route with a low crux that climbs the line of bolts between the cracks of Bedtime and  Baby Teddy.
routes.location: 7 bolts to a bolted anchor.

routes.description: The face to the right of Kiss is climbed directly. Funky gear to start then bolts.Area Topo:https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&opi=89978449&url= quickdrawpublications.com/w…;ved=2ahUKEwiakv_Ol7mAAxUmCjQIHTqdBygQFnoECBQQAQ&usg=AOvVaw0ikjH1OLp3KDz2lHiZyR-z
routes.location: The face immediately right of Kiss. Shares an anchor.
routes.protection: 2 bolts, mixed. Small cams and nuts

routes.description: Hands and wide hands, maybe even a fist or two. Jugs to the top.
routes.location: The splitter hand crack to the right of the crag.

routes.description: A fun albeit too short finger crack on the right side of the crag.
routes.location: To the right of the bolted slab/face of Tumour in the Head and just above where the rock ramp peters out at the base of the wall on the right.

routes.description: Very different flavour from the rest of the routes at the crag. A little less splitter, a little less jamming, a little more awkward and a little more runout.Awkward jam off the deck leads to some easier climbing up to a single bolt in the middle of the face. I'm assuming one is meant to slab up the face while avoiding the tantalizing edges that Owl Teddy offers. By the time you mantle the bolt feels kind of far away, but it's not that bad - just a little more spicy than the other routes.
routes.location: Towards the right end of the crag, two routes left of the obvious left trending finger/lieback crack. Starts on a slight pedestal and climbs underneath a single bolt high above.

routes.description: A higher first bolt is easily reached off the ledge, firing into tenuous slab climbing through all 3 bolts. For the full 10b experience don't grab the crack out right.
routes.location: The route immediately left of the Kiss crack.
routes.protection: 3 draws, you can plug in a #.75-#1 for the finish

routes.description: Climb up the slab over a small, thoughtful bulge until it eases up.
routes.location: On the left section of slab on Parking Lot Rock, shares anchors with its neighbor to the left (Covid Crusaders).

routes.description: Straight-forward climbing with 2 short cruxes at the 2 bolts. Friendly climbing in between.
routes.location: The left-most route off the top of the large boulder that separates the left routes from the right ones. Begin below a low bolt.
routes.protection: 2 bolts, a few thin-hands to hands pieces. Bolted anchor.

routes.description: The low angle crack that undulates a couple times near the top. Fun easy jamming!
routes.location: The right side of the crag, has a distinct couple ledges near the top.

routes.description: Standard slab climbing on well-featured rock.
routes.location: Left slab area, goes right up the middle. Third route from the left.

routes.description: The middle crack.
routes.location: Anchors at top of route.

routes.description: Facing climbing with a series of bolts (x6).
routes.location: Just left of Peder's Crack near the right end of the crag.

routes.description: "One of Squamish's best V5 boulders starts seated on a slab matched on a thick, slopey shelf. Put your left foot up, do a big rock over and crank up great features to an airy finish at the lip."
routes.location: "To approach, start left of the motorcycle signboard in the middle of the east side of the Smoke Bluffs parking lot. Follow a well-woen trail into the brush for about 40 paces to a less obvious trail on the righr that leads up exposed tree roots and into the forest. From here, this faint trail swings south (right) for a short distance before weaving directlt uphill through a shorr, corner weakness in the mossy cliffband, which requires a bit of scrambling. Continue steeply above and Vigilante will soon come into view on the left."

routes.fa: P Ourom, A Ourom & J Hughes, 2020
routes.description: A fun and easy slab//trad route on the far right side of the crag. At the top of the first pitch there is a two bolt anchor (no rap rings). Then it continues up with more bolts/slab until it ends with a single bolt/malleon. It was a bit confusing because there appears to be NO ANCHOR at the top of the second pitch at the moment and no clear tree to create an anchor off of, but we might've missed something. We built a trad anchor then ended up rapping off the single malleon. I would recommend only climbing the first pitch then rapping off the route next to it.
routes.location: two bolts after first pitch, no anchor at top of second

description: Penny Lane is one of the most popular and sunniest of all the Smoke Bluff crags. It over looks the beautiful Hospital Hill residential area.It's easy to rappel most routes. Walk-offs are also an option.
getting_there: You can either walk up from the designated parking area or access from the Loop trail/Pixie Corner trail at the west end of the cliff by climbing and easy gully.  At the east end you can climb an easy canyon-like gully which links Penny Lane to Fern Gully and Ronins Corner.

routes.description: Teenage Girls is a pretty but less popular line climbing the prominent dyke on the blunt arete just left of Up Up and Away. It's a nice Bluffs bolted climb that is not a slab climb, and the crux is short and soft for the grade.    There is some definite ledge fall potential at the crux. Apparently there used to be a midway anchor to help mitigate this, but it was removed.    Three ways to start this climb:  1) Climb the first 20 feet of Fishy Business (10d, most direct). Bring a small cam, maybe like metolius 0 or 1, to protect against ground fall. Otherwise, this has one bolt with some spicy moves getting up to it.  2) Climb a two bolt slabby mantle further to the right.   3) Climb up the initial corner of Up Up and Away. This is the easiest way to get to the base, maybe 5.7, wouldn't recommend placing any gear in the corner though for rope drag reasons.   Once you're on the big ledge below the arete, the line and it's six bolts become obvious. The crux is moving past the second.   If you lower off the top with a 60, tie knots. It's a full 30m back to the ground.
routes.location: Bolts. Possibly some gear depending on which start you use.

routes.description: Two sections of thin slab lead to a slabby, crimp/dyno (if short harder)
routes.location: Bolted face just to the right of Penny Lane
routes.protection: Draws and a .2 or .3 for the start (high first bolt)

routes.description: Wide chimney moves lead to a short slab crux ending at a low angle face/crack to anchors. 70 meter rope. Carful lowering on a 70.
routes.location: Just left of Wherewolves Of London. Go up old steps into base of wide chimney.
routes.protection: Draws and a .5 /.75 for the low angle crack above.

routes.description: This is the crack left of The Yorkshire Gripper.  It starts with a few good finger locks, then some good hand jamming until an obvious traverse to the left. The traverse is the crux, but if you just stick in a good piece and launch into it, whether you see a sequence or not, you shouldn't have too much trouble.   There are two additional variations:  1. Start from the ground and go directly up to the crack by passing a rotten roof.  Now listed in the guidebook at 10d, although I had done it prior to the book's publication and had noted 10c in my previous edition.  10d sounds good since the second time I tried it, while it was seeping, I couldn't commit to the moves.  The crumbly rock in the roof will keep the grade a moving target.  2. Instead of doing the upper traverse, go straight up the face.  Bold 11c apparently.
routes.location: This climb starts as for Quarryman, but then traverses the obvious ledge under Popeye and the Raven (place a piece at this point) and then under The Yorkshire Gripper to the crack a few feet left of the Gripper.  There are chains at the top.
routes.protection: Aside from the traverse to the base of the crack, the protection is excellent throughout.  A standard rack up to a 3" cam will suffice.

routes.description: The thin flake just left of Partners In Crime. This route has interesting moves the whole way. The crux is positive crimping not jamming.Climb up the flake, 5.9, to where there once was a fixed pin that has since fallen out. Reach up to crimps, crux moves, and then jugs. Move right easily to a crack and climb that, 5.9 for 30 feet to an anchor.
routes.location: Thin nuts to 3 inch cams.

routes.description: This is a legendary Squamish finger crack that starts just left of Penny Lane.    Start with a few boulder moves off the ground, this leads to a great finger crack above.
routes.location: Small finger size gear and nuts.

routes.description: Climb the corner left of Clandestine Affair, and then move right to the slabby arête and crux. There are 3 bolts.
routes.location: This route is in the Penny Lane area, at the big V-shaped groove left of Clandestine Affair, and right or Whorehorse. You should be able to see three bolts on the arête right of the groove.

routes.description: Same start as Witch Doctor's Apprentice, climb on top of the roof instead of staying in the crack, over the bulge and into the right-facing corner above (fingers).
routes.location: Standard Rack. 1 bolt way up top.

routes.description: Quality mini route featuring steep climbing through a small roof feature with a boulder problem roll over the lip.
routes.location: Located in the small "cave" feature between Partners in Crime and Werewolves. Exactly right of Piggie's Persversions and left of Inverted Pig
routes.protection: 3 bolts to lower off anchor. Bolts are nicer to clip with draws hung, you can probably hang all the draws from the ground with a long stickclip.

routes.fa: Robin Barley, John Howe, Dave Fulton 1006
routes.description: Climb a dyke/crack to a lone bolt (place a finger cam to get to bolt)The rest of the route is bolted, heads up and left, and slightly runout on slab in sections.Fun slab moves to the anchor.
routes.location: Basically equally between “Yorkshire Gripper” & “Crime Of The Century”To the left of the corner that forms “Witch Doctors Apprentice”
routes.protection: One finger sized piece to get to the first bolt.

routes.description: A really fun and varied pitch which involves linking various broken cracks via a bolted slab with three bolts. The climb remains pleasurable and thought-provoking up until the summit block. Do not let the name deter you—this pitch is awesome.
routes.location: The climb starts immediately left of the Body Snatcher chimney. Scramble up some blocks left of the Body Snatcher chimney, to step left, and gain a foot ledge at the base of the broken cracks. The cracks above this foot ledge form an X.
routes.protection: Single Rack to 2 inches and a few draws for the bolts. There are two bolts at the top.

routes.description: It starts with pulling a tricky roof off the ground and leads into steep slab climbing.
routes.location: Roof right of The Ugly American

routes.description: A burly little route that stays dry even in moderate rain. Starts on discontinuous flakes and slants up and right to an overhanging, splitter 1" to 4" crack. This route is prone to being overgrown, which is a shame given the great quality of the climbing and the minimal approach.
routes.location: The obvious line that splits the arete to the left of the large, fallen log staircase in the penny lane gully (far right end of penny lane). Start on a large, flat boulder.
routes.protection: single rack to 4". Small nuts and TCUs help for the first 15", after that it's pretty straightforward. Chain anchors at the top

routes.description: For Penny Lane, this climb is unusually low angle.  It's a good option when everything else in this area is busy (as it often is), and it takes you to anchor that allows you to TR some much harder climbs for a workout.
routes.location: Just right of Quarryman, this route takes the face close to the arete.
routes.protection: Two bolts plus small gear (nuts and cams up to #1 camalot).

routes.description: A right leaning crack
routes.location: anchor at top

routes.description: Balance up the left-arching corner crack and sneak in the best final small placements you can before being forced into a delicate rightward move on to the slab above the crack. A few more delicate moves gain access to a significantly tamer left-trending ramp to the first of three bolts through the next wildly perplexing crystal-crimping steep stemming slab sequence. After the third bolt, top the next ramp and follow fairly obvious (5.6-5.7?) movements to the anchors, possibly finding a placement around X4 0.3-0.4 before the anchors. You certainly do not want to fall during the easier movements leading to the anchors, as there is no 4th bolt as indicated in the guide book.You may find a C3 00 placement in the thin vertical flaring slot above the lower crack side-pull before stepping up to commit to the slab, but by no means is it a good placement. A small offset may prove more useful.The guide book does not denote a PG13 rating, but it is safe to say that if the vertical slot piece described above pops before you pull to the easy ramp and clip the first bolt, you are likely in ground-fall territory. Further, the route only has 3 bolts, not 4 as indicated in the guide book.
routes.location: The route starts with a deceptively inviting left-arching small corner crack climber's left of Teenage Girls Won't Blow Gorbies.   Chains at the top encourage a rappel descent.
routes.protection: BD C4 0.75 and smaller with an emphasis on small C3s and X4s. No need to double above 0.5.

routes.description: Climb Crime into Kahoukers, and immediately continue left across the seemingly blank slab to a weakness and the corner. Finish up Smashing Windows.
routes.location: At Penny Lane Crag right in the centre. Start on Crime of the Century, do the Kahoukers step across, continue leftwards then up the corner.
routes.protection: Finger size cams or nuts then 4 draws for the top of Smashing Windows. No hardware was added

routes.description: Kahoukers starts on the classic Crime of the Century. At the black spot left of the crack about  a third of the way up, trend left across the slab to the parallel thin barely tips splitter. Climb this slabby tips splitter to its top and eventual trend right to the anchors for Crime.
routes.location: Kahoukers is the thin tips splitter that runs parallel to the Penny Lane ultra classic Crime of the Century. The crack starts off the ground a ways so a start on Crime is required. It is the first set of crack lines seen when the trail meets the wall.
routes.protection: Protection is found in the crack of Crime of the Century and then, after the traverse, in the thin splitter. Good small tcu's and nuts. Use a few long slings to reduce rope drag. Chain anchors suitable for lowering at top.

routes.description: A fun variation to going deep in the chimney. Climb as for Satan's Slit but instead of going into the chimney, stem out the wide part and clip 6 bolts along the left side of the arete to a bolted anchor. You can continue for 8 more meters to make it 5.10b to a higher anchor.
routes.location: The obvious chimney right of Penny Lane.
routes.protection: Some gear for the bottom half and 6 bolts protect the chimney stemming.

routes.fa: FA: Chris Cooper, K. Rajala  1976  FFA: Randy Atkinson, Anders Ourom  1978
routes.description: This climb starts slightly down the hill from Penny Lane and Crime of the Century.  I think this might be harder then Crime of the Century?   climb a thin crack up to a layback flare or jam straight in, either way it's hard.  The crux is the bulge 30 feet up.
routes.location: Thin finger sized gear

routes.fa: FA: Keith Rajala, C. McCafferty (aid)  1975  FFA: Anders Ourom, John Arts  1978
routes.description: This is a classic Smoke Bluff crack. Start with a few boulder moves off the ground. Move up into the shallow corner by stemming and jamming, it eases up as it gets higher. Over the years, a top anchor is cyclically installed and chopped. It is currently in the "chopped" condition and thus you must traverse the cliff top to the left and rappel from above Crime of the Century or hike down on the trail up and right through the trees.
routes.location: Single rack to #2 Camalot (2x .5 - #1 helpful)
routes.protection: Top of the Fern Gully Trail.

routes.description: Climb up a steep ramp with increasing difficulty until reaching the crux around the third bolt.  Although the difficulty decreases from here, there are a few spicy moves after the fourth bolt to gain the anchors.
routes.location: Located on the left side of the Main Cliff. The climb begins just to the left of Quarryman and climbs the ramp to the top.
routes.protection: A few pieces .5 to 1 inch protect the lower section before reaching the first bolt. Four bolts will see you to the anchor with chains and rap rings 5 ft. left of Quarryman.

routes.description: Yet another enjoyable Smoke Bluffs fingercrack starts this one off.  When the crack seams out, traverse right (bolted, crux) to the slabby arete.
routes.location: The route starts in a fingercrack immediately right of the 5.9 corner, Witch Doctor's Apprentice.
routes.protection: Take a small selection of finger-sized protection and a few quickdraws for the bolts.  Don't forget yer dancin' shoes!  I'm pretty sure there's a bolted anchor at the top.

routes.description: Quarryman climbs an obvious, large, left-facing corner on the left side of the Penny Lane cliff band.  Scramble on top of a large boulder to start.  Fun, cruiser climbing leads to the top of the dihedral.  Follow a crack up the steep left face out of the dihedral and around the corner to a balancy hand crack which continues up to the anchor.  Nice moves and good gear the whole way.
routes.location: Gear to 2". A couple of hand-size pieces for the upper crack. Ends on 2 bolt anchor with rap rings.

routes.description: Climb 'Clandestine Affair' until the traverse. The go straight up the slabby wall above on edgy sidepulls and funky smears. Maybe the tiniest bit bold....
routes.location: See 'Clandestine Affair'
routes.protection: A small offset wire can be placed in the incipient face crack at the crux. Cams for the rest.

routes.description: Fun climbing. Crux is getting past the choke stone.
routes.location: A couple meters right of penny lane.
routes.protection: Takes a couple cams to 3", and a really long sling for the chock stone

routes.fa: P. Croft, D. Fulton, P. Kindree, 1990
routes.description: First things first, both the McLane and Bourdon books give this 11a, so that's what I entered, but I don't see how it can be.  After bailing, my partner and I set up a TR and got a little further on moves that that felt closer to 12a, and then still couldn't finish it.   The first two thirds of the climb does have feel like 11a and has some very fun, tricky climbing in a curving crack.  The final section, protected by three bolts (not the two listed in the books) and seems to have mandatory 5.12 climbing just to clip them.  Fortunately, it's possible to climb Health Hazard to the same anchor and TR, or just recover your gear.
routes.location: On the left side of Penny Lane, about 20 feet right of the Quarryman area.  A crack curves up and left with a piton and leads to blank face where three bolts are visible.
routes.protection: Small cams (#1 camalot and smaller) plus three bolts.  Shares a two bolt anchor with several routes, including Health Hazard.

routes.description: Climb directly up the blunt arete. Three bolts of desperately thin technical climbing bring you to a nice ledge, at which you may catch your breath and consider your life choices. The climbing from here eases significantly, but still requires focus through the next few more widely-spaced bolts.
routes.location: 7 bolts

routes.description: Climb 'Climb and Punishment' but instead of stepping right into the crack after that route's crux, move left up the steep corner. Some crazy, funky stemming past two bolts leads to more 5.11 jamming where the crack opens up again. A wicked climb!
routes.location: smaller cams/nuts ... two bolts.

routes.description: A variation of Quarryman that takes the upper crack to the same anchor, bringing the difficulty up to 5.10b. From the flake, instead of finishing left along the hand crack, go up into an awkward finger crack with some insecure moves to the same anchor.Top found here.
routes.location: As for Quarryman.
routes.protection: Standard rack. #0.2 is probably ideal up top for the 5.10b section, but you can make do with a mostly decent 0.3 and 0.4.

routes.description: A varied crack 3m right of Partners in Crime.  This mostly hand-sized crack has plenty of protection opportunities and good stances.  A sting in the tail gives it the grade.
routes.location: Full set of hand sized cams and nuts.  Lots of options.  Chain anchor.

routes.description: Begin up the wide and somewhat broken corner.  Wander up increasingly steep terrain past a nice section of gentle finger crack to a decent stance.  The fire up the final cruxy section of vertical finger crack.  I found this to be suprisingly tough and slightly pumpy, and longer than it looked from the ground.
routes.location: Up, Up and Away is left of Witch Doctor's Apprentice and Power Windows, just around the corner from Crime of the Century.  The final finger crack is obvious from the trail.
routes.protection: Standard rack to 2".  The lower section of the climb eats nuts, saving finger-sized cams for the final section.

routes.description: This overlooked route gets lots of sun and is one of the fastest drying routes in Squamish. A very good choice for a sunny winter day. This route has some committing yet safe moves between bomber protection followed by a continuous crux on make believe holds past three tightly spaced bolts. The lines of both Whorehorse and Mirage are off in the McLane and Bourdon guides. Mirage provides a good warmup and allows the feint of heart to set up a top rope.
routes.location: Located on the next Buttress north of Clandestine Affair. You can scramble up to a ledge or start lower on a 5.10 undercling flake for some bonus climbing.

routes.description: Weenie is a classic pitch on the left side of Penny Lane, directly right of the popular Quarryman area. It dosen't get the attention it deserves, probably because of it's slightly bold nature.Start up dark and featured rock and face climb up and left on incut edges and positive feet until you gain the start of an obvious right-slanting seam (around 5.10c but with no protection). Place your first pieces of gear here, then continue up the funky seam with good protection. Clip a bolt and solve a puzzling crux transitioning into short people. A cool traverse with small but good gear gets you into the end of Health Hazard. Up it to the chains.Don't let the 2-star rating in the select mislead you, this is a great pitch and a hidden gem in the Bluffs.
routes.location: Look for an obvious right-slanting seam in the middle of the wall and a lone bolt. There is often a seepage streak just to the right of the route.
routes.protection: Micro and thin finger sizes, RP's. Draws.

routes.description: A fine route at the far right end of Penny Lane, this route starts on the left side of a low slab, crosses the slab (bolt), and gains a finger crack on the right side. Follow the crack up, stepping left where its obvious to gain the top.
routes.location: Far right side of Penny Lane. Look for the striking finger crack that starts about 15' up a slab.

routes.description: Two roofs and a chimney. Fun stuff all around. The first crux is the first roof.
routes.location: It's around the corner West of Crime of the Century and Penny Lane, but East of Up Up and Away. South-West facing corner, the only one on Penny Lane that isn't Quarryman.
routes.protection: All trad, easily protectable but I equalized two cams below the first roof. I sewed it up though, placed eleven pieces.

routes.description: Yorkshire Gripper climbs the beautiful cracks up the center of a blunt prow left of Popeye and the Raven. Expect fairly solid finger jamming to a well-defined crux where the crack peters out.    Beta alert: I received the excellent advise to dispense with pro through the crux section. Simply load up the crack before the crux and punch through the crux moves without thinking of pro. After the crux, you should get a pretty good stance from which to place gear. The crux is pretty short and the gear before it is very solid.
routes.location: SR with extra small TCUs

description: Small cliff with a few fun climbs, not a busy spot. Good afternoon sun and a nice view of the Northridge development from the top.   Most routes have bolted/chain anchors, some shared.  Easy walk off around climbers left.
getting_there: From Penny Lane, head up the stairs through the gully. Pass Fern Gully on the right and continue up the trail to the left. This is the next obvious cliff on the right.

routes.description: Awkward jamming up a short and uninspiring fingers-to-hands crack.
routes.location: Furthest crack to the right of the crag, just right of Wankulator.
routes.protection: Single rack from 0.4 to #2 C4s, nuts. NO ANCHOR - you can use the Wankulator anchor but it can leave your second with a weird fall if you're not careful. Alternatively there is a thin tree further back, but too thin for my tastes.

routes.description: Climb the series of cracks up to a tree anchor (no fixed anchor).   Walk off climbers left.
routes.location: Follow standard approach to Pink Cliff, head up to left slabs and locate cracks on rightmost edge.

routes.description: The name of the route is somewhat of a misnomer, as there are no fist jams to be had.  This route climbs a short, steep, and slightly leaning flared crack using off fingers and thin hand jams.  If you have ever climbed at Vedauwoo, this will remind you of one of those 'harder than they look' routes that are oh so similar.  The right foot can be problematic most of the way.Overall, this is a very good route that could use a bit more traffic to clean off some of the moss.  One knock against this route is that the route could use a convenient anchor. I was kind of surprised by this as the other routes at this crag have handy anchors.
routes.location: the pink cliff is somewhat divided in half, with a slabby section on the left and a couple steep dihedrals on the right.  this route is on the right half of the crag and climbs the left of two prominent right facing dihedrals.  it is a striking line - you can't miss it.
routes.protection: off fingers to thin hands cams - 0.5 camalot to #1 camalot, maybe a #2 camalot for the top.

routes.description: A short right facing corner that accepts a few finger sized cams gives way to a pure friction slab past three bolts.  Above the third bolt a steep step is reached with the 4th bolt just above.  After clipping the 4th bolt and moving through the steep step on the left, another short section of slab leads to a vertical headwall.  A fun sequence of small crimps and friction lead past 2 final bolts to the cliff top and anchor above.
routes.location: Route is located on the left side of Pink Cliff, to the right of Vertically Challenged, and to the left of Pat on the Back and Environmentally Friendly.  From the bottom, all 6 bolts are visible and appear to lead to the highest point on the left side of the formation.
routes.protection: A few finger sized cams to start and then 6 bolts with a 2 bolt anchor.  Anchor may or may not have quicklinks, but easy enough to walk off to the left.

routes.description: Climb the thin seam left of Environmentally Friendly. Move left and and follow bolts up bulges.
routes.location: 5 bolts, SR. Anchor with rappel ring on top

routes.description: Furthest left side of Pink Cliff. Locate the large flake about 1-2m above the ground. Head up the left side into the right facing corner.  May be a bit dirty.   Walk off climbers left or rap from anchor chains.
routes.location: Far left side of Pink Cliff, follow approach for Pink Cliff then head up to the left slabs.

routes.description: Climb the right side of the large flake next to People of Size. Continue up the slab past 3 bolts.
routes.location: 3 bolts, SR. Chains and rappel ring on top

description: Pixie Corner sits in the trees above the Neat and Cool cliffs, and is a perfect place to bring beginners or a small group of friends.  The area hosts a dozen or so one pitch routes, ranging from classic Squamish 5.7 to 5.9 cracks to the one of the sickest, thinnest lines in Squamish (Digital Dexterity, 12c).   The main attractions are Wonderland (.9), the Locker (.7), and Pixie Corner (.8).  The last two make great beginner leads or TR's, as you can easily walk to the top of the cliff and set anchors and ropes, and/or walk off.
getting_there: Take the gravel road past Neat and Cool, then cut left up an obvious (and signed) trail towards Octopus' Garden.  Before the two flights of stairs up a small gully, go left.  Pixie Corner is the massive double dihedral area, and Wonderland is all the way to the left, at the end of a slightly exposed ledge.

routes.description: An unfortunately typical Smoke Bluffs bolted slab.  The holds are excruciatingly small and polished.  This climb feels really hard for the grade, even admitting that a slab 11a should have very small holds.  It's likely that the edges have lost a bit of their bite over time, as appears to have happened on a number of Smoke Bluffs slabs (Dreams of Passion at Ronin's Corner and especially Tools of Moss Destruction at Fern Gully).   Nevertheless, all of the moves are doable and a top-rope session can serve as an early-season tune-up for your slab technique.
routes.location: This is face just right of Davey Jones' Locker.
routes.protection: There are two bolts before the first ledge, one before the next ledge and then one more on the finishing arete of Diddly Squat. There is a two-bolt anchor shared with Diddly Squat at the top but the anchor lacks rappel rings or quicklinks for lowering.

routes.description: This worthwhile route has languished in obscurity having been climbed but not named and then treated as an italicized footnote in Squamish Rockclimbs. Definitely a proud line by Smoke Bluffs standards I have taken the liberty of naming it in the hopes of bringing it into the light.Starts on the classic Wonderland and then quickly break right up a finger crack that dissipates into tech crystal crimping. A couple of sloping chickenheads offer brief reprieve between cruxes. Exhilarating final moves with good exposure!
routes.location: Located between Wonderland and White Rabbit. This route is hard to see from the ledge below. For those who prefer to top rope inspect the anchor is pretty easy to find by walking past Joe's Crack top out.
routes.protection: A few cams from .3 -.75 protect the initial crack and then 3 bolts protect the crux slab. Stainless lower off rings installed courtesy of the Squamish Access Society.

routes.description: The crux is getting on this very popular, very easy route.  It takes pretty good gear, though, and it's easy to walk up and set up a TR, so it's worthwhile to bring beginners or first-time leaders here.
routes.location: The Locker is in the back of the left-most dihedral, just to the right of Joes Crack.
routes.protection: Cams, nuts, or hexes to 2 inches. Bolts at the top with chains.

routes.description: This climb starts hard right off the ground and consists of cranking up a flaring seam that provides no good locks or feet.  The wall steep and the crack angles awkwardly.  At about halfway, you pull around the arete to the left and continue on the type of bulging slab that characterizes so many routes at the Smoke Bluffs.  The grade drops to low 5.10 once you're on the arete.
routes.location: The is the obvious seam on the face left of the route Pixie Corner.
routes.protection: I didn't lead it so take this with a grain of salt, but small stoppers and micro cams are likely necessary near the bottom.  I believe that some bolts appear as the seam dies out and you move over to the arete.

routes.description: The strikingly thin pin scarred diagonal crack by the entrance of Pixies Corner.
routes.location: Entrance of Pixies Corner

routes.description: Don't be fooled by Pixie Corner's chill routes, because Joe's is pretty stout for a 5.9.  It can be tricky to place gear in the left to right angling crack, and the top out is very committing.     Joe's feels harder, or at least more awkward, than Penny Lane.
routes.location: Joe's Crack is on the right facing wall of the farthest-left dihedral in Pixie Corner.  It angles from left to right, then goes straight up into the trees.  You can't miss it.  Walk up and right to top of cliff, and follow path to stairs and the base of the dihedrals.
routes.protection: Cams to 2 inches. Two bolts with quicklinks at the top for lowering.

routes.description: Climb directy up the blunt arete to the left of Digital Dexterity staying out of the broken diagonal that lead out towards digital dexterity.
routes.location: Entrance of Pixes Corner directly to the left of Digital Dexterity.

routes.description: The "title" crack in Pixie Corner is the best of the lot, offering a fun, well protected climb up two thin parallel cracks in the back of a huge dihedral.  This is a fun introduction to Squamish's unique brand of slimy finger cracks, smearing, and jamming.
routes.location: This is the unmistakable "ski tracks" route in Pixie Corner, and the first to be encountered when entering the area.   Walk off the back, per every other climb on this cliff.
routes.protection: Cams to 1.5 inches, med. nuts.  There are anchors with chains at the top.

routes.fa: John Howe, Dave Lane, Kevin McLane, Keith Flavelle - 1984
routes.description: Start in a V cutout, climbing between two parallel right leaning cracks.  Climb straight up on good gear to another right leaning seam to top-out.
routes.location: South facing wall.  Two routes left of Digital Dexterity.

routes.description: A short but enjoyable route that follows the obvious, diagonal crack to the right of pixie corner. The crux comes at the last move and requires good foot placement to reach to a decently positive but slopey final hold.
routes.location: This is the left-slanting crack immediately to the right of the large dihedral crack system. Scamper up a low ledge to access the crack. Walk off the back as for other routes in this area.
routes.protection: standard nuts and cams to 1.5" or Easily toproped via backside approach. Single anchor bolt and a conveniently positioned tree at the top.

routes.description: Two parallel cracks on rounded buttress left of Joes Crack.  Start off a ledge.
routes.location: Standard rack.

routes.description: I found the Crux to be near the top portion of the arete feature with some tricky moves to work through. Really nice climb and well worth doing again. Would make for a really scary and dangerous lead as it only has 2 bolts protecting the whole 60ft. climb.
routes.location: This climb is found on the arete between Captain Hornblower 5.11a and Diddly Squat 5.12b which climbs the blank face just right of Weiner in the Bun. You can walk off or be lowered or rap off if you want. most people walk off right to the stair case leading back down to pixie corner crag.
routes.protection: Only two bolts protect the entire route. May be areas to place removable protection but take a good look before leading it. I say it simply needs more bolts to make it safe. Two bolts at the top for your anchor

routes.description: A low thin finger layback crux leads to a pumpy crack to anchors.  This route seems like a logical extension of Jabberwocky.
routes.location: standard rack to 1"

routes.fa: R. Barley, P. Shakleton, C. Murrell
routes.description: This is a wild and exposed line that traverses above the height of the wall area.  Begin on a ledge left of the Jabberwocky anchor, and hand traverse a finger/hand crack up and left across the void.  Pull up onto a bulge and move left through stellar moves on a series of flakes.  Traverse around the corner as the crack widens, then climb a short section of fist crack to the anchor.  Savor the view.  A unique and highly worthwhile pitch.
routes.location: Walk left from the Pixie corner area, or arrive at the base while doing the Smoke Bluff Connection.
routes.protection: Gear to 3-4", primarily finger and hand size pieces.  I had two #3 camalots and was pleased to have them near the end of the pitch.

description: Seldom visited area crag with a handful of routes.
getting_there: Crag sits above Auntie Gravity wall and left of Boulder Gully. Walk up Boulder Gully, eventually cutting left and the wall will be on your right in a minute.

routes.description: It climbs a slabby ramp then traverses left around a blunt arête to a seam which splits a smooth, slightly overhanging wall. Burl it out to reach jugs on the other side then climb up and right the gain the top of pillar. I did not clip any of the bolts which one could get to if they went out of the way a bit. The crux of the route through the horizontal seam has some of the best quality stone in the bluffs sort but sweet.
routes.location: Can’t be missed
routes.protection: Fists to tips. Couple long runners.

description: Area to the right around the corner from Penny Lane
getting_there: Approach as for Penny Lane and turn right, or alternatively follow the trail to Ronins Corner, and right before the tree trunk steps, it is on the left hand side.

routes.description: A really memorable 5.8. It's rated one star in the guidebook, and it's understandable why since it's extremely chossy and dirty, and the beginning has tons of ferns and sticks to climb through. However, it's also a four star experience if you're willing to risk the choss and spider webs. How often do you get to climb through a hole and emerge out into the sunlight? Super fun, burly, and dirty! Felt harder than 5.8 to me. Be very careful what you pull on as there are many loose and jiggly rocks including a very big chunk of rock on the left side of the crux that seems like it could slide of pretty easily since it made grinding noises when touched. Should probably be trundled before being climbed if it's as loose as it sounded. See photo of loose block in the image attached. If you do climb it just be careful of this block and avoid it at all costs, and at the crux it would be better to go right and avoid touching or putting pro around this block.
routes.location: The wide chunky chimney
routes.protection: Trad with anchor at the top

description: This small crag features a small variety of climbs from 5.4-5.12+. It is less popular than surround crags, so a good alternative for busy days when octopus' garden and funorama are too crowded.  Its main attraction is two of the only 5.10 roof cracks in the bluffs.
getting_there: Either  approach as for octopus' garden then continue 100m SE or approach as for Call it a Day and continue uphill for 5 minutes staying left at the fork in the road

routes.description: The hand crack through the smaller section of the roof
routes.location: Left side of the crag

routes.description: Wide, left-leaning crack to the right of Thrombosis. Fists and hands, but at an easy grade. Not too engaging for an experienced climber, but for a beginner it's never too early to learn proper jamming technique and it *is* splitter.
routes.location: To the right of the deep groove in the middle of the crag that is Thrombosis.
routes.protection: I placed a #4 and a #2. You could place more. 3/8" bolts the top, so when you're done I'd advise cleaning your anchor and walking to the big tree and rapping off.

routes.description: The right hand crack through the wider section of the roof.
routes.location: Gear to 2".

routes.description: While this route looks like an ugly offwidth battle, the crack is featured enough on the sides to climb like a jughaul. There are maybe two legitimate jams needed, the rest is edges and jugs. The crux is actually after the chimney, when you need to pull into the upper crack - the chimney is maybe 5.7.   Starting to get scruffy again, so climb it!
routes.location: Deep, wide, chimney-like groove to the right of Thorax Complaint.
routes.protection: I placed two #4s, a blue metolius and a #2 Camalot above the break. You could probably get away with a standard rack - there's enough options around to climb this safely without anything bigger than a #2.   3/8" bolts at the top that I wouldn't rap from. I'd recommend cleaning your anchor, walking to the big tree and rapping from that. (Or belay from the top so and you and your partner can follow the shortcut at the top of the crag to Funarama.)

description: This is the small crag immediately above the loop trail Between Mosquito and Neat and Cool area, it encompasses all routes Between Hummingbird and Dog Face and perhaps some obscure shorter routes/boulder problems to the North.   Beware of getting hit by out of control mountain bikers while belaying. Most of the routes have difficult undercut starts.
getting_there: 12 minutes from the main parking. If you can't find this cliff you should never go alpine climbing.

routes.fa: Peter Croft, Daryl Hatten, Tami Knight 1978
routes.description: An underrated classic. Delicate climbing up the vertical seam takes you to the ledge and a 2 bolt anchor. A .12c extension goes to the top over the bouldery bulge. (Andrew Boyd 1999)
routes.location: Left side of the wall, takes the clean, thin crack.

routes.description: Short but elegant. Dog Face climbs through a shallow dihedralet up a vertical wall past 3 bolts. Precise and technical, cold temps and good shoes are keys to success.
routes.location: Farthest right route on Roadside Distraction crag.
routes.protection: Hardware replaced in 2019 by Squamish Access Society. Please consider donating to SAS to keep the re-bolting program going! Donate here.3 bolts, 2 bolt rap anchor. Easy to set up a top rope. Don't be such a tough guy - pre hang the draws.

routes.description: Pull a tough move to get off the ground and gain a nice finger crack. Move right when it fizzles out and climb the next crack to the top. Re-Scrubbed December 2020, get on it!
routes.location: Immediately left of the offwidth, shares an anchor with Roadside Distraction

routes.description: Mantle up and clip the lone bolt before climbing left though cool scoops to gain the splitter finger crack. Climb it to the ledge and take the original finish up more nice cracks to the top of the wall and a new 2 bolt anchor with chains.Re-scrubbed Dec 2020. Good candidate for a stick clip.
routes.location: Lone bolt on the wall just left of Dog Face, taking the obvious splitter above.
routes.protection: SR with some small gear for the bottom of the crack.

description: A crag with three distinct sections: the left side, the center section and the Elephant's Arse area on the right.  Good climbs, relative seclusion, convenient location for a small group.
getting_there: Hike up the steep gully at the right end of Penny Lane, Ronin's corner is off to the right.

routes.description: Start on Free Spirit, but climb the crack on the right.
routes.location: SR

routes.description: Fun climb with lots of variety.  The lower section can be made harder by staying in the clean corner, or made easier by using the dirty face cracks.  Pulling around the first bulge is probably the crux (if you skipped the initial corner).  The overhanging section at the top is mellow.
routes.location: On the left side of Ronin's Corner, in a corner system left of more broken and scruffy area.
routes.protection: A standard rack (a variety of sizes), a few small wires for initial corner.

routes.description: Desperado is a prominent left diagonaling feature between Wobbler and the corner of Magical Child.  The name is appropriate: the angled nature of the feature and the smooth wall below conspire to have you placing pro from strenuous stances with your left foot smearing. The pro is in oddly shaped and poorly oriented cracks so while it requires care to place well you don't have luxury of hanging out forever.  I sprinted through it and got quite pumped.   The cobwebs seemed to indicate that it wasn't popular, probably because it couldn't be top-roped easily and it's a solid lead for the grade.
routes.location: Mostly small to medium nuts and finger sized cams.  A couple of larger cams (#1 or #2 camalot) for where it joins Wobbler.

routes.description: Just right of Magical Child is a classic Smoke Bluffs slab.  Tough moves on very small features give way to pure friction moves.  Amazing friction, but very technical requiring precise control and balance.
routes.location: Typical Squamish slab: bolts, but not enough to feel secure.

routes.description: Start up a dirty U-shaped gully and climb a crack-line on the left side of the slabby, right hand wall.
routes.location: 1 bolt, SR

routes.description: Short face climb
routes.location: 3 Bolts

routes.description: The main corner of the central area of Ronin's Corner, between Desperado and Dreams of Passion.   A beautiful climb for the 5.8 leader. Nice rock, nice moves, nice pro.
routes.location: Excellent.  Full set of nuts and cams.

routes.fa: D. Jones, T. Ryan, C. Ryan, 1992
routes.description: The corner right of Sky Dancing makes an excellent early venture for a beginning leader.
routes.location: Standard rack

routes.description: The crux is, well, the crux could be a lot of places.  it could be in the first third, where the the thinnest moves are, or it could be in the middle, where you literally palm the ridge for what feels like forever, or it could be the top-out mantle that occurs 15 feet above, and to the left of the last bolt....  I'll go with the mantle.  This can be a spooky route for a 5.8 leader, and not a pretty one to fall on.
routes.location: This route is the farthest left of Ronin's routes, and ascends the left side of the smooth ridge/arete (this is the first feature you'll see approaching along the trail from the west).
routes.protection: One or two small TCU's can be slotted behind a flake before reaching the first bolt.  Then just start clipping.

routes.description: Great friction climb right up the center of the slab.  Amazing what your feet will stick to.  Follow the first two bolts, possibly slightly easier on the left side, to a left trending ramp.  This is the crux and involved a couple edges down low, then just a lot of trust on whatever small bumps you can find.   Cruise through the next section of easier climbing to the final headwall and remaining two bolts.  A touch easier than the bottom, but still probably 10b fun slabbing.
routes.location: The right-most climb at Ronin's Corner.  About 15' right of MCM.

routes.fa: D. Jones, T. Ryan, C. Ryan, 1992
routes.description: The arete just right of Dreams of Passion.  This isn't as hard as Dreams, but still requires tough friction moves between bolts spaced enough to keep it exciting.
routes.location: The first bolt is pretty high.  It used to be possible to pre-clip it by standing on a stump, but the stump is now gone.  The first moves, especially if you take the slab on the left, could well be the crux, and the base drops off right below the bolt so you risk a fifteen foot fall after only climbing ten feet.  All this suggests that stick-clipping is a very good idea, but you may be able to climb MCM to the height of the bolt and traverse over to it.   Take a few nuts or small cams for the crack between the two slab sections.  There's a two-bolt anchor at the top of Dreams of Passion that works for this climb.

routes.description: Short slab up the arete
routes.location: Short slab up an aerate right of gravestone.

routes.description: A link up of MCM into Skydancing that avoids the high first bolt of Skydancing.   Start on MCM until it is possible to move left into a shallow corner that connects into Skydancing. Finish up Skydancing.
routes.location: Ronins corner between Skydancing and MCM.

routes.description: Wobbler is on the left wall of the central area of Ronin's corner.  Despite the cracks, this climb feels more like a balancy (or off-balancy) face climb.
routes.location: A set of nuts and cam to 3".

description: Slabby.  PM sun.
getting_there: From Lower Crag X continue up trail 30 meters past bridge alongside trail.

routes.description: Climb a thin crack just right of Sigurd.  The line dodges left into Sigurd near the top.
routes.location: SR to 2".  A guidebook I own states "1 bolt", correct me if I'm wrong but I did not see a bolt and I looked and looked and looked even going back after leading and hiking up just to rappel down and search....

routes.description: Left leaning crack/seam
routes.location: From parking area, walk trail until you see a wooden bridge to your left to access a chimney (Runestone Pinnacle). Just past this is another small wooden plank to the base of Cockhair Crack.
routes.protection: 2 bolts and shitty 2-bent-bolts-with-washers-and-chain anchor. You can get in a small cam before the first bolt if you want.

routes.description: Climb two parallel hand cracks that are approximately a shoulders width apart.   This climb is a great novice lead on a non-intimidating wall.
routes.location: Approximately in the middle of the Runestone wall.
routes.protection: Easily protected the entire way up with hand size nuts/cams.

routes.description: Climb two prominent cracks that converge slightly towards the top of the wall. At the base of the wall in the ditch, the cracks are an arms length apart, near the top they are shoulders width apart.   Crux move is near the top and is protected by small nuts (no cams). Was rescrubed in 2015 so the rock is currently very grippy.   One of the best routes on the wall.
routes.location: It is approimatley in the middle of the Runestone Wall or approximatley 2 meters to the left of "Grani". Grani is the two obvious parallel cracks that are a shoulders width apart.
routes.protection: Takes small cams near the bottom and small nuts near the top.

routes.description: Climb up the left side of the giant flake on the Runestone Wall to meet up with Runestone Pinnacle Right at the top of the flake to finish on a finger crack to the top.
routes.location: The left side of the giant detached flake at Runestone Wall.

routes.description: A little something different for the Bluffs. Wide chimney (~18"-24") on the right side of the Runestone, mantle on top of it, and make a few moves up a fingercrack.
routes.location: Can't miss it. See the giant detached boulder with the chimney to the right of it? There.
routes.protection: Up to a 0.75 Camalot (unless you plan on protecting the chimney bit, then you'll need a #5 or a #6 Camalot), bolts at the top.

routes.description: Left-leaning twin hand cracks.  Great for novices.
routes.location: Cams to 2.75"

description: Great beginner area, 2nd Ave provides everything from 5.5 to 5.10's with combination of trad, mixed and all bolted routes. Easy top roping is accessable from just below Nubile Women. Can also be used as a multi-pitch teaching area.
getting_there: Walk past Pixie Corner on the way to Octopus Garden This area is just below Nubile Woman.

routes.description: Climb the Arete on the far right side.
routes.location: SR

routes.description: Face climbing protected by bolts, then easy  slab. A few small mediocre gear placement to reduce runout on top.Linked with 2nd ave to make a full length route.
routes.location: Start on the upper ledge above 2nd ave.
routes.protection: 3 or 4 bolts, then small gear. Bolted anchor

routes.description: From the anchor above 3 - Wren, continue up the immediate left bolt line. There are no bolts for the final ~20 ft, though the climbing is mellow.
routes.location: Starts just left of the anchor above 3 - Wren. This is the second bolt line from the left on the upper section of this cliff.

routes.description: From the anchor of 6 - Sub Park Intellect, continue straight up through a slightly steep crux and finish on slab. This is the furthest line on the left of the upper section of this cliff.
routes.location: Begins from the anchor of 6 - Sub Park Intellect.

routes.description: Excellent beginner route for trad leads. climb the obvious crack that divides the area in two.
routes.location: SR

routes.description: Same start as Tripin on Salal but climb the left crack.
routes.location: SR

routes.description: Trad climb the short crack at the bottom and stay right of 3 blot across slab (Teo Land) to the anchors.
routes.location: SR + 3 bolts

routes.description: Climb the lower face with good gear placements to 3 bolts across a slab at the top.
routes.location: 0.5 and Smaller + 3 bolts

routes.description: 1 bolt low, then small gear the rest of the way to the top.
routes.location: .75 and lower + 1 bolt

routes.description: Shared start with Family Portrait. move right after start to 1 bolt on an outcropping.
routes.location: SR (Small stuff) + 1 bolt

routes.description: Shared start with Wired, move left and follow the dark colored crack up to the right side of the tree. Alt. 5.10- move right after start.
routes.location: SR

routes.description: Climb the face/slab. takes small gear well.  Alt. 5.9 start just to left.
routes.location: SR

routes.description: A gully of sorts that has many small scar cracks all the way to the top.
routes.location: Small gear 0.5 and lower

routes.description: just left of Drowning Fish, face climb using the small scar cracks for protection.
routes.location: small gear 0.75 and lower.

routes.description: Climb to the first bolt, trad climb the majority for the rest of the clmb to the last slab move to a bolt.
routes.location: Smoke Bluffs

routes.description: Slabby route with some fun step throughs (if you're in to that sort of thing).
routes.location: 3 bolts

routes.description: Excellent beginner lead, take a wide range of gear and there is a tree to sling. Really nice route for teaching.
routes.location: SR

routes.description: Climb the face and crack left of 2nd Ave. Half way move left and head for the only bolt above.
routes.location: SR + 1 bolt

routes.description: Bouldery start to slab for the last 3 bolts.
routes.location: Smoke Blufs - 2nd Ave (right)
routes.protection: 4 bolts. You should be able to reach the first one if you stand on the small ledge.

routes.description: Nearly all sport (3 bolts) the last part you can place a small piece BD C3 0 or 1, but it can be easily enough climbed thru to the anchors.
routes.location: 3 bolts low, 0.3" and lower at top.

description: Sidecar is a small bluff with a mix of trad, sport, and mixed routes. The routes are relatively short (~8-10m) but include some nice cracks and bolted slab.
getting_there: Immediately left of the Free and Easy area a small trail into the woods leads 15-20m to this bluff, visible from the main trail. Between the Zip area and Free and Easy area.

routes.description: Climb the straight hand crack towards the left of the bluff. Some nice climbing on good hands in the crack to pull on interspersed with some features to stand one for a break or to place gear. Good lead for a novice trad leader.
routes.location: Large obvious continuous crack on left side of Sidecar bluff.

description: A small crag, home to two obvious and short cracks- both of them fierce at their repspective grades.
getting_there: On the Smoke Bluff Loop trail- about 2 minutes past Penny Lane if you're coming from Neat and Cool.

routes.description: While the books give this thing 5.10d, myself and others consider that a total sandbag for Squamish and the Bluffs in particular. Feel free to give yourself 5.11a credit if you fire this one- especially if you onsight. Worth doing, despite the two stars it gets in the book.
routes.location: The right hand of the two cracks.
routes.protection: Gear to red camalot. Ends on two bolt anchor with mussy hooks.

routes.description: A fierce battle up the left hand crack- its about as hard as it looks from the ground. Protecting this thing on lead is probably the crux- especially if you're onsighting.
routes.location: The left hand of the two routes.
routes.protection: Thin gear- nothing bigger than a purple camalot.

description: Discovered between 2009-2011 by Jason Green, Robin Barley, and a few others, Split Asunder was lost for a period of time and reclaimed back by the forest. Many new routes were developed in 2022 and the winter saw a complete overhaul of anchor hardware. A major rescrubbing was done by ACC Squamish in 2023.Host to numerous routes in the 5.8 - 5.10- range from crack climbing to crimpy sport and even a must-do chimney. There are 2 rap stations above the main wall to give access to route anchors. There is a fixed line down a gully to allow access to Upper Tier routes. Nearly all routes have rap chains.
getting_there: Hike up to the base of Lumberland via the loop trail. From the base, follow a rough path on the left side up a short hill.  When at the top of the short hill, Split Asunder will be visible through the trees off to your left. Follow the trail left and loop around passing a beautiful viewpoint with a bench. Shortly after this, a path leading to the base will appear on your right.

routes.description: A pair of thin cracks up the wall to the upper ledge. Gear can be thin and a little tricky.Link with Pig's Ear for 2 pitches.Rap into gully in front of anchor.
routes.location: pair of cracks off the alder stump

routes.description: Crack starts thin with a root jug just out of reach. Crack widens towards the top.Be sure to try and save the huckleberry bush!
routes.location: left of Catwalk

routes.description: Paddle up the slabby arete until the wall steepens. Work the arete and small ledge to the top. Avoid using the headwall for full effect.Can be linked with Pig's Ear for 2 PitchesRap into the gully in front of anchor.
routes.location: left most portion of crag.

routes.description: Like the famous Boomstick Crack, without the risk of losing your cams into the abyss.It also climbs completely different, and is bolted. So, nothing like it, really.
routes.location: Upper Tier

routes.description: Thin seam that runs up and left along small edges.
Starting with a tall reach to jugs, climb through a tricky seam on specific gear to a rest under a large bulge.  Surmount the beefy bulge to delicate slab.  Sharpen your edges.
routes.location: Directly left of Mantleshelf Man.  Does not share the same start.

routes.description: Thin seam to the left of Digestive Tract
routes.location: Upper ledge on right side of crag

routes.description: Boulder through a roof down low to gain a comfortable stance. Continue up the direct seam to the anchor.Reaching out right for "La-Tea-Da" lowers the grade to 5.10b.
routes.location: Start down low, left of ledge

routes.description: A striking splitter from fingers to fists. At the ledge, clip the anchor and continue up the layback to the top protected by a single bolt.
routes.location: Follow a faint trail down left from the Split Asunder Chimney. A collection of 3 cracks will be seen just around the corner. Middle crack.

routes.description: Follow a zig zagging crack past a ledges before stepping right to a thin seam and exit
routes.location: obvious zig zag up middle of Upper Tier

routes.description: Climb the left leaning crack through a series of diagonal cracks and ledges. More thought provoking than it appears.
routes.location: upper tier.

routes.description: Right facing dihedral crack
routes.location: Far right of crag near slot between headwall and a large boulder

routes.description: Work the large obvious crack. Gets wider near the top.
routes.location: Upper ledge on right side of crag. Obvious crack

routes.description: Move past a few bolts to gain a small ledge, follow the seam up and right to the top.
routes.location: Start right of the right facing corner under a couple bolts in a slot between the headwall and a large boulder.

routes.description: work up a small left dihedral to a ledge, then follow thin seam with salal roots to the top.
routes.location: rightmost crack on upper tier

routes.description: Crack to the right of the obvious large crack.
routes.location: Thin crack to the right of the obvious large crack.

routes.description: A stiff start off the ground serves up solid finger pockets you'll wish went on forever.
routes.location: Follow a faint trail down left from the Split Asunder Chimney. A collection of 3 cracks will be seen just around the corner. Right most finger crack.

routes.description: Move along a small ledge to the base of a beautiful splitter crack. Solid jams from start to finish!
routes.location: right dihedral

routes.fa: Ryan Pierce, Trevor Harris, & Ania Polak, 2023
routes.description: A short slab crack with 3 variable finishes. Sarah stays right of the block and squeezes through to the top protected by a single bolt, Mary heads up and left under the block for a short traverse, and Winifred cuts left for some balancy slab protected by a couple bolts before cutting back right. All routes finish at the same chains around a tree.
routes.location: From the Split Asunder chimney, head left down the faint trail, past The Flame and Bye, Bud and around the corner.
routes.protection: Standard Rack, 3 bolts (pending finish) Chained Tree Anchor

routes.description: Thin crack to the left of the alder stump. Start down low, left of ledge. Gear can be thin and a little tricky.Link with Pig's Ear for 2 pitches.Rap into gully in front of anchor
routes.location: Left most portion of crag

routes.description: Thin shallow crack up a steep ramp. Gear is also thin. Spookier than it looks.
routes.location: steep ramp in center of crag.

routes.description: Work lower horizontal cracks under a small roof to gain the large boulder. Follow ledges and bolts to the top.
routes.location: left of large ledge under a small roof

routes.description: Stick clipping the first bolt to avoid a hazardous start, make some small moves past a few bolts to a small ledge leading to a thin seam to the top.
routes.location: The first route on the far right of the crag. Start below a couple bolts in the slot between the headwall and a large boulder.

routes.description: Thin seam up the face protected by a single bolt
thin sharp left facing dihedral crack
Follow the leftmost line of bolts up smooth slab. Think sticky thoughts.
Open Project. Work the ledges past bolts up and to the right until you run out of hands and feet, then keep going.
routes.location: Right of Witty

routes.description: An old project that needs work. Never completed, bolts haven't been tested.Route works the overhung edge of the Pig's Ear feature.
routes.location: pig's ear

routes.description: This is a route equipped years ago by Jesse Redden and Jason Green. They moved on to other things without having climbed it. Like much of the crag, the moss took it over but it is now clean, though there will likely always be some hollow-sounding rock in the crack.
routes.location: This route sits by itself, at the far left end of the crag, after a bit of a break-down in the cliff.  It is visible from the vague trail that leads downhill from the main part of the crag. Look for the short, overhanging, offwidth.

routes.description: Gain the ledge through a slot in the rock. A bouldery move off the ledge leads to smaller ledges with great holds and solid gear placement. A great quick route to gain access to Upper Tier climbs.
routes.location: Large ledge at entrance to crag.

routes.description: Unsure of route.
routes.location: Right of Trench Warfare

routes.description: Ride the 2 left running cracks out to a ledged arete, then gain the bulge to the anchor.
routes.location: standard rack

routes.description: The feature route of the crag!P1 (5.8) Paddle up the arete until its possible to move into the chimney along a small ledge. Work your way up and in until it's possible to exit left onto a ledge that leads back to an anchor below the pig's ear pitch.P2 (5.7) Gain the Pig's Ear by delicately moving back out over the chimney into a small corner. Work the ear to the top.Rap down to the ledge, then down into the gully directly in front of the rap rings. Walk back around to the base.
routes.location: Far left of the crag. The obvious split in the rock.

routes.description: A direct start to Sunny Summit down low through a thin seam that leads to a horizontal salal crack
routes.location: leftmost of upper tier
routes.protection: SR, small cams and nuts, 2 bolts

routes.description: Follow an overgrown salal crack ledge then head straight up the slab past bolts
routes.location: lefmost of upper tier

routes.description: Work small edges past bolts on the headwall.
routes.location: On upper ledge near slot between the headwall and a large boulder.

routes.description: Similar crack to the left of Trench Warfare
routes.location: Left of Trench Warfare

routes.description: Work a broken crack to an OW on a ramp to the top.
routes.location: Rusty crack

routes.description: Work a few ledges and a small arete to a spooky slap finish off right
routes.location: Bolted arete in center of crag

description: I only added this area as it was mentioned in the Smoke Bluffs Interconnector  mountainproject.com/route/1… and it took us a while to find it.We gave directions below, from the top of Octopus Garden crag, as Octopus is quite popular and therefore potentially the shortest way. Themyscira is also accessible from the loop trail but looks like no one ever comes up here, sadly. Hoping that the exact coordinates (as taken from my phone at the base of the crag) will also be helpful. 49.7078202, -123.1349960
getting_there: Unfortunately can't be very clear as we located it via a multi-pitch. If you ever find yourself on top of a route on Octopus Garden crag, walk straight back away from the edge. You will likely pass Christopher's wooden memorial bench and then a path (left to right). We suggest you take the right but immediately hop on one of the mountain biking trails on the other side, and start trending rightwards. If you hit a biking trail that goes straight back (or back/left) you will hit Skunk Hollow (pictured in the new squamish select). If you trend more rightward, you will end up arriving at Themyscira. It should only be a 5 - 10 min walk from the top of Octopus Garden. If it's longer, retrace your steps and try again.

routes.fa: R Barley, N Henderson, P Cooper, 2018
routes.description: If this route was in the parking lot it would be climbed all day long. Instead it's at the top of Smoke Bluffs and in sad need of cleaning. Despite the moss it's fairly secure. Bring a scrubbing brush if you're coming up this way.
routes.location: This is the obvious crack in the center of the crag that goes straight up and merges with a left leaning crack to get to the top.
routes.protection: single rack, no chains at the top (just two bolts and a funny-looking glued-in rap ring a couple of feet left) so walk off by using the mountain bike trail at the back of the crag

description: This is the last little crag at the end of the trail with the tunnel over on the drippy right side.  This was really overgrown a few years back. I am guessing that when Robin Barley and friends where here in 2008 it got the makeover.
getting_there: Follow the main trail behind houses as far as it goes east. Or you will run into it descending the trail from Funarama and Ronin's Corner.

routes.description: Start on Tunnel vision but move right through diagonal cracks to a bolted prow.
routes.location: 2 bolts, SR to 1.75"

routes.description: Pass two bolts on on the far right of the wall, clip the chains on the mid anchor, then pass another bolt and follow broken cracks to the top.
routes.location: Far right of the main wall

routes.description: The second route on this wall from the left side up the terraced hill. Follow the second mostly vertical crack line to the top of the wall. Crux is near the top.
routes.location: Tunnel Rock far left (up the terraces).

routes.description: Kevin's book calls this a 5.8, Marc's calls it a 5.9, so I went in-between. Feels more like a 5.8 to me.After the crack it winds around arete to the right and then finishes toward the left.The direct start with the 2 bolts is 10c and pretty scary getting to the 2nd bolt with ground fall potential.
routes.location: Center of the face, obvious hand crack leaning to the right.
routes.protection: Standard rack, with doubles in hand to fist size if unsure of leading at the grade.  Bolted anchor

routes.description: Thought this deserved it's own entry since it only shares the last few moves with the original line. I thought this was a much better and more sustained line - climbs the best part of the original route while skipping the easier climbing before the crux.   Low, distinct crux after clipping the second bolt, then follow thin hands left, hands up and fingers right before meeting up with the crux mantle of the 5.8 original line.    The crack climbing is 5.9-ish. The slab crux is given 10c by Bourdon, but it might be easier if you're 6 feet tall.
routes.location: On the west wall of Tunnel Rock, following two low bolts (within the first ten feet) into cracks. The (climbers) leftmost line of bolts at the crag.
routes.protection: 2 bolts, then gear from yellow C3 to blue C4. Chains at the top.

routes.description: Start on The constant gardener, but move right when possible to a thin crack that gains a ledge, climb left past a bolt and then follow the zig zag crack above, the crux being the leftward finger crack traverse
routes.location: Left side of the crag.

routes.description: hand crack on far left.
routes.location: up slope to far left end.
routes.protection: standard rack to 3", shares anchor with Go for Broke.

routes.description: Climb Vertical Sine Wave, but break off left before the zigzag onto the face following the line of 3 bolts.
routes.location: 3 bolts, SR to 2"

routes.description: Climb the start of Tunnelman, then follow 4 bolts left up the airy ridge.
routes.location: 4 bolts and a few cams

routes.fa: H Duty, E Olson, D Roberts (2013)
routes.description: Climb the steep right leaning hand crack 10 meters to the left of the tunnel. Then follow the line of 3 bolts just off to the left of the Noonday Ridge arete. The start is burly and can seep for awhile.    Shares an anchor with Noonday Ridge.
routes.location: 10 meters to the left of the Tunnel.
routes.protection: 3 Bolts, standard rack, chains at the top

routes.description: Basically an easier and less excellent right-hand variation on the direct start of Easy Skankin'. Face climb past 2 bolts, plug a bit of gear then join up with the splitter finger crack up to the mantles of Easy Skankin'.
routes.location: To the right of Easy Skankin' is a set of two bolts up a thin face to some splitter cracks. This is the direct start to Easy Skankin' (aka Queasy Crankin') and offers some pleasant climbing.   Keep going around the corner and you'll see another 2 bolts with more obvious face holds. This is Sunstroker.

routes.description: This odd route climbs the thin pillar right of Tunnelman, right beside the tunnel
routes.location: 2 bolts, SR

routes.description: Climb the small corner (0.1 and 0.2 BD Cams) up to the bolt and make a difficult move across with bad feet into the crack, then back right onto the ledge and chains.
routes.location: The single bolt that sits on the face between Centralia and Washers and Chains
routes.protection: A couple of small cams and a quickdraw.

routes.description: The route starts with low angle easy moves before getting steeper about half way up.
routes.location: Gear to 2". Anchors with rap rings on top.

routes.description: An alright route on fingers to hands. Bouldery start leads to straightforward jamming.
routes.location: It's pretty close to the tunnel, on the left side. Slants to the right with a big block feature sticking out at chest/eye level. Technically in the "Vandalarium", though I have no idea why they should be considered seperate crags.
routes.protection: Single rack is fine, rap rings at the top.

routes.description: The first route done on this wall. On the left side, up terraced hill. Zig zag route with the crux being the left ward finger traverse near the top.After the hand crack start there is a right leaning traverse, and then the left crux traverse, if you go straight up before the right traverse it is a 5.8 variation.
routes.location: 2nd route in from the left, the first is a 5.7 crack
routes.protection: standard rack to 3". The crux takes small cams. Use long slings to help with rope drag.  Bolted anchor

routes.description: Start on Tunnel Vision, but break right up a groove to a massive ledge, Discontinuous cracks lead to chains above.
routes.location: SR to 2"

description: A small outlier crag next to Tunnel Rock. The Vandalarium is located just to the right of the tunnel.Most routes aren't climbed very frequently and are likely slightly dirty or mossy.
getting_there: From Tunnel Rock, walk up the trail to the right towards the Tunnel. Crag is to the right fo the tunnel.

routes.description: A slab climb up the left face, just to the left of the large groove that splits the Vandalarium
routes.location: Just left of the large groove in the middle of the Vandalarium

routes.description: The very short face climb just to the right of the tunnel.
routes.location: Immediately to the right of the tunnel.

routes.description: Follows discontinuous cracks up the short face near the tunnel. Bring your RPs
routes.location: Just right of the tunnel.

description: This cliff provides some of the longest and best routes, which makes this one of the most popular areas to climb. It also has a variety of links ups which provide fun multi pitch climbing.New routes have been cleaned and added to the right of Mosquito.
getting_there: From the main intersection at the entrance of the town center on highway 99 turn right (North) onto Loggers Lane.  Park in the designated parking area on the right-hand side of the road at the north end of the Smoke Bluffs.

routes.fa: Dean Hart, Bruce McDonald, Kevin McLane
routes.description: Crux above the 4th bolt. Good mantling. A little mossy in just a couple spots. Some crystals for foot holds and interesting sequences.
routes.location: Directly above the anchor on Mosquito. Left of Plegmish Dance.

routes.description: A short pitch on its own, but of significantly more merit if continues as a direct finish to SM's Delight.  The rock appears broken and rough, but the holds and protection are good.  The pitch is best done as an extension to the single pitch of SM's delight, as it lies directly in line with that climb and is consistent with most of it's climbing.
routes.location: From the bolt and chain anchor atop SM's delight, this climb is the threaded cracks  leaning slightly left, directly overhead.
routes.protection: A few small cams and stoppers protect this climb, and get you to a 2-bolt anchor (no chains to rap from) up and left, high on the slab above. To retreat without walking Rap or lower in 2 stages as for the anchors on Mosquito back down to the anchors for  Mosquito or SM's Delight and re-thread.  Even a single 70M won't quite get you down to the base of the lower wall from the top of this.

routes.description: This is the notch between "Sex" and "Rock 'n' Roll"
routes.location: Guidebook says SR to 2" (I haven't climbed it)

routes.description: This line uses the bolts to the right of "Through the Never". It climbs through two roofs (bolted) then up thin ice weeping down left of the Killer Fridge corner. Finish on the ledge below Jabberwocky.
routes.location: Just to the right of the summer rock route Through the Never at Smoke Bluff Wall area, and well left of Alice on Ice and not that far left of Killer Fridge/The Myld Thing.

routes.description: A worthwhile crack if you are stumped by the Jabberwocky boulder problem, or already done it.  A alterate start to Jabberwocky.
routes.location: left of Jabberwocky.  there is a bolted anchor, same as Jabberwocky.
routes.protection: standard rack, long slings for traversing and wandering back and forth.

routes.description: A bouldery low crux leads to a nice technical finger crack.
routes.location: The route starts on the upper tier of the smoke bluff wall.

routes.description: Steep and dynamic
routes.location: Right of Zombie Roof, Left of Old Age

routes.description: Another great hand and finger crack.  Plenty of protection.
routes.location: From the Zombie Roof (mondo roof with a crack running through it, visible from the trail), follow a trail along the base of the wall to the left. It switches back up, under a large boulder, to a fixed hand-line. Climb the hand-line (not trivial, some may want a belay) up to the ledge. Toward the right end of the ledge begins Laughing Crack (it will be obvious). Rappel the route.
routes.protection: Gear to 2 inches.  Two-bolt anchor on top.

routes.description: This is the start for the "Smoke Bluff Connection".     Handjam and lieback to a good ledge, if it were only longer it would be the best 5.8 out there?
routes.location: Patience:  You'll need it when you see the line for this climb.

routes.fa: S. Frimer, B. Backhouse, J. Frimer
routes.description: Up a corner immediately right of Mosquito past a block (crux), then wriggle up a deep corner/chimney.
routes.location: immediately right of Mosquito

routes.fa: Bob Milward, Peter Shackleton, Robin Barley: April 1984
routes.description: Old Age climbs a fun corner with some interesting moves up steep rock about halfway up.  Good rests are available before the harder sections.
routes.location: This route starts on the right side of the Zombie Roof in a large left facing dihedral.  Rap the route or lower off with one 60m rope.
routes.protection: A single set of wires and cams to a #3 Camalot.  There is a two bolt anchor at the top.

routes.description: From the top of Mosquito, step slightly right, then continue up thin, parallel cracks to the top.  Consistent, interesting 5.8 finger jams and stemming the whole way.
