routes.location: To descend: Continue up Smoke Bluff Connection to the top, or 2 rappells to the base of Mosquito.
routes.protection: Gear to 2", emphasize wires and small cams. The gear is great to the top, but every placement looks like it will be your last.

routes.fa: 1985 I. Christiansen.  Recleaned 2010 by J. Frimer
routes.description: In 2010, this route was reclaimed from the jungle.  The opening left facing corner is technical and fun.  Head up and then a little right and pass through the gap to the left of the capstone.
routes.location: Right of Mosquito, find the largest left facing open book. It starts directly off a little platform.

routes.description: A great, technical seam up a steep headwall is the highlight of this little gem.
routes.location: The seam splitting the headwall is obvious. Climb the easy corner below to access it.
routes.protection: RPs/HP offsets (bring a few of the medium to bigger sizes) to #2 camalot. Gear is excellent despite appearances.  Rap anchors on top.

routes.description: A great new pitch! Technical steep shallow corner to start, and then clip the two bolts on the arete leading to the capstone.  Head up to the capstone (steep) and then move right and layback to the top.
routes.location: The last appealing corner/slot to the right of Mosquito. You can see the two bolts on the arete above the corner.  The bolts are on arete to the LEFT of this corner.  There is another corner shallow between this and Rock & Roll to the left.
routes.protection: Standard rack - bring a #4 or #4.5 camalot for the top.

routes.description: Climb the slightly flared crack just left of Mosquito. Thin gear and technical feet to start before a deceptive crux. Get into good hands up an easing and widening crack to an optional belay. If continuing up Phlegmish Dance, step right across the slab to the second anchor on the bigger ledge.
routes.location: Small rack to 3" - emphasis in .4-.75

routes.description: The most popular link up at the Smoke Bluffs, and with good reason.  A case of the sum being greater than its parts.   Climb Mosquito (5.8), then Phlegmish Dance (5.8).  Walk ~50 feet through the woods and climb Jabberwocky (5.10b).  Finish with Wonderland (5.9).  Smile.
routes.location: Start as for Mosquito.  Walk off from the top of Wonderland.
routes.protection: Gear to 3".  Bolted anchors on each pitch.

routes.description: Long, left-leaning hand-crack visible from the main trail directly below wonderland. Start by romping up flakes and then pulling up cracks in a corner. Traverse out to the splitter 40' thin-to-wide hands crack. Great intro to the size. There is an extension above the anchor which leads into Wonderland at 5.10b (Sparky Goes to Wonderland).
routes.location: Approach as for Jabberwocky by way of the smoke bluff connection or by wandering down from Pixie Corner. Start on bulges and flakes 10' left of Jabberwocky.
routes.protection: Standard rack to 3". Doubles in 1-2" are useful, as are some extendable draws. Bolts and chains at the top.

routes.description: Just right of Mosquito is a boulder that once surmounted leads to this very fun face.
routes.location: A couple of medium cams (1/2 to 1 inch) and long slings are necessary, but it's mostly bolted.

routes.description: Start on Old Age and then go right through the roof following bolts.
routes.location: Last line of the right of the Zombie Roof area.

routes.description: The legendary roof crack in the Smoke Bluffs. Start up an easy groove to get established on a good jug at the start of the roof. Then use hand-jams, fingerlocks, heel-toe cams and more crack trickery to climb through the roof with a cruxy sequence just before turning the lip. Better than it looks!
routes.location: Just off the trail before 'Mosquito' very easy to find.

description: Beautiful white rock left of the Zip. Topo found on Quickdraw Publications:https://quickdrawpublications.com/wp-content/uploads/topos/Smoke_Bluffs_Boys_Porteau2.pdf
getting_there: Same as the Zip.

routes.description: This is a slabby, left-facing corner with a crack that peters out roughly 2/3rds up. The rest of the route, including the balancey crux that exits the corner, is protected by bolts. Place gear as high as you can in the crack before moving on, as it's a short climb and you're still pretty close to terra firma. Clamber up low-angled slab to chains.
routes.location: Approach as for any other route in Burning Man Corner. If you're walking south, this section of wall is the first area of the crag visible thought the trees after walking past the runoff pipes. Can't miss it.
routes.protection: A few finger-sized pieces and quickdraws for the two bolts. I found a tricam was really handy at the top of the crack.

routes.location: SR

routes.description: This is rated 5.8 in the original topo but I thought it was a bit harder. It's a thin slab with a few tenuous moves past bolts. It's still pretty untrodden so expect the occasional crystal to break off.
routes.location: Left of the Boys in the Woods corner. This is the northernmost area of the Burning Man Corner crag, visible through the trees just south of the runoff pipes.
routes.protection: Quickdraws. Optional finger sized piece between the second and third bolt.
routes.route_name: Do It Right the First Time

routes.description: Start up Swampton, but after reaching the big ledge, step right below two bolts. A few techy (10+) moves take you up to another big ledge. The original route then takes the further right, left-leaning diagonal reds and golds crack and then breaks right to a third bolt, followed by a mantle to a third ledge and a bolted anchor. It seemed more logical to me to instead climb the middle, more straight-up 5.8 crack to a bolted anchor, but there is a potential that by doing this you skip the intended 10d crux.
routes.location: Start up the middle, curvy wide-hands crack in the middle of the face and break right to a ledge. Topo here.
routes.protection: A #4 Camalot is nice to protect the bottom section, but no gear necessary that is smaller than 0.5 Camalot. Bolted anchors with rap rings.

routes.description: Nice corner crack
routes.location: Either rap down from above, or climb the 10b corner and walk over.

routes.description: Fun wide crack that zig zags up the wall. Has a funny dihedral that almost acts as a chimney in the middle, where you'll really be worming your way up.
routes.location: SR to 3'', Can place a 4

routes.description: Slightly overhung hand jamming in a corner leads to an easier 5.9 pitch above.
routes.location: SR to 3''

description: Enter a description of this area.
getting_there: Provide some directions to this area.

routes.description: A route with an...interesting, but well protected crux that sits just to the right of the Zip.   Climb the crack to a ledge, then climb the dihedral on the left to a roof and follow the crack to the top.
routes.location: The crack system just right of the zip.

routes.description: Same start, easier variation
routes.location: SR

routes.description: Sustained, delicate, cryptic climbing on very sharp little holds. Bring stiff shoes and fresh skin! You might want a little cam for the start if you're uncomfortable with the somewhat high, somewhat tricky first bolt.
routes.location: The leftmost route on the wall that has The Zip (just right of the arete).

routes.description: A shorter, lower-angle and less classic version of The Zip. Very similar locks and crack formation, but more casual and less sustained.
routes.location: (Climbers) right-most of the three cracks. To the right of Crystal Ball.
routes.protection: Mostly fingers-to-thin hands. Chain anchors with rap rings.

routes.description: Just right of The Zip is a worthwhile sport climb.  The first half of the climb is unrelentingly technical and thin.  The finish is much easier but pleasant.
routes.location: Three bolts protect the first half.  A few nuts or medium sized cams protect the much easier second half.

routes.description: A short splitter climb. Starts with a 15 feet of flaring fingers and finishes with 15 feet of flaring hands, good feet abound. The gear may be a little tricky at the start but the beginning will eat offset nuts, overall a very safe lead.
routes.location: If standing at the Zip look south and slight uphill, this route is the obvious freshly cleaned splitter. There is a sharpied piece of plywood at the base which identifies this route as a 10a.
routes.protection: .3 BD-#1 BD, a set of nuts

routes.description: It's impossible to miss this climb once at the crag.  Start by scrambling onto the obvious ledge.  The hand and finger locks on this crack are great, but it's too small for solid foot jams in most places.  Small edges provide thin but adequate feet in most places...except the crux.  A very fun and well protected climb.  It might be a tough on-sight for a beginning 10a leader, but that shouldn't deter anyone from trying.
routes.location: Finger and hand-sized nuts and cams. Take as many or as few as you like. Chains with quick links at the top, although you could walk off if you wanted to.

description: With a decent cold snap, the AMO wall turns into a reliably forming multi pitch ice slab.Expect thin ice and long run outs, but with a decent cold snap, the ice will become fatter.
getting_there: Same approach as the AMO wall in Summer.

routes.description: Adding this as a distinct entry given there are a number of routes that form on the AMO wall and each climbs differently.The line described here is the leftmost of the three lines that form in a large corner feature about 3 minutes hike climber's left and uphill of the base of the actual AMO Wall with established rock climbing routes. If the ice is there, the routes will be obvious.P1 - WI3-4, 30m - Climb up what can be a steep pillar for about 10 meters before topping out onto a low angle ledge and then rambling up easy ice to a tree belay.P2 - WI3, 70m - Climb one long rope stretcher start with a steeper step into easy ice, finishing with another steeper step to a tree belay with a bunch of tat. Rappel here if you have double 70s or take it to the top.P3 - WI2-3, 20m - Climb a shorter pitch into the woods (may need to finish by pulling on some bushes to get over the final rock) and belay off a tree.If you took it to the end, unrope and bushwack traversing directly climber's right through the trees until you come across a trail that runs along the left side of Shannon Falls. Follow this down to the tourist trail and back to the parking lot.
routes.location: Stubbies and prayers. Ice is probably going to be too thin for screws in most places, it's all tree belays.

routes.description: 2-3 pitches of easy, runout ice slabs.
routes.location: AMO Wall
routes.protection: Stubby screws + some rock gear. But don't expect to place much.

routes.description: The rock climbing route, Stranger than Friction, has a seep that can freeze in the winter.I climbed it on lead on inch thin ice and figured it's worth documenting. Scratch your way up whatever ice is on the steep slab start to the one and only bolt you'll have as pro from the rock route. Once you clip the bolt the angle eases to a good ledge where you can sling a bush. Easier angled ice will get you to a tree you can sling before making the final moves to the chain anchor ledge.If the ice is thick or you're bold, you can probably continue up further.
routes.location: Right side of AMO wall, exactly the same spot the rock route Stranger than Friction starts.
routes.protection: A bolt, a bush, and a tree.

description: A collection of ice routes that occasionally form on the Stawamus Chief.Most routes require a solid 4-5 days of consistent, below freezing temperatures to reliably form.
getting_there: A good cold snap and a lot of patience

routes.fa: Peter Croft, Bruce Kay & Tami Knight, January 1982
routes.description: This route climbs a narrow streak that forms from seepage underneath the impressive University Wall.The route actually climbs the line of a slabby sport climb called "The First Course" and ends at the trees to the left of the P1 anchors for the University Wall.Probably best to rappel the route, but also possible to walk off to the left on the standard U-Wall approach which follows a narrow ledge down and climbers left of Seasoned in the Sun.
routes.location: About 60-100m right of Seasoned in the Sun.If it's in, it'll be hard to miss.
routes.protection: Screws, and possibly the occasional bolt if ice is thin, especially near the base.

description: Crack Scratch is a new beginner friendly dry tooling developed by Gabriel Viel-Cote and Will Hickson near Squamish in February 2021. One of Squamish's few dedicated dry tooling crags! Climbs are well bolted, so it's a good place to learn dry tooling and get mileage. TR access up the chossy slope to the right of the crag.
getting_there: Located 1km north bound of Brohm lake on the right side of the highway driving towards Whistler.Or 1.5km south bound of Area 44 parking lot on the left side of the highway driving towards Squamish.There is a small gravel pullout on the East side of the highway.

routes.fa: Gabriel Viel-Côté and Will Hickson, Feb 2021
routes.description: Right most line at the crag. A fairly mellow start leads to a slabby section with a long reach on decent hooks with poor feet.
routes.location: Left of the face graffiti.

routes.fa: Gabriel Viel-Côté and Will Hickson, Feb 2021
routes.description: Center line, up the crack with the tree root in it at the base. Follow the cracks up to a small ledge, then left.
routes.location: Center of the slab.
routes.protection: Bolts, but can also be lead on gear.
routes.route_name: Does My Butt Look Good in This Crack?

routes.fa: Gabriel Viel-Côté and Will Hickson, Feb 2021
routes.description: The awkward right leaning crack on the left side of the crag. The start feels especially awkward.
routes.location: Left side of the slab.
routes.protection: 9 BoltsCould also be lead on gear.

description: New dry tooling crag developed at the end of Tantalus Road near StudioQ.
getting_there: Park at the end of Tantalus Road. Cross the bridge and look up and right.Approx 60 seconds from the car.

routes.description: The first new line established at the Cul De Sac crag. Short, steep and pumpy!Permadraws and a short approach?! What's not to love?
routes.location: Follow the draws up and over the small roof.

description: The Fitness Center is a new Dry Tooling crag situated on the SW side of Debeck’s Hill. There are 8 routes in total, ranging from D6+ to D10. The cliff sees moderate filtered sun from mid morning onwards.All of the routes are fully fixed with steel chains and steel carabiners on every bolt, as well as all anchors. A 40m rope will safely get you down from all the routes. All hardware was supplied by the developer, as well as a few friends who helped contribute financially to the endeavor.The choice to develop this cliff for dry tooling was made with the understanding that it would not provide for good rock climbing. The quality of rock is simply such that it would remain dirty, and small holds would continuously break. You will find many holds have been enhanced (drilled), particularly in the areas of lesser quality rock. This is to prevent holds from repeatedly “blowing out” under the force of picks. Efforts have been made to clean as much of the loose rock as feasible, however, rockfall remains a possibility. Helmets are highly recommended, and standing underneath climbers should be avoided when possible.Many routes seep extensively over the winter, especially the steepest ones through the central roof. During our coveted arctic outflows, unsupported ice features form along the top. None of the routes have yet to see a true mixed winter ascent, but it is foreseeable that conditions will permit for this in the future. If you are climbing here when ice is present, be aware of your surroundings and continually assess for overhead hazards!All first ascents were completed while wearing crampons. Climbing in rock shoes is certainly possible and would feel easier.Topo HERE
getting_there: Park at the North end of Tantalus road. The approach follows existing MTB trails.   Hike up Plural of Nemesis until it is possible to take a faint trail left that links into Pleasure Trail. Continue up Pleasure Trail to the base of a small cliff. Faint trail left will take you to the base of the crag.   Please be aware of any downhill bike traffic while hiking and yield the right of way to bikers.

routes.description: Start in a shallow dihedral and pull through a small bulge to transition right with technical footwork. A high foot to pull through the upper bulge will surely open up the hips and get you warmed up!
routes.location: 4 Bolts

routes.description: Start in the steep crack with good holds and torques (pick weights may add some security). A restful stance midway leads powerful movement through steep terrain to the anchors. One of the best lines at the cliff!
routes.location: Furthest left, below a small prominent roof.

routes.description: Similar in flavor to its neighbor. Take the right split at the second clip. Big moves get progressively harder as you climb higher. It’s not over until it’s over!
routes.location: #5. Share's a start with "Five Minute Shower Token"

routes.description: Take the left split at the second clip. Big moves on good holds with thin feet are the recurring theme. The final roof can be a heartbreaker!
routes.location: Line #4. Share's a start with "Drill Sergeant"

routes.description: Easier climbing up the initial dihedral with torques, stemming, and technical placements leads to a steep sequence at the top. Enjoy the exposed position while you clip the anchors.
routes.location: 7 Bolts

routes.description: Fun climbing through many natural features leads to a high crux getting established into a good stein pull.
routes.location: 8 Bolts

routes.description: Fun climbing through blocky terrain. Negotiate your way through multiple small bulges to a technical finish.
routes.location: Furthest right route

routes.description: Climb up the dihedral. Good sticks with bad feet will keep you on (or off) your toes and add to the ever building pump.
routes.location: Second line from the left, up the right facing dihedral.

description: An ice/mixed climbing crag across from Nightmare Rock in Murrin Park. The mixed lines can be climbed year round.The cliff also sports a few sport climbs to the left of the mixed lines.
getting_there: Park at Murrin Park, and carefully run across the road. Walk north for a few minutes until you get to the trailhead

routes.description: A thin curtain of ice that forms from below the roof after several days of consistent cold temperatures.
routes.location: If it's in, you won't miss it.
routes.protection: Short screws depending on thickness or TR

routes.description: Can be climbed year round, with no ice. Shares an anchor with Puke and Spew
routes.location: Bolts + Gear, Double Rack to 4"

routes.description: Can be climbed year round, with no ice. Shares an anchor with Poop and Spew.
routes.location: 7 Bolts, plus 0.2 - 0.5 gear

routes.description: Can be climbed year round, with no ice. Shares an anchor with Poop and Puke.
routes.location: 6 bolts and gear, 0.2 - 0.5

description: This area encompasses the climbs found in the valley between the backside of the Chief and the massif that forms the area of the Sea to Sky gondola and ultimately Mt. Habrich. There are a number of routes found on the south side of this valley, but the most well known (and worth doing) is A Scottish Tale.
getting_there: These climbs can either be accessed via a ~2-3 hour approach from the gondola parking lot, starting up the Sea to Sky trail, and then cutting left parallel along the creek after you cross it on a wooden bridge (there is flagging tape and lots of GPS tracks out there). The other, more convenient access, is to simply take the gondola up and then rappel in a little bit before you get to the Chief viewpoint on the Panorama trail.

routes.description: An area classic and a great outing with an alpine feel.A Scottish Tale climbs a corner system through easy easy mixed terrain, over an iconic chockstone into thin ice smears and eventually fat ice up high.There are 9 pitches or so in total, but the reality is that you will likely spend a fair bit of time soloing the lower half depending on conditions as pro is sparse or nonexistent and the only options for anchors at times are not ideal. The upper half generally has great ice, and is often done as an outing unto itself by rappelling in from the Panorama trail down to where the good ice ends.
routes.location: See area description for approach information.
routes.protection: Standard rack for ice, some rock gear if you can find spots for it down low.

description: Squamish's premier dry tooling crag!
getting_there: Park at the end of Tantalus Road.Follow the trail about 150m and cross a foot bridge. Take a left on a mountain bike trail and follow it up hill for about 15-20 minutes until you get to the climbers trail marked with a cairn sharply to your left. Follow this climbers trail for approx 5 minutes.The mountain bike trail you follow is called Pleasure Trail and the climbers trail cuts out past a tree right at the apex of a switch back.

routes.description: **Note this is a placeholder name for this route, if someone knows the FA details of it (or just the established name), please message me and I will happily change the entry to reflect that info**The center line at the main crag, start with some thin moves into overhanging powerful moves that don't really let up until the top.
routes.location: Center line at the main area, follows a prominent black dyke feature through a series of roofs.

routes.description: **Note this is a placeholder name for this route, if someone knows the FA details of it (or just the established name), please message me and I will happily change the entry to reflect that info**A tough and insecure start leads into the off width/chimney where creative movement will get you past some blank sections.
routes.location: 3rd route from the left, immediately next to the one with golden chained permadraws.

description: My inspiration for creating this area was the collection of linkups in the Linville Gorge area of western North Carolina, particularly the Linville Crusher. Add to it as you please! Squamish is a brilliant area for linking routes, as there are dozens of multis within short walking distance of each other. Huge, proud enchainments are possible: one notable recent example is Tim Emmett's link of University Wall, Freeway, and Northern Lights.
getting_there: Depends on what you do!

routes.description: As a North Carolina native, I was inspired by the notorious Linville Crusher to put together my own enchainment, climbing five of the major west-facing features along the Sea-to-Sky, from the Papoose to Slhanay. For full value, do the connection entirely on foot. This link-up has very likely been done before, and probably with much harder variations. I include it here as a resource for other people who might be interested in a fun long day out. As there are multiple moderate routes up each of the formations listed, you can have a lot of creative freedom with the style and difficulty, as well as the pitch count. 5.10a is about as easy as it gets, as Hairpin and Jungle Warfare are the easiest routes up their respective formations.  Start at the Papoose. Climb Hairpin (5p, 10a). Walk off, then hike up to the base of the Shannon Falls Wall. Climb Spirit of Squamish (8p, 5.8). Descend, then take the connector trail up to the Chief campground, and walk down to the pedestrian overpass connecting the Grand Wall parking lot to the Malamute. (If you're not pressed for time and want to add a bit more fun jamming to your day, stop by the Bulletheads and run up Slot Machine. For full value, do it in one pitch) Descend the Malamute via the Stooge Slab and Grub Street rappels. Climb Old Style into Cider Crack, traversing left past a bolt just before Midway Ledge to access the base of the Starr Wall (I had a mini epic trying to find the correct spot to traverse--an alternate finish would be to just continue up Grubber's Highway by climbing Sodbuster). Finish it up by climbing the mega-classic High Mountain Woody to the top of the formation (3p, 10a). Hike back to the Grand Wall parking lot and take the Apron Connector down the hill to the Apron lot. Walk over to Rambles and climb it (4p 5.8-), then walk over to Over the Rainbow (6p 5.9+). Smear your way up to Broadway Ledge and scramble off climber's right. Upon arriving back at the Apron lot, stroll up the Mamquam Forest Service Road until you reach the clearing through which Slhanay is visible (about 1.5 km). Hike steeply up to the wall, then climb Jungle Warfare (5p 10a). After topping out, locate the descent trail about 30m above the final anchor and hike off. You're done! If it's still light out, go take a dip in the Mamquam or get celebratory beers in town--you've climbed a fair bit of rock and hiked around 8 km (including walk-offs)!
routes.location: To start, park at the Shannon Falls parking lot, or at the overflow lot across the street. Hike from there! Having a car in support to pick you up from the Slhanay parking area, or from the Apron lot, is nice to avoid extra hiking after climbing all those routes!
routes.protection: Varied rack depending on which routes you do. Generally speaking, gear to 4" and a number of alpine draws. Over the Rainbow requires only a small handful of cams, as it's primarily bolted.

description: Variety of fun bolted sport climbs. Slabby to slightly overhanging. Well bolted with unique basalt features.
getting_there: From the fork in the clearing on the logging road, take the left-hand option. Follow it for a few minutes and cross a creek. Chuck Chuck Wall will clearly come into view on the left of the road. Can't miss it.

routes.description: Big moves through big holds to a roof. Nice basalt features at the top.
routes.location: 6 bolts

routes.description: Excellent moderate.
routes.location: 7 bolts

routes.description: Steep and sustained, several hidden holds.  Flexibility will help you get to the fun features near the top.  "Best route at the cliff," wrote Marc Bourdon, even though he did not include it in his Top 100 list, and did include its neighbor just to the right, Under the Influence (11a).  Too many other awesome 11d's at Squamish to fit this one in his quota.  See if you can fit it in yours!
routes.location: Just left of Under the Influence

routes.description: Excellent moderate.
routes.location: 7 bolts

routes.description: Boulder up past two bolts to a hallelujah jug (climbing up the juggy crack to the right of the first bolt drops the grade to 11+/12-). A difficult sequence gains a strenuous rest on a mid-height ledge, then move up left on good holds and finish with a pumpy, right-trending crack.
routes.location: The rightmost route on the main section of the crag.

routes.description: Awesome tricky route. Great basalt features at the top.
routes.location: 7 bolts

routes.description: Good jugs and hand/fist jams through a crack to a no hands rest followed, by a sustained, difficult climbing up a corner.
routes.location: To the right of Under the Influence in the middle of thw crag; look for the obvious crack.

description: Sunny. Morning shade on the left side.Good climbing on solid granite, gneiss, basalt stuff.This is a quality area but needs some traffic if it is to stay clean.Quickdraw publications PDF is available here (download it before you lose cell service in the valley): https://quickdrawpublications.com/wp-content/uploads/topos/Squamish.Valley.Clint.Chuck.pdf
getting_there: As for Chuck Chuck but go right and up hill at a fork. Follow this until a wash out impedes your progress. Cross the wash out and walk another 15 minutes or so up the road to the base of the cliff. You can't miss it.

routes.description: Easy face climbing into slab (5.9). A corner hand crack takes you to a ledge (10.a). A single 11a move on a short final pitch.
routes.location: Way off on the right

routes.description: Awkward bouldery moves up a corner. Fun stemming! Shares first few clips with Pale Rider, but stays left.
routes.location: Up a ladder to the base of the main arete, starts in an obvious corner.

routes.description: first pitch 5.9, traverse right. second 10a, continue go up the left side of arete. Great view and exposure
routes.location: Third bolted line from the left, below a pine tree.

routes.description: P1 11a A tricky start leads up "The Gauntlet" and then breaks right up the steep face to an anchor. Book rates it as a 10d, felt harder than some Squamish 11's to me.                       P2 11CClimb easily up to a hand crack then continue up awesome features to a crux roof move...excellent
routes.location: Obvious clean streak up the white corner

routes.description: Delicate face climbing, a crack move, and a slab finish with a view ta boot! 5.10b, 5.9, 5.10a.
routes.location: Around the corner from the main wall, path may be slightly overgrown with shrubs

description: A sun-trap of a crag, this is an excellent choice for early or late season climbing. Lots of routes in the 5.12 range, with a few easier routes as well. The main wall has multi-pitch routes up to 60 m, and there are stellar single-pitch routes up to 35 m as well. Solid rock and great climbing.For now (until the next edition of Squamish Select is released), you can find a good topo here.
getting_there: Follow Squamish Valley Rd for 22km past Fergie's Cafe. The parking is 400 m after the bridge at the hydro station (before the High Falls Creek Trailhead). The parking is on the right side and is an obvious square lot for 2-3 cars. To find the trail, walk back the way you drove in 10 m - it will be on the same side as the parking. The hike is 15 mins up a pretty steep hill.

routes.description: By far the easiest climb at the crag. Big holds, good feet, and good fun.
routes.location: The obvious less-than-vertical romp near the left side of the lower pitches below the headwall.

routes.description: Starts in a corner crack then works through a dihedral. An awesome karate kick move leads to a finish through a v-slot.
routes.location: The lower ground belay below the headwall and after the gap in climbs to the right of the 5.8.

routes.description: An excellent climb up the featured arete, with diverse movements and holds. Technical, crimpy sequences down load and big movements on big holds through the steeper section up top.
routes.location: The obvious arete near the left side of the lower wall. Start off the stump.

routes.description: Really nice sequences on edges with decent rests. Follows the face of an outside corner feature for the second half.
routes.location: Start as for Black Velveteen (11d) and at the fifth bolt branch right.

description: Excellent introductory sport crag with a high density of moderate climbs on good stone. A series of small roofs.
getting_there: To find the cliff, locate the trailhead on the north side of the road about 150 meters south of Chuck Chuck Wall (the turn-off is marked by a rock cairn). Hike uphill through the forest for a few minutes to the crag. Sunny in the middle of the day.

routes.description: Cruise-y beginning leading up to a well protected roof crux.
routes.location: 7 bolts
routes.route_name: Didn't I See You on TV?

routes.description: A nice mid-level roof.
routes.location: 7 bolts

routes.description: excellent hands free rest
routes.location: 7 bolts

routes.description: Left most
routes.location: 5 bolts

routes.description: Smooth moves leading up to a short crack which is too small to fit fingers - look for the jug at the top of the crack.  Tricky crux at the top.
routes.location: 7 bolts

routes.description: description
routes.location: just above a stump

description: Remote area on the Third peak past the solarium, with some excellent climbs, worth the walk
getting_there: A few options : From the Third peak trail past white cliff and the Cirque of the uncrackables keep going for 10 minutes, you will see a small sign on your left and a faint trail going up.  From the Solarium, just after Sunshine Breakfast you can bushwhack on a faint trail and go along the cliff, you will end up at a fixed line, after that keep going for 200m for Glory boys.  From the Slhanay( to complete)

routes.description: Pitch 1 : Short corner under a roof with one bolt, traverse left and follow a twin crack. (10b,(25m)Pitch 2 : Short groove, boulder past a bolt and finish at a station under a splitter crack. (10c, 15m)Pitch 3 : Beautiful splitter crack from hands to off-width, traverse right and layback the flake to the ledge and the anchor, enjoy ! (10c, 30m)Pitch 4 : Up the beautiful corner to the top of the large pillar, clip a bolt and make the right traverse to another bolt and step up and climb the fine finger crack. (11a, 25m)
routes.location: Once under the big roof of Dr. Rocktagon there is a fixed rope on your left to the ledge of Glory boy
routes.protection: 2x 0.3- 3, 1x4 and small nuts and cams for the last pitch

description: Shady early in the morning. Noisy due to proximity to the road.  Quick drying  bouldering.
getting_there: Hike down the old road and onto the shoulder of the existing road. Boulders will be on the right.

routes.description: Climb jugs up the south face.
routes.location: Gibb's Cave area.  Same boulder as Communication Breakdown.

routes.description: Start on low horizontal jug rail(same start as Gull Skull) and go straight up(slightly left)
routes.location: same start as gull skull

routes.description: Slap up the triangular-shaped face.
routes.location: The Snake Pit area

routes.description: Climb the slabby SW prow.
routes.location: same boulder as potato gun

routes.description: Climb the right side of the smooth, glassy slab, moving right onto the ramp.
routes.location: Right of Good Bush

routes.description: Start on a flat edge and dyno to the top. Mantel.
routes.location: Around the corner from shots fired. On the stand alone boulder.

routes.description: From the undercling, do a big cross onto a jug and follow a cool ramp to a dihedral. Finish as for Harry's Rail and Sheep Tricks.
routes.location: This is located at Gibb's Cave on the east side. The side is kinda hidden below giant flakes. It start on a huge undercling.

routes.description: Unique movement on small holds with generally good feet.
routes.location: Toward the right side of Gibb's cave starts on very chalked nose feature with a few good edges on it. Exit right of the arete on the face.

routes.description: Sit down start.  Seated start with left sidepull and low right arete.  Grab the top of the pillar and mantle.
routes.location: Jungle area.  Same boulder grouping as The Cutting Edge.

routes.description: Fin feature behind and nearby Hummingbird boulder.
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: A fabulous crack splits this roadside boulder just down the road from the very popular area with ‘The Boot’​Traverse the crack from left to right and either jam or fire up to the high-ish jug to top out. It’s difficulty depends on how well you can jam, in my opinion.A real gem, not to be missed by boulderers and trad climbers alike!Enjoy
routes.location: Unmissable, roadside near ‘The Boot’ & Gibbs Cave’
routes.protection: Good spotters and pads as the route is over a small pit. Typical Squamish.

routes.description: Ramen raws little sister, climb the overhanging lip from the opposite side of the boulder as the ramen raw start. Start down and right at the most obvious start, use the edge of the roof and interesting squeezing opportunities in the roof to traverse towards the tip of the boulder
routes.location: Putting this in the apron area as that's where ramen raw is(my fault as well) but technically in the north wall area. Right past the parking lot of the mfsr, you can see it through the trees from the dirt road of you look carefully, short hike up a very clear and steep trail
routes.protection: Pads, landing is a little worse than ramen

routes.description: Obvious blade between Hummingbird boulder and Magic Carpet Ride boulder.
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Same start as Constrictor.  Go left and top out when holds appear.
routes.location: See Venom Arete

routes.description: Start on edges 2meters below the intersection of 2 boulders.  Traverse the flake rightward and finish on edges right of the small dihedral.
routes.location: Gibb's Cave area.  NE slightly under Gibb's Cave boulder.

routes.description: Start in the crack.  Climb straight up.
routes.location: The other side of Venom Arête ... arête ...

routes.description: Start sitting on the obvious sloping hold and work your way along the arete.  Turn the lip and follow the edge to the top.
routes.location: Follow the old highway bed past the grand wall boulders until you see the cutting edge on the right.

routes.description: Start crouching and climb the crack.
routes.location: Drive By area on Reach the Beach boulder.

routes.description: Start as for Middle Cave, but move right to some jug flakes before trending back left to finish as for Gibbs' Cave.
routes.location: Gibbs' Cave

routes.description: Sit down start.  Start seated and grab a diagonal ledge 2meters right of The Sickle.
routes.location: The Jungle area.  Same boulder cluster as The Cutting Edge.

routes.description: Fin feature behind and nearby Hummingbird boulder.
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Start in a horizontal slot and compress up the hanging boulder. Climb up and right around the arete.
routes.location: 4-5 pads
routes.protection: Located in the same outcropping as Cutting Edge. Approximately 20ft from the Apron trail,

routes.description: Fantastic slab problem up a beautiful pyramid.
routes.location: Decent landing but high.

routes.description: pull on with a heel or toe, climb easily to good crimps then figure out your beta for getting through the cluster of slopers
routes.location: from approach trail you can see a very steep arete on a large boulder up the hill (that's Gibb's Cave area) this boulder is on the furthest left side of the cave starting on a sloping ledge

routes.description: Slabby.  Climb the far left side of the slab.
routes.location: Walk W on MFSR trail heads into trees on right 20meters in from end of pavement.

routes.description: Slabby.
routes.location: Drive By area on Recoil boulder

routes.description: Start low on the big shelf. Move up and right to the arete and then straight up. The first move is a little tough and hanging on at the end requires a little tenacity.
routes.location: To find Gull Skull,locate The Cutting Edge and it will be on your left as you are looking at the boulders from the old road

routes.description: Start on the diagonal rail in the middle of the overhanging face. Make a big move up to the sloper, match, then another big move up to the lip. Top out from there. A little contrived in that you shouldn't use the jug to the left of the sloper. Powerful.
routes.location: Follow the path past Killa' Gorilla and the Serpent Boulders. When you hit the Magic Carpet Ride (obvious chalked V5 lip traverse), it's just around the corner on the same boulder.

routes.description: Start seated on a slopey, left-facing diagonal rail. Move up and slightly right through a few cruxy moves until you reach a jug and easier climbing for the topout.
routes.location: One of the first few boulders at the Apron when approaching from the South.

routes.description: SDS the splitter crack through the middle of Killing Me Softly that appeared Spring 2019 courtesy of BC Hydro drilling supports into the rock.
routes.location: Gibb's Cave Area

routes.description: Find edges deep in the cave and do an awkward lying start. Traverse the rail out the roof and turn the lip without using the giant shelf out right.
routes.location: pad

routes.description: Climb Inside Out to the lip, and continue around the corner to the right. Finish with an awkward roll using good holds in the parallel cracks.
routes.location: pad

routes.description: jump to ledge do a super tough mantel to the lip
routes.location: one tier down from Ramen Raw (when you top out you are staring at RR)

routes.description: Sit down start.  Start seated and climb jutting prow.
routes.location: The Snake Pit area.

routes.description: Lip traverse from the corner to the right then mantle.
routes.location: The Jungle

routes.description: Follow the Gibbs’ Cave start rail right for two meters to sloping edges. Start here, make a tough move straight up to an uncut slot in the next rail and trend left to finish on cruxy slippers right of Gibbs’ Cave.
routes.location: Gibbs’ Cave

routes.description: Climb the arete on the W side of boulder.
routes.location: Parking lot area Outhouse boulder

routes.description: horizontal edges trending up and right
routes.location: if looking at cutting edge from the trail it is to the left on a separate boulder

routes.description: Sit down start.  Do a low sitstart with a left triangular edge and a righ arete pinch.  Climb the short arete.
routes.location: Drive By area Potato Gun boulder.

routes.description: A classic Squamish lip traverse start low and left traverse left through progressively more interesting movement and better holds, enjoy really rad moves through the unique fat brick like pinch just before mantling over the lip
routes.location: up the Apron approach trail

routes.description: Reachy.  Start with an obvious sidepull on the right.  Smear your feet and make a big span for the top.
routes.location: Drive By are Reach the Beach boulder

routes.description: Start with a sloping, triangular arete edge. Lunge to the lip and pull onto a fin.
routes.location: Apron boulders

routes.description: Slabby.  Climb the slab left of the small corner.
routes.location: The Snake Pit area.  Lizard Skull boulder.

routes.description: Start on bottom right lower rail of Gibb's Cave
routes.location: Gibb's Cave Area

routes.description: Start low rt hand on a sidepull and left of a sloping crimp. The first move is easier if your taller. Move up on good holds to slopers to the top.    Great problem.
routes.location: Pads spotter

routes.description: climbs cool arching feature left of ET and Gull Skull, start low on chalked up block and on/around the arete climb up
routes.location: left of ET, cant miss it

routes.description: Start as for Shots Fired and climb the first couple moves, but then traverse right across the face using a series of interesting quartz holds. Exit up the arete and top out at the apex.
routes.location: Shots Fired boulder

routes.description: Slabby.  Climb the slabby west face.
routes.location: Drive By area opposite Trooper Traverse

routes.description: Slabby.  Climb slabby center of NW face.
routes.location: Parking lot area.  Outhouse Boulder.

routes.description: A great steep problem involving tons of body tension on great holds.  Starts sitting in a cave on two crimps with a high foot, throws horizontally back to a rail, to a jug, then a fun sloper rail and mantle to finish.
routes.location: Park at the pullout between the Grand Wall lot and the Apron lot.  Go south on the old road two meters.  Take the first left on an obvious trail.  Follow it up and right to an electrical pole, head left into some trees, and you will see the cave of Tatonka on your left after 10 meters.
routes.protection: two pads are nice, and a spotter is appreciated on the mantle.

routes.description: Tall and spicy with the crux midway
routes.location: Gibb's Cave area

routes.description: Big moves on decent edges up a slightly overhanging wall.  The landing is a bit scary!
routes.location: As many crash pads and spotters as you can get.

routes.description: Start on a right facing jug low down in the cave (same start as DJ Pimp Daddy). From the start, pull progressively more difficult moves until either going big or finessing your way to the lip. Pull on jugs to the top.
routes.location: Low down in Gibb's Cave. Right of Gibb's Cave and left of Big Boy.

routes.fa: Jack Fieldhouse, Tyler Jordan, & Brian Goldstone
routes.description: Traverse the gorgeous curved face in either direction.
routes.location: Drive By area opposite Spring Thaw

routes.description: Climb the sharp fin.  Found this very mossy and wet on onsight attempt few months back.  Therefore gets bomb.  I've since re cleaned it so you may wish to give it a star or more.
routes.location: The Jungle.  Entrance closest to Grand Wall boulders.

routes.description: Smooth face beside the arête.
routes.location: Snake Pit
routes.protection: Boulder pad.  Good for solo sessions.

routes.description: Climb starts down and right on shield of rock to the right of the Tatonka cave matched on good crimp rail to the right of that feature. Climb through some small crimps and cool pinch to join into Tatonka, finish that problem
routes.location: Same boulder as Tatonka, head up trail at jim carrey boulder
routes.protection: pads, long traverse so more is better

description: The Apron is the low angled formation of granite that extends N. off of the Chief. There are many varied climbs on this formation from classic moderate crack climbs like St. Vitus Dance, or Diedre to runout scary slab climbs such as Unfinished Symphony, or Dancing in the Light. The granite in squamish is said by some to be better than Yosemite making it some of the best Granite in the world. The Apron is a wonderful place to climb and contains some of the best moderate routes in Squamish. The views of the sound and the surrounding mountains are spectacular. Some of the first established routes on the chief are on the Apron.
getting_there: Start at a parking lot at the intersection of Highway 99 and a Mamquam Forest Service Road. Many trails from here depending on the climb you do. The Base of the Apron is thick forest and it can be tricky to find specific climbs.

routes.description: Climb the route directly to the left of Pig Dogs on Parade. The route roughly goes up the middle of the slab (P1) and then veers back left into Granvile Street (P2). Look closely for the bolts as there aren't many. This is a pure friction climb with little to no features.   P1: Carefully make your way up the slab passing three spaced out bolts to a bolted anchor. Note that there is a huge runout between the third bolt and the anchors. It is further than it appears from the bottom.   P2: Veer left from the bolted anchor past another three spaced out bolts into the Granvile Street route. From here either continue up Granvile Street or make 3 raps down the Granvile Street anchors.   Note that there are a few variations available for P2, however the description for P2 above was the original route.
routes.location: Large slab to the right of Boom Stick Crack and Granvile Street. It is immediately above the Apron Walk off trail.

routes.description: All anchors are Fixed. mix trad and bolted route up near vertical rock with some small over hung sectionsPitch #1 5.10 Start up slab by arete until it is possible to move right into a near horizontal power layback, climb this until you gain the lip and follow the crack back left and up to the anchor.Pitch #2 5.10 continue following crack up and slightly left to two opposing pancake flakes which climb beautifully straight up, one these flakes die out climb up and right gaining a very cool exposed no hands rest near the first bolt, move directly right to a wild move to gain some more sweet pancake flakes (shorties may have to jump) climb the flakes straight up until they die out and clip the second bolt, gain the small foot ledge up and right to clip the anchors.Pitch #3 5.11 Reach up to clip a bolt to the left of the anchors, then climb down and left to gain the corner, climb this straight up till its end and clip a bolt, make some crispy/balancey slab moves past two more bolts to gain the stunning corner system climb this up to where it turns completely horizontal, make the transition and traverse left with some wicked undercling moves, follow easy terrain up and left to a tough move to gain the big tree and the tree ledge, continue straight up to anchors.Pitch #4 5.11 slightly right of the anchor boulder up to a ledge and a bolt, boulder again straight up to gain a lay back crack system which will take you to the lip of the roof, turn the lip with awesome moves, then great face climbing will take you up to a tiny ledge and the second bolt, make some hard moves to gain the third bolt and up and left to anchors.Pitch #5 5.12a climb left clip a bolt and boulder straight up to gain micro crimps then left to gain easier ground, climb straight up to a dead end at a roof, gain a crimp rail over the lip clip a bolt and traverse left on tiny holds and horrible feet (Campus anyone?) once at the end of the crimper rail make a throw for a awesome hueco and clip a bolt. continue up and left to anchorPitch #6 5.9 walk left on tiny ledge and clip and bolt then climb straight up then right following the easiest way to the anchor and top of climb! you top out right where the trail from the apron to the upper climbs i.e. buttress/ultimate everything comes close to the gully's lip. either continue up to other climbs or you can rap down the routeDescent: 4 35m raps get you the ground. off the top do a 35m rap to the top of the 4th pitch then a 35m rap to the tree ledge, walk right on the tree ledge over a cool side walk like chunk of rock to a fixed anchor by a large tree, do another 35m rap to the top of the 3rd pitch, and a final 35m rap to the ground.
routes.location: Approach as for Rock on, when at the start of rock on follow trail up gully, passing the start of the opal on your right, the climb is visible now. continue up the gully following faint trail on the opal side until you reach the base of the climb, on your right (rock on side) can't miss it.
routes.protection: You will need cams up to 4.5" with doubles of 0.75"-1". Bring 1 or 2 alpine draws 5-6 quick draws. I did not use any nuts.

routes.description: P1+2+3: The start is as for Diedre or to the right up a couple bolts. Climb the slab and then move right along the narrow ledge. Sling tree on the way by. Belay here or sling the tree and stem up onto the slab right in front of you to a tree belay on the left.   P4: Head up the slab aiming for a right facing corner past a bolt. Look for good holds above your head and have at it (crux 5.7). Ramble left up a finger crack traverse and belay at a tree.     P5: Continue up the route following the obvious line of water scoops to a little alcove and a gear belay.    P6: Surmount the slab - crux 5.7 a little freaky but super fun! Continue right along a small ripple upwards to a huge hole then you have 2 options.     Option 1 Place a cam high on the flake to create a semi toprope for the second coming across the slab and belay from a tree island below.  Option 2 continue up a corner to a huge flake and to a tree belay up and left. (If your second is confident then go for option 2 you eliminate a belay)   P7: Ramble up the water scoops (5.easy) and either a gear belay at the overlap just below a big block or do a little simul-climbing so that you can belay from behind the big block.   P8: Ramble up the final easy slab (4th class) to the tree belay at the finish. This route is 2 moderate moves then jug haul flake fest in between. Super fun though a little run out in spots.
routes.location: Standard rack to 2", extra long slings

routes.fa: J. Baldwin, J. Sinclair, P. Neilson, 1961
routes.description: To get from Broadway Ledge (where most of the lower Apron climb like Diedre finish) to the Squamish Buttress, The Ultimate Everything, or the Echelon Wall, the shortest and easiest option is this route.   The wildly thin flake is very interesting and makes the easy climbing into a bit of a unique experience.  While McLane's guidebook calls it two pitches, it's easily done in one with a 70m rope and probably a 60m (although being wrong in this case would be a shame since the crux is the very first move which makes simul-climbing unappealing).   The very first move off of Broadway Ledge is the crux and requires some faith that the flake is good, but it's not hard.
routes.location: Start a the right side of Broadway Ledge just before it starts to head downwards.  The wall is smooth and concave, but a flake provides and undercling that is sufficient to reach the top side of the same flake.   The end of this route leaves you on a trail that heads into the forest towards the Buttress and the Ultimate Everything.  It's a fifteen minute hike, so untie and coil the rope before proceeding.
routes.protection: A few cams up to 3 inches are plenty, but they are more for the comfort of the second so they don't swing rather than the leader since the flake is so thin it would be very disconcerting to fall onto them, although it would probably be fine.

routes.fa: p1,2, 4&5 partial, 7, and FCFA Kris Wild, Fraser Young, Phil Bonham, May 2020 p3, 4&5 partial, 6, Gordon Smaill & Squamish Hardcore, 1971 (Bloodlust)
routes.description: This route combines sections of older, under-appreciated climbs with new pitches to create the best protected 5.10 on the Apron. Begin 20m right of Snake at the low-point of the approach trail heading towards Diedre. 5.8, 35m Ascend the slab past several bolts and discontinuous crack features to a ledge on the right. 5.9, 30m Thin moves with close bolts leads to easy rambling and a station 10m above the large ledge. The old station out left on the ledge is the top of P1 of Dream On.5.9, 45m Step right into the thin corner and follow it all the way to the top. A few face moves to the left take you to the anchor. Many nut and small cam placements. 10b, 25m Past an old chain station at the top of the corner, and horizontally out right across the slab. You will be crossing Dancing in the Light at your 4th bolt. Continue right to the base of a crack system. (Bloodlust Direct comes straight up to this station from below)10a, 30m Up intermittent cracks until forced to step right around the arete into flakes on the sidewall of the Diedre corner. Up these for several metres, then back left past two bolts into the next crack system. You may need to give climbers on Diedre space when in the close section. Belay at the large ledge with a cedar tree. (Stepping left at the end of the initial crack to old bolts is the crux of Bloodlust, 5.11b) 5.9, 35m The splitter hands-to-fingers corner, and face crack above. Begin on the right behind the tree. 5.9, 50m Step right into a scoop, and follow the blunt arete to a station just below a ramp leading to Broadway ledgeDescent: Probably wise to keep the rope on to get up onto Broadway, then down right to the top of Diedre. 40m 4th class. Standard Apron descent to the South.
routes.location: Approach via the regular Apron approach trail for the Central Apron routes. 30m after climbing the V-groove past the start of Snake, the route begins at the low-point of the trail, before it goes up to Diedre, Banana Peel, etc.
routes.protection: "Standard" trad rack, nuts and cams to 3" (7.5cm), with doubles of 3/8"-1.5" cams (1-4cm). Optional use of more small cams for P3 only.

routes.description: A Lower Apron route. Might be the easiest way to actually find the base of Diedre, Banana Peel, Over the Rainbow, etc. A fairly sustained slab route and a logical link-up contender for Over the Rainbow.
routes.location: Climbs the Lower Apron, from the ground to the base of all the South Apron Routes. From the carpark, walk South past the outhouse for maybe a minute, you should see two (as of 2011) scrubbed bolt-lines, you're going to the second one. "The start of the route is marked by a slanting crack with a cedar near the base" - Marc Bourdon, Squamish Select. At the second belay, go right. The left path is an 11a variation: "Sorry, Joe".
routes.protection: Mixed, mainly bolts but some medium cams are nice. Nuts unecessary.

routes.description: The start of this climb shares the same two pitches as St. Vitus Dance.Pitch 1. A committing move gets you off the ground.  Work your way up pulling on roots and using large cracks.  Larger cams are a good idea for the last section of this pitch if you're not that comfortable with crack climbing yet.  5.8(?)Pitch 2.  Step out a few feet left of the tree stump and onto the face, using multiple cracks and twin finger cracks to work your way up to a bolted anchor on the right. 5.7(?)Pitch 3. Step back out onto the face an work your way around a tree and up two stellar cracks that run side by side.  When nearing the the end of the cracks, start looking left for the thin finger crack and small ledge just below.  This is where you want to set up your belay.  A second option is to set up the belay on the parallel cracks just to the right of the finger crack and save your small gear for pitch 4. 5.6(?)Pitch 4.  Fun and easy finger crack that takes gear really good.  Follow this crack up and end up on a ramp on the left and build your anchor here. 5.8Pitch 5. Low angle slab. Start off the ramp going up and right.  Work your way to a crack to plug some gear, then head straight up to the trees.  People tend to want to head right for some reason. Don't do that. 5-Descent:Scramble to the top of Broadway ledge, or climb Memorial Crack (5.9), then walk down, or rappel from the tree'd ledge before Memorial Ledge. Find the brown rap anchors on the climbers left side of the ledge between the two down slab trees.R1: Large chain from bolts (15m)R2: Chain anchor station part way down the wall on a ledge (35m)R2.5: If have a 60, there is a single bolt with a locker to the right for the remaining 5mR3: Large chain anchor off tree (28m)R4: Bolted anchor (25m)
routes.location: This climb starts on Baseline Ledge on the north Buttress of the Apron.
routes.protection: Gear to 4", doubles for trad anchors at belays.

routes.fa: Kris Wild, Adrian Jones, Tavis Thomson
routes.description: One way to get to Baseline Ledge and the start of Calculus Crack is to climb the first two pitches of St. Vitus' Dance. This is an alternative method that provides a couple of fun pitches.   Pitch 1 (5.9): Move up to the bolt and climb past it to get on to the slab to its right. Move a few feet to the right to get to a left-facing dihedral. Make a tricky move to get into the corner and climb it until some flakes are encountered (maybe 40 or 50 feet). Climb the flakes but trend to the right to a sloping ledge with several cracks above it. Make a gear belay here.   (This pitch is also the start for Start from Scratch; if you continue up the corner instead of stepping right, you'd be on that route.)   Pitch 2 (5.8): climb a steep hand crack, move slightly left on cracks, and climb a face with intermittent cracks and pods until you can see a two-bolt anchor. Traverse a few feet to the right to that anchor. Verbal communication with your second will be difficult from the top of the second pitch because of road noise and your second being out of sight.   You're now at the base of Calculus Crack.   (The route name and first ascent information was obtained from "Squamish Select" by Marc Bourdon.)
routes.location: The start of this is a bit to the left and uphill from the start of St. Vitus' Dance. Look carefully for a bolt in a shallow left-facing corner about ten feet off the ground; that's the start.
routes.protection: Same rack as for Calculus Crack. Mostly finger-sized gear for the corner on pitch one and finger- and hand-sized gear for the second pitch.

routes.description: Left leaning and thin looking finger crack. kind of hidden behind tress. Four (4) in situ pitons.
routes.location: Go up the east-most Apron descent trail from the Apron connector. When you hit the wall follow it east. There's a fixed rope that helps getting to the base of the climb.

routes.description: A name that's clever and descriptive.  This climb requires honed Squamish friction technique, as well as, to a lesser degree, some crack proficiency.  Fortunately, there's an alternate start to the first pitch that brings the entire route down to a slightly sandbagged 10b.  This climb makes an good alternate approach to St. Vitus Dance or Vector.   The first 40 feet of the first pitch are the business here -- hard friction, and fairly well bolted.  The 10b alternate start joins once the crux start is done, it the climbing is still tenuous.  There are bolts, but it's not a sport climb.  The last 20 feet of the first pitch consists of a slippery crack to an obvious bolted  belay below and overlap.   The second pitch (5.10b) traverses left under the overlap and then up into a corner that uses a combination of friction and small holds on the right wall, finger-tips in the crack and the occasional stem on he right wall.  A relatively short pitch, but fun.   The third pitch (5.9) takes you to the little patch of forest that marks the start of St. Vitus Dance, Calculus Crack and Vector.
routes.location: This climb has what must be the shortest approach to any Apron climb from the main Apron parking lot.  Head up the forest service road and take the very first trail that heads up and right.  It's only a few steps up the road from the lot.  At a T-juntion go right.  The trail will dead end in a clearing in front of a slab with two scrubbed lines.  The left line is Crack Slabbeth, the right is Evergreen State.  The 10b alternate start is back left and up some wild tree routes to a comfy belay on a log.
routes.protection: The first pitch is mostly bolted, but as with most slabs, the distance between bolts keeps it very exciting.  The 10b start has bigger distances between the bolts than the 11c.   The second pitch goes on few finger sized nuts and cams, but a larger cam (#3 or #3.5 camalot) under the overlap will protect the moves off the belay.

routes.fa: Numerous, FFA Marc Bourdon, Jay Audenart, 2001
routes.description: This route is a stellar way to climb a ton of hard friction slab without frazzling your nerves with mind-frying runouts. It's not always a sport climb and there are certainly places where a fall would be undesirable, but it's better protected than many of the other Apron slabs: no three bolt .10c pitches here. Most of the pitches are 5.11 and your feet and toes will remember the continuous nature of the climbing for at least a few days afterwards. The .12d is completely optional as it's a short, steep boulder problem you can easily pull through.P1 (.11b): Right off the bat, 'warm up' on a very thin mossy slab that climbs out of the forest above a downed tree. You can start from under/behind the tree but the slab is pretty dirty lower down. I started from a ledge a little higher. As the select book states, it is a rather cruel warmup.P2 (.10b): Much easier and shorter slab. Belay amongst trees on the ledge.P3 (.10d): Climb the well-protected slab directly above. 50m long, this pitch feels harder than some of the later .11a pitches. Very sustained. Ends just below Snake.P4 (.11a): Cross Snake and angle right. Slightly thinner at one point but much shorter than the previous pitch.P5 (.11d): The business. Move right, then up until you encounter a steepening, thin section. Turn on the magic footwork switch, weld your feet to some miniscule features and hope for the best. Doesn't ease up much until you're clipping the anchor.P6 (.11a): The guide says .11b; feels more like .10c-.11a at most, maybe because it's much, much easier than the previous pitch.P7 (.11a): Feet hurting yet? Another thin, low-angle slab leads up to a belay below a steeper section of slab.P8 (.11b or c?): The guide bills this as another non-descript .11a but I found it to be a major 'sting in the tail'. A bleak bulge of 5.11 glacier glass in the middle of the pitch with a little too much sun on it felt much, much harder than all but the crux slab pitch. Perhaps this is instead the '.11b with a bulge' described as P6 or perhaps my feet were just tired by this point.P9 (.12d or .9 A0): Glassy and beautiful glacier polish leads to the short, steep headwall. Checking out the moves briefly seemed to put the section at about V6 or so. Bolts are right in your face, so go for it! Dirt on the slab above made the subsequent easier climbing a bit scarier.P10 (.10a): I think I may have combined this with P9 but I can't recall. In any case, the climbing remains easier but becomes more and more dirty. If I'd had a brush, 10 minutes would have been enough to create an improved path through the thickening murk.
routes.location: Approach as for Diedre but before the trail goes up to the slippery V-groove, head left on another fork. Almost right away, you'll see the big downed tree against the wall. Start right off the ground behind/on top of the tree and fight through moss for two or three bolts, or scramble up a little on the left and step onto the slab there. Rapping the route is an option but P3 is 50m and trailing a second rope would make the climbing less enjoyable. If completing the route, walk off Broadway Ledge as for other Apron routes.
routes.protection: Bolts. The guidebook says P3 has 11 so you could get away with, say, 12 quickdraws including some slings for meandering around. The runouts are pretty tame although a few pitches have bits of necky climbing here and there, especially right off the belays. I brought some small cams but didn't use a single one save for a green Camalot as a belay piece since I started P1 a little ways off the ground to miss the grunge. All belays are bolted. Supportive footwear recommended.

routes.description: Crux at 3rd bolt where  slab angle increases.
routes.location: First left off of main trail past bathroom. There are two bolt lines to your right upon intersecting the apron.  Mighty Mouse is the left one.
routes.protection: 5 or 6 bolts.  2 bolt anchor, no rap rings.  You could traverse to Mickey Mouse rap anchor, or head up 20-30 feet to Rambles P2 anchor to rap.

routes.description: Long run-out route to the right of A Question of Balance.  The first pitch, while not too hard, has few bolts.  The second pitch is cruxy but better protected.  The third pitch is 5.4 slab (aka walking) to a tree anchor.
routes.location: Farthest right route on the Granville St. slab.  Climb a route to Broadway Ledge to get there.  Descend by rappelling (2 ropes) or by using the Memorial Ledge/South Gully rappel route.

routes.description: This is an inspiring line directly up the right edge of the Central Apron.  Prepare for great slab climbing, with the easier sections being somewhat runout.   P1 (10c):  From the Snake start go out right and wander up the right hand side of the slab.  40m, 4 bolts  P2 (10a): Move right and plug a .75 camalot into the corner and pull out onto the slab.  Put your head down and keep your faith in friction.  35m, 3 bolts + cam.  P3 (10b): More slab climbing straight up...not over-bolted. 30m, 3 bolts  P4 (11a): The slab steepens and the climbing turns more to 'front-pointing' than smearing.  Veer slightly left then back right to a scoop with two bolts, one old one new.  The bolts are more closely spaced on this pitch. 30m, 7bolts.  P5 (10d):  More of the same (this pitch can be linked with P4 if you feel like you need the challenge). 12m, 2 bolts.  P6 (11b):  Move up to the small seam and tickle in some small gear if you can find it - I didn't.  Pull a mantle on decent holds and clip a 'thank-god' bolt.  The crux is moving left and up on tiny crystals. 25m, 4 bolts.  P7 (5.9):  The final pitch feels like a cake-walk after the first 6, but it still has some real climbing.  32m, 3 bolts.   I debated whether to call this PG13 or R but went with the former. If anyone else who has climbed it feels otherwise I can change.
routes.location: Scramble up the trail as per Snake but where that route starts, take the right hand side of the slab.  Descend as per any other Apron route
routes.protection: Take about 8-10 draws and a .75 camalot for the start of P2.  In theory, a #5 RP will protect the start of the crux pitch but I couldn't find the slot.  It's a tricky place to try fishing in gear as you are a bit run-out and not at a great stance....probably better to just pull the move (maybe 10a/b) and clip the bolt.

routes.description: Dessert Dike a convenient finish for the climbs ending on the left side of the Apron - we did it after finishing Snake.  You can climb this route as an alternative to thrashing up the gully to reach the Broadway descent.   The climbing follows a small dike, and is somewhat spicy for the grade. I wouldn't call it runout (except the first 30-40 feet), but I also wouldn't call it closely bolted.   Pad up the slab (5.9ish) to reach the dike and then follow it upwards.  Your first piece is about 30-40 feet up - but the climbing is pretty easy.  I got a dodgy green camalot (or a manky nut, your choice). I bet a pick tricam would work perfecty here.  One more move up and then a bomber small nut can be placed out left.  Continue upwards to the first bolt.   Three more bolts protect thin face climbing to the top.
routes.location: Top of the Apron, right of the gully leading to Memorial Ledge/Broadway.
routes.protection: I placed a green camalot, small nut, and yellow mastercam.  Then three bolts to the top.

routes.description: The first pitch isn't anything to write home about, but it gets you to the second, which is a good and varied right-facing slab and thin-fingers affair.   P1. Climb the jagged crack, cleaning with a nut tool will probably be needed.   P2. Pull around the bulge to the right and follow the crack until you reach Broadway Ledge.  The climbing is fairly straightforward and sustained at 5.9 with good protection until you reach a obvious crux section that will require good slab footwork as your pro moves below your feet.  The good news is that the crux ends with a good hold and good protection opportunities.
routes.location: There is a region of low-angle slabs below Broadway Ledge that you reach from routes such as St. Vitus Dance and Snake.  Near the right side of this area is the jagged crack of Pitch 1 that leads to ledge about forty feet up that had a foot diameter pine tree and some large blocks above.   Alternatively, continue Edge Of Anxiety until it joins near the start of P2.
routes.protection: Lots of small cams and wires.

routes.description: Diedre climbs a small right facing dihedral on the right side of the central slab.  Over 100m of consistent laybacking on nicely textured rock make this climb very popular; arrive early or be prepared to join a line.   P1.  Begin up a low-angle slab to a horizontal break with a tree.  Make a few face moves to a left-angling crack system and follow it up before making a slightly downward traverse across a small face as the cracks end.  Follow a second crack system to an anchor on a ledge.  5.7, 55m.   P2.  Climb a short distance above the ledge and make a slabby traverse across the face to the left.  This unprotected pitch is hardest at the beginning, then eases before reaching an anchor on a good ledge.  5.6, 15 m.   P3.  Layback and smear your way up the corner, making a move over a small step partway up.  End  at a semi-hanging belay.  5.8, 45 m.   P4.  Continue up the obvious corner.  Ignore the incipient calf cramp.  5.8, 50m.   P5.  The climbing eases somewhat as the angle of the dihedral lessens.  Belay at a nice ledge. 5.7,  50 m.   P6.  The crack in the dihedral becomes a small seam and dissappears just as the angle of the wall becomes most forgiving.  Smear and stem your way up to Broadway, overcoming a tricky bulge onto the ledge.  The gear on this pitch is notably small and fairly run-out.  The final move is easy to protect.  5.8, 40m.
routes.location: Follow the trail from the parking lot past the toilet.  Head left until reaching a 3rd class gully heading up and right.  Climb the gully, then continue up the subsequent ledge system to the right, climbing a 3rd class step to a final ledge system which leads up and right to the low angle slabs of the south apron.   To descend:  Continue up the Chief to more adventure, traverse Broadway ledge to the south to walk off, take the 3rd class slab descent, or, in a fix, rap the route (double ropes required).
routes.protection: Gear to 2", emphasizing stoppers and small cams.  Bring nothing larger than a #2 camalot.  If you want to sew the route up, doubles of small to mid-size stoppers and a few doubles of cams below 0.75 will serve you well.  A pink tri-cam works well in a flaring scar on the final pitch.  All belays are bolted.

routes.description: This route on the apron is a link-up of the best pitches of two routes: Unfinished Symphony and Dream On. 3 pitches of 5.10 slab lead up to a 5.10b traverse and then a 2 pitch shallow corner (10d) finishing with a 5.11b slab crux pitch. The route is runout in places but generally well protected. Like a number of other routes on the apron, there are a few rusty quarter-inch bolts that add some spice to the route.
routes.location: A handful of cams up to # 2 Camalot and 8 draws. Double up on small cams  (blue to yellow Aliens) and nuts for shallow pin scars in the 10d corners.

routes.fa: Robin Barley, plus the existing FAs
routes.description: This is a link up of Unfinished Symphony, Anxiety State and  Diamondback.  The only new climbing on this route is the traverse left from Unfinished Symphony.  This traverse is found by climbing to the first bolt on the second 10d pitch of that route, clipping it and then downclimbing until you can cross the vertical wall that divides the tiers of slab.  Depending on where you start moving left, it may be very difficult without employing some tension from the rope.  The rest of the traverse is probably 5.9+ and finishes with the bolt you clipped about 20 feet horizontally to your right!  Despite that, it might be wise to have the weaker climber in the party, if it's an issue, lead the traverse since seconding it leaves you even more exposed at the moment you unclip the bolt (you can, however, place some cams below the bolt to protect your downclimb).
routes.location: Starts on Unfinished Symphony (which itself starts on  Snake).

routes.description: A single pitch of slab climbing that gradually increases in difficulty to a distinct crux at a steepening bulge near the fourth bolt, as the holds get smaller and further apart. Joins Dessert Dyke at the last bolt
routes.location: Just right of Dessert Dyke on the walk off ledges at the top of Snake/St Vitus
routes.protection: Five bolts. Bolted anchors on top (the Snake walkoff ledge). Your second will probably follow you up and you'll walk off from the top.

routes.description: If Boomstick Crack is crowded, or you're trying to pass a party, this is a good option to get from Broadway Ledge up to Squamish Buttress.   P1. Start just right on Boomstick.  Place a ~1 in cam in the undercling, reach really high, and crank a fun move right off the ledge.  Easier if you're tall. Face climb up and right past a bolt to the obvious tree and crack.  Climb crack past a few anchor stations (this is a popular rappel route).  Finish where the crack peters out near and belay at the last large tree.  Almost 200 feet long.   P2. Face climb straight up, then a little left, past a bolt at 5.8.  Easier climbing all the way up the forest and a huge ledge.  Belay from a tree.  About 180 feet.
routes.location: Broadway Ledge, on the right side, where the trees peter out. Just right of Boomstick, the obvious huge flake that goes sharply left and up.
routes.protection: A couple bolts, a few pieces of gear, but not much needed.  Mostly trivial climbing.

routes.description: The Great Arch is one of squamish's very best difficult stemming corners.  With no moves being too difficult, it will stay on you till the VERY end and leave you wondering why your legs still hurt 3 days later.  The guidebook gives a 13a rating but locals believe it to be more in the 12+ range.  A fantastic route.
routes.location: The Great Arch is located just left of the second pitch of Rock On.  It is accessed via the top of pitch one from rock on or a dirty 4th class low 5th pitch lookers left of the climb.
routes.protection: It was originally climbed with fixed pins, then retro bolted after the removal of the pins.  The climb has been done (twice) by my knowledge on gear (I watched my partner send skipping the bolts and placing 25 pieces.)  However, if you don't have the time to figure out the gear and are less inclined for that challenge, there are 8 bolts.  The climb still requires a set of micro nuts, 1 purple tcu, 2 blue tcu's, 2 yellow tcu's, 2 purple camalots, and one each from green camalot to gold.  An all gear ascent will require the full gamet including brass nuts, 000 c3s etc.

routes.description: From Lower Baseline Ledge.  Follow the spitter hand crack right of pitch two of South Arete/Calculus Crack.  Some delicate face moves at the bulge defines the crux.
routes.location: From baseline ledge it’s The crack right of the standard pitch for Calculus Crack, and left of St. Bernard.

routes.description: A fun little route with an exciting crux for both leader and follower.   Climb the crack to the flake, at the top of the flake clip a bolt then traverse left to a seam and follow it to Memorial Ledge.
routes.location: Directly above the top of Vector, Vitus, and Calculus, is a VERY obvious flake leading to Memorial Ledge. Start in the gully below the flake at a crack system.

routes.description: New beginner-friendly 5.9 starting just to the left of Calculus Direct. Short, well-protected pitches with short cruxes and all bolted anchors. North-facing and great for hot days - you can make it to the top of the Apron and barely see the sun at all.(Pitch lengths are all estimated)P1 (5.9, ~10m, 2 bolts) Start up a fixed line to a small platform with a bolt just above your head. Clip it and pull onto the face. Kind of odd and awkward climbing, clip another bolt and you're done.There is a 10a direct start that looks thin and adds another 10m or so of climbing to this pitch by avoiding the fixed line and climbing directly up to the first bolt.P2 (5.9, ~35m) Easy climbing to a short roof below a flake, then wider climbing at a low angle - hands, fists and a few stacks. You could place a #5 if you were so inclined, but we found a single #3 and single #4 were fine for this pitch.P3 (5.7, ~35m) Climbs fast, similar to P5 of Calculus Crack in nature.P4 (5.7, ~40m) Beautiful, clean climbing. You can choose to climb the hands splitter or the hands corner. Easy until the top, where it steepens slightly.P5 (5.easy, ~25m) Easy climbing, again choose between a face crack or a corner crack.P6 (5.7, ~35m) Layback up a handcrack to an interesting set of roof moves, traversing underneath a roof. Fun.P7 (5.8, ~45m, 4 bolts) Finesse up a thin left-leaning crack. Slightly awkward to place gear - bolts help protect you through the thin sections. This pitch will take you to the top of Calculus & St. Vitus - you can sling a tree to belay, or continue up to the belay bolts before the gulley next to Karen's Math that takes you to the rest of Broadway Ledge.If you want you can walk off at this point, or rappel Bad Pants Party into the South Gulley.P8 - (5.7) Continue up easy, low angle crack climbing through some interesting features.P9 - (5.8) Up a finger crack, then continue more vertically through some challenging ground, avoiding Memorial Crack. I found this pitch more challenging than the first two.
