Finesse your way up to some horizontal breaks then go straight left on the finger tip traverse with no gear. Don't fall, then get some gear in and climb the amazingly thin and hollow flake - I am 190lbs and it has held me a half a dozen times so pull away! Clip a bolt and do a weird mystery slab move and traverse back right to the corner, and climb it to the comfy belay ledge. Going straight up is the Shadow variation, 12-, RPs.p7. 10+ 70'. All fixed pins and bolts, traverses right a bunch, short crux.p8. 11+ 80'. THE sting in the tail. Hard and spicey. Pull a hard slab/mantel move off the belay, go to the head wall and traverse left to the new free bolt. Clip it and balance your way up the wall to grab the ledge. Hand traverse till you get to the fixed knifeblade tips traverse and punch it. Pull on to an easy ledge and don't slip on the pine needles. Watch for heinous rope drag and belay in the trees.You can continue straight up from here on the Roman Chimneys or walk off belly good ledge.
routes.location: Continue past the base of the Grand Wall as for Seasoned in the Sun.  Keep going for about 2 minutes until you see the bushy ramp that cuts back right and up via a few fixed lines to the obvious STEEP and clean U-wall.  A fixed line is in place for the exposed traverse to the start.  A belay seat is a good idea for P1 and P2 (top of) belays.
routes.protection: 2 sets of gear from micro to Green camalot.  maybe one or two extra finger pieces.  One each Red, gold, blue and big gray camalot.  RPS and nuts, slings and draws.  All anchors are bolted, and retreat would be easy from any pitch with 2 ropes through the top of pitch 6.

routes.description: A four-pitch bolt-protected face climb up a basalt dyke. Crux is at the final bolt on the final pitch. Juggy climbing or moderate difficulty in high exposure at the top of the Grand Wall. If finishing the Grand Wall, the Upper Black Dyke is the easiest way to the top of the wall. The rock is not as solid as granite but good enough.
routes.location: The climb begins on Bellygood Ledge, which can be reached by climbing The Grand Wall, Milk Road, Freeway, Europa, or any other route on the Grand Wall, Dihedrals, or Tantalus Wall. Alternatively, one can approach via the backside trail then follow the Bellygood trail (tricky to find the turn-off).    Descent: walk down the backside trail.
routes.protection: draws. optional single of cams (fingers to tight hands).

routes.fa: Bob Milward, Jim Campbell Oct '84. FFA p3 Scott Young '85. FCA / FFA P5&6 John Rosholt, Peder Ourom '96
routes.description: Wall of Attrition is called route #26 on the top #50 chief routes list. For us, it was pretty dirty with a decent amount of loose rock, vegetation and required gardening on lead. All in all, I don't really recommend the route... or at least, do the top 25 first and come over here if you're really itching for something new.   P1 (5.10-): Go straight left on the ledge about 25 feet to the tight dihedral with a continuous crack. Beware the long, skinny flake in the corner at the start, it is not really in there (but you use it anyways). Continue straight up and maybe slightly right through the left end of the roof bands on some ok gear then up a little more to a bolted anchor. (Note: about half way up the pitch, there is a flake that is easy to traverse out left to a ledge. I went over there and it was all mossy and seemed off route).   P2 (5.11b): The money pitch. Climb seams past 4 or 5 fixed pins to a series of three stacked flakes in the corner that you can either jam or lieback. The seam was rather dirty and grassy so you might want to have your nut tool ready to clean on lead. Finish at a bolted anchor. Recommend to keep going and link to the next anchor as it would be an uncomfortable belay.   P3 (5.10-): Continue up and right to another bolted belay on a ledge at the base of the main dihedral #3 or #4 to back up since bolts are rusty).   P4 (5.10): The dihedral pitch. Start out on a 15 section of wide crack. A #4 might fit but we didnt take one. You can place a #3 deeper in one spot or just punch it to the ledge that starts the main dihedral. Climb this left leaning to right leaning dihedral past bushes and loose chockstones. Be prepared to clean on lead and be careful not to dislodge the loose blocks. Topo shows bolt or FP for traverse left at the end but I didnt see anything. Grey or yellow alien protects the traverse well. End at bolted belay.   (From here, the old 2001 McClane book shows the last two pitches as mid 5.10 but I had a different experience, which I will write up here since I spent plenty of time unsuccessfully looking for the documented line).   P5 (10+ / 11-): Go up and left around the corner from the belay. Punch it through dirty, loose stuff. Place a couple marginal pieces. Pull a hard move to claw some dirt until you can grab the tree root (if you're tall you might not have to jump to it). Yard on this and tie it off, continuing to a really chossy ledge.  I got lost here but I really think you just want to go straight left at this ledge because there is a three bolt anchor over there. I tried to go up and right (as topo indicated) and ended up on a poorly protected slab which I tried to start 4 times before backing off. Then I tried going far right on the ledge, which went nowhere, then finally back left and found that anchor. Book says bold 10c. Id say harder than that, chossy and a potentially bad fall on the hard move.   P6 (5.11- PG13):  Looking up and slightly right from the bolted belay you will see 2 right angling hand cracks (slung horn with fixed biner on top) and a right angling flake just right of these. Choose one (I took the left crack) and climb past the pinnacle, clipping the fixed sling up and left into a dihedral. I thought this dihedral was full-on. Not great gear and really thin, I ended up aiding it using four micro brass offset nuts in little crystals (including the tiny black one) and it still felt sketch. Climb (or aid) this dihedral then pull some thin flake/sport moves up and right to reach the far left end of the dance platform behind some massive boulders. Use the rope to extend the anchor all the way back to a tree (or further to a bolted anchor) and a #1 & #2 behind a chocktone up there and then just use the fixed cordalette as a directional.    To get off, traverse right behind the huge boulders to the bolted anchor. Walk the bellygood style ledge to 4th class that takes you up to the roman chimneys start. You can rap from this tree back down to the the far left side of bellygood and escape, or link into upper black dyke or some other route.
routes.location: Just left of University Wall, starting from the U Wall approach ledge. All of this is about a 5 minute walk left/uphill from the grand wall scramble start. The approach ledge is basically right above Seasoned in the Sun.   To approach, go up and right on the U Wall approach ledge almost to the end (where U Wall starts). Then scramble up steep 4th class gully past bushes and use an old, ratty fixed rope to go up and left to another little ledge with a slung tree. Belay here to start the climb.
routes.protection: Double rack from blue alien to #3 camalot, optional #4 camalot but not necessary (you can also get by with just 1x #3). Full set of nuts (I use offsets, including micro brass hb offsets and I really needed them for the end).

description: As with the Grand Wall Area, the Grand Wall Base Area faces west, but as many of the routes are shorter, there is a lot more shade from the forest.  This area runs from the Dihedrals area in the south to the University Wall are in the north.   The routes tend to be steep slab/face and beautiful cracks.   Helmets are highly recommended as the face above holds popular routes and trails.  Stuff does come down somewhat regularly.
getting_there: See the Grand Wall Area description for the most direct approach.  The area can also be approached by walking along the trail that follows the base of the Chief from the Campground in the south to the Apron in the north.

routes.description: Scramble up the Uwall ramp.   P1. From the Uwall approach ramp, get to the right side, clip the bolt and start left on ledges then up the face past bolts and maybe gear (11a).    P2. Up and left past 5 bolts to a stance and a belay station (5.10).   From here I think you can continue up into an 11b or A0 pitch up a sustained groove to another anchor (this is Never Were Warriors).   Two raps back to the ground. More if you continue up Never Were Warriors. You can also rap over to the Kneewrecker Chimney and/or the 10c pitch of Ghostdancing on the way down.
routes.location: Scramble up the U Wall access ramp a little ways. Ends up being pretty much straight above Seasoned in the Sun. The climb starts by taking bolts up and left off of the ledge.
routes.protection: Bolts plus medium sized cams and nuts.

routes.description: The crux is definitely the first pitch - very sustained laybacking with delicate smearing. The higher you climb, the thinner it gets. Not super technical but sustained and pumpy.    The second pitch starts with thin laybacking, but after pulling around an a little roof/corner feature, you'll zig-zag up an easy (5.5 or so) off-width crack before finishing on another sweet ledge (and the first pitch of Mercy Me).
routes.location: Gear (and rock) are impeccable.    Pitch One: One fixed piece about 20 feet up the first pitch.  Bolted belays; bring two ropes for the rap.   Medium rack, a few small TCU's, and at least two 3.5 to 4 inch pieces for the wide stuff up top.

routes.fa: P. Croft, R. Suddaby, T. Knight
routes.description: This is a great climb among the great climbs along the base of the Chief.  This ones starts easier than some, but it turns into a classic fingers and tight hands crack.  At the little roof the crack becomes a lot more consistent and tougher, but the locks are great, considerably better than Seasoned in the Sun.
routes.location: This climb is at the far right side of the Chief Base, just about below the Dihedrals area.  The area is fairly distinct for being in a pleasant hollow with only one other route nearby (Rutabega).  This climb crosses the one-foot overlap at its apex.
routes.protection: This climb will take plenty of medium to large stoppers as well as doubles or triples of the finger and tight hand sized cams.  The largest piece you could place would be a #1 camalot at the overlap, but there are many alternatives.  There is one very old bolt near the top and then a good two bolt anchor with chains.   NOTE: with a 70m rope you can get down, but you have to be careful to take advantage of the base sloping up to the left and rope stretch.  With anything shorter, you'll need to use two ropes to get down.  Alternatively, the leader can top belay (on a very nice ledge) and the second can bring up the second rope.   If you're SUPER careful, you can rap with a single 60m rope if you land to the left, where the ground slopes upward.  Use knots!

routes.fa: 1975: Eric Weinstein and Dave Nicol for the route as described, original FA by Jim Sinclair and Jim Baldwin in 1960
routes.description: This is a probably a Squamish top-ten short route on most people's lists.   Its two pitches are themselves reasonably short, but it's often done as a single long pitch (probably not possible with a 50m rope, but 60 is fine).  You can rap twice or bring a second rope and do one long rappel.   The crux comes shortly after the first belay station and requires careful smearing while reaching between small but good finger locks.
routes.location: This is the first distinct crack right of the Peasant's Route dihedral, which is right of the Apron Strings dihedral system.  It looks short from below, but don't be fooled.
routes.protection: Excellent the entire way.  Primarily small nuts and small cams up to tight hands.  Take lots of them, especially the nuts, and especially if you're going to link the two pitches.  You probably won't need a hand-sized piece until the final fifteen feet, by which time the difficulty has eased somewhat.

routes.fa: Jim Baldwin, Ed Cooper, June, 1961. FFA: Dan Tate, 1968
routes.description: Follow clean cracks and features up the interface between the clean slab of the lower Grand Wall, and the major flake/ledge features on the left. This is mostly comprised of a major right-facing corner/flake system and has a prominent chimney 1/3 of the way up.   This pitch is sustained and harder than it looks, involving physical climbing of many sorts (chimney, wide crack, laybacking).The top of the pitch puts you at the base of P2 of Apron Strings (moving left) or P1 of Cruel Shoes (moving right).
routes.location: From the base of the Grand Wall, this climb is located left of the left-facing corner of The Peasants Route, and just right of the thin layback crack "Apron Strings".
routes.protection: Double set of cams to 3" and a set of nuts.

routes.description: Fun new addition to the Grand Wall Base area.    P1 tackles a typical Squamish finger crack corner.  The bottom was quite wet, even after a dry spell... but it was easy enough to pull through on a piece of gear to bypass the wet spot.  End at a bolted anchor above the alcove.   P2 The business.  Work into the arch and place your #4 in the first wide pod.  Good feet keep appearing, and when they start to vanish the crack gets good in the corner.  Good gear throughout.  The crux is probably the last 15 feet, and the two bolts take the edge off.   Clip the anchor and have your partner lower you to the anchor 60' below (about the same height as your belayer)... much better stance there!   Topo available here:  jeremyfrimer.com/uploads/2/…
routes.location: Head climber's right from the base of Exasperator up the short hill.  At the top of the hill look for a right facing corner that leads to a beautiful arch.  Can't miss it.
routes.protection: Double rack small nuts to #3 camalot plus one #4 camalot.

routes.description: A good long forgotten route. The first pitch was cleaned up for Flex Capacitor, the second pitch needs a makeover.The first pitch is a sustained 5.9 fingers layback that seems to always surprise the unsuspecting leaders I see get on it.When you reach the bolted anchor you traverse left ( north ) around trees and from a ledge around the corner go up a right facing corner.There are loose holds, lots of moss and lichen and some fun climbing.I found this pitch to be more relaxed with a few moves of 5.9.Hangup is a 5.9 variation that starts up the first pitch. About 3/4 the way up there is a groove leading left where the other two routes continue with the steep layback on the right and up to the bolted anchor. Hangup traverses about 10 meters up and left, and then down about 8 meters crossing Moving to Montana. It meets up with Peasants route.
routes.location: same start as Flex Capacitor, up the hill going south along the base from Exasperator. The north side right facing corner of a large slab.
routes.protection: Standard rack up to #3 with plenty of finger size cams for 1st pitch.  1st anchor is a good bolted anchor.  2nd pitch anchor does not really exist, it was a very faded series of slings knotted behind a flake with a nut that was very poorly placed. There are some trees near this that would be better if you brought sling material . If someone wants to add a bolted anchor that would be awesome.

routes.description: In my opinion somewhat of a forgotten classic. The first two pitches of climbing tackle many varied cruxes. Your prize for questing up the delightful flakes and slabs of the lower pitches is the mellower but super classic third pitch corner.   P1) Start off of the large pancake flake leaning against the wall. Climb up, clip a bolt, and then pull the route's first crux, a burly and perplexing slab overlap. After clipping more bolts traverse right to a large layback flake. Ascend this flake placing gear until you reach a bolt, and pull some hard face/arete moves. Easier climbing leads to a bolted belay. 5.11b   P2) Easy but interesting slab moves lead to a bolt and a good stance before the route's technical crux, a thin techy slab problem. Pull the crux and then traverse up and left into a corner on easy but runout terrain. The bolt protected corner provides interesting arete/corner moves. Bolted anchor. 5.11c   P3) Ascend the beautiful right-facing layback corner, eventually exiting left up a system of cracks. Bolted belay. 5.10c   Three double rope raps down the route will reach the ground.
routes.location: Uphill from seasoned in the sun, starting off of a very distinct pancake flake.
routes.protection: Doubles to #2 Camalot, stoppers, quickdraws, two ropes recommended for the rappels.

routes.description: A full on, classic-quality, right angling off fingers to thin fingers dihedral past a ledge. Lieback you way up this low angle beauty then make some face moves left to the anchor after clipping the bolt on the face. Don't go too high at the bolt or youhave to reverse it and start the traverse all over again. The book calls this pitch 10b.   Worth noting that more bolts continue above the anchor. I think this continues into Never Never Land (7p 12a).
routes.location: Left of Seasoned in the Sun, where the main path curves left and away from the wall into the wood, stay on a faint trail right at the base of the wall and keep going uphill. You will know when you see it. Splitter off fingers on a low angle slab looking right at you. All in all just a few hunder meters uphill from Seasoned.
routes.protection: Doubles of green alien (blue tcu) to .75 camalot. Single #1 and #2 camalot. You could get by with just one green alien too. Like lots of Squamish, you could use 3 or 4 in the off fingers size. I usually roll with doubles of both grey and red alien. Bolt at the top. Two bolt anchor.

routes.fa: Peter Croft, Randy Atkinson, Joe Buszowski
routes.description: Thin crack with a low crux.  The feet are surprisingly good and the finger jams are reasonable (and continually get better).
routes.location: Between teenage wasteland and commando crack.  More broadly, between exasperator and flex capacitor.
routes.protection: Micro nuts at the bottom, RPs are nice.  A few tiny cams.  After the crack widens the climbing is quite easy, but having a .75,1 and 2 will be useful.

routes.fa: P1: Jim Sinclair, Dave Harris, (Eric Lance, Alex Bertulis) Sept. 1967.  P2: Dean Hart, Jim Sinclair  July 1969
routes.description: Merci Me is a fun face route that continues for two more pitches where Apron Strings ends.  It's pretty runout (there are only eight bolts total for both pitches combined) but the climbing isn't that hard and most leaders that can climb Apron Strings should be fine.
routes.location: Merci Me starts where Apron Strings ends.  Two double rope rappels down the same route or using the anchor at the top of pitch one for Grey Matter will get you to the Flake Trail (I think one 70m rope might work but I'm not 100% on that, find out first!)  From here you can scramble down the Flake Trail or do one more 60m rappel down Sense of Urgency to the ground.
routes.protection: Pitch one has three bolts to a two bolt anchor, pitch two has five bolts to a two bolt anchor.

routes.description: An engaging route with some excellent face/slab climbing.  Moving to Montana is very similar in style and quality to Cruel Shoes, just a little harder and a bit more heady.   This climb has been retro-scrubbed and its rusty 1/4" bolts were replaced in an excellent gesture of public service.   p1 (11a): Originally graded 10d, I think this pitch should be bumped up as the recent cleaning removed a stump that provided a key rest/foothold.  Some easy climbing gets you to a bolt, but the the next 15' are hard and a bit scary.  You then get a great rest before a section of sustained tips laybacking/smearing.   p2 (10a): I've seen this pitch rated 5.9 and 10b but I think 10a is reasonable.  From the belay climb some easy cracks to an overlap before boldly breaking out left onto the slab where a bolt will get you to the belay.   p3 (10c):  Tricky face climbing past 2 bolts leads to a 'memorable mantle' that must be executed before you get the 3rd bolt.  The runout is about 20' and the mantle move is probably about 5.8 or 9.  Move left into a nice crack and under-cling it as it arches right past another couple of bolts.  A long and excellent pitch.   p4 (11a):  The Money.  Step down from the belay and traverse right along an under-cling with good pro.  Climb up on the hanging slab at the obvious opportunity and move up easily to clip a bolt.  Weave a devious line up and down across the slab past 3 more bolts, sustained all the way to the anchor.
routes.location: Scramble up just left of Flex Capacitor to a bolted station.
routes.protection: Doubles from small (purple metolius) to #1 (red) camalots, singles in #2 and #3.  A single grey metolius (or equivalent) is not a bad idea, but not critical

routes.description: An awesome left facing corner is where you begin.  The first pitch is slick and ends at a ledge. Pitch 2 has the crux 10c layback. After that 4 shorter pitches get you to the end of the route, where you can rap with 1 60m rope.
routes.location: Nice corner about 100' left of Exasperator.

routes.description: Rutabaga is a nicely varied pair of pitches.    P1 climbs the obvious but somewhat awkward crack to a bolted anchor (10b).   P2 continues up and right on very fun cracks to the left facing dihedral.  Face holds, good locks and good protection take you up the dihedral past one crux to the top crux which requires some solid stemming, and while the protection right at the crux isn't as good as the rest of the route, there are bomber placements about five feet lower.
routes.location: Right side of the Grand Wall base, just right of Arrowroot.
routes.protection: Standard Squamish rack for P1 to a bolted anchor.   For P2, a good selection of stoppers from small (but not micro) to large.  You can place many stoppers so bring enough slings or draws.  You'll also want a good selection of small cams and at least a 1 and 2 camalot.  I'm told that a green alien is good at the top crux, but I didn't have one so I'm not sure.   Thanks to extra anchors to climber's left, the rappel from the top can be done with a single 70m and probably a single 60 (but not certain).

routes.description: Seasoned in the Sun is would make a great warm up for a day of 5.10 climbing at the Chief, and in some ways is more enjoyable than Exasperator: no finger buckets/pinscars, bouldery crux at bottom and super-sustained hands at top, all in a cool, rarely visited part of the Grand Wall "base" area.  Highly, highly recommended.
routes.location: From the base of the Grand Wall, where Apron Strings, Exasperator, and Peasant's Route all start, hike left along the base of the cliff (the Flake Escape start to the Grand is over here, too).  It's always farther than I remember, but keep going: you can't miss the beautiful splitter going straight up from the trail, which peters out pretty quick after that.
routes.protection: TCUs, cams to 2.5 inches or so, set of nuts.  Fixed anchors at the top with rap rings, and you can TR and rap with a 60, but it will be close, so knot the ends of your rope!

routes.description: Easy hand jamming in a fine setting.  Up a 5.8 hand crack for 50 feet to chains. Descend from there, or (better yet), step easily right into Rutabaga and climb a 5.9 hand crack for another 40 feet to the chains on that route.
routes.location: Start in the crack 2m left of Rutabaga.
routes.protection: standard rack with double in the hand sizes

description: This is the southernmost area and encompasses the bouldering that is near the Stawamus Chief campground. These problems are somewhat isolated from the rest of the Grand Wall boulder problems, and are located north of, or behind, the main cook shelter
getting_there: Behind the cook shelter in the campground.

routes.description: One hard move.
routes.location: Start to the right of The Fuzz.

routes.description: start on incut side pull and horizontal rail(the huge chalked up foot hold is the start to a different climb but feel free to chunk a foot behind it). climb up through a variety of neat holds, finish with a big lock off of a perfect pinch
routes.location: hike up grand wall trail in the campground, as the trail climbs look left, across a stream below a waterfall is the Fuzz boulder

routes.description: Start on the obvious juggy rail far left of Red Wall and climb right through flake crimps.
routes.location: The Red Wall boulder.

routes.description: Short and powerful problems involving great movements.
routes.location: Follow the campground wall past the route Bullethead East Direct heading North. The boulder is kinda hidden and on it's own.

routes.description: Start seated low and left on the arete, get a  pinch out right and then make a long slap for a slopey lip to top out.
routes.location: North end of the Boulder, 10 feet right of Mounting the Throne V3.

routes.description: Paddle your way up the glassy bulge about five meters right of the dyke.
routes.location: On white slab

description: The southernmost area of the Grand Wall boulders, this area is accessed from the parking lot trail (see Grand Wall page). The first boulder reached on this trail is the Titanic boulder. The Titanic south area includes all problems that are south of the Titanic boulder, and extends uphill towards the Grand Wall itself.

routes.description: Start on Timeless shelf and go straight up, if you look like funky mantel boulder problems this is one not to be missed
routes.location: on Timeless boulder, in Titanic zone

routes.description: start on edge left of arete and arete itself pullup top out left using cool pocket
routes.location: up the hill in Titanic South

routes.description: Sit start using a sloping rail/shelf with a right heel or toe hook on the arete. Move right to the arete then up using some combination of monos, heel hooks, and other trickery.    It's About Time is a great problem and well deserving of its top 100 status.
routes.location: It's About Time is located in the southern portion of the Grand Wall boulders, near the Titanic boulder which is somewhat of a landmark. Look for the It's About Time boulder just south of Titanic and uphill, hidden in a bit of an alcove. For reference, the It's About Time boulder is just uphill from the Timeless boulder.
routes.protection: With a low crux and a relatively flat landing, I felt comfortable on this with one pad and no spotter.

routes.description: Sit start matching on a shelf on the east side of the boulder. Go around the corner, then up.
routes.location: Titanic South area. Shares same boulder as Squish á Gauche and Squishy Low.

routes.description: climb good edges to tougher exit
routes.location: just uphill from timeless, a small cave is formed by two overhanging boulders this climbs the edges on the right boulder

routes.description: climb prow facing uphill on seperate boulder at the corner of patriarchy (very low ball) Start with low right hand heel match and left on arete
routes.location: Titanic zone on the opposite side of the Patriarchy boulder as timeless, very short clean arete

routes.description: Head under Timeless to find a right sloper/edge rail and a left incut. Start here and toe-hook/trickery your way to victory.
routes.location: Timeless boulder

routes.description: From the book -Start with one hand over the lip and one underneath the roof. A crazy throw and tricky mantle gain a tall committing slab. This is a great high ball with a good landing that’s close to the parking lot. It’s easy to shuttle to which is helpful since you’ll need plenty.Great climb with a very committing top, as the book said. Start After the massive throw, trust some high feet to the two right facing slopers, then insecure high feet to the finish. https://youtu.be/c8Tc-9Daa0g
routes.location: Few pads at least

routes.description: fun moderate slab, crux comes at the start(start at the lowest point of boulder)
routes.location: up the hill in Titanic South

routes.description: Sit start matching on a shelf on the west side of the boulder (facing the parking lot). Go left and up.
routes.location: Titanic South area. Shares same boulder as Squishy Low and The Little One.

routes.description: Sit start matching on a shelf on the north side of the boulder. There's an obvious right heel hook. Go up.
routes.location: Titanic South area. Shares same boulder as Squish á Gauche and The Little One.

routes.description: Super fun little boulder start sitting on arete climb up through good holds
routes.location: from the trail heading towards timeless it is the right arete just before entering the timeless alcove

routes.description: An excellent problem, Timeless was originally graded V4 but is V5 in the current guidebook. Decide for yourself.   Start on the left side of the boulder matched on a shelf . Move right to decent holds and up.   Its also possible to use sidepull crimps out left and some say the problem is easier this way.
routes.location: Timeless is located in the southern portion of the Grand Wall boulders, near the Titanic boulder which is somewhat of a landmark. Look for the Timeless boulder just south of Titanic and slightly uphill, in a bit of an alcove.
routes.protection: Though not very high, the landing is typical Squamish. Bring a spotter and at least two pads.

routes.description: Start deeper into the cave than Pendulum Into Timeless (aka Timeless Low,) matched on the undercling jug, and pull two moves into Pendulum.
routes.location: Timeless boulder

description: This area is accessed from the parking lot trail (see Grand Wall page). The first boulder reached on this trail is the Titanic boulder. The Titanic north area includes all problems on the Titanic boulder as well as those nearby.

routes.description: A powerful 2-move problem.  Summon up all the body tension that you can, get your heelhooking muscles warmed up, and launch yourself out of the roof.   It's short, but with fun moves and great rock it's a classic.
routes.location: Just North (and ever-so-slightly uphill) of the Titanic boulder.

routes.description: Good to do in Titanic area.
routes.location: Page 96 in the Squamish Bouldering guidebook (2nd Edition).

routes.description: start seated to the right of surfing on heroin, right hand on arete left hand on sloping edge in cave, go up using cool holds on arete
routes.location: Up the hill from Mantra look for a steep north facing wall

routes.description: Almost as fun as the Mantis, same start go right to crimps and top out to the right
routes.location: Titanic Boulder

routes.description: Sit start on good edges. Go straight up. Not very clean at the top, aside from the immediate ledge.
routes.location: Titanic North area. Smaller boulder situated between Anubis and Mantra. Right beside the trail.

routes.description: Start with a hand in the V-notch and a left edge that's lower and climb up and top out.
routes.location: Furthest left problem from Mr. Bigglesworth.

routes.description: Short slab.  Fun little climb, especially for novices.
routes.location: Titanic North.  Same boulder as Titanic V3.

routes.description: Sit start on holds along diagonal ledge. Go straight up. Holds feel great.
routes.location: Titanic North area. Smaller boulder situated between Anubis and Mantra. Shares the same boulder as Slow and Easy.

routes.description: Climb the lip of the triangular boulder, starting on the good jug.
routes.location: The triangular boulder past (east) of Titanic between a couple of trees.

routes.description: Start just right of the centre of the boulder on an obvious crimp feature. Bring your feet high up over the lip and commit.
routes.location: Middle of the Iceberg boulder.

routes.description: Start on the right side of the boulder on an obvious edge feature, move up on a committing move to the slab.
routes.location: Left of the triangular Ice Cube boulder.

routes.description: Start on two well chalked crimps to the right and above the dart to the Mantis.  Bust out left with a couple hard moves to slippers and fight the pump as you traverse the lip of the Titanic boulder into the topout for Titanic.
routes.location: Couple pads

routes.description: Start on good edges on right side of the boulder go up through obvious bulge
routes.location: made in the shade boulder, right side of the face facing titanic

routes.description: SDS with a good undercling and slap to positive slopers.  Shuffle left along the lip until you are able to mantle.
routes.location: On the Titanic Boulder, opposite Titanic (V3).  Locate underclings below obvious slopers on the undercut portion of the boulder.

routes.description: start on obvious jug on arete, climb up fun moves to a difficult big move up and left
routes.location: up the hill from titanic/ black dyke(?) pretty hard to miss

routes.description: boulder
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: A short problem one boulder east of Titanic. Start seated on a good jug, make two moves up to the top.
routes.location: The boulder east of Titanic.

routes.description: Pull on from the boulder underneath this problem with a left hand on a rail and a right hand on the arete. Slap up the arete and top out on slopers.
routes.location: A couple hundred feet north of the Titanic boulder, about 20 feet uphill from Anubis.

routes.description: Start standing with left hand crystal slimper and right hand gaston. Climb the narrow dihedral and top out directly above.Guidebook lists this as V6 but I thought it felt easier
routes.location: About 35' uphill from Mantra, the cleaned narrow dihedral.

routes.description: Climb up and left on good basalt edges
routes.location: made in the shade boulder climb the obvious heavily chalked jugs

routes.description: Another fun Mantel climb, start left of super cool sloper, traverse right into it and mantel up
routes.location: from titanic hike towards black dyke this climb faces the trail about 30 seconds from titanic

routes.description: Northwest side of the boulder. Sit start holding opposite slopers. Go up and right.
routes.location: Titanic North area. Smaller boulder situated between Anubis and Mantra. Shares the same boulder as Fast and Hard.

routes.description: True to the name. Start from the right end of the lip, and smear traverse your way left, mantling at the other end.
routes.location: Titanic North area. Shares the same boulder as Shade Mantel, Shade Mantis, Shade Dyke, and Made in the Shade.

routes.description: Fun but Dabby, start low on diagonal dyke feature right hand on pinch left on lower sloper, traverse right through good holds while trying not to dab until you can get on the slab
routes.location: straight up from titanic just past big bottoms boulder (look for a low cave with chalked holds at the lip) probably alot of moss/lichen on slab above

routes.description: Fun
routes.location: Page 96 in the Squamish Bouldering guidebook (2nd Edition).

routes.description: climb up the dyke feature
routes.location: obvious across from titanic boulder, look for dyke feature

routes.description: A short problem on the opposite side of Stu's Dyke. Start match low on good holds, make two moves up.
routes.location: Opposite side of Stu's Dyke.

routes.description: right hand on crimpy sidepull left on sloper, big moves to good holds on a steep face, rock quality detracts from an otherwise really fun boulder
routes.location: Up the hill from Mantra look for a steep north facing wall

routes.description: Start wedged between the two boulders on basalt jugs, move left and up the arete.
routes.location: Two boulders east of Titanic.

routes.description: This is by far the shortest problem I have ever done. However, it is extremely fun. Start on two crimper side pulls and make moves up the arete. Really cool problem.
routes.location: Tallest arete on the Titanic boulder.

routes.description: Start same as Titanic, but throw for the lip
routes.location: See Titanic
routes.protection: Couple of pads in case you blow from the swing

routes.description: Fun short boulder that starts in a small pit. Start right hand low on arete and left hand on low pinch. Head straight up.
routes.location: Small boulder west of the Mantra boulder (and the Three Amigos Boulder). Trap door start low in the pit on north side and climbs straight up.
routes.protection: several pads for pit and rock behind

routes.description: Crux is the first move (hitting the small crimp with the left hand).
routes.location: To the left of Titanic on a separate boulder.
routes.protection: Flat landing, 1 pad is all that is needed.

routes.description: Climb the featured dyke left of The Mantis.  Start on a big positive dyke hold and up.
routes.location: Titanic North.  On same boulder as Titanic.

description: This area is accessed from the parking lot trail (see Grand Wall page). The first boulder reached on this trail is the Titanic boulder.    For the Thighmaster area follow the trail north from the Titanic boulder. There is a large concentration of excellent problems here.

routes.description: Start matched on low gaston. Pull left to side pull and go to lip and mantle.
routes.location: Left of Black Mark

routes.description: Start on lowest chalked holds. Slap your way up the blunt arete.
routes.location: A little south of Gastronomical located on a roundish boulder.

routes.description: Start standing matched on the big sidepull, work the feet, move up with the right hand to slopers, crimps, and top out.May feel soft if you are very flexible or stack many pads.
routes.location: Obvious clean face around the corner from Black Mark
routes.protection: Landing is good for squamish, one pad would be fine although 2 pads and/or a spotter may make it a bit more comfortable.

routes.description: Start in a slanting corner. Traverse right around the corner, through Adam's Apple, to finish on the lip of Black Mark.
routes.location: Just downhill from The Airtight Garage and Black Mark.

routes.description: Start low and climb the giant flake to the knife edge.
routes.location: In the Thighmaster area next to Sesame Street.
routes.route_name: Bert and Ernie were just good friends

routes.description: Start on the Black Mark but move left on crimps and dyno for the top.
routes.location: Just left of Black Mark

routes.description: Obvious dyke feature.  Start seated and trend up and right with poor feet and a big throw at the top.
routes.location: Black Mark boulder, just north of Titanic

routes.description: Starting move to crimps is often the crux.
routes.location: On the corner of the same boulder to the right of Gastonomical (V5).

routes.description: Start on a positive block hold in the dyke and move up and slightly left through a few moves on crimps and slopers.
routes.location: On the backside of the Gastonomical boulder.

routes.description: Start on a good sidepull under the leaning tree and move out right to a decent rail.  Heading up is finicky, but trust the feet and grunt to the last pocket!
routes.location: Pg. 103 in Squamish Bouldering Guide.   20 ft SW of Thighmaster.
routes.protection: pad or willing friend laying under the route

routes.description: Straightforward compression moves on actual holds and a decent landing - is this really Squamish?
routes.location: Descend into the obvious hole in the Thighmaster Area.

routes.description: Climb the juggy arete that forms the left side of the corridor wall.
routes.location: At the start of the corridor/tunnel between the large boulder of The Other Side and the smaller Lowdown boulder.

routes.description: Start seated on basalt crimps deep in the corridor/tunnel between the large boulder of The Other Side and the smaller Lowdown boulder. Climb out via the north wall of the corridor.
routes.location: Deep in the corridor/tunnel between the large boulder of The Other Side and the smaller Lowdown boulder.
routes.protection: A pad if you can wedge it down in there. Climbing is super secure due to the chimney aspect of the corridor,

routes.description: Sit start. Short problem. Grab the juggy rail, hit the top, mantle.
routes.location: Behind "Airtight Garage" and "Black Mark" boulders, squeeze trough them and it's on your right.

routes.description: Start seated and matched on good sloper. Move out right on good holds.
routes.location: just around the corner from airtight garage and option B

routes.description: Begin matched on a jug rail. Throw for the lip and traverse the left.
routes.location: Thighmaster Boulders

routes.description: Climb the arête to the top from either side.
routes.location: On small block left of Airtight Garage

routes.description: Start low and right on the sloped rail and work up,  mantling. Mantle is secure when you figure it out.
routes.location: Behind the Garage and Black Spot, next to Treeson (V2). It's short!

routes.description: Start in the cave matched on the big left facing fin and make series of tenuous moves to get out onto the face. Traverse right across the slab to top out.The big rock is just behind and below you the whole time, which detracts from the problem a bit, but the movement and technical footwork more than make up for it.
routes.location: Just across from Tim's Sloper Problem

routes.description: Short arete problem
routes.location: The arete

routes.description: Climb the arete left of airtight garage
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: climb the right side of the obvious arete
routes.location: none

routes.description: Climb the slabby southeast corner of the large boulder. Committing for V0.
routes.location: The large boulder behind Airtight Garage and to the right of Black Mark.

routes.description: Start on two low opposing crimps, place a left heel, and climb directly up the face into the second half of Sesame Street (V9). Lots of beta options and some really interesting holds. This one will probably favor scrunchy and technical climbers a little more.
routes.location: Sesame Street boulder

routes.description: Set your feet, squeeze with the legs and make some powerful moves to big holds.
routes.location: Left of Tim's sloper problem

routes.description: Squat start with two opposing sidepulls (right hand is discrete but locate the good edge below the obvious flat hold) and slap up and right to a large sloping rail, aiming as high as you can reach.  Feet up and slap left to another decent sloper again aiming high.  With the right hand, bump from a bad sloper to, you guessed it, another sloper.  Press to the final slope with high feet and some left hand trickery.     Top 100 in Bourdon's guidebook.  A must do.
routes.location: Follow the main trail past the Titanic Boulder and look for slopers.
routes.protection: Couple of crashpads and a spotter as the topout is a bit tenuous.

routes.description: Sit start on large flat pinches and make a couple tricky moves into the stand
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: boulder
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Start right on the short boulder, traverse left, do a muscley mantle.
routes.location: Adjacent to the striking Choss-a-block on a different boulder. Boulder is short and unassuming.

routes.description: Start with a sidepull and edge on the south side of the corridor, chimney out and top out on the wall behind you.
routes.location: At the mouth of the corridor/tunnel between the large boulder of The Other Side and the smaller Lowdown boulder.

description: This area is rather spread out and is found to the east of the Thighmaster area (i.e. up hill towards the Grand Wall)

routes.description: Start in the scooped face on an obvious edge matched and feet on a thin edge, fire straight up to a good jug and up and over.
routes.location: One boulder uphill from Slingshot, on a scooped east face next to the flat boulder that sits above Slingshot.

routes.description: Start matched on the big, low fin on the arete. Pull the first move or two of Hunt's Arete, then find a way to rock over onto the slab right of the arete. Top out above
routes.location: Hunts arete, just above Phat Slab

routes.description: Start matched on a sloping rail, make a small move up right to a RH crimp/sloper. Then execute a tough rockover utilizing sidepulls out left.
routes.location: 15m or so above Slingshot

routes.description: Sit start on a good downpulling shelf and climb straight up using the slopey arete and possibly some scrunchy feet. Excellent lowball!
routes.location: A couple boulders past Mr. Bigglesworth and just above Airtight Garage.

routes.description: Start on the slopey rail/lip on the left of the face with poor feet, and traverse right to the top through insecure slopers.
routes.location: One boulder uphill from Slingshot, on a scooped east face next to the flat boulder that sits above Slingshot.

routes.description: Sit start matched on a good right facing rail and climb up the face using more rails and the arete. Definitely makes you think!
routes.location: A few boulders uphill from Mr. Bigglesworth and Airtight Garage. Look for the face with a series of right facing dyke-like rails.

routes.description: Sit start on a good left hand crimp and right hand jug sidepull. Climb out of the steep roof through a sloper to finish up the v2 stand start (Prestoe). Excellent rock quality down low!
routes.location: Just uphill of Slingshot and downhill from Immunity Challenge. Look for the boulder with the huge low angle slab.

routes.description: Start matched in a slot jug and move up and right through crimps and slots to a decent right sidepull at the lip, then climb back left along the lip to a large shelf and mantel onto the slab. Excellent climb that probably should be Top 100! The only downside is the dab potential.
routes.location: Off the main trail between Black Dyke and Thighmaster you should see a small trail that goes uphill about 20m to Slingshot (V2). From Slingshot, head up and slightly left into the forest for another 100m or so. A bit scrambly in places, but the Immunity Challenge boulder is huge so it should be hard to miss.
routes.protection: 4+ pads and a spotter to make sure you don't fall off the pedestal

routes.description: Start with a small left crimp and right sloper, climb to the center of the face on some more okay slopers, then figure out a way to get to the good crimp about 4 feet above. Top out using the arete.
routes.location: Just past Dealer, follow a trail that skirts around the left of a small boulder before heading uphill for another hundred feet or so.

routes.description: Climb the awesome, Font-like slab. Tread directly up the middle of the face and finish at the highest point of the boulder. Don't veer off to the right.
routes.location: Northwest of Hunt's Arete
routes.protection: 1-2 pads for the landing and maybe another for the boulder to the right.

routes.description: Start on a jug shelf, make a powerful move to the lip and press it out onto the blank slab above
routes.location: Uphill and visible from the slingshot boulder in the obvious talus field

routes.description: This excellent problem is all about the first few moves. Once you hit the first left hand jug, you should be good to the top as long as you hold it together. With distinct short person and tall person beta, the moves off the crimps can be done a few different ways. Start low with your left hand on the shelf, your right hand on the crimp, your left foot down in the pit, and your right foot on the obvious heel hook. Straight up to the top.
routes.location: After passing Titanic on the main trail, continue past Black Mark and Thighmaster, then turn right and follow a path through smaller boulders. If you've walked for more than a minute off the main path, you've gone too far!
routes.protection: Two pads would be good here.

routes.description: Start on the far right side of the face. Traverse left below the lip on edges to connect into the face of Slingshot. Cruxy in the middle section.
routes.location: After passing Titanic on the main trail, continue past Black Mark and Thighmaster, then turn right and follow a path through smaller boulders. If you've walked for more than a minute off the main path, you've gone too far!

description: This area encompasses the problems immediately south of the Black Dyke boulder, and is typically accessed by following the first Psych Ledge trail to the Black Dyke boulder, then heading south. Alternatively this area can be reached by continuing along the trail north from the Thighmaster area.   There are an incredible number of excellent problems in this popular area.

routes.description: American Gigolo is one of the coveted Top 100.Start matched on a sloper/pinch and move up to a good rail. A sidepull around the left side leads to a fun top out.
routes.location: The American Gigolo boulder is immediately south of the landmark Black Dyke boulder. Other problems on the boulder include Left Rib and Doubt, both excellent problems in their own right.
routes.protection: One pad is probably sufficient, though you may want to pad the rock behind as well.

routes.description: Sit start with right hand pinching the arete and your left on a sloper.  Use some body english to get to the top.  Cool problem and perfect rock!
routes.location: Just south of the Black Dyke boulder.  Directly across from Squamish Days

routes.description: Slab behind the fried ant boulder
routes.location: Behind the fried ant boulder

routes.description: Left hand on a basalt circular hold, right hand on an edge, start standing and get your feet up and throw to a big pinch above. One move wonder mostly.
routes.location: Picture is mislabeled in the Squamish Bouldering book, this is actually a separate boulder pretty much opposite of American Gigalo arete.

routes.description: Start matched on good holds above the lip, heel around the right side and fire straight up on good holds.
routes.location: South end of the Fried Ant boulder.

routes.description: Start seated matched under a jug below the left arete.  Heel hook the arete and hit the top.  Fun!   Viper Area.  On same boulder as University Crawl.
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Start sitting matched on the jug rail and make a hard move to get feet up and top out.
routes.location: East of American Gigalo, on the trail.

routes.description: Stand start using a great jug.  Use a good side pull on the arete to reach a bad right hand crinch. Slap left then go for the rail with some combination of trickery and desperation.   This a great problem.
routes.location: Located on the American Gigolo boulder, Doubt is between that problem and Left Rib. The American Gigolo boulder is immediately south of the landmark Black Dyke boulder.
routes.protection: Doubt looks a little scary, but dont let that stop you. Looks can be deceiving.    You'll want a few pads for this one. Don't worry too much about falling into the hole, but you definitely want to pad the big rocks in front of the boulder quite well.   The falls are actually quite good, despite what it might look like.

routes.description: Start as for Fried Ant (or just below and left on a small edge), then climb to the jug shelf on Fried Ant before exiting right to the mantle on Ode to the Choad.
routes.location: Fried Ant boulder
routes.protection: A few pads. There's a hole under the mantle that would be good to protect

routes.description: Reach up from the left of the tree to good basalt crimps, bring your feet up and commit to up and over on good holds and a bad landing.
routes.location: Just before the Viper Boulder.

routes.description: Start on a low flexing undercling. Fire upwards and figure out how to use the sloping block feature to top out.
routes.location: Just left of Anatomy Lesson and across from Squamish Days.

routes.description: Start on good sidepull edges with feet under the boulder, shoot left into obvious crimps, bump up to the jug horn and over.
routes.location: East side of the Pulling Teeth boulder. The jug horn/flake is obvious at a little over head height.

routes.description: Start matched on a ledge and move up the slab.
routes.location: Backside of White Bread problem.

routes.description: Start matched on the right starting jug for Carpenter Ants. Move leftward, making a big move to a large flat hold and then straight up from there.
routes.location: On the south side of the Fried Ant boulder, the start hold is the right start jug for Carpenter Ants

routes.description: pull on to two decent crimps, being reach to the lip
routes.location: starts in a pit behind White bread (look for two chalked crimps above a funky little pit)

routes.description: Start low and left on good holds.  Move up right to an amazing hold.
routes.location: Viper Area.  Fried Ant boulder is just "above"ish of Squamish Days boulder.

routes.description: Left Rib is an excellent problem in a similar style to Cheese Grater, only a little longer, a little harder, and a little better.   Start with your left hand on a slanting rail and move up and right to a decent crimp. Slap right for the rib. Move up the rib with good footwork (crux) and some trickery to an easy topout.   Alternately climb the rib directly from below at the same grade.
routes.location: Left Rib is on the same boulder as the classic V3 American Gigolo, and is just south of the Black Dyke boulder   For more beta I recommend purchasing Marc Bourdon's excellent guidebook from one of the local stores.
routes.protection: The landing is very good for Squamish, though two pads are nice to have.

routes.description: Traverse in from the nose of the boulder along the lip to Dropping the Pearl
routes.location: Just opposite the Viper boulder.

routes.description: Fun climb up a basalt arete. Start on a small rail on the left and heel hook and climb up the arete.
routes.location: Behind the Squamish Days boulder.

routes.description: Crouch start on crimps and make a tricky move to the sloping jug at the lip. Mantle to top out
routes.location: Fried ant boulder

routes.description: Sit start using a small rail and move up to a good right hand and then a higher side-pull. Traverse the boulder on good holds to its left arête. High step then make committing moves up the slab to the the top.   An outstanding problem that's well deserving of its top 100 status.
routes.location: The Old and Serious boulder is uphill from the landmark Black Dyke boulder, just above Viper
routes.protection: Great landing for Squamish, though most people will want two pads and a spotter for reassurance as the slab moves are a bit scary.

routes.description: Technical slab climbing up the big north side of the American Gigalo boulder.
routes.location: North side of the American Gigalo boulder, the easier and spookier slab right of the break.

routes.description: start on pinch in cave climb up
routes.location: in a pit between white bread and old and serious

routes.description: Start matched at the lowest part of the seam. Find a way to get out left to the mega jug on the arete, using the obvious tooth hold and possibly some trickery.
routes.location: Opposite of Anatomy Lesson on the same boulder. You should see an obvious cave on your left if coming from Thighmaster.
routes.protection: At least a couple pads, the landing is a little annoying

routes.description: Start matched on the lowest part of the seam and climb up and right out of the steep roof through crimps. Great board style movement!
routes.location: Opposite of Anatomy Lesson on the same boulder. You should see an obvious cave on your left if coming from Thighmaster.

routes.description: Start on the left side of the jug-covered face with 2 good holds and climb up and left to the arete.  A loose hold as been taken out.  I believe this may make this problem considerably easier as it as left a large positive hold in its place, anyone familliar with this please comment.
routes.location: Viper area.  Just up the stairs from Pulling Teeth boulder.

routes.description: Start as for Squamish Days but shoot straight up to the top instead of using the arête
routes.location: Squamish Days boulder

routes.description: Sit Down Start.  Start seated using a very low sloping shelf.  Pull up to good holds then traverse right to finish.
routes.location: Viper area, same boulder as Squamish Days.

routes.description: Sit start Squamish Days on a good low left crimp and a rattling right sidepull undercut (with a loose rock inside it), then climb up and finish as for the regular line. This is as low as it seems possible to start with the hands—lower than the shelfs—and is quite dabby.
routes.location: A blubber pad helps to avoid dabbing the start. If you can do the first moves you won’t fall on any other.

routes.description: Start on a small left crimp and right hand sloping sidepull. Make a tricky move up to a good downpulling crimp, then top out above on jugs.
routes.location: Just to the left of Left Rib and adjacent to the huge Black Dyke boulder. Should be easily visible up on a ledge if you're at Sloppy Poppy.

routes.description: Start with right dyke hold at undercut with no feet. Fire left to sloping edge in overhang, match, move left and exit onto slab
routes.location: Near the Black Dyke Boulder

routes.description: Climb the insecure, snakelike fin of rock up the overhinging face. Start with hands on the fin at mid-height and go for it!
routes.location: SE of the Black Dyke Boulder
routes.protection: a couple of crashpads and good spotters

routes.description: Start pinching the arete on the right with a decent nub for your foot. Move up and left to a large block feature. Mantle, then top out. Pleasant movement.
routes.location: On the north face of the White Bread boulder, which is just southwest of Viper. The big juggy block in the middle of a 15ft face is the key feature.

routes.description: Sit start on small crimps just left of White Bread and make a couple very tricky moves into the White Bread jug.
routes.location: White Bread boulder

routes.description: Essentially a variation of the start of the excellent problem Old and Serious, Young and Furious is a worthy problem in its own right.   Start standing on the left side of the boulder using an undercling and bad feet. Make a big move up and right to a good hold. Finish as for Old and Serious.
routes.location: The Old and Serious boulder is uphill from the landmark Black Dyke boulder, just above Viper
routes.protection: Great landing for Squamish, though most people will want two pads and a spotter for reassurance as the slab moves are a bit scary.

description: This area encompasses the problems immediately on the Black Dyke boulder, as well as those immediately north of this. It is typically accessed by following the first Psych Ledge trail which leads directly to the Black Dyke boulder.
getting_there: Tea Bag Undies V4  Super Daddy Long Limbs V6  Sloppy Poppy V4  Summer Vacation V0  Skin Graft V4  Cheese Grater V1  Wafer Thin V5  Double Decker V3  Physics Hyperbole V9  The Physics V10  World of Hurt V10  Bobo Jones V3

routes.description: A great right to left lip traverse.      Sit start matched on a rail. Traverse right to left using the lip and good holds below the lip. Top out to the left of the tree. Pumpy.   Style points deducted for using the tree to top out.   Note that a typo in an earlier guidebook showed this as Bojo Jones.
routes.location: Bo Jo Jones is located roughly midway between the Superfly boulder and the Black Dyke boulder, and is right on the main trail.

routes.description: Great highball.
routes.location: Page 118 in the Squamish Bouldering guidebook (2nd Edition).
routes.protection: Not necessarily a good landing. Have a spotter.
routes.route_name: Bob Barker Cut My Dog's Nuts Off

routes.description: start on a shaped crimp/pinch and sloping vert edge, struggle to pull on and throw out right to a decent hold, traverse right into an interesting top out
routes.location: in between Black dyke boulder and Viper area

routes.description: climb slabby dihedral feature ...
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Start on the undercling and crimps (establish on boulder, not the small rock below) and throw for the large ledge. Pull for the top with a mantle or high lock-off. Down climb on opposite side.
routes.location: large crash pad, or 2-3 smaller ones.
routes.protection: Second boulder north of Black Dyke. North side of boulder on trail. Obvious overhang.

routes.description: Enjoyable and easy face climb.
routes.location: Black Dyke boulder, East side.

routes.description: Slabby.  Climb up the left edge of the boulder.
routes.location: Black Dyke area.  Same boulder as Peter's Crack.

routes.description: Shares the same start with “Bo Jo Jones-V3” only, you exit via mantel directly up the middle of the problem, just before you grab any of the good jugs out left. Grab the pinch slopers, throw up a heel to rock over on and DONT grab the tree! Very tempting, yes, but control yourself :)Could be a FA?? The locals I were climbing with said to post it up and see what comes about it. Either way, ENJOY!
routes.location: Shares start of Bo Jo Jones

routes.description: Same as Wafer Thin but eliminate the farthest left gaston edge.
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Slabby.  Big crack feature.
routes.location: Black Dyke area.  This boulder lies just east of Black Dyke proper.

routes.description: Stand start with sloping hands and work your way up the arete for a move or three.  Eventually move left onto the slab and top out.  Super fun.
routes.location: If you're looking at the Black Dyke boulder from the downhill side (i.e. looking uphill), Skin Graft is on the right corner of a smaller boulder to the left and uphill.  This YouTube video shows someone climbing it while looking down on the problem from above:  youtu.be/ItXfGBOa5Yw?t=6m45s

routes.description: A variation of Sloppy Poppy that traverses immediately left onto the slab.
routes.location: Sloppy Poppy

routes.description: SDS on large shelf.  Go straight up on good holds to left hand sloper on the arete.  Long move to sloping shelf and topout.
routes.location: One Black Dyke Boulder.  The left side of the south facing face.

routes.description: Start as for Sloppy Poppy but traverse right to finish on Super Daddy Long Limbs
routes.location: Black Dyke boulder

routes.description: easy highball that gets slightly more thin at the top
routes.location: center of black dyke boulder, 12 feet left of summer vacation

routes.description: Four star warm up. Climb great jugs from low on the rail up and left, then straight up to top out. Easy, but awkward and off the deck. This is an amazing highball Boulder problem.
routes.location: On the large overhanging arete of the Black Dyke Boulder. Around the corner from Sloppy Poppy.

routes.description: Starts on the sloper shelf to the right of the Sloppy Poppy start, utilize cool holds in the hueco, and be prepared for a pretty engaging top out(traverse right on slopers or go straight up for bonus points)
routes.location: on Blake dyke boulder right next to the ultra classic Sloppy Poppy
routes.protection: pads, spotter would be nice for finish

routes.description: One move wonder. Sit start matched on large sloping pinch. Move up right and up the high wall to finish
routes.location: Black Dyke boulder

routes.description: Climb the wall left of Easy Peezy.
routes.location: Black Dyke Boulder.

routes.description: Start for Wafer Thin but traverse left into double decker and finish it up.
routes.location: Double decker boulder.

routes.description: This problem is over with quickly.  Crimp your way to better holds and a decent topout. Kinda sharp.
routes.location: This problem is on the Double Decker boulder and is located past the Black Dyke boulder on your way to the SuperFly boulder.
routes.protection: A pad and a spot wouldn't hurt.

routes.description: The Witch starts just left of Summer Vacation around the arete. Start on a low jug and climb on the arete for a few moves before exiting left onto the face. Top out via large flat shelves.
routes.location: Black Dyke boulder
routes.protection: Many pads if this is near your limit

routes.description: Sit start on the lowest rail on the middle of the face. Work your way up the right arete until you can shoot for the left arete and top out.
routes.location: Look for the obvious triangular shaped rock around the corner of Skin Graft

routes.description: SDS--Right hand low on side pull and left hand high on crimper.  Climb on small holds along a seam.
routes.location: On west facing side of the Black Dyke Boulder.

description: This area encompasses the problems on the Octagon boulder as well as those to the east of this. The nude carving is in this area.   Access by taking the second Psych Ledge trail (see Grand Wall boulders page) past the Superfly boulder to an intersection. The statue and the Octagon boulder are just to the right.

routes.description: This used to be a seated start apparently, I don't think that goes at the given grade anymore as the forest floor level has dropped due to trail building. For a V0ish problem, start on a left sidepull and right underclingy sidepull with feet on edges, and fire up a couple moves to the lip.
routes.location: NW side of the boulder opposite the climber carving.

routes.description: Start seated grabbing the nose/arete of the boulder and work your way up the arete to the lip. Very hard to get established at the start unless you figure out the beta.
routes.location: Directly opposite of the carving of a climber, on the trail past the Octagon boulder.

routes.description: Formerly Fetal Alcohol Syndrome V1(?), before the 2021 rockfall opened up a harder lower start. Start matched on the high sloping shelf and campus or tech your way up and left to a good jug. Top out left. Use caution up high, the holds up there are jugs but were a bit dirty when I climbed this. Should clean up well with more traffic.
routes.location: Octagon, between Shelter and Be On Four

routes.description: Start on a large sidepull jug under the overhang. Using heel-hooks and other trickery, work out the roof and finish on the tall slab above.
routes.location: On the west side of the Octagon Boulder. Located the heavily chalked up roof.

routes.description: Jump Start to slopers at two meters up. Climb the crimps straight upwards into a committing top out.
routes.location: N/A

description: This area encompasses the problems immediately east of the Octagon area. To access follow the second Psych Ledge trail (see Grand Wall page) past the BC Parks sign. Pass the Superfly boulder on your left. At an intersection the nude statue is to your right. Stay straight (this is the trail to the Grand Wall base).   The Lip-Smack area is to the south of the trail, just past the intersection.

routes.description: Step up to a sidepull and follow the slabby rail to the top.
routes.location: On the O-Face boulder. This boulder can be tricky to find. It is directly across from Hunkster's Roof, but downhill from the Nefarious boulder.

routes.description: Sidepull for the left hand and a small scooped sloper for the right to start. Aim for a triangular jug and a good edge and top out.
routes.location: On the O-Face boulder. This boulder can be tricky to find. It is directly across from Hunkster's Roof, but downhill from the Nefarious boulder.

routes.description: Slabby.  Climb the nice slab adjacent to the end of the Crackhead log.
routes.location: Lip-Smack area.  Same boulder as Crackhead.

routes.description: Start as low as you can in the crack, work your way up with toe hooks and underclings, do a big move to gain the right side of the arete and muscle your way up and over.
routes.location: Up the path from Octagon, look for the obvious horizontal log stuck in a crack.
routes.protection: Be careful where you put your pads. Use at least two and make sure a spotter watches the rock a foot off the ground on the climbers left. A fall in the crack at the wrong place can lead to a dangerous knock to the back of the head on that bad boy.

routes.description: Find a small overhung lowball. Start with hand right with a right hand crimp and a left hand sloper knob. Double toe hook the left side with both feet to start. Make some big moves in the tension-y horizontal position and fire to some crimps and good lip. Controlling the swing from taking out the toe hooks is tricky!
routes.location: Further up and to the right of Crack Head. It's small-ish and a bit hidden. Above black slabbath boulder to the left.

routes.description: Start standing matched on a good sloping rail. Move up past another good hold to the lip. The unique moves over the lip are what give this problem its name.
routes.location: Take the trail that leads into the forest by the Superfly boulder. Follow this trail for a short distance to a fork. The naked statue is by this fork. Going right leads to Bobo Jones, Cheese Grater, the Black Dyke boulder, and more. Going left leads up towards the Grand Wall. Take this left fork.    After a very short distance you will pass the obvious Crackhead boulder on your right and off the trail, with a large tree sticking out of it. Hulkster's Humpfest is on the backside of the Crackhead boulder, around the right, and is not visible from the main trail.
routes.protection: The landing is quite flat though there is a rock that requires some careful padding.

routes.description: Start on two small crimps low on the face and make a couple tricky moves to get into the stand start.
routes.location: Large boulder just south of Crackhead

routes.description: Start matched on a left facing ledge and bust a couple hard moves to the sloping lip
routes.location: A few boulders left of Crackhead. Just off the Grand Wall trail to climbers right

routes.description: Start low using good holds in the crack. follow the crack up and right to finish on slopey holds.
routes.location: This problem can be found on the Nefarious boulder. To the right of that problem, find the right-angling lieback crack. This is the start for Nazar.

routes.description: Start on a good rail that you can only get onto with a ledge or possibly a tree on the left side on the ledge. Canvas the first move (or all if you desire). Falling would be spicy.
routes.location: Big boulder directly behind Hulkster's Humpfest.

routes.description: Start on opposing sidepulls about a meter off the ground. Aim for the O-shaped depression above (which gives the boulder and problem its name) and smear to the top.
routes.location: On the O-Face boulder. This boulder can be tricky to find. It is directly across from Hunkster's Roof, but downhill from the Nefarious boulder.

routes.description: Start matched on the right side of the boulder on a good incut edge. Traverse the rail left and up to the lip using some combination of heel hooks and/or horrifically bad feet.    The first time I tried this it felt ridiculously hard for V2, and then I tried the heel hook. Aha.   A nice problem and deserving of its Top 100 status.
routes.location: I recommend purchasing Marc Bourdon's excellent guidebook from one of the local stores, but even with that I thought it was rather tricky to find.   Take the trail that leads into the forest by the Superfly boulder. Follow this trail for a short distance to a fork. The naked statue is by this fork. Going right leads to Bobo Jones, Cheese Grater, the Black Dyke boulder, and more. Going left leads up towards the Grand Wall. Take this left fork for Paperboy.    After a very short distance you will pass the obvious Crackhead boulder on your right and off the trail, with a large tree sticking out of it. Paperboy is a short distance beyond this, also on the right, and is not visible from the trail.
routes.protection: A nice flat landing and a fairly low top out makes Paperboy quite safe with just a single pad and no spotter.

routes.description: Start in the back of the cave formed by the boulder on wide fists, which narrow down to perfect gold jams. Turn the roof and top out.If you like hand cracks, this is a must-do!Make sure you have a spotter on the downhill side of the crack to prevent tumbling into the pit.
routes.location: This one is a bit tricky to find. Using Black Slabbath as a reference, look for a short boulder with a visible crack splitting it, just a few meters downhill from the Black Slabbath boulder. The visible part of the crack is the finish for Rumble in the Tunnel.

routes.description: Start matched on a rail with bad feet, trying not to fall in the hole. Move up to a sloping shelf, and an easy top out.
routes.location: Take the Grand Wall trail as per the Lip-Smack area description. Just past the Superfly area there is a fork. The nude statue is to your right, and the Grand Wall base straight ahead. Take the Grand Wall trail and after a very short distance past the fork you will pass the obvious Crackhead boulder on your right and off the trail, with a large tree sticking out of it. WWF Action is on the backside of the Crackhead boulder, around the right, and is not visible from the main trail.
routes.protection: The landing is quite flat though there is a rock that requires some careful padding.

description: This area encompasses the problems near the upper portion of the Grand Wall trail. To access follow the second Psych Ledge trail (see Grand Wall page) past the BC Parks sign. Pass the Superfly boulder on your left. At an intersection the nude statue is to your right. Stay straight (this is the trail to the Grand Wall base).

routes.description: Start with left hand on the arete and right hand on an undercling/sidepull. Make a thrutchy move or two up to a left hand jug, maybe plug a toehook, then climb directly up through decent edges.
routes.location: Follow the Grand Wall trail up and left of Crackhead.
routes.protection: Several pads - falls at the top are possible.

routes.description: Start on a good juggy crimp and move up and left through bad slopers. Very condition dependent.
routes.location: Follow the Grand Wall trail past Crackhead. Undertow is just uphill of Child Abuse.

routes.description: Sit start matched on the starting foothold for Undertow and make a couple very strange moves into the V7 start. There are several different ways to do this, all hard enough to make the Undertow crux feel much more desperate!
routes.location: Undertow boulder

routes.description: Start is just right of the tree
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Right arête on concave face of Pyramid Arête/War Tour boulder.
routes.location: N/A

description: This area encompasses the problems on the Superfly boulder and on Rat Rock just to the north. To access follow the second Psych Ledge trail (see Grand Wall page) past the BC Parks sign. The Superfly boulder is right there.

routes.description: Sit down start, make a few sloper moves to a good hold, set your heel, wrestle with some slimpers and eventually find "the good one" out left. The holds up and above the lip are better but still require your attention.Food for thought: "Growing up in laid-back Santa Cruz, California, he inherited a mystical bent from his parents, Gita and Bob, who were students of Baba Hari Dass, a yogi who took a vow of silence in 1952 and who still communicates by writing on a chalkboard that hangs on a string around his neck. The yogi married Sharma's parents in a Hindu ceremony, and he gave them their last name." ( mensjournal.com/magazine/ch…)
routes.location: same boulder as for superfly
routes.protection: great landing, some pads and a spot is nice.

routes.description: Sit start matched on the low sloping rail with a good right foot and make an extremely tricky move to the better rail above. One move wonder and one of the Seven Terrors. The right arete is not used for this climb.
routes.location: Just behind the huge Bulb boulder and Superfly.

routes.description: Full traverse of the boulder from left to right.
routes.location: The backside of the Good as Gold boulder which is immediately to the right of Superfly when facing towards the Chief.

routes.description: One move wonder. Start with right hand on a sidepull near a v shaped feature, left hand on a mini roof out left. Get established on back feet and hit the lip.
routes.location: Right side of the backside of the Good as Gold boulder which is immediately right of Superfly boulder when facing the Chief

routes.description: Pinch and lift the boulder. Easier if you have big hands.V10 if you go up the V0 "Superfly Slab" with no hands while lifting Portable.V4 if you mantle it. Pretty easy, like doing a dip if you have feet off and "campus" it. Quite hard, and worthy of the V4 grade if you can do the mantle starting with both feet on the rock. Make sure it's sitting level!
routes.location: 1 foot tall boulder usually found near superfly

routes.description: Start matched on the bottom of the L, work your way up the seam, and then pop to the jug. Traverse slightly left for the top out to avoid moss.
routes.location: From Superfly, walk towards the large Dreamcatcher boulder and it'll be on your right

routes.description: start left of Superfly on low jug climb the arete using fun heel hooks and compression moves
routes.location: Superfly boulder

routes.description: Slabby.  Climb the obvious cleaned streak.
routes.location: Superfly boulder.

routes.description: Start on the minijug and work your way up and to the right with crimpers and slopers and an excellent finish.  This problem is extremely popular and a little polished.  Climbing the arete is a different, easier problem.
routes.location: Walk in the main entrance to the forest and you can't miss it. There is even a picture of it on the message board in the forest next to it.
routes.protection: Flat landing so a pad will do.  Downclimb the tree.

routes.description: Fun eliminate climb Superfly to good crimp and dyno for the lip
routes.location: superfly boulder

description: This area encompasses the problems immediately to the north of the Grand Wall trail. This area is just to the north of the Lip-Smack area. To access follow the second Psych Ledge trail (see Grand Wall page) past the BC Parks sign. Pass the Superfly boulder on your left. At an intersection the nude statue is to your right. Stay straight (this is the trail to the Grand Wall base).   The Mantel Madness area is to the north of the trail.

routes.description: Start matched on the obvious low jug and pull to a good incut hold above. Traverse the sloper lip to the center of the face and use an edge beyond the lip to assist in a mantle.
routes.location: Just opposite Autobody on the same boulder. Most easily accessed by a faint trail just behind the Superfly Boulder.

routes.description: Classic lip traverse behind the cacodemon boulder.
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: short but fun, start seated pinching left hand arete right hand on incut side pull crimp, utilize the arete and find your way to the lip of the boulder. With good beta may feel easier
routes.location: Around the backside of Cacodemon boulder on a separate smaller boulder right next to the weasel (Mantel Madness zone)

routes.description: Start on two obvious pinches on left side of boulder (same start as Nevertheless). Traverse right, then go up.
routes.location: Mantel Madness area. Shares same boulder as Nevertheless.

routes.description: Start on two obvious pinches on left side of boulder (same start as Less is More). Go straight up.
routes.location: Mantel Madness area. Shares same boulder as Less is More.

routes.description: Match start on obvious right hold.
