routes.location: Mantel Madness area. South side of Cacodemon, right beside the trail. Shares the same boulder as Finger Lickin' and Rubber Ain't Stickin'.

routes.description: Sit start in the steep face. Gun for the lip and mantel.
routes.location: Steep face with mantel below Auto body.

routes.description: Start as for Ryan’s Basement Left. At the arête jug of Hey, Mr. DJ!, dyno up and right to the lip.
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: The hardest boulder problem found in all of Squamish. Start at the low lip of the face when entering the mouth of the boulder. A featureless classic that will test even the greatest of climbers.
routes.location: The inlet that is behind the Cacodemon boulder facing the dirt trail. Its the largest boulder of the grand wall, its hard to miss it. Famous for being right beside Dreamcatcher.

routes.description: Finicky heel hooks, horrible slopers, desperate arete slapping, physics defying hamhocks and a heartbreaking finish.
routes.location: A couple of pads.

description: Originally a sport climb with bolts (currently chopped), this boulder now hosts a life list highball for the Squamish are. Bring a rope and as many pads as you can wrangle. You’ll need them.
getting_there: You can follow the directions to Gilligan’s Island, but I personally like to start by hiking to the left of Easy Chair (V4), and then to the right of Superdyke (V3) going around the Cacodemon Boulder to the tunnel behind The Room and Dreamcatcher. From here hike up the hill (initially scrambling up the rocks) and slightly right (staying left of the first chalked up overhung boulder on your right) until you reach another chalked up bulbous boulder around 50m up. Go to the left of the boulder and you should see a faint trail switchbacking up to the talus beneath the bolted boulder. Follow this and you should see Straight Outta Squampton a little further to the left.

routes.description: One of the Crown Jewels of Squamish highballingStand start on the stack of rocks reaching up and back to a crimp about 10 feet above the ground. Make moves through the dike to reach a sloping rail and pinch. From here make the hardest moves in order to reach a good rail to the right.Get set up on a decent flat horn and a 1/4 pad mono crimp and prepare for a wild dyno to the lip to a great incut just below the lip, or a juggier edge a few inches higher. Perform an easy but sloping top out to finish.Good luck, and don’t miss the pads.Just above the lip there are bolted anchors for top roping (bring a tarp to protect your anchor from the lip of the boulder) and 10m up the slab of the boulder there is a large tree to rig another line down (as of August 2023 there is a decent condition 11mm dynamic rope rigged for solo top roping the upper moves, the rope is too thick to use an ascender on)The best method for working this boulder is to bring a normal size rope and descend the large line attached to the tree in order to rig a top rope from the bolted anchors so you can jug or ascend it as necessary.Working the moves on and to the left of the sloper rail is extremely challenging due to the overhang of the boulder and the fact that the holds are far left of the anchor. You will likely need a partner to pull you in if you are just on the rope with a grigri or will have to have someone belay a full top rope set up so you can safely try the moves from the ground without pads.Beta video (Front angle): https://youtu.be/dWc6hd3zgDY?si=orQwPyBXVpDfMxhcBeta video (Side angle):  youtu.be/5b1CA7qoWE8?si=5p_…
routes.location: Center of the overhung face
routes.protection: At least 10 pads with lots of spotters and shufflers, pretty comfy with 20 pads.

description: This area encompasses the problems on the Easy Chair boulder and those nearby. To access follow the second Psych Ledge trail (see Grand Wall page) to the BC Parks sign. The Superfly boulder is right their, while the Easy Chair area is a very short distance to the north. The Easy Chair boulder is the first one you reach and is right on the main trail.
getting_there: Easy in an Easy Chair V4  Superdyke V3  Largonian Bulge  Slave to the Pushers V5  The Green Traverse V6  Practical Horsemen V4  Lounge Act V6  Swank Stretch V5

routes.description: Start crouching matched on the positive scooped lip rail. Using a small right foothold in the overhang, shoot up to a higher jug and then execute a rather tricky roll over the lip. V1 if you start seated using the two tiny crimpers just below the lip rail.
routes.location: Right behind Stupid Face, near Stud Arete.

routes.description: start on low chalked edges traverse up and left
routes.location: very lowball lip traverse just across from the pool, in the easy chair zone
routes.protection: maybe a slider pad, to keep your shoes dry

routes.description: Fun, start on large shelf(same as green traverse) go up and left
routes.location: near superdyke in easy chair zone

routes.description: Start the same as Superdyke, but climb straight up the slabby face after doing the first couple traverse moves.
routes.location: On the big slab boulder behind Easy Chair. Starts the same as Superdyke on a large obvious jug.

routes.description: Starts on large shelf traverse the lip up and right
routes.location: problem ascends an arete on the right side of a small boulder just west of the large cacodemon boulder

routes.description: Climb up the center of the slabby face uphill from easy chair. The line is best if you avoid the rail out left part way up and just friction your way to the top. The guide suggests trying this feet only, or by getting a running start.The left face is v1, the right face is v2. All great fun lines.
routes.location: Uphill from east trail on the trail towards The Room

routes.description: Sit start with a left sidepull, pinch around the arete on the right side. Stand into the flake on the arete, climb up along the arete to the jug directly above and top out.NOTE: the current guidebook grades this @ V7. A few have mentioned that it used be a really sandbagged V3. I climbed this and Easy Lounge on the same day; this was definitely easier than Easy Lounge, definitely harder than V3/4 so I'm settling on V5. Feel free to chime in or even "correct" the grade though! I don't mean to be a sand bagging ***hole.Either way, it's a fun route! Try it and decide for yourselves.
routes.location: Directly right of Lounge Act. Right in front of this boulder is the back/top of Swank Stretch.
routes.protection: One or two pads, maybe a spotter.

routes.description: Start on right leaning ramp on two (2) bad sloper. Do a hard move to an higher good hold. Get the lip and traverse left to an easy top out.
routes.location: To the south of the Green Traverse boulder, to the south-est of Easy Chair.

routes.description: Start directly below the large slopey edge with your right on a pinch and your left on a diagonal edge.  Paste your feet low, throw to the rail, then topout through the hole on jugs.
routes.location: Directly to right down in a cave as you are entering forest on trail to Animal Magnetism boulder.
routes.protection: Pads for the rocks in the pit.
routes.route_name: Direct Start to Up From the Depths

routes.description: Start on an incut dike edge. Traverse left and up on good holds.
routes.location: Easy Chair area.  Superdyke boulder

routes.description: Start low and traverse right until it is possible to mantle.  Slopes and hooks are abundant here.
routes.location: Found on the main trail....cut left when you enter the forest.

routes.description: Start right on a rail.  Traverse left and finish at the top of Easy in a Easy Chair.
routes.location: Same boulder an just right of Easy in a Easy Chair.

routes.description: Start as for easy chair. Head right and mantle in the middle
routes.location: Easy chair area

routes.description: Start on shelf do a low dabby traverse out right until you get to the nose of the boulder, mantle it out
routes.location: easy chair zone, the finish is near superdyke

routes.description: Match start on the obvious edge beside the arête. Go up and left.
routes.location: Easy Chair area. Shares the same boulder as Starsky and Hutch.

routes.description: start under roof on block like hold fire up to sloper and top out
routes.location: on the boulder directly behind super dyke boulder

routes.description: Start in the middle of the face with bad crimps and huge feet.  Work your way up tiny holds to the juggy lip.  Exciting mantle.
routes.location: This problem is located to the right of the Animal Magnetism area as your are approach said boulders.  The landing is on top of the Swank Stretch boulder.
routes.protection: A few pads and good spotter would be handy.

routes.description: Sit down start.  Start seated on an obvious rail.  Go up an' left.
routes.location: Easy Chair area.

routes.description: starts in undercling feature on the right side of blunt arete, climb up and left.
routes.location: in between animal magnetism and easy chair, if coming from easy chair hike towards lounge act, Minor threat is the heavily chalked boulder arete just past

routes.description: Start as for Easy Chair, make one move right then go up and left to a far crimp. Top out.
routes.location: Easy Chair Boulder

routes.description: Starts on same undercling feature as minor threat go up and right to top out finishes up on same shelf as seam problem
routes.location: same start as minor threat(heavily chalked arete climb just before Animal Magnetism boulder)

routes.description: Top 100 V4.
routes.location: Page 166 in the Squamish Bouldering guidebook (2nd Edition).
routes.protection: Relatively high but not too bad. Have a spotter for the barn door move.

routes.description: start low on blocky horizontal feature, climb up and left through interesting pinches and a jug or two
routes.location: to the right of Minor threat on same boulder(start is heavily chalked)

routes.description: (this route was renamed by request of the FA in 2020)the finish of green traverse pull up on slopers and climb an interesting mantle
routes.location: easy chair zone( near superdyke)

routes.description: Start in diagonal crack feature, traverse right through incut edges
routes.location: directly across from practical horsemen in pit (easy chair zone)

routes.description: Stand on a big ledge and reach high and right to a good left edge and lip.  Mantel.
routes.location: Easy Chair area behind Superdyke boulder

routes.description: Climb a nicely featured face with a old rivet stud in it.  The arête is great for hands.
routes.location: Across/beside easy in a easy chair.

routes.description: Sit start on bad holds make a couple tricky moves to the lip. One of the most iconic climbs in Squamish.
routes.location: Boulder just left of Easy Chair

routes.description: Start low on a good jug as for Dyke Surfer V0. Traverse the tenuous dyke up and right behind the tree to a top out on the right side of the boulder.   Quite possibly the worlds hardest V3, and one of the coveted Top 100.
routes.location: Superdyke is located in a little alcove just behind Easy in an Easy Chair V4, near the outhouse along Psyche Ledge. There are a cluster of good problems here, including Dyke Surfer V0, Largonian Bulge V2, Slayed by the Pushers V5, and The Green Traverse V6.
routes.protection: Though a bit scary because of the nature of the small holds, and of course the tree in your way, it's really not that bad. Most slips can be averted by a quick press backwards to the tree, and the landing is flat. There is the issue of fitting a pad in the small space between the tree and the boulder.

routes.description: A variation of Swank Stretch that climbs directly up the seam before exiting left using a large jug on the corner.
routes.location: Same as Swank Stretch
routes.protection: A few pads and maybe one on the rock behind you

routes.description: Start seating on a flat jug. Using the thin slot to work up to better holds and top out
routes.location: Easy Chair area, under the boulder that forms the landing zone for Lounge Act

routes.description: Start left on good rail, move up and right climbing "up from the depths"
routes.location: North end near Golden Boy

description: This area encompasses the problems on the Animal Magnetism boulder as well as problems just to the east of this. Access is via the third Psych Ledge trail (see Grand Wall page) which is located just north of the outhouse.

routes.description: Technical slab climbing towards a juggy top.
routes.location: The second problem to the left of Jack's Baby start.

routes.description: Start on a positive edge and work up the crimps
routes.location: On the face of the boulder to the right of Jack's Baby

routes.description: Start on the slopey edge typically used as a foot hold for Golden boy and go straight up.
routes.location: The end of Golden Boy.

routes.description: Start down low on flat ledges (same start hold as The Proposal) and work your way up and left through fun dynamic moves.  A solid heelhook and some lateral momentum will get you out to the end of the problem.   Don't discount the mantle though-- it's not quite as straightforward as it looks.
routes.location: Down in the hole on the right side of the Animal Magnetism boulder

routes.description: Start on low crimp rail, move up and right on smaller crimps.
routes.location: In a channel between two close rocks, near Worm World.

routes.description: A classic Squamish sloper problem that begins somewhat awkwardly with a high right-hand and bad foot; a left-hand undercling and heelhook. Traverse right on slopers. The crux is moving your heel as you go.
routes.location: Located just a few steps east of the Animal Magnetism boulder the start is marked by a large chalky undercling on the left side of the boulder. Traverse right and mantel on the far right side. Climb down the southeast side of the boulder and jump (nice to have a pad).
routes.protection: Pads to cover the roots and rocks.

routes.description: 1-2-PUNCHStart matched on an edge and paste your left foot on a sloping ledge way out left (starting hold for Square Cut Low). Keep the tension as you move to the lip, then float up to a good hold. You are amazing.
routes.location: Right of Square Cut, and left of Golden Boy. Many problems begin in this same area. Shares starting holds with King Swing.
routes.protection: A thin pad to protect the big rock behind your head.

routes.description: Start matched on slopers and find a way to get up the arete and top out.
routes.location: The shelf to the right of Jack's Baby

routes.description: Begin matched on an obvious low rail seated directly in front of the prow. Move out the roof trending left to a great jug at the lip. Shake out and keep it together up the slab. I avoid the crack entirely on the top-out, it doesn't seem appropriate.
routes.location: Follow the trail uphill passing the Animal Magnetism boulder on your left. Some mellow scrambling will lead you past Jack's Baby and The Broom. Continue forward until No Troublems will emerge high on your right. If you hit the tall Worm World boulder you've gone too far.
routes.protection: 3+ pads and a spotter for the top-out.

routes.description: Directly below Brain Squeeze is a triangular pinch in the roof. Start with your left hand here and your right on a gnarly sloper. Make a long slap to the Golden Boy crimps and finish above. A beta intensive one-move-wonder that feels impossible until it doesn't.
routes.location: On Animal Magnetism, left of Golden Boy.

routes.description: Scrunchy climb on the way to Golden Boy from the Apron trail.
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Start sitting with good right flake. Throw up to sloper rail trendng left. Figure out which holds work for you. Top out on good holds.
routes.location: To the left of Golden Boy. Left trending sloper rail with a flat boulder right under it.

routes.description: Climb up the slab toward the big diagonal feature.
routes.location: First slab problem to the left of Jack's Baby start

routes.description: Climb starts on large chalked jug a couple feet right of sit down holm boy, goes straight up   maybe a pad for protection
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Start matched on the crimpers about chest height left of the arete. Move to the right rail and then make your way back left and up onto the face left of the arete and top out.
routes.location: Opposite side of the same boulder for Worm World.

routes.description: Start with left hand on polished gaston, right hand on a sidepull in a groove. High tech.
routes.location: On boulder just south of Worm World cave, the one with the slightly overhanging glassy face.

description: This area encompasses the problems to the east of the Animal Magnetism area. Access is via the third Psych Ledge trail (see Grand Wall page) which is located just north of the outhouse. Follow this trail past the Animal Magnetism boulder and scramble past the Cacodemon boulder (home of the route Dreamcatcher 5.14d). The Hearbreak Hotel boulder is the first one you reach.   Alternately you can hike around the Cacodemon boulder from the Mantel Madness area and this avoids any scrambling.
getting_there: Heartbreak Hotel V2  Trad Killer V4  Turtle Back V3  Worm World Cave V9  Corrupted V7  Pocket Problem V4  Under the Staircase V1

routes.description: Start deep in an alcove right of the dyke on a good hold. Move up and left
routes.location: Pocket problem boulder in Heartbreak Hotel area

routes.description: Begin with a left hand on a decent sloping pinch in the middle of the overhanging prow of the “worm world” boulder, and a right hand low on a small crystal sidepull around the arete. Make powerful moves up the blunt arete on the right side, topping out straight over the lip of the boulder.
routes.location: Just downhill from heartbreak hotel, and between “No Troublems” and “Worm world cave”.

routes.description: Start seated far to the left using holds in the horizontal dyke. Traverse right using sharp edges to finish up the juggy dyke.
Follow the rail right to a hard move or two depending on your reach or lock off strength.
routes.location: Close to trad killer
routes.protection: several pads, sheer ledge under top-out, have good spotters

routes.description: Start low and left of Heartbreak Hotel Climb up and slightly right to an interesting T/O
routes.location: Heartbreak hotel boulder

routes.description: starts on the typically wet juggy sidepull deep in the cave, climb into the cool toothy undercling and make your way to the giant sloper shelf, from here traverse right on mostly good holds. traditionally finished by matching large jug sidepull on the far right and stepping off onto the slab to the right
routes.location: Just down the hill from worm world cave
routes.protection: pads, spooky rock but more of a dab problem than dangerous

routes.description: Start on a jug about 6 feet off the ground. Make a big move up the blank wall to a pocket. Grab the lip and traverse right to finish.
routes.location: Heartbreak Hotel area

routes.description: Climb the green face beginning with a good left sidepull and a hold out to the right. It climbs better than it looks. Pond Scum Low (V2) starts seated using a finicky undercling.
routes.location: Left side of the Trad Killer boulder. 15 meters north of Heartbreak Hotel.

routes.description: Granite Crimps/side pulls created by the waves on the Granite Face.
routes.location: North of Heartbreak Hotel boulder
routes.protection: Pad, or none. Very low start and then ~15'/4.6m up

routes.description: climb jugs up and right on the corrupted boulder
routes.location: near Heartbreak hotel just behind Worm World Cave

routes.description: A Squamish classic.  Start down in the cave on the two head-level holds, and make a low-percentage deadpoint to a decent edge.  From there, work up the arete and prepare for the backwards throw to get into the topout sequence.   This is a must-do for the grade.
routes.location: The big cave on the Wormworld boulder.

routes.description: This sit start adds a few more difficult moves to the opening sequence of the Wormworld Cave problem.  Start as low as possible on the right side of the cave and make some tenuous and difficult moves up the arete until you can break left into the opening deadpoint on the original Cave problem.
routes.location: Wormworld Cave.

description: As the guidebook puts it, "one of the more remote areas in the Grand Wall forest." Really close to the Heartbreak Hotel area, past/uphill from Tradkiller.
getting_there: Follow the trail from Heartbreak Hotel going uphill.

routes.description: Start matched on the right-most side of the boulder. Big move to a sloper followed by some really fun heel-toe footwork moves you leftwards towards a rail. Final big move takes you to some jugs and a satisfying top out.
routes.location: Pads

routes.description: Roof crack
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Start as for 21st Century Digital Boy, but instead of going up from the sloping jugs, continue left on decent edges to a big finish on the left edge of the boulder.
routes.location: Same boulder as 21st Century Digital Boy.

routes.description: Start on the big low rail above the hole, then move your way up through big holds to the lip and rock over.
routes.location: Find this well-chalked boulder just downhill and left of the trail of the Ride the Lightning Bouler (only a couple mins past Heartbreak Hotel and Trad Killer on the path leading from the main areas of the Grand Wall Boulders).

routes.description: Super-fun sit-start on the lowest rail that you can pull on with a left heel, climb (or even chuck) to the lip on the right side of the boulder and then finish up on the left side.
routes.location: Right past Heartbreak Hotel, go left off the main trail towards Trad Killer. There's a fairly clear trail leading to this boulder. Trek down a bit past the Sticky Fingers boulder and follow the trail into a small grouping of boulders.

routes.description: Tall with a high mantel. Start on obvious rails in the middle of the western face, top out straight above to the right of the tree.
routes.location: Walk North and uphill from Heartbreak Hotel around 50m

routes.description: Start matched on a decent crimp and climb upwards on slopers to a tough rockover. Very pure.
routes.location: Just north of Sunshine and Lollipops. The boulder is tucked away in a dark alcove close to the edge of the forest before it opens up into the talus.
routes.protection: Pad, and something to cover the jagged stump

routes.description: Begin on a sloping rail in the overhang, powerfully work your way up past a triangular hold to good holds at the lip. Top out directly above using reach or finesse.
routes.location: North of Worm World Cave, on the edge of the forest.

description: East facing. 100m wide, mostly undeveloped crag on the west side of the top of the North Gully.
getting_there: Hike the third peak trail until you get to the crotch of the North Gully. Head North along the top of the West side of the North Gully. About 1 hour from the car.

routes.description: Very overhanging corner with stepped roofs, very exposed, with very good gear. Easily one of the best at the grade in Squamish.
routes.location: The route is on the Northern most end of the Highline Wall. Rap Munitions Plant (which is located about 20ft to the North) placing a couple pieces on the way down (it's really steep!) to a large but sloping ledge. Examination of time starts from climbers left (South) side of this ledge.
routes.protection: Mostly thin fingers to a couple tight hand placements. Two bolts at the top, two at the bottom.

routes.description: Steep climbing up a thin crack feature using mostly face holds. Bouldery and very exposed.
routes.location: Munitions Plant is on the Northern most end of the High Line wall. The top anchors are located right next to a spindly tree at the edge of the wall (use a rope to get to them). Rap the route putting a few pieces in on the way down in order to make the ledge (its really steep!). It's a good idea to walk along the other side of the North Gully to scope the route(s).
routes.protection: Mostly finger size, one tight hands placement near the start. Two bolts at the top two at the ledge.

description: An impressive, steep and clean face. Quality rock.   Rarely visited, but often walked past for parties climbing The Ultimate Everything.  It is north facing and thus receives little sun - a great place for sky cragging in the warmer summer months.
getting_there: It is located left of the start of The Squamish Buttress (after the Apron). Once you branch left, it is on your right. If you have entered the gulley between the First Peak and Second Peak, you have gone too far.

routes.description: Climb the first pitch of the aid route Bladerunner to the two bolt anchor. Easier start leads to a technical corner followed by some fun and burly overhanging crack.
routes.location: The line starts in the centre of Kashmir wall and follows the obvious slanting crack.

routes.description: A varied line starting on a steep slanting finger crack. Climb in to a difficult slabby corner on micro cams/RP's. Continue to an overhanging layback corner with pumpy and bouldery climbing to the chains.
routes.location: Starts 2m left of Bladerunner. Kashmir Wall.
routes.protection: Full double rack RP's to BD #3's.

routes.description: An amazing climb seldom visited and unlike anything in Squamish. Steep, powerful, exposed and full value!   Climb P1 of Tintin in Tibet. Also climb the first ~ six metres of P2 of Tintin in Tibet, but where that route veers right up the corner, this route stays on the slanted slab and continues left. Follow this awkward feature for a few more metres until you reach an rest and obvious point when the moderate climbing ends. At this point, you climb a steep and exposed left-slanting crack under a roof with amazing finger locks, but horrible feet. The crux is only a few metres long, but it packs a punch. Stopping to place gear whilst campusing on finger locks my be the true crux. Once you reach a rest, regain some energy and fire straight up and along a left-facing corner to the top. This top section is moderate by comparison, but milk the rests to make sure you get the send!
routes.location: Gear to 2". Doubles in the finger size (and smaller) for the crux.

routes.description: A quality sport route that serves as a good warmup for the other routes on the wall. Located towards the left of the wall, scramble up onto an obvious ledge of stacked boulders and spot the bolts.    Easier climbing at the start leads through to some tenuous moves higher up.
routes.location: About 10 QD's + anchor material. Anchor is two large bolts.

routes.description: This route combines Kashmir and the aid route Bladerunner for some exciting free climbing in very overhanging terrain. No hardware was added to the aid pitches.P1. First pitch of Kashmir. 5.11c. Bolts.P2. Traverse across a face from the Kashmir anchors to join the third pitch of the aid route Bladerunner. 5.13b. Mixed. Wild! P3. Up a corner and in to some interesting moves pulling the lip before the chains. 5.12a. Gear.P4.  Head left from the chains up some steep face moves followed by an exciting finish around the corner to the right. 5.12a. Gear
routes.location: Start on Kashmir.
routes.protection: Gear to 3". 9? draws for first pitch.

routes.fa: Will Stanhope, Jason Kruk and Gavin Tansley (2004)
routes.description: The start is located at the right of Kashmir Wall. The first pitch ascends the obvious left slanting corner and brings you to a bolted anchor. The start of P2 is the crux of the climb as you climb right off of the belay into a right-facing crack that is awkward - good locks but marginal feet. Once you're out of this crack and onto the slanted slab above, make a right turn (continuing left is Fandangler) up the corner and into a left-facing corner. Take this corner and top out to a two bolt anchor.
routes.location: Pro to 2". Doubles in the finger sizes for P2. Some tiny pieces are helpful for P1.

routes.description: Start with difficult and runout lay backing in to a mediocre rest. Place some cams and do the V12ish boulder problem to the ledge. Head right on the ledge past a bolt to an anchor. Twin ropes or long slings is not a bad idea due to the sharp arete.
routes.location: Second pitch of Bladerunner in the middle of Kashmir Wall.

description: A little known wall with a few good multi pitch routes across the gully from the Apron.
getting_there: Approach as for Rock On but immediately after entering the gully proper cross it and pick up a cairned trail which leads you up to the wall. 3-4min after crossing gully.

routes.description: Fun route. Some steep slab with thoughtful cruxes and a jam or two. Bring a brush for the last pitch.
routes.location: 10 mins up South Gully trail, a bit below Rock On take a faint but cairned trail off left for another few mins. Up a handline and then carry on up left to a big down and leftward sloping ledge. Start of the route is a bolt at head height near the high point of the ledge.
routes.protection: ~8-10 draws with some extendables, Single rack 0.2-3". 60m rope, stations are ringed, rap route to descend.

description: The first bouldering area you encounter when driving into the North Walls.
getting_there: 0.4km from the Apron parking lot.

routes.description: This climb is on the Action Man boulder. Start matched on a low sloper 2m underneath a small jug. Traverse right onto a low sloppy rail using heel hooks. Make a big move move to a good edge and mantle out.
routes.location: Action Man Boulder

routes.description: Start on the small jug. Finish as for The Whisker.
routes.location: Action Man boulder

routes.description: On the far left of the Action Man boulder. Start on top of a small boulder. Use a high rail and traverse right.
routes.location: Action Man boulder

routes.description: Start as far right as possible on the Action Man boulder. Traverse left and mantle.
routes.location: Action Man boulder

routes.description: Climb the ramp starting low and matched on a bad sloper. Exit when it’s possible to a good hold.
routes.location: On the Lick My Lolly boulder

description: Smaller area west of the Clean Boulders on MFSR
getting_there: Park at the Clean Boulders pull off 2.4 km up MFSR. Walk to the Close Shave Boulder and turn right to walk to the Burial Grounds area

routes.description: Start matched on lowest pinch/rail. Follow this feature up and top out.
routes.location: West of the cerebellum boulder

routes.description: Crouch start matched on a decent shelf and climb up the cave through crimps and sloping edges. Bit of a tricky topout.
routes.location: Just past Tyler's Dihedral, very close to the road.

routes.description: This is a weird one...bat hang the start of Tyler's Cave (V2), then establish with difficulty on the slopers deep in the cave. Reach up to the stand start holds and top out that problem.
routes.location: Just past Tyler's Dihedral, very close to the road.

routes.description: Start seated on a flat edge and climb straight up through the dihedral.
routes.location: Obvious boulder to the left of the Burial Ground trail coming from the clean boulders

description: 1-5 mins approach.  Nowhere else in Squamish is there so many flat landings.  Quick Drying.  PM sun depending on season
getting_there: 2.4 km from hwy

routes.description: Start with crimps on either side of the arete, and some careful footwork. You can use a few intermediates, or if you have the reach, bump straight up to the slopers and the lip, throw a heel, and mantle onto the slab.
routes.location: On the Deadhead boulder, up the hill from Outrage and the main cluster when you first enter The Clear area. Battered Shrimp is facing the trail as you approach from below, the arete with a large clean slab on top.
routes.protection: Pads, landing is flat and good

routes.description: Climb the face left of the small dihedral.
routes.location: The Clean Boulders

routes.description: "Start on a slopey shelf at one metre." - Marc Bourdon, Squamish Bouldering, 3rd edition.Sit start.
routes.location: North side (facing the parking lot) of Tennis Star boulder.

routes.description: Start on a shelf and climb the right arete.
routes.location: The Clean Boulders

routes.description: “Start on dyke edges at 1.25 m. Nice Moves!” - guidebook. The moves arent actually that nice.
routes.location: In the main Clean Boulders area, right across from Close Shave.

routes.description: Right hand on the big, diagonal sloper, left hand on the crimp just under the sloper, feet on the low shelf. High step and pull to the crimpy sidepull and continue straight up. The V0 to the left is off.Start from the low crimpers to make the grade solid.
routes.location: First boulder to the right as you walk into the Clean Boulders. Across from the Tennis Star boulder.
routes.protection: Pads, the landing here is nice and flat

routes.description: Starts on high edges.  Climb short face right of small dihedral.
routes.location: Right of Blind Spot
routes.protection: Boulder pad, good for solo sessions

routes.description: Start with a left undercling and good right hand sloper, paste your feet on the face, throw to the sloping lip and mantle
routes.location: Perched boulder just opposite Kung Fu Fighter (huge boulder in the center of the area - you can't miss it)

routes.description: Traverse the lip from right to left.
routes.location: The Clean Boulders

routes.description: Start on a big edge and top out.
routes.location: Start left of dyke. On 3rd boulder in.  The one after The Wiz.
routes.protection: Boulder pad.  Good for solo sessions

routes.fa: Sam Hurley, Andrew Turner, Thad Matilda, 2001
routes.description: Sit start left of the boulder. Traverse right, and mantle just before the tree.
routes.location: You can't miss this boulder when walking from Outrage to Deadhead Boulder. It's short, wide, and has a giant log on top of it.

routes.description: Should be "Start on a high, flat shelf. Slap to a big jug and finish up and right.” - as per the guidebook
routes.location: Pads

routes.description: Start matched on the right arête (below shelf). Traverse left and top out around the middle.
routes.location: Southeast of Deadhead Boulder. Shares same boulder as Exceptional Energy and Mistakes and Failures.

routes.description: Start matched on a high sloping rail with a good left foot. Continue up and right along the rail to some deeper incuts and decent feet. Punch right to a lower crimp, then continue right to a jug flake. Top out from the flake.   (The jug flake flexed on me when I did it - didn't feel like the flake will be there for forever, and if it goes you'll fall on the fallen logs below.)   There is another V5 variation that exits directly upwards after the deeper incut section of the rail.
routes.location: On the SE face of The Hydra boulder. Descend to the north, jumping from the Hydra boulder to a smaller boulder, then down a tree.
routes.protection: Some pads and spotter(s) around the last leg of the problem where you start to get a little higher and the fall gets a little gnarlier.

routes.description: Start on a left side pull and climb up the slab.
routes.location: Same boulder as The Wiz.  On "right side" when looking at The Wiz

routes.description: Starting holds are a large left side pull and a sloping edge.  Move up to a shelf and the top.
routes.location: Same boulder but on other side from Mr. Green

routes.description: Left side pull and right sloping ramp.  Climb large features straight to top.
routes.location: Boulder pad, good for solo sessions

routes.description: Start on obvious crimps, attain a sharp undercling and maybe a side pull and slap to the juggy lip.
routes.location: Follow obvious trail uphill from first area in clean boulders.
routes.protection: a couple of pads. landing is good.

routes.description: Start left, and traverse right. Finish on same horn as The Skimmer.
routes.location: Southwest of Deadhead Boulder. Shames same boulder as The Skimmer.

routes.description: Campus from good edges until you gain the knob at the top of the boulder. Foot up, top out.
routes.location: On the first boulder as you walk in from the road

routes.description: Climb the middle, straight up to the horn.
routes.location: Southwest of Deadhead Boulder. Shares same boulder as Ramadan Traverse.

routes.description: Start by reaching to a high, angular hold. Pull on and crank through diagonal seams
routes.location: Just uphill of the Hydra boulder

routes.description: Start standing with right hand arete pinch and left hand gaston. work the feet up and move through good crimps up to topout. Best line on the boulder and good warmup for the area.
routes.location: Main area in Clean Boulders, right across from Close Shave.

routes.description: Climb the arête right of Water is Life.
routes.location: First boulder upon entering cleans.

routes.description: Start matched on the obvious left facing jug and execute a tricky mantel
routes.location: Perched boulder just opposite Kung Fu Fighter (huge boulder in the center of the area - you can't miss it)

routes.description: Start matched on a lightly sloping rail at about 6 feet.Climb directly up the vertical face.
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Start matched very low in the seam.
routes.location: The Clean Boulders

routes.description: Start this problem on a jug under the lip.  Slap the arête and to the top.  Steep and powerful.
routes.location: On 2nd boulder in.  In between the boulder with Water is Life and Double the Points

description: Great collection of unique boulders, mostly easy to moderate, with the main attraction being Secret Lives of Children.
getting_there: Take MFSR until you reach Powerhouse Springs Road. Drive up Powerhouse Springs for a minute or two until you see The Courtyard sport crag, an obvious cliff on your left. Park here and hike up the trail, passing right under The Courtyard. The trail winds around the left side of the cliff and up above it. You should reach Secret Lives in about 10 minutes.

routes.description: Crouch start with a left undercling and a right hand sidepull and bust a couple burly moves up to a jug topout. It seems like the original V6 started on the right hand crimp just next to the sidepull, but I guess most people just start on the sidepull and take V4ish?
routes.location: Follow the network of trails just above Secret Lives, you should find the Neat boulder a hundred feet beyond it. A bit scrambly in a couple places.

routes.description: The prize of the area. Start practically lying down with a right hand slot jug and left hand on a sloper. Tech your way out left through the steep roof before exiting on the tall arete above.
routes.location: Follow the trail around and up above the Courtyard crag. Keep an eye out for an unobvious hairpin left turn at a fork in the trail a few hundred feet up. You should see the Secret Lives boulder soon after.

routes.description: Stand start on an obvious pinch rail and climb right through jugs into the finish of How Neat Is That
routes.location: Up the hill from Secret Lives. You'll have to scramble up some small boulders and over a crosshatched log. Should be no more than a couple hundred feet past Secret Lives

routes.description: Start on a right sidepull crimp and bad left hand pinch and make a big, tricky move into the start stand pinch.
routes.location: Couple pads

description: Large and super dense collection of boulders off the MFSR. It's a bit of a maze, with a lot of debris and deadfall in some areas from the Sept 2021 rockfall, but there are still decent trails between most of the popular boulders.
getting_there: There are a couple approach trails accessed from the road, between .75 and .85 km from the Highway 99 junction

routes.description: Start on the lowest chalked holds and compress up the obvious dyke prow until you can make a big reach out right to the arete. Finish with a delicate rockover just below the apex. Watch out for pine needles on the upper slab!
routes.location: Just off the .85km trail and past The I. You should see a tall prow off to climber's left.

routes.description: Start with two high opposing sidepulls and execute a tricky rockup move to gain a mega jug.
Start on the jug rail and make a few powerful moves up to the lip to top out. Fun lowball!
routes.location: Best accessed from the .85 km trailhead. Just south of The I and right across from Stevie Nicks (V3).

routes.description: Right arete problem. Start matched on the incut shelf on the face and bump up the arete to a tricky lip encounter, possibly using a jug undercling around the corner on the slab.
routes.location: About 50m up the .75km trail, it's the second cluster of boulders you come upon

routes.description: Start with left hand at base of the steep ramp and right on a higher fat edge. Move up and right. Or move to the left, which is a bit harder.
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Climb the slab by the tree. Downclimbing this is more challenging than climbing up.
routes.location: Shares same boulder as Turd Ferguson, facing north.

routes.description: Start on the lowest two holds in a layback and climb directly up. Lots of hold options, and really good rock quality.
routes.location: Roadside face of the huge FAROUK boulder just next to the "II" graffiti. Most easily accessed from the .85 km trail.
routes.protection: A little high, so bring plenty of pads if this is near your limit

routes.description: Sit start, match around left-facing sidepull
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Stand start and compress slopey features until you get to an okay jug at the apex, then topout the mossy slab. A lot of hold options and different ways to do this one.
routes.location: Southeast of the huge FAROUK boulder. Hard to miss if you walk due south from the .85 km trailhead
routes.protection: Several pads, the topout is a bit high

routes.description: start squeezing neat compression boulder, crux is getting established on the obvious ledges at about halfway, then top out through easy but somewhat spooky terrain
routes.location: obvious compression prow off the trail, tall boulder

routes.description: Start on the obvious shelf, and go up.
routes.location: Shares same boulder as Slabdercling, The Sac, Fire Spire, and Tres Brujas. If you're walking from The I to The Net, you'll run into this.

routes.description: Starting on the lower right of the roof, climb up and out onto the face, exiting directly up using a high right gaston. Amazing hold quality and movement!
routes.location: Follow the main trail uphill, a couple minutes past The I and the large 911 boulder. Shanksville sits off by itself in the southeast corner of Dark Side.
routes.protection: 2+ pads and maybe a spotter. A fall at the very very top could send you rolling down the hillside

routes.description: Start on obvious far left hold over a pit, traverse right towards a jug in the center of the face, then continue traversing right through a crimpy crux just before the top out
routes.location: on the Sirius boulder, take the main trail up

routes.description: Start on right arête and left gaston. Go up and left.
routes.location: After walking from parking and reaching Arm Your Thoughts, take the right fork (westbound). Shares same boulder as False Arête and Slab World.

routes.description: Start with a left hand sloper and right hand sidepull jug, make a move or two up before executing a scrunchy mantle.
routes.location: Big boulder just past The I. Right on .85km trail so you can't miss it.

description: Small but high quality collection of problems.  Some as good or better than anything in the grand walls.  1-5 mins. approach time.  Filtered PM sun depending on season.
getting_there: 1.7km from Highway.  turn left after entering forest

routes.description: Unsure.
routes.location: Page 276 in the Squamish Bouldering guidebook (2nd Edition).

routes.description: Unsure.
routes.location: The high face just right of the arete right of detached flake.

routes.description: Start as for Chicken Lips and Assholes, but head up the center of the face without using the right arete. Finish with a big move for the lip.
routes.location: 20 meters east of the Detached Flake, just past Ressurection.

routes.description: Unsure.
routes.location: Page 276 in the Squamish Bouldering guidebook (2nd Edition).

routes.description: Face climb up the wall beside the right arete.
routes.location: On the boulder just south of "Ride the Waves" (so further from the parking), visible from the trail. The climb is the obvious line on the right side of the face.

routes.description: Start on rail holds around one metre, just left of an adjacent boulder. Climb up left into the overhang and onto the slab above.
routes.location: Turn left at detached flake an go in the cave like system across from the beautiful wavelike overhung rock.
routes.protection: 2-3 pads and a decent spot is nice

routes.description: On the corner to the left of Honey Bee (the west side of the boulder). Start seated and climb up and left along the lip using good low footholds and a heel hook to gain the mantle.
routes.location: The Farm on Chive Rock

routes.description: Sit down start.  Climb the unbelievable layback flake.
routes.location: The Farm

routes.description: Begin on the furthest left chalked sloper and traverse right along the rail. Top out above when the rail begins to peter out. Bring your mantel skills.
routes.location: Directly across from Chicken Lips and Assholes. 30 meters east of the Detached Flake.

routes.description: Slab climb on the left part of the northeast side of Chive Rock. Start with a good, low foot ledge and small crimpers.  Follow good holds up the low angle slab and top out along the edge of the highest and steepest part of the face.
routes.location: The Farm on Chive Rock

routes.description: Climb the obvious slab that goes up the center of the moss covered face.
routes.location: Just opposite Detached Flake on the Stroke of Luck boulder

routes.description: Begin on a right side pull and a sharp, left edge. Follow the scooped wall to more positive holds above and a slightly spooky topout. The problem was originally much easier before a large flake broke, significantly changing the moves.
routes.location: Large boulder on your left after ascending the main trail from Mamquam Forest Service Road. You can't miss the striking arete.

routes.description: Start right hand on obvious edge and left hand on the sloper rail that's pointing down towards the chasm of doom (It's actually not that scary). Throw your heel up before executing some really fun and powerful moves up!
routes.location: Pads

routes.description: Climb the scooped face from a stand start. Begin on small crimps above the lip and head upward over the tricky bulge.
routes.location: On the backside of the Detached Flake boulder.

routes.description: Sit start to Ride the Waves. Beginning with your left hand on a positive vertical edge and your right hand on a sloping pinch, climb up and over the lip.
routes.location: On the backside of the Detached Flake boulder.

routes.description: Cool moves on perfectly positioned holds crimps/sidepulls.  Juggy spike for the mantle.
routes.location: The Farm

description: Although home to some Squamish's best power problems, including double-digit testpieces like Squaminator and Terminator, there is still something for everyone here. Whether you're looking for a top 100 V0 or pushing into the double digits, the Lost World is worth a visit.
getting_there: From the Apron parking lot, drive east on the Mamquam Forest Service Road for 1.15 kilometers to a pullout on your left. Cross the road and take a trail that weaves directly uphill toward a giant rock that houses problems like Squaminator.   It is easy to accidentally pick the wrong pullout or trail so if you hike more than 200 meters into the forest and don't see a giant rock (it is massive - maybe 20m tall), you're likely not in the right spot.

routes.description: Start as for the V4 "Good Training", under the roof matched on the shelf, but move straight up from the holds at the lip instead of up and to the right. You can use some crimps on the face to pull up into the lieback, or grab the sidepull block with your right hand at the base of the lieback feature and bump up from there (some people use a left undercling to help), or just launch straight to the good part higher up. Also have seen people cam their right foot into the slot at the lip.
routes.location: Same boulder as Good Training, on the trail to the right. Across the trail from Squaminator.

routes.description: Start seated under the roof matched on the obvious small shelf. Move up and right through the overhand to a mantel at the lip.
routes.location: Immediately off the trail to the right (west) as you reach the Squaminator boulder.

routes.description: Do you love your Moonboard but wish you could climb it in the beautiful woods of Squamish? Then this is your problem.Start matched on a crimpy ledge at chest height and fire up to a good (but far away) right hand crimp. Top out above. May feel easier for taller climbers.
routes.location: Follow the trail up and around the backside (south side) of the Squaminator boulder. Turn right when you see a small clearing and the boulder will be toward the back.

routes.description: Start matched on a low, incut flake at 2 meters and follow the holds up and right to a slightly spooky topout.
routes.location: The north side of the Nick's Adventure boulder. Slightly left off the trail when walking up to the Squaminator boulder.

routes.description: A top 100 climb in the Squamish Bouldering guidebook and certainly worth the designation. Start in a shallow, left-facing corner and climb a diagonal crack and work leftward to the lip. A great warm-up with surprisingly engaging movement for a V0.
routes.location: As you approach the Squaminator boulder, it is immediately left (east) off the trail.

description: Moderately large area along MSFR with quality problems.
getting_there: Driving east on MFSR, the trailhead is 1.7km from the Apron parking lot. Hike uphill looking for a giant, house sized boulder. The Magic Kindom is right and uphill of this boulder

routes.description: Start on a big undercling jug and move up the face and slightly left through crimps and a big juggy sidepull. Potentially tricky topout. Don't hit your head on the tree!
Sit start on the lowest two holds and climb directly up through sloping edges.
routes.location: Small boulder just past and slightly downhill of Space Monkey

routes.description: Start with left rail and right shelf (below lip). Go up and right. The mantle is the hardest part of this boulder.
routes.location: After walking from parking and reaching Mad Cow, follow the left trail. You'll shortly find this boulder under a log.

routes.description: Begin on an edge at head height in the scoop. Find tricky feet to stand up tall into a high sidepull, traverse left on the lip, then finish with a heady mantle.
routes.location: Down the hill and west from Space Monkey, through a corridor of rock.

routes.description: Start as Space Monkey. At the mailbox, do a funky inversion with a super high heel and cross left hand on to a crack. Do a big move right and finish on Space Rubber
routes.location: Space Monkey

routes.description: Start seated on a large jug adjecent to a slabby face. Move up and right following the crack to the top of the boulder.
routes.location: Pads and spotter

routes.description: Start on two low opposing crimps and make a tricky move up to the big ledge. Top out via a large flake jug.
routes.location: Just left of Wild Kingdom. Identifiable by the huge chalked shelf.

routes.description: Start standing compressing the base of the overhanging pillar, using a flat sidepull for your right hand and a sidepull-unercling a bit lower for your left. Physical moves and heel-hooks lead out the overhang. A great feature, one that begs to be climbed!
routes.location: Behind The Tragedy boulder.

routes.description: Top 100 V5 in Squamish.
routes.location: Page 272 in the Squamish Bouldering guidebook (2nd Edition).

routes.description: Start matched on the rail and move towards the left, then straight up to top out.
routes.location: Starts on the rail to the right of Space Monkey on the same boulder.

routes.description: Start with a low left undercling and right hand on the arete. Climb directly up the fridge-style prow, possibly using some tricky high feet.
routes.location: Just past the huge Mad Cow boulder on the way to Space Monkey, take left into the forest. You should see the prominent prow of Taco Loco soon after.

routes.description: Start as for Finger Scoop of Peanut Butter but mantel straight up to the slabby face. Follow the high ramp up and right to finish.
routes.location: Pads and spotter

routes.description: Start standing matched on the lowest rail.The landing area isn't great.
routes.location: A steep stand-alone boulder wedged between two other boulders.

routes.description: Traverse the left facing lip to the apex
routes.location: Small boulder just past and slightly downhill of Space Monkey

description: The boulders located at the base of the Sheriff's Badge.
getting_there: From the Apron parking lot, walk along the forest service road past the trail for Rock On. The next access trail will get you to the boulders.

routes.description: Start seated in two slot-like crimps and climb up and left through the lip
routes.location: Just off the main trail as soon as you pass the massive End of My Rope boulder. There should be a fainter trail that leads off to the right

routes.description: relatively steep arete with some small sharp crimps. Start seated matched on obvious block and slap up the arete using whatever you can to get to the ledge at the top
routes.location: upper sherrif, look for moderately worn trail heading west from very clean tall arete just to the left of the trail (you will be walking away from this boulder)
routes.protection: pad or two, not tall may want a spotter depending on how you choose to do the last move

routes.description: It's a lot like easy in an easy chair except it goes from right to left. Traverse along the lip to the arete on the left and top out.
routes.location: Walk along the lower badge trail and turn right off the main trail after the 2nd large tree stump to a clearing between a group of boulders.

routes.description: Good techy highball.
routes.location: Decent landing.

routes.description: Traverse the the right facing lip to the apex. Tricky movement!
routes.location: Just behind Backwards in an Easy Chair

routes.description: Start left hand on an okay undercling and right hand on a sloping sidepull. Climb directly up and left using some crimps in the face and a decent pinch on the arete.
routes.location: Just past the End of My Rope boulder, you should see a faint trail leading off to climber's right.
routes.protection: Several pads to even out the landing

routes.description: Start on the obvious high jug and make a big move directly up (not out left!) to a nice, fat pinch. Top out easily, as for The Nihilist (V1).
routes.location: Just off the left of the main trail, right after you pass the End of My Rope boulder

routes.description: Traverse left across good holds.
routes.location: Page 246 in the Squamish Bouldering guidebook (2nd Edition).
routes.protection: Flat landing but relatively high so have a good pad setup.

routes.description: Start and finish. Fun and easy.
routes.location: Decent landing.

routes.description: Stand start on the left side of Backwards in an Easy Chair on opposing edges, and slap up into the topout of Backwards.
routes.location: Backwards in an Easy Chair

routes.description: Kinda tall face, start stemming in the middle of it
routes.location: N/A

routes.description: Really fun highball. Pretty technical for a V0.
routes.location: Good landing

routes.description: Try it in lots of different positions for maximum fun.
routes.location: Flat landing.

routes.description: Start matched on the diagonal crimp rail and climb directly up the technical face. Very footwork intensive.Jug topout, but don't let your guard down up there. As good as it gets!
routes.location: Planet of the Apes sits off by itself just past Laser Blade 5000. There's a faint trail that goes off to the left and over a tree.

routes.description: Sit start on the right arete, working up and left along the arete and the face to top out.
routes.location: On the Re-Up boulder, to the right of Re-Up V5.

routes.description: Hard first move for a V0.
routes.location: Decent landing

routes.description: Technical
routes.location: Page 248 in the Squamish Bouldering guidebook (2nd Edition).

routes.description: Start matched on the low jug rail. Fight the barn door as you work your way up and right.Bust left to the lip at the nose of the boulder and figure out how to snag the jug at the top.
routes.location: Located in the lower Sheriff Badge area in the Squamish Bouldering guide.

routes.description: Climb your way up and right out of the overhang on jugs. Top out directly above on the exposed face.
routes.location: N/A

description: A steep roadside boulder littered with hard and often mossy problems. This one doesn't seem to get a ton of traffic.Downclimb the right side of the slab that faces the road. There are plenty of holds and the climbing is quite secure once you find them.
getting_there: Take Mamquam Forest Service Road to its junction with Powerhouse Springs Road, then turn left on Powerhouse Springs Road. The Swamp Thing is the unmistakable large, steep boulder on the right side of the road a few minutes down.

routes.description: Start standing in the dihedral with a low left hand nubbin and high right hand undercling, then power up through juggy ledges and a crimp or two.
routes.location: Facing the boulder from the road, this problem is on its left side in the second slight overhang. (The first overhang, with the long obvious undercling feature, is a different, harder problem.)
routes.protection: 1-2 pads. The hard moves are very easy to protect.

routes.description: Start sitting with a wide pinch undercling for the left hand and a left-facing shelf for the right. Power up through good holds to a sloping topout with a few key positive holds.
routes.location: Facing the boulder from the road, this one's on the right side wall.
routes.protection: 1-3 pads depending on your comfort level. The landing is pretty clean and it's not too tall, so you don't really need a spotter.
routes.route_name: It's My Duty to Please Da' Booty

description: The dark, north facing section of the Chief left of Angel's Crest and the North North Gully holds some of the area's hardest, purest and longest free climbs.  Testpieces like Alaska Highway and The Calling make this the realm of the honed.  Some slightly more accessible pitches can be found along with some single pitches routes.   The wall is split horizontally at mid-height by the Zodiac ledge, which can be reached by any of the long routes that start from the ground, or by scrambling up from the far left side.   The north facing aspect can make this a cool place in the heat, but also makes it slower to dry and shortens the spring and fall season compared to the rest of the chief.  Expect a little extra dirt and munge than other areas on The Chief.
getting_there: Approach as for Angel's Crest, but once at the base, head up the gully a touch further until you are on a very flat boulder with a cairn indicating a rough trail that heads left under the wall.  This area isn't well traveled so the trails are rough and prone to overgrow or be hidden by seasonal debris.

routes.description: Alaska Highway ascends an imposing system of overhanging corners and chimneys...   When arriving at the belay after  the second pitch, try and recall if you've done aid pitches that took as long to finish, then think of Steve "Roadie" Seats soloing this pitch.    This route deserves its reputation. Not so much because p2 is the hardest pitch you'll ever climb, but because few pitches will challenge your repertoire of granite trickery as this. Improv at its finest.Pitch one begins with some steep arboreal fiddling to a hanging belay below a roof. Many fixed nuts. Scruffy. 10d   Pull into the powerful traversing undercling and onto a sloping ledge. Did you think it was over?...nope! Continue up the steeply overhanging groove/chimney. Like vertical break dancing...   11c/d   The third pitch may be the best 5.11a in town. 35m of steep laybacking and finger locks are rewarded by a traverse to a cool stump/gear belay. 11a   Layback on great finger locks to a chimney/off-width and on to a ledge after some face moves.10c   A thin n' crimpy seam leads to a crux hand traverse. Face climb to the ledge. You're done. 11aThree raps from the last anchor will get you back down to the ground. Pay attention to the third, and final, station way out (climbers) right...it's easy to miss. Walk down a steep trail from a treed ledge to the start. Go drink a beer.If you can finish "The Calling" after this; it's official, you're fit.    Many belay bolts need to be replaced and repositioned IMO. Any volunteers?
routes.location: North Walls. Approach via Angels Crest and cut left across the scree of the north gully at a cairn by the start of The Crest. Walk 30m past Astrologger and thrutch up some dirty, loose blocks and a ratty fixed line.
routes.protection: Gear to #3 Camalot, doubles from .5 to #2. 2 green and yellow aliens each and a selection of medium stoppers. 8 long runners.   2 60m ropes for descent. Can also be descended by foot to the North-North Gulley

routes.description: "I hope you ate your Wheaties" (TM).  Astrologger is on good rock and is an attractive line, but the necessary difficulty in getting to it and its lonely position mean that it is seldom traveled. If you could climb the top alone, or the route had been cleaner, I would have given this 3 or 4 stars.    As well, its given grade of 11b is way out of line with other local grades and is sandbagged sufficiently so as to be hard on the Ego.   To avoid an awkward scramble, we elected to lead up the "approach pitch" past the anchors and combine this into a single pitch. The opening is A0, french-freeing a fixed line to the first of several bolts, then 5.10 climbing up on good but dirty holds (I cleaned these, but rain might restore their dirty condition), to an anchor. The climbing is sufficient to assure that you will not arrive to the anchor at 'the base' in fresh condition, and the climbing right off this anchor starts off tough and gets tougher.  From the anchor get up a leaning, overhanging flake, (1.5" gear) get into the corner (2" gear) and then fight your way up the corner on slick thin jams (2-2.5" gear) with an occasional wide piece. The crux comes about 1/3 the way up the main pitch, but the rest is still exhausting.  At the top the climbing relaxes back to 5.10 after a few good jams (3") and is a thinner crack (fingerlocks) to reach a serviceable bolt-and-chain anchor.
routes.location: Approach as for the Sheriff's Badge and continue North to the North Walls. Heading up into the Gully as for Alaska Highway, you will be perhaps 40 meters from intercepting the wall on the left when you come over a HUGE flat-topped boulder and see a large rock-pile (Cairn) on your left. Turn left and follow the light path (I dare not call it a trail) to the rock and keep and eye up on the wall at eye level for a fixed and knotted line with bolts above, and the bolt line to the anchor below the steep left-facing acute dihedral/flake.
routes.protection: Either a short batman up a fixed line to 4 bolts (dirty 5.10) to an anchor at the base, or do a messy scramble from the left to the base, then:  Two 1.5" cams, (or 2 purple camalots)  Three 2.0" cams (or 3 green camalots)  Three 2.5" cams (or 3 red camalots)  two 3" cams (or two yellow camalots)  and finally a 1" or a .75" cam or two for the top. (or a blue or grey micro camalot)   To reach a set of chains.  That should put in pretty tightly spaced pro.  YMMV.

routes.description: This climb ascends the exposed arete to right of High Plains Drifter. Excellent, varied crack and face climbing. Some of the best positions on the Chief.   Pitch 1. 5,12c. Overhanging tips layback. Difficult moves around lip (crux) lead to easier hand crack which peters out to tricky face climbing exit.   Pitch 2. 5.12a. Beautiful exposed arete climbing with amazing crimps and multiple cruxes. Bolted but a 00 tcu and yellow alien were used to protect the exit. Down climb ledge to belay below pitch 2 of High Plains Drifter.   Pitch 3. 5.11c. Climb crux pitch of the Drifter.
routes.location: Approach as for High Plains Drifter at vetical gulley that leads to the Drifter, continue 10 meters along main ledge and pull into alcove at the base of pitch one.
routes.protection: One set of cams to gold bd. extra tiny cams, green c3 seemed critical to protecting crux. Nuts.

routes.fa: D Hart, R Atkinson 1986. FFA of P4 by D Hart later
routes.description: The Calling boasts one of the best splitter dihedral cracks in Squamish. You can get there by climbing Alaska Highway to Astro Ledge then traversing left 30' or by taking Astro Ledge instead of climbing AK Hwy. If you only climbed P1 - 3, this would be an absolute 5 star classic. The pitches above are dirty and chossy and detract.   P1 (11d): Starting from Astro Ledge at a two bolt anchor go up the obvious corner with a hard move off the ledge. Mostly bolted and past fixed pins/wires, plus a small piece or two to a two bolt anchor (hanging belay).   P2 (11d/12a): New books upgraded this pitch to 12a. This is the classic splitter corner on the cover of Alpinist 35. Fingers to off fingers to .75 camalot to #1 to #2s to a bolted anchor (hanging belay). If you really want the mega pitch, link P1 & 2 for full value. You could place 3x #1s on this pitch but not necessary. Alternately, the book shows that you can link this pitch into the next one in 50m. You could use 3x #1s if linking this way. You probably cannot link P1,2 &3 into the super-mega-pitch.   P3 (5.10+): If you belayed on bolts at the end of the last pitch, get back into the splitter for 30' then up into the chimney roof. If you only brought 1x #3 then bump it as you pull the roof and leave it above. You could bring a second #3 if you wanted. Don't wear a pack in the chimney. Climb to the top of the splitter and traverse on undercling fingers to a bolted belay (hanging belay).   Side note: a partial linkup variation of Alaska Highway to The Calling but ending here at the end of P3 on the Calling and rapping out is called "Southern Lights". This is my recommendation. This way is an absolute 5 star classic. The following pitches aren't that good and get REALLY dirty. Seemed like you could rap off with a single 70 but I'm not positive. Might want to bring two ropes if rapping. Linking AK Hwy and all of the Calling is called "Northern Lights".   P4 (5.12a): Sport pitch (maybe a gear placement). Right around the corner and into the dihedral (tricky start). Continue up this rather dirty corner past bolts then left up onto the face and a stance. Pull the crux (maybe 12a for a tall person but way harder for a short person, or A0). Pass a few more bolts to a bolted anchor on a super dirty slab with 6" think moss everywhere and be perplexed as to where you should go to navigate the dirtiness on the next pitch.   P5 (5.10 moss & choss): From the belay there are two bolts. One is out right towards a cool looking crack but the slab seemed plenty harder than 5.10 and runout (and was really dirty and mossy friction climbing). I don't think the route goes this way as the book says "rock continues to deteriorate in the bushy corner above". Look up and slightly left of the belay. There is a bolt about 25' up hiding in the moss. You will see an old pin with tat on the vert wall above it. Go up that way (there's also two bolts next to the pin), clip, go right into the bushy corner. Climb poor quality rock up then left across a loose 4th class ramp to a ledge. Belay here on gear in kitty litter or on a tree or off an old single smc bolt.   P6 (5.10+): Another pretty dirty pitch with subpar rock takes to you the top. Start up the corner, then past the pins on the face, back to the crack, pulling the #2 roof, then right through one more roof with undercling lock. Mantle the sandy ledge. Belay off a tree.   Descent: Go straight right along the cliff edge for 5 minutes (past the big cave/chimney) until you're forced up and into a switchback. Go to the Chief summit and walk down the Chief trail.
routes.location: On the North Walls starting above Alaska Highway on Astro Ledge. Just Left of Yukon Gold. Approach via Alaska Highway or scramble up via Astro Ledge. If you do top the route out, go straight right along the cliff edge for a while following a well beaten path (go around right of the massive chimney cave thing, do NOT switchback after the first 50m of walking). Make a switchback after about 5 - 10 minutes of walking. Follow the well beaten path past red tape. Take this up to the summit area then wander back down via the Chief trail.
routes.protection: The guidebook rack says 2x 1/2" to 3.5" with 3x 1.5" - 2" and 2 sets of wire, RPs to 1". Now that the first pitch is mostly bolted, you can get away with less. I think a standard double rack from green alien to #2 camalot plus a #3 camalot would be fine. You could take a third .5, #1 or #2 camlot, especially if linking the enduro corner. Also take 12 draws / shoulder slings. All anchors are beefy bolts until the last one on route and the topout.

routes.description: Face climbing up a vertical offset to a hand traverse with a crux mantle. Continue up the obvious right facing corner, a 5.10 crux occurs at the transition into the deep flared corner above. Surf the tube to the anchor.Big thanks to everyone who gets stoked on our new climbs and continue to encourage us. Much gratitude those who have contributed some of their hard earned dollars to the Sea to Sky Route Development gofundme campaign. Funds go directly to high quality bolts and anchors used on routes such as this.https://www.gofundme.com/seatoskyroutedevelopment
routes.location: This is obvious corner between Forgotten Flake and Astrologger.
routes.protection: 3 bolts and then a standard rack with emphasis on bigger finger to hand size cams. 35m - a 70m rope just makes back to the ground.

routes.description: Chilkoot Pass is a two-pitch variation finish to the excellent climb of The Calling. It avoids the final two pitches of the Calling, which are overgrown, uneventful and rarely climbed. This variation keeps the climbing in the sustained 5.11 range. Both pitches are varied, exciting and fun! They are full value after previously climbing to this point!   This variation begins near the end of the fourth (aka. crux) pitch of the Calling. After pulling the crux on this pitch, veer immediately right on a small ledge to a two bolt anchor. This cuts the fourth pitch of the Calling short by ~ 30 feet and avoids the run out moves on the moss minefield slab that The Calling continues up.    P1: Make easy moves and clip a bolt to the right of the anchor. Down climb a few feet on a hanging slab and make a few slab moves as you angle rightward and up. Gain a slabby crack, which leads to an obvious crack on a headwall. Climb the thin-hands crack, which narrows to fingers at the end. Pull into a slabby right-facing corner which angles rightward. Gear anchor. 5.11+   P2: This pitch works its way through the two intimidating small roofs that are obvious from the anchor immediately above. Clip two bolts as you face climb slightly right to the entrance of the first roof and, once established under the roof, hand traverse left to the obvious entrance of the first roof.  Take a quick rest with perfect hand jams and prepare to pull yourself, on great jug(s) and finger lock(s), up into a small a small alcove. Pull yourself into the alcove. Clip a bolt to the left of this alcove (to prevent rope drag) and take an optional seated rest as you admire Squamish below. Stiff and tight underlining and/or ring-locks get you through the second roof, which leads to a finger-to-hand crack in a right-facing corner. Ride this to crack to the ledge with one quick roof to battle with en route. Tree anchor. 5.11+   Topo and description by Matt Maddaloni:  mattmaddaloni.com/Chilkoot%…   Description by Paul Cordy:  climblife.blogspot.ca/2007/…
routes.location: The climb ends to the right of The Calling. Same descent as The Calling. The descent can be tricky if you've never been up there before and/or it is dark. It also has a couple exposed steps. Be careful.
routes.protection: Standard Squamish rack. Doubles to 2" with one 3" maybe?

routes.description: I'm not sure why High and Dry is often suggested to be climbed through the left start. Come From Away is the direct start to that climb and deserves its own route description.Also, I found Come From Away easier than High and Dry (upper)Starts in a hand crack, quickly turns into a very wide beast (7")After this you get a 5" crack which at the top of you can get a super great knee jam.Above this is an overhanging very wide crack. I chose to layback this section with great knee-bar option.Above this is wide, but with options on the face to avoid a lot of jamming techniques and thinner inside for smaller cams.Definitely bring BD C4 #3s, #4s, #5s, and #6sI found I had too much rope drag to finish High and Dry, so I built a mid-anchor to bring my partner up.
routes.location: Direct start to High and Dry

routes.description: Crafted by the skilled hands of Didier Berthod over several years of dedicated effort, this awe-inspiring route gracefully traces the captivating curve of The North Walls. It demands a heroic feat – a daring swing (v9) onto the path of The North Star – before seamlessly merging into a climactic ascent culminating in an airy V7 boulder problem. A testament to precision and passion, this climb stands as a testament to the artistry of Berthod's first ascent.Don't let the hike deter you, this is a 6/5 climb.
routes.location: 1x Blue Metolius/Red C3/ Black Totem sized cam.4x (ish) 0.34x (ish) 0.41x #11x 0.2

routes.description: This is a proper North Wall offering that will always live up to its name and has everything from fingers to squeeze.Start in a corner and climb up into an alcove beneath a short offwidth roof. Work out the offwidth to a good stance then follow the long corner/crack system above. If you still have large cams when you reach the first anchor, carry on up the short offwidth above.From the lower anchor, a single 70m rope will get you down. From the higher anchor, rappel twice.The corner above the upper anchor looks attractive but is always wet, and the face to its left is composed of massive, leaning, flakes of dubious stability.
routes.location: The start is one minute to the right of High And Dry, and 30 ft. off the trail, above a vegetated slope.

routes.description: A fantastic climb that does not get the attention it deserves!    Memorable crack climbing that is sustained in the 3"-4" range.   The climb is located on Astro Ledge, approximately half-way between Parallel Passages / Public Image and The Calling. It is located on a slightly overhung orange and white wall.   There is no real anchor at the start, but rather one bolt which can be backed up by slinging a nearby tree.    All anchors bolted.   P1: Make some easy moves on sketchy and loose rock until you can reach a fixed rope. Batman up this rope until its end. Climb twin-broken cracks, clipping one bolt en route, until you can enter an alcove-type feature in the middle of the wall. Climb the crack in the back of this feature as it widens from fingers to wide hands. Once at the end, pull a small roof and continue up the 3"-4" crack to the base of a left-facing corner. 5.11a   P2: Climb the obvious left-facing corner. The crack is fairly sustained in the 4" range, but there are several bolts en route to clip. There are several features on the wall that make the climbing easier than it appears. The final few feet feature some simple off-width moves. Climb through this and find the anchor to the right and below the roof. 5.10b   Rappel the route with one 70m rope. It might be possible with one 60m? It would be VERY close on the first rappel.
routes.location: Doubles to BD #4.

routes.description: FA: 10/2014 - Ben Stanley, Dom Ngo   FFA: 03/2015 - Jon Rigg, Ben Stanley   A route for the wide lovers. The offwidth on this climb stays dry even during the rainiest winter days.  Climb the corner system to the right of Nanook and make delicate moves right to gain the ever widening offwidth.
routes.location: Take the N.N. Gully trail and climb the single pitch offwidth 10 m right of Nanoonk (or 40 m right Tall Skinny People)   30m rappel to get down.

routes.description: Challenging climbing on bolts in an AMAZING position on a part of the Chief that sees little traffic? Sign me up. While all of the hardest climbing is bolted, this is not a sport climb. There are some decent runouts and heads-up moments throughout.P1. Climb the first pitch of New Life. 50m, 5.10bP2. Walk right to the end of the ledge until you can traverse right and move around a corner (crux, exposed!). Once around the corner, keep traversing on poor crimps, good underclings, and smeary feet until you can stem across the cavernous chimney and reach the belay station on the other side. The end of this pitch is pretty gripping to follow; the first ascensionists recommend clipping the first bolt of P3 to protect the second. 5.11d, about 15m.P3. What you came for. Move up and right from the belay around the corner to the face (an alpine on the first bolt will help reduce rope drag. Then get ready for what feels like an eternity of techy, sustained climbing that weaves between the face and the arete. The first crux comes about halfway up, when the angle of the face kicks back to slightly overhanging. This is followed by an easier section (5.10a-ish) of crack and face climbing which is protected with gear (you could also set up a gear belay here). The second (in my opinion, much harder) crux comes immediately after this section. BETA WARNING: it involves slapping between a lefthand vertical rail and a righthand arete until you can get a high foot and pull a delicate rockover move to clip the next bolt. After the second crux, a couple more bolts bring you to the huge belay ledge. Look up and left for the anchor. 50m, 5.12- (the first ascensionists claim 12a, but that's a bit of a sandbag)P4. The final pich follows Nanook's rappel route. Although there are some beautiful cracks and cool movement, as of writing, this pitch was dirty and overgrown, and very out-of-character with the quality of the rest of the route. If you arrive here and this is still the case, then rapping is reccommended. If you choose to continue, then head up a crack choked with sketchy, horrible treestumps until you can get in a fist sized cam. A few grunty moves past a wide section get you to some hand jams, then an alcove where you can chill out. Move up right from this along a cool, detached flake, which brings you to a horizontal, leftward finger traverse (save that black totem for this). From here, climb a tight hands to fist crack (0.75 to #1 camalots) for about 8m.
