A  steep, beautiful north facing corner at the outside edge of the wall. It is gained by climbing the cracks to its right, off the ledge.  Step left into the corner and jam and stem to the crux just below the exit.  This is protected by an old pin, with great gear placements everywhere that will allow for a little old fashioned AO if needed.  Step up onto the ledge to a bolt belay, bring the second up, then rap down and do it again! (5.10C)  Pitch 6: Follow easy ledges that wander up to the base of the Raven's Castle. (5.6)  Climb one of the Raven's Castle routes to the top, or move right around the bottom of the rock to pick up easier trails.  descend via the tourist trail down the back.
routes.location: From the top of Memorial Crack or Rock On, find the obvious trail heading up through the trees and trending right to the base of the wall.  There are several fainter trails, but they all lead to the start of the first pitch, which is below several small roofs.
routes.protection: Standard rack with gear up to 3 inches.  Singles on most everything will be fine with finger to small hand size pieces for the crux pitch, with stoppers at the bottom of the same.  A .75 Camalot works nicely above the pin at the crux on Pitch 5

description: South facing slab at the back of the First peak
getting_there: From the chief campground, hike the first peak trail until it branch to the second peak, go up the switchback of the second peak gully the slab are on your left.

routes.description: Pitch 1 : Steep bulge an traverse to the left at the start of a sike.(10c, 20m)Pitch 2 : Amazing climbing on a dyke, short pitch (10b, 15m)Pitch 3 : More dyke climbing bring you to a crack and a small roof. Belay on a ledge, then scramble 50 meter up and walk 200m right to a big boulder under a steep corner crack  (10c, 25m)Pitch 4 : Beautiful corner crack wide hand to finger, tree belay on a ledge (5.8, 20m)Pitch 5 : Slab climb to a crak, tree belay (5.11a, 15m) hike 100m to the rightPitch 6 : Pick your line up the 3 bolted routes and enjoy the few from the First peak (middle line is 10a, easiest)
routes.location: The start of the climb is located just where switchback of the second peak gully are the closest from the wall, 2 bolt on a bulge,

description: The great flat wall Right of the black dike, squeezed between the grand wall and the Bulletheads.  This cliff hold such beauties as Freeway(11C/D), The Tantalus Wall(11c+4pa), and one of north Americas best slab climbs, Cerberus(11D PG-13/R).
getting_there: Hike up the grand wall trail to the base of exasperator.  From there keep on hiking climbers right passing the black dike, and wha la, you climbing awaits you.

routes.fa: 1969 Eric Lance, T. DeGuistini, Brian Norris / FFA : 09/09/2008 Stanhope, Kruk
routes.description: Popular 5 pitches aid climb, has seen two free ascents.Pitch 1 : Gong flake : C2,  4 hooks mood bring you to the bolt ladder, with some rivets at the end of the bolt ladder hook left and pendulum in the corner to join a tree and a 3 bolts belay with chain.Pitch 2 : C2 Right on the ledge, up in the corner closing in a thin seam copperhead size to0 2 bolts, nuts, few copper heads, you may need a beak depend what's in place. Chain anchorsPitch 3 :Pitch 4 :Pitch 5 :
routes.location: Approach via the Freeway trail, starting on the corner of the climber's parking lot of the Chief.You can see the obvious gong flake at the start and the bolt ladder.
routes.protection: 3 sets cams to 1”, 2 2”, 1 3”  5 heads, selection   2 #1 peckers  2 sets, nuts and rps  2 sets of hooks  2 rivet hangers for the bolt ladder

routes.description: Follow Tantalus Wall or Milk Run for 3 pitches to the halfway ledge, or rap in to the upper pitches.  Move up right 15M and gain a superb dike trending right across the wall(9 Bolts, 10D).  The next pitch, turning through the roof is long and sustained, following the dike the whole way(14 bolts, 11D).  Climb a hollow flake (SKETCH!!!) to a belay(11D). A tricky start on the second to last pitch scares some away(11D).  Save a #2 and #3 Camalot for the last pitch.
routes.location: At the start of the Yosemite Pinnacle, or milk run.  Walk down.
routes.protection: Bolts and Gear.  Always be prepared for rain and to bail.

routes.description: This 5 pitch route is one of the most continuously difficult multi pitches in Squamish. P1. 5.12d. A. Boyd. Face climb up the bolt line to the right of Cannabis Wall placing some small pro at the flake mid pitch.P2. 5.13b. J. Smith. Traverse right on a thin dyke until all holds disappear. Go another 10 ft right through impossible looking terrain to the belay at P2 of Milk Run.P3. 5.12b. A. Boyd. Climb up and left following bolts through fun bouldery climbing.P4. "The Lightning Bolt" 5.12a. A Boyd. Head up and left on underclings following the awesome feature. All gear.P5. "Good Boy Scoutie" 5.13d. J. Smith. Head up and right on bolts through improbable moves on chicken heads. Bring a green alien if you don't want to run out the final 5.10 section.P6. 5.11a. Head up and right on bolts to reach the belay.Finish up Midnight Run or Crescent Ramp.
routes.location: In between Cannabis Wall and Milk Run.
routes.protection: Set of draws and a double set of cams to Red C4.

routes.fa: Andrew Boyd, Damien Kelly, Klise Kelly, 2003
routes.description: Climb to the top of Milk Run, step left to a line of 4 bolts.  Climb an outstanding crackline that splits the wall (11C).  Climb another pitch to a roof with a FP (11C/D).  Traverse left on a Stenuous pitch (11B).  Lead off bolts to a slanting dike with a small crack system (11D).  Traverse to the belay, weird pro (11A).  A short boulder problem on rope leads to the top of the final headwall (12A/B).
routes.location: Left of the Tantalus Wall.

routes.description: After a new first pitch, the route follows the best three pitches of Milk Run before following cracks above and a final dyke finish. The best pitches are the 10b and 10d fingery corners (3 and 4) of Milk Run, with the second one being the crux. The climbing on the crux pitch is exceptionally sustained on excellent finger locks and as much gear as one wants to place. The final real pitch (8) is a memorable walk sideways along a featured dyke.
routes.location: Tantalus Wall. From the base of the wall, walk right, uphill, for 50m to a wooded platform. A V-crack marks the start.   Descent: walk off via the Bellygood Ledge trail.
routes.protection: rack fingers to #4 with triples or quadruples in the finger sizes for the blockbuster corner pitch. All but the corner pitches have at least one bolt. All anchors are bolted for rappel.

routes.description: Yet another Peter Croft and Tammy Knight tour-de-force.  A devious couple of pitches take you to a spectacular corner system   P1. Climb the obvious path through the moss and bushes past some surprisingly tricky and committing moves until you emerge from the vegetation and the wall sweeps out to your left (5.7).  You could belay here, but there's no reason not to carry on to the station for Rock Loggers rather than belaying from the forest.  There are two choices for getting there.  You can head straight up to the first bolt on Tantalus Wall and then aid left to a groove and downclimb the groove to the station.  This presents difficulties for protecting the second on the traverse and the downclimb as the groove is overgrown and slick when wet.  The other option is to immediately traverse straight out left on some bolts.  This was wet so we opted for the groove, which was also wet and unpleasant.   P2. Head up the obvious left facing crack until it arches around to become an undercling.  It apparently goes free at 11d, but is called 10c if you use the second and third bolt for aid.  After the bolts it continues to head left and the holds appear to die out just before you reach the corner.  The trick here is to downclimb about ten feet, then go left into the corner and back up to the station. (5.11d or 5.10c A0)   P3. This beautiful left facing corner has great locks, takes great pro and is one of the most sustained pitches of its grade around. (5.10b).   P4. The spectacular corner continues and is long and steep. (5.10d).   You can rappel here (double ropes), continue up Midnight Run, or take a 5.8 pitch to join up with pitch 5 of Tantalus Wall.  You can also connect up with the start of Cerberus.
routes.location: Starts as for Tantalus wall.  Essentially, walk right along the base of the Chief from Freeway, past a nice open area beside a slab with two prominent bolted dykes until the trail heads uphill and into a bit more vegetation.  A cleared path up the wall is obvious.
routes.protection: Doubles of cams from finger to hand.  Triples of the finger sizes (.3 through .75 Camalots) are great.  Some micro cams (green C3 in our case) are key for P2.  The corners take great nuts, but they're so sustained that plugging cams is much more convenient.

routes.type: Trad, Sport, Aid, 8 pitches, Grade IV
routes.description: A distinctive crack line from the base of the Tantalus wall using french ethics. 1st pitch: 11C. Take the left hand crack to the impeccable Yosemite Crack. Classic Offwidths take you to the top of the 3rd pitch (10A). Easy 4th to Tantalus ledge (5.8). A small finger crack leads to the cedar tree (11B). Use AO bolts Tensioning to the base of the headwall crack system (11A+4pa). Climb two 5.11's to the top of the headwall. Gear to 4 1/2" for the hand cracks and offwidth.
routes.location: Scramble up the bullethead gully right below the Yosemite pinnacle.
routes.protection: Gear to 4 1/2" for the hand cracks and ofwidth.  Some bolts.

routes.description: A classic climb in a stunning position, and likely the shortest aid route in Squamish. Wrist Twister is among the easiest aid routes (that are still aid routes and not free climbs) - it's a good next step after Cannabis Wall (C2, 5p). This route involves equal shares of old/new rivets, questionable fixed heads and fun hooking. Good pro and 3/8" bolts are infrequent enough to keep you on your toes the whole time.P1 (45m): climb thoughtfully off the deck into a long, left-arching rivet ladder which ends at an intermediate 2-bolt anchor. Continue past this anchor leftwards into a traversing mini roof/flake then head up the face to the anchor. C2P2 (35m): this pitch heads straight up the wall and is quite sustained. Lots of fixed heads (of varying quality), some rivets, and then fun hooking moves lead you to the anchor. A fall (while safe) might zipper a sizeable portion of the pitch, so try not to. C2+P3 (45m): a reachy move off the belay takes you into the final brief crack system. A series of continuous rivets and hook moves lead you upwards to the dyke. Do some engaging hook moves along the dyke for a couple of meters then quest directly upwards through bat holes and rivets. C2+
routes.location: Start on the same platform as the free climbs Cerebus and Call of the Sirens but head vertically up the wall on the features described in P1.
routes.protection: Cams: DR to 1", offsets very usefulNuts: 1-2 sets offset nutsHooks: doubles including pointedRivet hangers: varietyBeaks: 1-2 sets of straightsA single 1.5" and 2" cam can provide a solid ground anchor to make the P1 belay much comfier.There are two bolt anchors at the top of every pitch.* A heading and bolting kit (and the knowledge to use them) are recommended as Squamish aid routes aren't repeated regularly and old fixed gear may be missing or need replacing. *

routes.fa: Hammish Mutch, Mavis McCuaig, Glenn Woodsworth, 1965. Recleaned in 2011 by Bruce Kay
routes.description: Nice dihedral climbing. We approached this by Jeremy Frimer's new 1st pitch of Milk Road. The book description is to start via Tantalus Wall 1st pitch with the 11c A0 move and cutting left below pinnacle to get on the left side. The Milk Road  1st P is nice and clean, 5 bolts at the 11d/ or 10b A0.   Pitch 2 after MR approach is short right traverse to sod climbing up a ramp that runs into the 10a corner of YPLS. There is a good new anchor at top of this pitch.  Pitch 3,10b, prepare for intense chimney with a bolt to gladly clip.
routes.location: far right end of Tantalus Wall. 2 double rope raps from top of Pinnacle heading for the Tantalus anchor on the right side of the pinnacle, or continue up Tantalus Wall route. Maybe single rope raps would work down the route, but I don't remember how far it is from top of pinnacle to the 10a bolted anchor.
routes.protection: Standard rack to 3". I did not have any bigger gear, not sure if it would help in the chimney, maybe nice to have big Bros.

description: Sunny in the morning this crag has late afternoon shade.   Super steep bomber granite with sport and trad climbs. An ideal place to espace the crowd.
getting_there: Follow the trails leading to the 3rd peak. The cliff is at the junction of third peak trail and the trail that leads to the cirque.

routes.description: The steep dihedral that widens quickly from 1 to 9 inches. Bolted anchor.The name means 'hummingbird' in Squamish.
routes.location: This route is not at White Cliff proper, but is just off the Third Peak trail, several minutes before White Cliff.Turn off the First Peak trail onto the Third Peak trail and, after one or two minutes, you will see a shed-sized, pyramid-shaped, undercut boulder to the left of the trail. Go around the boulder and up a vegetated slope to the base of the steep corner.

routes.fa: Jim Campbell, R. Gordon (1978).       FFA: Perry Beckham (1986)
routes.description: Awesome looking finger. Haven't climb it yet but its looks thin!
routes.location: The striking finger splitter to the right of the sport climbs. Can't miss it!

description: This crag is of the same character as the rest of the valley, it's mostly shady with big trees and no road noise.
getting_there: When you get to the bottom of the gully of death, head left less than 100 yards. The first pitch starts up bouldery flake with a shiny bolt to protect the first difficult moves then trends up a left facing corner system.

routes.description: Pitch one, Avalon: 10c. The pitch has a difficult bouldery start protected by a bolt. There is a nice jug in the shallow left facing corner, climb the nice finger sized flake crack up staying mostly to the left. There are anchor bolts on a roomy ledge at the top.  Pitch two, Pyrix: 10a. (this pitch can be linked into the first pitch) It is short and follows a groove up the arete. It packs a punch for 10a.  Pitch three, Closing Number: 10c. To get to the start of the pitch, walk maybe 30 feet back in to the forest from the top of the second pitch There will be a giant wide chimney, scramble up the left side of the chimney ( 10 feet of 5.easy moves) gain a nice open ledge covered in salal bushes. The route starts from the right side of this ledge and hand traverses up in a beautiful and burly crack. A bolt protects the first difficult crux through a roof. Fun!
routes.location: At the bottom of the gully of death turn left and walk about 100 yards. The route starts in a wavy shallow left facing corner system. There is a shiny bolt maybe 10 feet off the ground protecting the the starting crux boulder sequence. You can see the other two bolts on the first pitch as well.
routes.protection: Standard rack up to gold camalot. three bolts protect the thin cruxy sections on the first pitch, one bolt protects the initial move on the second pitch, and there are two bolts protecting the difficulties on the last pitch. Two-bolt anchors at the top of each pitch, there may or may not be cords with bail biners/rings to rap off... but you can walk through the fields of salal bushes back to the the top of the gully of death pretty easily.   Warning: the Valley of Shaddai gets very little traffic and so there tends to be some cobwebs and pine needles on most of the routes. Bring a nut tool to scrape out the holds, and/or a little brush.

description: This is the south-facing wall south and uphill from the base of Avalon Connection.
getting_there: Taking the trail that starts across from the lake at Murrin Park, you encounter this area on the descent from Quail's Gate Col.

routes.description: The handcrack to the left of Desperate Echo.  Bolted anchor.This route hadn't been cleaned and there were no anchors on the trees above but it may have been climbed in the 90s when other routes in the area were being put up. If anyone has previous ascent information, please let me know and I will update the information here.
routes.location: Just upslope from Desperate Echo.

routes.fa: FA: Glenn Payan, Jeff Thomson (1 PA), 1998;  FFA: Jack Fieldhouse, 1998
routes.description: Facey/ bouldery moves past a couple of bolts lead to steep wide climbing.
routes.location: This is the obvious crack near the bottom of the descent from Quail's Gate Col.
routes.protection: A couple of bolts and gear to 6 inches.

description: This is probably the crown jewel of The Valley of Shaddai.  Pictures don't do this formation justice; it's quite spectacular when approached.
getting_there: From the bottom of the gully (Death Gully), head south on a vague trail, crossing the creek (dry in the summer) several times.  After ten or fifteen minutes this boilerplate wall should come into view on the right.

routes.fa: FA G. Payan and J. Thompson, July 1998, FFA Jack Fieldhouse, Aug 1998
routes.description: This is the left arete at The Pillar of Payan.  This is one of the longest and consistently difficult sport climbs in Squamish.  The whole thing is just one long technical crux, brutally difficult to figure out initially, but it succumbs to being worked as once the moves are figured out, it's not as physical as most routes at the grade.   This route on its own is worth the trip into The Valley of Shaddai.
routes.location: At least 14 bolts to a two bolt anchor.  After the last bolt, the climbing gets easier, but a few cams (.5 to #2 Camalot) took the sting out of the unknown.

routes.fa: Glenn Payan, Jeff Thomson and John Thompson  Aug. 1997
routes.description: If you're going to make the trek to the Valley of Shaddai then this route is a must while you're there.  Climb the left facing dihedral for about 35' to a nice ledge and a brief rest before launching into the harder climbing.  Follow an obvious vertical crack that ranges in size from finger to hands with nice jamming and face holds.  After about 90' of climbing the crack traverses almost straight left for an exciting finish to the anchors.
routes.location: This route is the obvious left facing corner to a crack just left of Cliptomaniac.
routes.protection: A set of wires and small cams up to a #3 Camalot.  Two bolt anchor at the top (Cliptomaniac shares this anchor).

description: Afternoon sun. Home to the legendary splitter Zap Crack (5.12d).
getting_there: A 15 mins drive from Squamish. Head south onto BC-99 S to Britannia Beach, then turn left onto Copper Dr. Keep going for 2 km, then left onto Goat Ridge Dr. Coordinate for parking lot are : 49.629855, -123.200128. Walk north-west onto Goat Drive for 500m and you'll see a trail that goes up to the your right. Follow this trail uphill heading north until it goes get into the forest. Once, in the forest you'll go down and see the Shaddai Creek. Follow the creek for about 1 km until it goes right and uphill steeply. Keep following the mountain bike path for like 500m until you see the Wonder Wall.   Walk onto the paved road

routes.fa: Glenn Payan, 1997 FFA: Andreas Taylor & Jeremy Blumel, 2000
routes.description: A very nice looking slipper finger crack. The rock is quite polished. It looks like it's a harder version of Masses are Asses.
routes.location: You can't miss it once you reach the Wonder Wall.
